Still the positives exceed the negatives, but you should use the higher quality Nikor lenses.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Great camera, not so good video cam
column8:
I upgraded from D80 because of the video feature, and although the quality of video itself is amazing, autofocus feature during video shot is virtually useless... The focus motor noise is recorded quite loudly, and the motor keeps running continuously even at the slightest movement of the subject.

However, there seem to be a vast improvement in the CMOS sensor. You can take pictures of moving subject day and night without a flash. At high ISO, I cannot see any noticeable noise at all...

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I purchased a D7000 locally (body only).  I have an HD Camcorder, so my only use for the D7000 is taking pictures.  And wow, all I can say is that it takes amazing pictures.  I've tried the camera in different indoor lighting settings and I can say that camera's auto white balance settings has produced beautiful and accurate colors every time.  I haven't had to use my Expodisc once so far.  The metering system on the camera is the best in the DSLR world at this time.  I always shoot in manual, but so far with the D7000 - i've put the camera on Auto or on Aperture Priority and the pictures have been out of this world.  Instead of having to play around with settings, you can let the camera do the work and focus on your composition.  If you have any thought whatsoever of purchasing this camera, I would say do so!  Go out an buy it.  I cannot imagine any improvement to this camera that can be made.  I would have no problems keeping this camera for the next 10 years.  Its absolutely perfect.  The size is just right, I actually like the feel of it a little better than the D90, particularly where i grip the camera using my right hand.  I've used the camera with my 17-55mm and 16-85mm and the weight is just right.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: This is the best consumer electronic device I have ever purchased!
column8: Wow, is all I can say. This camera is simply amazing. Makes my photography skills look WAY better than they actually are (I love good photography, just never thought I could create any!). By the way, matched with this lens: Nikon 50mm f/1.4G SIC SW Prime Nikkor Lens for Nikon Digital SLR Cameras the camera is an absolute blast to use! This lens has an unbelievable ability to shoot in low light, never need a flash. Bokeh is absolutely beautiful. Still can't believe my shots are coming from me! Wow, Wow, Wow, incredible technology! Way to go Nikon! P.S. The D7000 doesn't need an AFS lens, so if you want to save some money on the lens, get this one: Nikon 50mm f/1.4D AF Nikkor Lens for Nikon Digital SLR Cameras

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column8: It's a shame Amazon lets their dealers gouge customers on this new Nikon D7000 camera, I would order 2 bodies today at the regular price, Amazon needs to start taking better care of their long time customers.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I loved my D90, and thought long and hard about upgrading to the D7000.  It arrived yesterday as promised (Thanks Amazon! Awesome service once again), and I have to say, this camera is awesome.  The feel of the camera is very sturdy, the shutter sound is great.  I've taken about 150 shots with it, and am very pleased with the outcome using my Nikon 16-85mm lens.  As great as the D90 was, I feel that the D7000 is a good upgrade, and well worth the money....Thanks

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Lives up to, and exceeds, the hype!
column8: I've only been experimenting with this body-only a short time, but I'm already blown away. I upgraded from a Nikon D5000, and am using primarily a Sigma 18-50mm f/2.8 HSM lens on it. The first thing I noticed is how substantial and sturdy it seems. The shutter button is great (not mushy like some others have said), and it autofocuses FAST! I am in love. I can't wait to dig even deeper into this cameras abilities and get creative!

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Cool things you might not know the D7000 can do
column8:
Just take it for granted that this takes amazing pictures under all conditions, including low light, and that it contains all the manual controls that you'd ever want.

Instead, here's some things that the camera does that you might not have heard about:

* Built-in EyeFi support

If you've used EyeFi SD cards before, you probably assumed that it would work with the D7000, since the D7000 now uses SD cards instead of CF. But not only do you not have to mess around with SD-to-CF adapters, the camera is actually EyeFi aware-- you can choose to have it upload or not upload on a slot-by-slot basis (so you might have it automatically upload the RAW files you saved to an EyeFi Pro card in slot 1, but not bother to upload the JPEGs you saved to the EyeFi Explorer card in slot 2), and there is also an icon that appears on the Info display to indicate that there are files waiting to upload, that the upload is in progress or disabled, etc.

The Nikon Wifi adapter is going for $400. A 4GB, class 6 EyeFi card goes for $40. If you really want to move RAW files, snag the Pro version for $80. Yes, the Nikon adapter does things that EyeFi can't, but if you just want to get your files onto a PC without pulling the card, why spend 10X the money?

You're stuck with the usual limitations of the EyeFi card, but I fully expect to use this feature a LOT with studio portraits-- yeah, it only takes 10 seconds to pull the card and have Windows recognize that you added it, then another 5 seconds to eject the card and stick it back in the camera. But if you just want a quick check that your exposure or focus is where you want it, wouldn't you rather just hit a single key and see your last shot, then get right back into the flow? You may want to drop your JPEG file sizes to speed up the transfer.

* In-camera RAW file processing

The camera contains a ton of built-in settings-- in addition to the basics like Standard, Normal, Landscape, etc, you also get all the various Scene modes, which are basically variations on those main settings.

RAW processing allows you to see how the shot would have looked had you used one of those other modes. In other words, you shoot in Normal, which basically applies no processing to the image, then select the RAW file, and choose how you'd like to adjust it. You can change the white balance settings, exposure, basic picture setting (landscape, portrait, etc), noise reduction, color space, and dynamic lighting. With the exception of the advanced details on the basic picture settings, you see a preview of how your change will affect the picture.

If you like it, just hit EXEcute and it writes out a JPEG to your card. Don't like it, just back out and nothing's saved.

This means that you don't have to worry that shooting in Vivid is going to result in an oversaturated image, or you can punch something up even more after the fact. The only real drawback here to me is that it is going to kick out a JPEG, so if you're planning on doing further editing in Photoshop, this may not be the best route. But if you're just looking to go right from the camera to the web, or want to get an idea of how playing with custom settings will affect your shots, this is a massive shortcut to taking and then deleting a ton of shots. (And keep in mind that Photoshop will allow you to mess with most of these settings when importing RAW files anyway, and the plugin D7000-compatible RAW plugin had a release candidate posted yesterday, so you can finally open your RAW shots.)

And a related feature that's in most other Nikons, but that you might not know about-- you can define your own basic picture settings. Want something that's super-saturated and super-contrasty? Just hit a few buttons, choose a name, and you're done. On the older Nikons, you had to edit the basic profile itself, now, you can use one as a starting point and adjust from there. Much cleaner.

* User-defined settings on the control knob

Not as hidden as the first two, but I can't emphasize how cool this feature is. Here's the situation I was in last night-- I was shooting a singing contest in a dimly-lit venue. I was allowed to use a flash, but I didn't want to constantly be blasting the singers while they were performing.

I defined one setting as shutter priority, 1/60th, ISO Hi 2, center-weighted metering & focus, no flash. The second setting was automatic, ISO auto, full metering and autofocus, flash enabled. I'd take a couple shots in U2 with the flash, close the flash down and switch to U1 and shoot a half a dozen shots, then switch back to U2 and use the flash for a couple more shots. There was no fumbling for controls, no worrying that I changed the shutter speed without realizing it when changing between Auto and S-- every time I went from U2 to U1, all my settings were reset to where I put them before the event started.

I don't think I ever felt as confident about my camera settings in a rapidly changing situation as I did last night-- with just a simple twist of a knob, I was able to change to a completely different shooting configuration with absolute confidence that it was what I wanted.

To me, the utility of this is almost endless-- I'll probably set up one setting for studio portraits, and the other for landscape stuff. If I was still shooting news, I'd probably be swapping between flash and no-flash configurations. For sports, I'd change between action modes and post-game portraits.

The only thing that would make this even better would be if I could import and export settings for later use-- even if you use the "Save/Load" settings option to back up your current configuration to a memory card, it doesn't appear that this information is stored. However, it may be a bug in the Load settings feature, as a number of my settings were incorrectly reset when I tried to load in settings. Either way, it would work better if I could treat these like custom basic picture settings, saving them by name and loading them at will.

* Built-in interval timer shooting

Want to take time-lapse pictures? Just set up your camera on the tripod, specify when you want it to start, how many pictures to take overall, and how many pictures to take each interval and walk away. When it's time to start taking pictures, the camera will automatically focus and shoot, then go back to waiting for the next shot. No messing around with tethering, 3rd party software, whatever-- it's all in the camera, and it's all super-easy to set up. You'll find yourself taking pictures of your living room just to see what your cat actually does all day while you're at work.

* Zoom in live view

This might just be "new to me," but I found it to be very cool for manually adjusting focus when on a tripod-- frame your basic shot, then change to live view. From there, zoom in with the magnifying glass key, and move around the image with the navigation pad until you find the point you want to focus on, then manually focus. Since you can zoom into a tiny portion of the overall image, you can see that you're getting exactly the focus point you want before you take the shot. One gotcha that I always forget, though-- don't forget to pick your aperture BEFORE going into live view, as you can't change it once live view has started.

* Adjustable shooting rate

Again, might be "new to me," but in addition to blasting away at 6fps, you can manually adjust that from 1 to 5 FPS in order to get a different effect. You obviously need to be using a fast enough shutter speed to support your choice-- if you're at 1/2 a second, you're not going to shoot faster than 2FPS.

As I mentioned in one of my other reviews, I used to be a semi-pro photographer-- I was the photo editor for both a weekly and a daily paper, I've shot tons of sports and news photos, and landscape photography is my hobby. I've recently gotten back into portrait photography as well. While I never owned as many cameras as a true pro would have (that semi- means that I never made enough money at it to be able to really spring for equipment), I have shot with a lot of other people's equipment, and I can honestly say that this is the best camera I've ever used.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
In April of 2004, I bought my first DSLR, the Nikon D70.  I paid $1299.99 for the D70 and 18-70 kit lens.  I loved the D70 - it was good enough that I could resist the D80, D200, etc.  I spent my money on lenses instead.  Then along came the D7000.  I was nervous about jumping before DP Review has given their full report, but trusted Nikon and couldn't resist the specs.  Well, after several hundred shots I'm resting easy: this is an absolutely fantastic camera.

If you're like me coming from the D70, the D7000 is a step forward by every objective and subjective measure.  I'm especially pleased with the D7000's new sensor.  Two and half times the resolution changed the way I frame shots.  I can pull back a bit during sports shooting to leave room for alignment corrections that eat up pixels at the edges.  Unlike the D70, ISO 1600 is quite usable and ISO 3200 viable.  I'm actually using Auto-ISO now, a feature I switched off in the D70 since I couldn't stand the noise.

The back panel display is also a sight to behold.  With 7 times the resolution of the D70, the display is beautiful, bright and good enough to weed out poor shots on site.

The D7000 ergonomics felt immediately comfortable to my Nikon fingers.  The only thing that made me pause was to locate the trash can button, which is now upper left rather than bottom right.

Of course, many other pleasant surprises await, a customizable button, live view, Active D-Lighting, not to mention 1080P video.

So, to those still snapping away with their D70's, this is the one!  Enjoy!!!

-- EDIT --
If you are interested in the various GPS adapters for location tagging, be aware the D7000 uses a USB style connector for GPS units.  This is different and incompatible with most other Nikon DSLRs.  Make sure your GPS specifically states D7000 in it's compatibility list.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: D7000 - Meets and maybe exceeds the D300 as a serious performance DX camera
column8:
Pros: 1. 16.2 MP image sensor
2. weather sealing similar to the D300
3. AMAZING ISO range (100-6400) and lack of noise in low light
4. FAST burst speeds, up to 6 fps
5. 12&14 bit selectable RAW files
6. twin SD card slots
7. ergonomics identical to D90

Cons: 1. still unable to shoot 1080p video at 30 fps
2. RAW files not yet recognized by 3rd party software at time of this writing
3. still not weight balanced when using larger telephoto zoom lens
4. difficult to think of any real cons

Summary: Being a Nikon D90 user for the last year, I love the combination of ease of use, shooting power and image quality. However over time I quickly grew to learn and appreciate the performance limits (fps shooting, ISO range, 12 bit RAW files only) that are addressed by the more expensive and professional level D300.

Imagine to my shock when Nikon announced several months ago a successor to the D90, initially dubbed the D95 then finalized as the D7000. When the spec sheets were announced, my jaw dropped. Basically what we have is a camera that is priced between the pro-am D90 and pro D300 DX crop sensor cameras. While the D7000 clearly and unsurprisingly outclasses the very competent and capable D90 in nearly every respect, from image quality, shooting performance and video capabilities, whats more shocking is how it seems to match or even exceed the specs of the D300s (if you're taking video shooting capabilities into account).

I was lucky to pick up a preorder of the 18-105mm kit from a local store (body only was not available yet at the time of this writing) and with excitement I set about opening it up. Packaged very similar to the D90, the camera comes with the 18-105mm VR kit lens in a separate box and instruction manuals/software CD. A nice change is the battery charger which comes with the usual long cable, but also has a short outlet plug that allows the charger to mount directly to the wall, much like most compact P&S camera battery chargers.

Onto the camera itself. As I've mentioned before, users of the Nikon D90 should find this new camera very easy to use, as nearly all the buttons, menus and controls are identical. They changed the live view button to a spring loaded switch similar to the D3100 with a button that is used to start/stop video recording. I tested the video at 1080p/24 fps and like the previews state, it does continuous AF during the recording unlike previous Nikon HD video dSLRs, however with the built in mic, the AF is LOUD and you can hear it whirring constantly in the video playback. If you want to shoot some serious video you're better off getting the optional external stereo mic that fits in the hotshoe.

Now onto the camera shooting itself. Having the 100% viewfinder coverage is nice, since the 96% coverage on the D90 made for some errors in composition, allowing objects to creep into the edges of my previous shots that I couldn't see due to the incomplete coverage.

The new 39 point AF with 11 cross type AF points is amazingly fast, and you can set to single AF so it only does it once before you shoot, or continuous AF so it'll continue to seek out AF points while the shutter is half pressed.

Shooting speed is FAST on this camera, at a respectable 6 fps at max speed, although you'll need at least a class 10 SD card to acheive this, and it maybe slightly slowed choosing 14 over 12 bit NEF RAW files. Speaking of which, like the D300, 700 and D3, you can shoot 14 bit RAW files now where the D90 and lower end cameras allowed you to only shoot 12 bit RAW which made for inferior picture quality in the final images.

The dual SD card slots are a great feature and the camera gives you multiple options how you want to use these cards, I chose to set mine up as overflow, altho when I start to shoot video I may set up the 2nd card as video only instead.

Now my favorite aspect of this camera, is not, contrary to some, the increased 16.2 MP over the 12.6 MP of the D90/300 image sensor, but the amazing ISO range and low light sensitivity. The D90 had a range of 200-3200 but images became pretty unusable above 2400 without serious software PP NR. I did some nighttime and indoor low light test shooting of the D7000 with its 100-6400 range and found images that looks better at 4000 than the D90 did at 2000 ISO. At 5000 or above, the noise does start to become noticable, but this new sensor plus a good image stabilized lens makes for a powerful low light shooter in most situations. I've read subject user reviews from people who own the D300 and FX sensor D700 and say this camera gives the D300 serious pause and in fact, can compare image quality to the D700.

Something to think about.

Overall this is a fantastic camera for the price and probably the last DX sensor camera I will need for a long time.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
My wife and I each had a D90 and have been very happy with those,but when a friend offered to buy my D90 I just had to go for the D7000. I have only taken a couple hundred shots but what I have seen after comparing the 90 to the 7000 is the image quality is definitely better and it seems that not only is there a better sensor and processor but also because the camera settings can be adjusted easier and more accurately. For example, the auto white balance is much more accurate and the shutter speed up to 1/8000 along with the great high ISO abilities and the metering seems much more accurate as well. Auto focus is great but I had no complaints with the d90s auto focus.  The controls and the feel of the camera are pretty similar with the 7000 being a little heavier but for the most part the menus and buttons are also very similar with the 7000 being a little easier to adjust with a few nicely placed camera buttons added on. The tripod base plate from my D90 will not properly fit the 7000 but the 7000 and 90 are real close in size other then that. I have no doubt this cameras capabilities are much more than my skill and/or knowledge warrant at this time but I don't see that being a problem. I believe anyone upgrading from a previous Nikon model will absolutely love this camera. I have not had any issues with Video noise or hot pixels. The video that I played around with is excellent quality. I had it on Pre-Order from Amazon but found Calumet photo had it available for the same price so I got it next day air from them.

After a few more days playing with this camera and comparing the D90 and this 7000 the 7000 is so much better than I first realized. Especially the high ISO capability and white balance. Great Camera!

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Best DX (cropped) Camera To Date; Amazing ISO Performance
column8:
My first DSLR was a D80 I purchased four years ago.  The shutter went out a few weeks back but I had been planning to upgrade to the D7000 anyway so this just hurried things up.  I bought the D7000 kit with the 18-105 lens but quickly sold that on Ebay.  I was shooting with a Tamron 17-50 2.8 lens on the D80.  For low light, it worked pretty well but greater than half the time I needed to use my SB-600 flash to capture my young kids doing what they do (move).  The only downside to the Tamron, or combination of the Tamron with the D80, was that the images tended to be soft, especially when opened up.  So I also upgraded my lens to the Nikkor 16-85.  While this is a variable lens that maxes out at 3.5, it is amazingly sharp combined with the D7000.  And the extra reach is great for getting better shots and also providing relatively shallow depth of field that otherwise would be lost with the slower aperture.

The reason I mention the lens change is that I wouldn't have gone to a variable lens had it not been for the amazing ISO performance on the D7000.  I am now shooting flashless at very fast shutter speeds.  I usually shoot raw and process with Lightroom and I'm seeing amazing results at 800 ISO even when fully blown up (1:1).  At ISO 1600, I can see minor noise but Lightroom 3's noise reduction easily eliminates it. 3200 certainly isn't noiseless but again, Lightroom can clean it up very well in most situations.  My old D80 had more noise at 400 than the D7000 has at 1600; I'd say 800 on it was equivalent to 3200 on the D7000.  I could see printing 1600 shots at smaller sizes with no need for software cleanup.  So while my results are preliminary (3 weeks in), I am astonished at the ISO capabilities of this camera.  I no longer have d700 envy and am glad I can get great dx lenses for under $700 as opposed to $1500 for fx.  Perfect for enthusiasts like me!

You've seen the stat that the D7000 can shoot 6 shots per second.  The 6FPS shutter is in some ways overkill.  But if you shoot HDR/Bracket shots in quick succession having such a rapid shutter can allow you to do so handheld in a pinch. This is really only possible because of the high ISO capabilities enabling very fast shutter times. And for sporting events and the like, it's nice to have the ability to rapidly fire off shots.

I have also noticed considerably improved metering and white balance on the D7000 compared to my old D80.  Of the 350 or so shots I've taken, I am spending much less time adjusting lighting and white balance in Lightroom.

As others have mentioned, the ergonomics/design of the camera are quite good and I really enjoy the many direct access shortcuts for adjusting everything from focus to flash to white balance and much more.  The two custom settings are very easy to set and perfect for your two most common profiles (e.g. indoor portrait and outdoor landscape).  The screen is beautiful and moving in and around even RAW files is very smooth and fast.  I went with two 16GB SD class 10 Transcend cards and while I'm currently using the RAW 1 / JPEG 2 option, I plan to use the second as a backup card once I go to RAW only.

I've only toyed with the video function but that was a part of my consideration since I dislike carrying two cameras, plus chargers and media, on family vacations.  The tests I've done in 1080P have been very impressive, albeit large as you would expect.  Auto-focusing while video recording is okay, as long as the background isn't too noisy or subjects too many.  The biggest downside I have experienced is the built-in microphone picks up lots of auto focusing noise.  I have not yet invested in an external mic but probably will need to.

All in all I am very pleased with the D7000 and see no major shortcomings.  It's not cheap, but you get a lot for your money if you are in the market for a prosumer class DSLR.  For users who won't explore and use  the MANY options and capabilities of this camera, I would recommend considering the 3100/5100.  For D80/90 users who are ready to step up big time in terms of performance, this is the upgrade you have been waiting for.  Some will hold out for a D700 successor (D800 or whatever it ends up being called).  I have no doubt it will be an amazing camera but cost wise, you're going to be looking at $2500+ for the body alone and pay roughly double for coverage equivalent lenses.  So figure $4K just to get started.  Too rich for my non-professional needs but certainly should be considered if your work or wants dictate that level of camera.  And there maybe be a D300s replacement in the works too.  Still, I'd urge anyone to consider the D7000, which in my opinion is the best cropped sensor DSLR to date.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Great Camera -- A perspective from a D300/700 Owner
column8: This is very simple, if you are a Nikon shooter looking for a new camera then stop reading and buy this camera. It's that good. Handling This camera is brilliant to hold and use. Nikon has done it again and has made the user interface more usable and streamlined. What to change flash modes. Press the flash pop-up button and rotate the control wheel. Sweet. Want to change create and use a User defined mode? There are two. Set your mode up. Go to the menu and save it. To use it rotate the shooting mode dial to U1 or U2. Presto you are there. In the D300 and D700 you to have to setup things in the menu and switch in the menu. Also, there were 2 sets of things you could change and they were not all inclusive. It was all horribly confusing and I never used it. Speaking of shooting modes. There is now one position on the shooting mode dial for scene mode shooting. You change through the different scene modes with the control wheel and the type scene shows up on the back screen. Sweet. I can go on and on but needless to say Nikon have really improved their interface. One caveat, I don't think it is quite up to par with the GH1 to change exposure compensation (IMO the most important control) but still a huge step in the correct direction in handling. I like the handling of the D7000 better than either the D700/300. Low Light Shooting The D300 wasn't that great for Hi ISO. It shoots clean at 400 ISO and usable up to 1600. (The D90 and D300s were better) The D700 was fantastic. Clean at 1600 ISO and usable up to 6400. It opened up new worlds. The D7000 is close to the equal of the D700. Enough said. Just to give you an example. The bouquet toss at a reception is often done in poor light. By using 1600 instead of 400 you get the equivalent of 4 times more light. At ISO400 you flash may need to use 1/4 power and you can get 1 maybe 2 shots of the toss and catch before the flash needs to recharge. At ISO1600 your flash would only need to use 1/16th power and now you can get 5-6 shots. This is huge. Picture Quality Like all modern DSLRs it takes great pictures. I don't pixel peep so I can't really say that I notice a difference between the pictures from the D7000 and any of my 12mp cameras. It makes really nice pictures and that is all I care about. Useful Photography Features (Not Marketing Features) --100% view finder! Big bright with 100% coverage. No more guessing of your framing. (It is not as bright as the D700. However, it is 100% vice 95%) --2 SD slots - When your getting paid to shoot a wedding or any gig, my card broke is not an excuse. Very useful feature. For the home user put two smaller cards rather than one big card and save some money. --Smaller and lighter than D300, D700, D3s, D3x- When you stand on your feet for 9 hours shooting the wedding and reception, you start to feel every ounce you are carrying. Often you will be carrying two bodies with a fast tele zoom and fast wide zoom. That starts to get heavy. Light weight here we come. --2016-Segment RGB Meter- for spot on exposure and white balance--No one touches Nikon on this and this one is fantastic. --1/8000th -- Very useful for shooting into the sun wide open with a bright lens --1/250 -- Could be better (1/500th for D40) but could be much worse. Auto FP helps. --Magnesium body and better sealing -- Shoot in dusty environments without messing up the inside your camera. --Uses the ML-L3 infra red remote -- Small and cheap. IR sensor on the front and back of the camera. --Autofocus focus motor for non-AF-S lenses Marketing Features that will sometimes be Useful --16Mp -- Nikon was obviously getting creamed in the marketing wars on this. This is going to lead to bigger files requiring larger hard drives and faster computers. Occasionally it will be useful if you can't frame as close as you would like and you need to crop or you need to print big. Alien Skin Blow Up 2, Image Resizing Plug-in Software for Photoshop, Macintosh & Windows and Genuine Fractals 6 Professional Edition 1-user Full are two very nice programs that can increase the size of your photos for printing large. 16 MP is nice by not necessary. --39 Point Auto Focus -- To me in some ways this is better than the 51 point of the D300 and D700 as that gets too unwieldy. However, you really don't even need 39. However, still useful on occasion. --6 frames per second-- I very rarely ever put my camera in 3 frames per second. When I do so it fills the card quickly. If you are shooting the big game then 6 is nice. Or it is nice for some cool special effects shots. Other than that you won't really find yourself using it that much. Video The other thing I am not really going to dwell on is the video capabilities. In my opinion all the various video options are mostly marketing hype really targeted at a niche market. Shallow depth of field video is difficult and time consuming to shoot and edit properly. The average family home user has neither the time nor inclination to do this. With that said, it is nice to only have to carry one device to take still pictures and video. So I do enjoy that feature, however 1080 is not really necessary. In fact with up converting DVD players standard def is still very usable and takes up far less space. Suffice it to say that the video capabilities are very good and should do anything a home user would need it to do. Can be used for pro Videos as demonstrated by Chase Jarvis. Intangibles This is a very nice camera and it feels very solid in your hands. It feels far more substantial than the D40/D90 without feeling like a brick the way the D300/D700 do. I am sure the D300 has more marketing features than the D7000 but I would have to research them to figure out what they are. Conclusion In the end it all comes down to what is important to you. Smaller weight and size is becoming much more important to me and this camera is a very good trade off of features for size and weight. Anything that is missing I don't even use so I am not sure what it may be. My D700 was recently stolen and while I miss it, the D7000 is a worthy replacement for it. I opted to get the D7000 and Panasonic GH2 and save the $300 difference for a lens. Pros --100% view finder! --6 fps (7D is 8. However, I think this number is overhyped in most cases. Even shooting at 3 FPS will fill up you card with photos that look remarkably similar) 8+ is needed for professionals shooting professional sports. Not enthusiast shooting High School etc. --16mp sensor (a marketing increase but still nice to allow some room for cropping) --14 bit photos --39 point auto focus sensors (19 cross point) this is a bit of a marketing thing but it is still nice and it does not matter about the 51 on D300s and above. Still very nice. --2016 scene meter - compares against data base for WB setting and color settings --Excellent battery life --MD-11 Optional Battery Grip --2 SD card slots for back up redundancy or double the card space! Outstanding --Magnesium used to make camera stronger Cons --16mp senor (takes up more storage on your hard drive) (12mp JPG 3mb 12 mp RAW = 12 mb 16mp JPEG = 5 mb 16 mp RAW = 16 mb. This is for 12 bit. 14 bit would require more) --Camera heavier than it used to be --No swivel screen - after using the GH1 extensively you really miss this when shooting at weird angles. You especially miss it for macro photography. --No full time live view - Ditto from above. Live view is what you see is what you get. Forgot to change white balance-- you will see that when people are yellow, blue or green. Have it set in manual and blowing everything out-- you'll see that as a white screen. Decision Matrix Nikon For the Nikon shooter this is a no brainer. If you are in the market for a camera, then skip the D300s. The D700 is getting long in the tooth and many people are buying the D7000 while waiting for D800. If you already own a D700 then this camera is a very good complement to it. Use the money you saved over the more expensive camera to buy a nice lens. Here is a breakdown vs other Nikon DSLRs D3100-- Two completely different classes with the D7000 being worth the difference in many. However at the end of the day they will both make nice pictures. Also, the lenses are more important than the camera. You can get the D3100 and 18-200mm for the same price. Something to think about. D5000-- Good sensor and nice camera. D3100 comments also apply here. D90--Tough choice. The best DX sensor of its generation and still better than most. If you can't quite stretch to the D7000, this is a very tempting proposition. D300S-- Irrelevant. The D7000 has a much better sensor, is smaller, lighter, cheaper, and better metering. Nikon D700-- Would be a good complement to the D7000. Use D7000 when you need the 1.5x crop on the long end and a deeper depth of field due to the smaller chip (about 1 stop deeper) and D700 for when you want to isolate a subject with a shallow depth of field or you want to use the full width of a wide angle such as the 14-24mm. If you don't need the shallower depth of field of a FX sensor and you have the lenses to cover the 1.5x crop then the D7000 should suit just fine. D3s and D3x -- Different leagues altogether. However, the D7000 is 90% of the camera for 1/4 to 1/6th the money. Canon The 7D is an outstanding camera and while I think the D7000 is a better camera (better sensor, 2 SD card slots, 2016 RGB metering, Price) it is not that much better to warrant switching if you are already invested in lenses. Sony The Sony SLT-A55 is a great camera but not in the league of the D7000. However it is $350 less and does have so unique properties. It is rumored to have the same sensor as the D7000 but Nikon always does their magic and makes it better (D3x vs A900). The translucent mirror allows for fast shooting but loses 1/3 a stop of light. Still a very nice camera. Non-DSLR Owner or DSLR owner with just the Kit Lens When you are buying a DSLR, you are really buying into the lens system. So factor that into you decision making matrix. For that reason, if you have not spent a fortune on lenses yet then I recommend the m4/3 as in my opinion that is the future. The sensor of the top m4/3(GH2) is every bit as good if not better than the current crop of DX sensors and almost as good as the D7000. It is getting to the point, the sensor doesn't matter as much. At this point handling, size and weight start to become more important. With this in mind I would recommend the Panasonic Lumix DMC-GH2 16.05 MP Live MOS Interchangeable Lens Camera with 3-inch Free-Angle Touch Screen LCD and 14-42mm Hybrid Lens (Black) to anyone not invested in a lens system. It is smaller, lighter, more capable on the video side and in many ways better on the stills side. It needs a faster flash sync speed, faster shutter speed and the construction is not up to Nikon or Canon standards (In all fairness this cuts down on weight and I have not had a failure with my GH1.) It is probably not quite as good at the high ISO. On the positive side it has a multi-aspect sensor as it is actually an 18mp sensor (16:9, 2:3, and 4:3 will all be 16mp not crops of one aspect ratio) It sells for $899 body only, $999 with the 14-42mm and $1499 with the fantastic 14-140mm 10x zoom. The lack of a mirror flipping up is a benefit in all cases. Also, you can use just about any lens ever made on this camera. Nikon, Leica, Canon, Pentax, C Lenses. You lose auto focus on any auto focus lenses and there is no accurate way to adjust your aperture on G series lenses. While the GH1 sensor was by far the best M4/3 sensor and equaled most DX sensors of its generation, it did not quite stand up to the D90 sensor. I expect the D7000 to have a higher Dynamic Range and be an overall better sensor. However, that difference will not be noticeable to the lay users. What you get is a noticeably smaller and lighter camera that out handles any DSLR on the market and has the best video capabilities. In my opinion the GH2 will be the best all-around camera of its generation. The GH1 is the camera I reach for 90% of the time when I shoot for pleasure. When Panasonic puts out a full Pro line of lenses, I will use it more in the Pro situations. I am sure the GH2 will be my new go to camera.

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: This Camera Will Change Your Life.
column8:
When Nikon announced the D7000, I immediately placed my preorder into Amazon as soon as they would take my credit card information.  Boy am I glad I did, this camera is amazing.
The image quality is outstanding - it's like they combined Shania Twain and Caroline Wozniaki into the camera - BEAUTIFUL.  I mentioned this to my wife and now she's jealous when I pixel peep at 100% on my photos.  I keep telling her it's simply platonic, but she won't listen.

High ISO performance is very good - I shoot RAW, so I can't comment on JPEG, but I'm sure all the Facebook people who shoot small JPEG will also be impressed.  I'm not sure why they think everyone cares about them sharing every facet of their life through photos, but whatever.

Weather Sealing - This stuff WORKS and thank goodness, because the tears the Canon guys cried once they heard the 60D compared to the D7000 would have completely ruined any lesser camera.
Autofocus performance - It autofocuses so good I don't even really have to lift the camera myself - it just seems to have a life of its own.  Frankly I'd be surprised if one day it just doesn't go out by itself and get some good photos, making me all but obsolete.  Luckily Nikon didn't include arms, so the camera will still need me to extract the photos to my computer.  Opposable thumbs, baby - EAT IT D7000.

Meters with AIS lenses - Finally Nikon got awesome and brought this feature downward.  Of course, a lot of people buying the D7000 won't even know what an AI/AI-S lens is, or why it won't autofocus on their camera, and they surely won't even know what "metering" is, but at least Nikon threw the knowledgeable enthusiasts a bone without requiring a DXXX purchase.

In all, this camera is amazing.  It has enhanced my endurance and satisfaction, made me last longer, and has overall improved my confidence.  I'm now firmly committed to Nikon, and I'm sure with this caliber of camera they're going to achieve maximum penetration into the market.  Just wait until someone thrusts this camera into your face and you'll know what all the hub-bub is about!

column4: Nikon D7000 DSLR (Body Only) (OLD MODEL)
column7: DO NOT TRUST Good Luck Bargains!!!!
column8:
This is not a review about the camera.-I love this camera. This is about the vendor: Good Luck Bargains.

Accidents happen. My camera got wet (after 2 years, well after the warranty expired), and I thought "no problem. Nikon is GREAT at repairs, and completely worth the money" and I sent it into them. Well, it seems Good Luck Bargains sells "gray market" cameras. This one was intended for the UAE (United Arab Emirates). Nikon was NEVER going to honor the warranty and won't repair it at ANY Cost.. It is costing me extra time and effort to get my camera fixed by a third party (while they seem reliable, they aren't Nikon). There is no indication in Good Luck Bargains description to indicate that this wasn't meant for the US market, in fact it was the reverse "Item can be shipped within U.S.", "This item is not eligible for international shipping". I would NEVER AGAIN buy anything from Good Luck Bargains, because of this.deception.

for the savings and this particular model was no different. The upgrades to the D7100 were minimal
for what I do and the price drop made for a good price/performance point.
No complaints about this particular model.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: Too-small fit on my average sized ears, sound just OK.
column8:
Too-small fit on my average sized ears, sound just OK.

I had these for a day, returned them and got the Skullcandy Hesh 3, which are great, fit my ears, and have superior sound.

Some reviews on here say the Hesh 2 have great sound, they don't. I think the people who are saying that have never used very good headphones, have only used cheap ear buds, and are impressed to actually hear some bass. But the Hesh 2 has kinda muddy bass and kinda brittle high end compared to the Hesh 3.

Ear cups are round and too small for my ears on the Hesh 2, and my ears aren't huge. Unless you have tiny ears, I think these won't really fit your ears. An hour of wearing these and my ears were hot. Not comfortable.

Plus points: sound OK, cost is OK, and paired effortlessly, unlike many Bluetooth devices. And the headband is solid without hurting. I wish the headband on the 3 were as solid as on the 2.

column7: Let me start by saying I LOVE Skullcandy. Have always had GREAT luck and sound ...
column8: Let me start by saying I LOVE Skullcandy. Have always had GREAT luck and sound with them. I really would LOVE to give this a 5-star review and I would do that now, but the battery life isn't as awesome as they say. I have never gotten 12 full hours after a full charge. And it takes quite awhile to charge these headphones. So I can use it during the day but have to leave them on the charger all night. I'm not saying it takes all night to charge, but you'd think with a battery so small. Their own website says 15 hours after full charge, but I haven't been able to break 5 hours before it dies. When it is charged though, I get great sound both on music and phone calls. Great product, sub-par battery life.

column7: Look and sound more expensive than they are!

We bought these to replace a cheaper set, made by another company, that broke very quickly. We wanted a higher-quality product that could stand up to a teenager's level of usage. These blow those cheap ones out of the water! They're not that much more expensive, either.

These babies have great sound! Skullcandy are always high quality, and these are no exception They're so lightweight. They charge relatively quickly. The buttons are easy to use and easy to tell apart without looking. Some headphones grip the ears too tightly and cause headaches. These have a springy rubber top piece that has exactly the right pressure to keep them on your head without causing pain. Bonus is, they won't break there, unlike other headphones we've owned.  Even the cord feels pricey. The materials & design are excellent, these feel and sound more expensive than they are. That's always wonderful.

Overall, extremely happy with this purchase.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: Superior sound, superior sturdy construction, exceptional value. Comparing headphones is tough - the solution? Buy these!
column8:
These headphones are fantastic! I was worried that they were a bit pricey, but they are well worth it. After trying several others, including some that were twice as much, I selected these - boy am I glad I did! Why?

The pros:
1. The sound quality is truly superior. The basses are rich and deep, the trebles are crisp and clean, spoken word and music sound fantastic!!!
2. The sound isolation is the best I have encountered without active noise-cancellation. This means you are listening to your audio without interference from the outside world. (There is danger here too, however, don't listen with these in a situation where you need to hear your surroundings!
3. The durability is very impressive -  I dropped these out of my car and partially ran over them. I was very worried that I would have to replace them but, other than some minor scratches, they work just like they did from day one. Very impressive! (I wouldn't recommend others doing this, however, I think I was very lucky - particularly as I had only had them less than a week!)
4. The included soft case (pouch) and the cord for use directly with your audio device when unpowered are definitely superior touches. Both have been very useful!

Cons:
The cons are minor, and they are what make the pros so strong (so I can't give stars for them and then take them away! That said, they need to be pointed out for a fair review:)

1. The noise-isolation can be dangerous in the wrong situation.
2. Their sturdiness makes them pretty heavy! Doesn't bother me, but may not be good for a child or a petite person.
3. They can cause your ears to get hot and sweat - part of the full noise isolation means that there is no air circulation either!

Overall I am very glad I purchased these. I think that they are a great deal at this price-point, and any headphones that would be superior would cost many hundreds of dollars.

column7: Edited review: quality control problems - battery stops charging
column8:
EDITED, SEE BELOW.

Original review:
These work pretty well. The sound control on the headphones is nice, as is the rechargeable internal battery. They pair easily with my USB Bluetooth dongle on my PC, and a full charge lasts a while. The audio is pretty good, and the ear foam is comfortable for a while. Like most headphones, though, the ear part and the band over your head get uncomfortable after about an hour or two. It's fine, I move it around a bit and it feels better for a while, but I can't wear them for more than about 4 hours at a time.

EDIT 6/3/18: After much use, I have some more thoughts. This was originally a 4-star review. After about 11 months (right near the time when the warranty was to expire), the battery stopped charging. It became usable only as a wired headset; the wire is included, but I didn't buy these to use wired. I sent for a warranty claim, and they sent me a new set. However, within a month this second set developed exactly the same problem. This is a Quality Control problem, perhaps mixed with a design problem. I would not recommend buying these.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column8:
I've only used these for a day now so take what you will from this. I really like these. The sound is good. People are saying it's crap but it's not. I also was thinking it was quiet but I had my windows 10 headphone volume turned down to 45%. The ear pads deafen outside noise fairly good.

Now for cons.

So yes, the "over ear" is kind of a joke. Why they don't make these oval shaped is beyond me. Is it cause they wouldn't look "cool" enough? Luckily I got tiny ears. The overall comfort is good. Maybe a little tight on the skull. Just a little. I've had way worse.

So I read that these are Bluetooth 2.0. Really, 2004 tech. They have 5.0 out now even though I doubt it's on the market yet. If it's anything like computer hardware, they announce stuff but it takes 5+ years to see it in the product. Like USB 3.1. Anyways, my guess is they're thinking; why change something that works and sells?. I would think they could sell much more if it had newer tech in it. I have a cheap dongle and it's making the headphones cut out when I walk more then 4 feet away from my tower. I'm buying a better transmitter and hope that helps it. Hope.

Those are my only two gripes about these. Thus the big fat star minus. Totally worth the 40 bucks. Anymore then that no.

column8: I purchased these recently as a daily deal.  I'm no audiophile, just a daily listener of music including alternative and hard rock, and to my ears these sound fantastic.  I do also own the Audio Technica ATH-M50 and though they are very highly rated, I think these sound better.  In comparison from what I can tell, the high notes aren't quite as bright sounding and the bass is more pronounced (I'm a big fan of hearing a pronounced kick drum).  I understand the ATH-M50's are supposed to sound very "natural" and are preferred by a lot of audio engineers, but for my taste these just sound better to me.  If you listen to any type of Rock, you'll love these.  Build quality also seems excellent.  Nice materials, sturdy design, and really comfortable soft stitched ear pads.

column8:
Pros:
*Good range
*Very long battery life (last full day)
*I like big "+" and "-" buttons.
You don't need to guess which button you are holding with your finger - you'll fill it right away.

Cons:

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column8: Audio Engineer here, I heartily recommend these headphones, having used them daily for 2 years now, and after trying Sony and Mpow Bluetooth headphones.  The Sony's would fall off my head and weren't loud enough.  The Mpow had ridiculous bass 'enhancement' - very annoying.  The Hesh is great - clear sound, good dynamic range, solid bass without overemphasis, and the headband is strong and springy enough to stay on your head when you bend over.  They don't fold up like the Sony's but I will trade that for staying on my head and being indestructible.  The earpads are comfortable for a few hours of listening at a time as well.  I like the big fat buttons, I just leave the volume on max and use the phone volume.  They work great for cellphone talking too - very clear speech.  Just be sure you have the right side on the right side, since then the microphone hole is placed to face forward correctly.

column8:
Bought these because I have a phone that doesn't use a traditional headphone jack. I charge these the night before I need to use them, and the charge lasts for a long while - I didn't need to charge them after 8 hours of travel, and they had enough while I went around town for ~4 hours the next day. I don't even think they ran out; I just like to keep things charged to be safe.

I will say that these are comfortable, but if you have a variety of ear piercings (especially tragus piercings and/or stretched lobes), these might rest a little uncomfortably on them.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: Decent for the price - too small for adult ears
column8:
Update:  3 months after buying these headphones, they will no longer pair to any Bluetooth device.

Pros:  I bought these for about $42, which was a great price.  I use these headphones all day at work, and they last the whole shift.  They connect to the bluetooth source very quickly.  They drown out a good deal of noise, and the audio is decent enough for listening to music casually.  These were about as minimalist as you can get in terms of logos and flashy colors, which is best for the workplace.

Cons: They don't actually go over your ear, but instead, sit on top of your ear.  This will eventually make your ears hurt after some time.  I often have to take them off every hour or so and take a break.

They are a nice set of headphones if you don't mind the small size of the ear part.  Honestly, I probably would not buy another set of these in the future if these broke.  While they are a great bargain if you can get them for cheap, it does not make up for being uncomfortable.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: Terrible product, doesnt last 5 months. These should be labeled as "on-ear" not "over-ear"
column8:
While these are easy to use and have a great battery life, if you are looking for "over-ear" bluetooth headphones, these are not for you (unless you are 5 years old and have really small ears). These should be labeled as "on-ear" not "over-ear". After an hour or so of use the tops and bottoms of my ears are very red and painful. Had these not been a gift, I would likely return them.

Update: After a couple months of use the balance has gone to shit. I have to adjust the sound output on my Mac to fix the balance. Appears to be even sound when the slider is set to 80% to the right. Warranty process sucks, they make *you* pay to ship the defective item back and will mail you a new pair in "a few weeks". Ended up junking them and going with these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MSZSJE9/ Much better product, wish I would have spent the extra money up front. Wont be buying any more skullcandy products in the future.

column8: I've been using these for a while now, and I must say - I really like them! The only down side is that they do not cancel outside noise - even when I turn the volume up pretty loud, I can still hear what's going on around me. For the most part, they do block out enough noise that I can focus on what I'm listening to or watching on Netflix - I have major issues with "competing noise" (noise coming from multiple sources, such as music playing in my office while I am on a phone call and coworkers are talking around me or the break room - which is directly across the hall from my office - is super noisy at lunchtime) so it's important to me that I be able to tune out most of the noise around me to avoid becoming overwhelmed and anxious. Compared to my other Bluetooth headphones, these are easier for my coworkers to see - this helped solve the issue of people coming in and talking to me when I can't hear them and/or don't know they're there! They were definitely worth the money - I only wish I could have found them in pink!

column8: Arrived quickly, and on time. Got these to use for tablets and a computer, and wanted the option to hardwire to 3.5mm when desired/needed. Overall, comfort is good. These are "on ear" design, unless you have really small ears. They are not noise cancelling, but they do get loud enough to bleed out the surrounding environment - too loud in fact. The highs and mids are perfectly good for this price range - if not better, and the lows are what I would expect - IE, partially existent. These are not $400 headphones, so if you're expecting to get $400 quality sound out of this price range then you will be disappointed. If you are looking for reasonably priced headphones without sacrificing too much quality, wireless and wired option, then these will work great for you. This comes with a soft "sack like" case. Wish they would have come with a hard case like the Koss ones I purchased, but there are options here on Amazon. As far as durability, they are currently surviving daily use from my 6 and 9 year old on their tablets. Would definitely buy these again.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column8:
I'm not a audio snob but I had my doubts about this brand. I'm not really a part of Skullcandy's demographic, I'm a tad past it, but I was in their price point so I was willing to give these cans a go.  Surprisingly they are very nice cans. The bluetooth is rock solid, which is high praise for me. I have other bluetooth buds and cans and they have occasional and persistent issues with connectivity. Not so the Hesh 2. Granted, the use case for the Hesh 2 is an iPad, and watching video at a desk, which means immobile, but even this challenge is too much for other units I own.

The only drawback is that the cans are a bit heavy and they make the ears sweat. I can watch one movie before they have to come off and I have to take a break. Sound quality is good, if not awe-inspiring. The cans are plenty loud, I'll give them that, and they are accurate enough for dialogue.  I've played music through them a few times and it's been a pleasant enough experience, the sound is accurate and well rounded. For the money, it's a very nice set of cans.

Set up is typical for Bluetooth on Apple products, a bit of drama, and then it works. It comes with  supplied cords, one for audio, one for charging. The charge cord is your typical and utterly bland usb micro that is a bit longer than most but not all that functional. Power reserve is 10 hours of active play, which is more than most people could stand considering the wight and pressure of the cans on the ears.

Overall, these are the best bluetooth cans I have purchased, and probably the best at their price point. I highly recommend them for casual users. If you are spending more time with your cans, you are most likely going to have to spend more.

column8: These headphones almost get the job done. This is my third pair of headphones in a month and unfortunately I'm going through a bit of a a goldilocks and the three bears scenario. The Chinese brands I bought were ok and comfortable but they leaked too much sound and the build quality was subpar. I bought these hoping for the winner and aside from how painful they are to wear, I almost got it. The headphones connect seamlessly with any of my bluetooth capable devices (ipad, macbook, android phone, and iPhone). They sound great. I can say they sound great because I'm not an audiophile so I can't hear whatever it is that they hear that makes things bad ;). That being said, after 10 minutes of wearing these, my ears become almost raw to the touch. If I put them on my ears, the ear-pads, which are way too small, crush the top and bottom of my ear against my face. Because of the weight of these, that hurts. To combat that effect, I started tucking my ears into the ear-pad holes. That hurts too. I was promised "All day Comfort" and I did not get it. They will be going back.

column8:
The Hesh 2 wireless headphones are a huge disappointment for me:
- Mediocre sound quality - even with EQ app on iPhone I couldn't make them sound good
- Not very comfortable - ear holes too small
- Ear cups become hot and sweaty after only about 30 minutes
- Bulky

On the plus side, the Bluetooth pairing worked well and reliably with good range.

There is a lot of hype around these headphones. They didn't meet my expectations
as they sound like cheap headphones. Yes, they are inexpensive, but I expected something better.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: Overall they are pretty serviceable headphones
column8:
Overall they are pretty serviceable headphones. I am not going to say they are amazing or can compare with any high end brands, but for under $100 these things are pretty good. They are not great in any one category but middle of the road type of headphones, and for the price they met my expectations.

Sound Quality - These sound decent but nothing amazing. I listen to mostly hard rock/hip hop./blues/alternative and they seem to handle everything fine. I would not say bass is over-pronounced. Overall average sounding which is fine for less than $100 bluetooth headphones

Comfort - these hold up pretty well for a few hours and then start to become more uncomfortable. I think it is because they are an hybrid over the ear on the ear style. The ear holes are too small but the muffs are very soft and form onto the ear nicely. The headhand doesnt have any padding but is a type of rubber/silicone so it does not put much pressure on the top of the head.

Style - I have the black version and i like the way they look. not too flashy and skullycandy log on the side is subtle. I've seen them described as bulbous by other reviewers and id tend to agree. The black looks slick though and i also enjoy the camo style.

Build Quality - Headband is a rubber/silicone coated over the plastic and easy to bend so im not too concerned about it snapping. when adjusting the headband you can see the plastic under the rubber so this could be a weakpoint.

Bluetooth - the connection has been pretty solid and pairs quickly. range is average but i don't go to far from the source with them. i do notice some cutting out when moving into other rooms if there is any obstacles in the between.

Features - i like the simplicity of the buttons on this. there is an overemphasized plus and minus sign for the volume. and the main power button servces as pause/answer call function. skipping tracks is a long press of the volume button. all buttons are on the right ear cup. they are easy to use and work great. charging inside of the ear piece is kind of weird. i have had some issues occasionally with getting the connector into its slot. its not a major issue though. i have not tried the microphone so cannot comment on that. noise isolation is decent because the cups seal pretty good on my ears. probably depends a lot on your size. while you cannot use the ear piece buttons when in wire mode, the clicker button on the wire works simple enough. overall this set has a lot to offer in way of features.

Constant blinking blue light when on - this is the main reason i took off a star. it is just annoying. i wear glasses and can see the blinking reflection sometimes in the glass depending on the lighting. it is also annoying for others around you. i know other bluetooth headphones have this same concept but their lights are usually pin sized. the power button on the hesh 2 wireless is quite large and the whole button lights up. this is obnoxious and the only solution is to put some black tape over it. some could probably ignore this but for me it is annoying.

Final Impressions - overall i like these headphones and thats why i gave them 4 stars. they are mostly average in all areas but are simple and function well. they do a lot of things and this is a strong point for a sub $100 pair of bluetooth headphones. i thought they were comfortable and look appealing. Sound overall is not bad and will probably be good enough for average listener. The constant blinking large blue light is annoying but not a deal breaker. overall a solid headphone for the price.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: All good, except a bit uncomfortable for a long days worth of listening
column8:
EDITED:  I'm taking two stars off now, the comfort thing really keeps me from wearing these all days.  Love the sound quality, but the comfort thing has become a deal break.  Was in BB yesterday and tried on several more expensive models, and the comfort issue was definitely not an issue on these (JBL/Bose/Etc)  ... I'm trying to find an around the ear set now

I really wanted to love these headphones and give them a 5 star rating.  I'm taking off the star for one con --- comfort.  Otherwise I really like these, especially for the price and would recommend them to others.  I really think they represent a pretty good value.

Pros:  Sound is good, pairing was simple and easy, bluetooth range is good and battery life far exceeded expectations!  I use it to make Skype calls as well, and the mic/speaker combo work well.  Noise cancellation/isolation is good enough for me (I can still hear background noise, but it's enough that I can block just about everything out in the house).

Now my one con.... I can't seem to wear these for more than about an hour or two without getting some discomfort.  If the ear openings were a bit wider I think these would work a little better for me.  I will likely use these for some time, but I will likely end up trying to figure out some headphones that don't bug my ears as much on the next go around.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column8:
I don't typically do reviews unless I feel strongly about a product, both positively and negatively. But I felt strongly enough about this purchase I decided to write a short review.

I recently upgraded to the iphone 7 and have been looking for a good sounding pair of Bluetooth headphones. While I love my AT M50X and my Sony MDR 7506 (now relegated to my vintage stereo) headphones, I needed a set of wireless.

I read about a million reviews and thought I would take a look at the new Sonys. I decided to head out to the local big box store that carried a variety of headphones.

Well I tried on the Sonys and they were ok, a bit muddled but ok. I was bummed. I then tried (only for so I could say I tried them, the Beats) and they SUCKED! I won't bore you with my opinion on these, but I will say I can't believe people die so much for a mediocre pair of headphones. Marketing does work I guess. But my opinion only matters to me, I get that.

I tried on some other headphones as well to get as wide a sample as I could while I was there. And let me tell you I am glad I did.

So lastly I tried on the Skullcandy Hesh 2 and have to say I really was surprised! I had never heard the Skullcandy brand before, but to my ears, the HEah 2 wireless sounded great. I listened to a variety of music and was really impressed. Good vocals, good bass, and crisp highs. The phone calls I have made sound nice and clear and in fact the people on the other end have had no idea I'm on wireless headphones. I also tried on the Crushers (bought a pair of those too), but that's for another review.

Long story longer, I bought a pair for my wife and another family member. They have been equally impressed.

Now I can't speak to longevity, but they appear to be solidly built and so far are very comfortable. I have had them on for about 90mins and while my ears get a tad warm, it's nothing that bothers me enough to take them off. Battery life has been about as advertised, but I typically charge them every or every other night so I can't swear to the 15 hours exactly. Range has been great within my house, 50+ feet with no issues. I haven't tried them outside, and may not ever do so. I mean who leaves their 800$ phone sitting on a table and walks away from it just to see how far away they can hear Bob Marley without breaking up?

Bottom line, If your looking for a set of affordable, solidly built, nice looking, great sounding wireless headphones, in my humble opinion, you can't go wrong. This is especially true if you can find them used but like new. Give them a test run, you could do a lot worse.

The Bluetooth feature works well, and the sound quality is very good. I have noticed that once the battery gets below about 50%, the Bluetooth connection does get a little fuzzy at times. The comfort level is very good with these too. I can wear these for hours at a time and still be comfortable. They link instantly with my phone and laptop whenever my bluetooth is connected, which is also a plus. All in all, yeah $80-100 is a good amount of money to be spending on headphones but when it comes to these types of electronics, you usually get what you paid for. Would buy again and would recommend.

column7: they are OK at best. Pros
column8:
Got mine locally. Honestly, they are OK at best.

Pros: Decent battery life
comfortable

Cons: Only remembers one device.
lacking bass. -- I don't want something like the Sony Extra Bass nonsense, but I don't want the bassline to be invisible either.
Cannot use the MIC with stereo sound. So no chat while gaming (for example).
Loud popping noises as it changes modes, goes to sleep, etc.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column8:
Seriously these headphones are awesome for the price. Bluetooth works like a charm, battery life is good, the cable is a nice touch, they look and feel great. Been using them for a month, no problem.

They're not exactly 'Over-Ear' because they do press down on top and bottom of your ears a bit, if you have earlobes. They still are comfortable to wear hours at a time and a quick 3-4 minute break is enough rest to then wear them again for a few hours.

THE ONE CON

These don't swivel right and left, only up and down. For users who don't live alone and want to hear people speak the one-headphone-on-one-off is a bit uncomfortable because they will lean causing more pressure because of the lack of swivel.

I've been using them for about 3 weeks and haven't had any big problems, especially for the price, these are 100% worth the buy. If you are looking for good premium build headphones for a cheaper price. There are probably better 'Over-Ear' headphones that may do the job a little better for comfort.  But I haven't tried those so I can't say. Also not much of an audio-file so can't say much about that either, I buy headphones for the comfort and price mainly.

column7: I was not expecting to like it much more than the V8-1 set I usually ...
column8:
I have to admit, this is a well designed, well built headset.  I was not expecting to like it much more than the V8-1 set I usually use, and in the end maybe I don't, but it has it's points:

It probably is much more rugged than the cheaper headsets, so if you are in a situation where you expect it to take some abuse, that could make a difference.  I occasionally drop it about a foot onto the carpet, so not any particular value to me.

It doesn't creek when you twist it (or your head) around like the V8-1 does.  That can be nice.

The controls are easier to find with your fingers than on the V8-1.

The cushions are really lush.

The microphone is a pinhole type on the right ear, so you won't find it in the picture.  Both flash (this one on the right, the V8-1 on the left, which can be important to your mate if you wear them to bed) and make my head look like a plane coming in for a landing.

The sound on both is fine, hard to say there was any difference there, except the V8-1 seemed to have slightly more bass.

So, is it twice as good as the V8-1?  Not for me, but it depends.  Still, this will be the set that I favor.

column7: So far so good. (10 min out of the box)
column8: Updated Review 2: (37 days later) I've had these headphones for quite a while and they are nothing short of awesome. I still think the sound could be a tiny bit crispier (like the beats) but the price range for this headset makes it ok. The battery takes a long time to discharge and I can get one full day out of one charge which is great. My ears do get a bit hot but it's expected if there's warm weather and the cups cover the entire ear. They do hurt the top part of my ear (left mostly) after long periods of time but it's not something too bad. What did get me annoyed (A LOT) was the lack of volume control when wired and the lack of song control when wireless, so I was trying to find a solution. Just out of curiosity, I plugged my beats cable into this to see if the control would work and it does!! So I purchased a new cable for these headphones (Barely $7): Replacement Cable/Wire for Beats By Dre Headphones with Leather Pouch for them and it's just what I needed! There will never be a solution for my wireless problem, but this tiny cable brings new life into a pair of headphones that are already amazing to begin with. Bottom line: I wouldn't hesitate to purchase again! Updated Review: (8 hours later) I've literally had these headphones on for the last 8 hours and I can tell they are very comfy to wear. Haven't charged them at all and they are still holding up strong. Paired them with a Macbook Pro and no issues at all. Marathoned a tv show on iTunes (4 hrs aprox) and the sound is very good for spoken word. There is no lag between the sound and the video. Had a 2 hour FaceTime call and the sound quality is great. Testing on my mac I asked the other party to see if there was a degradation of sound by using the built-in mic and the one on the mac and they reported no major differences. Using the mic on the headset on bluetooth does lower the sound quality for the listener considerably. So I would suggest (if you're using a mac), to go to sound preferences and on the input tab, use the built in microphone. It's more reliable. Leaving my phone on a table, I'd say the bluetooth range is about 20 average steps away from the device and the music is still very clear. Started jumping, dancing around, spinning and they didn't come off, they fit kind of snug and over my entire ears (which is a good thing for me). The only thing I didn't notice before my purchase is that there is no play/pause, rw, fw buttons on the headset, only the on/off button, and volume up/down. This isn't necessarily a deal breaker (nor it would demerit a star) but if you're looking for this, they aren't there. The cable is as long as the one of the Solo HD Beats I had so that's also a plus. I'll make a third review later during the week to see how they hold up with more use. Original Review: Just got these on the mail and I have to admit I'm impressed. Although I have been thoroughly spoiled by the sound my Solo HD Beats have given me for the past 4 years, I wanted to give these a try. I have owned Skullcandy in-ear headphones before but never these. I have to admit pairing them to an iPhone 6S was very easy and I like the quality of sound (for $70), but I'll still end up splurging on a new pair of Beats wireless, just because the sound on these tends to be a little flat in comparison. Don't get me wrong, they sound really good, but they don't have the extra oomph I was looking for. The cans are very light and they rest very nicely over my ears. I'll be testing out these headphones and updating my review in the future. So far, 5 stars to them.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column8:
Updating to 5 based on purchasing some 30 dollar other brand BT headphones over the ear for my wife and the skull candy headphones put them to shame.  The battery life is way better and the sound lag on the other headphones while watching TV is way worse.  The skull candy headphone audio syncs pretty much exactly with the video.  The comfort thing is still an issue, but like I said, not if you only have them on for a few hours.  Still great headphones!

I wish I could give these 4.5 stars, but I really had to take some stars off for comfort.  I can only wear these for about 5 hours a day without my ears hurting.  This isn't really a huge deal for me because I rarely wear them for more than a few hours at a time.  Below is my review on the individual aspects of the headphones:

Style:  3 stars.  These things are kind of bulky in comparison to beats or some other more expensive headphones.
Sound;  5 stars.  This things sound awesome!  I really like listening to music with these headphones on.
Quality:  5 stars.  These are high quality, look like they will last forever.  I have had them for 5 months now and had no issues.
Connectivity:  5 stars.  Very easy to pair with all of my BT compatible devices.  Stays connected and has a good range.
Battery Life:  5 stars.  The battery seems like it lasts forever!  I charge these every once in a while just to be sure they don't die on me.  I can listen to them all week for several hours a day without them dying.
Price:  5 stars.  The price is very good for name brand, well built headphones.  I didn't have to worry about paid reviewers reviewing these and making them sound better than they are.  I know several other people that have these headphones.  Sometimes name brand is just a better way to go for warranty and reliability.
Comfort:  3 stars.  They are ok for a little while, but the pads are nowhere near as soft and comfy as my friends Beats headphones.  He let me try them for a while one day and they are way more comfortable.  I am not going to spend and extra $150 to $200 for that comfort when I really don't wear headphones all day anyway.

Bottom line:  I do recommend these headphones to anyone looking for a good BT over the ear headphone for moderate use.  If you can try them on first, I recommend that.  Skullcandy is a reliable and trustworthy name brand and you can't go wrong with these headphones at this price!
