column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: Sound quality and clever controls don't redeem these headphones.
column8: I wanted to like these, I really did.  I wanted my search for bluetooth headphones to be over, but it's not.  First thing I noticed when I opened the package was how well built and durable they felt.  I knew that, at the time, I was really going to like them.  Nice big easy to feel buttons on the right side.  Nice easy to see "R" and "L" on the band so I can throw them on in the right direction quickly.  I thought "wow, this is a nicely designed unit."  Then I was ready to plug them in and charge them for the first time...wait...where's the micro-USB charging port?  On the right botton next to the controls?  Nope.  On the left ear next to the 3.5mm jack?  Nope.  I had to go to the manual to find that they're on the top of the left speaker under the headband.  Wait, what?  You have all this easily accessible real estate on the outside edge of either speaker and you tuck it away in the worst possible location?  It takes me probably 5-10 seconds longer to plug them in (usually requiring shifting my finger position at least once to get the plug to the right angle.  Easily and without question the worst charging port position I've ever seen.  But oh well, if the rest of the headphones are as good as I'm expecting them to be, it's a small price to pay, right?  So I paired the headphones with my mobile device.  It was probably easiest pairing I've ever done.  Plus the ascending and descending power on/off tones are a nice touch.  I've had devices that give you the same beep for both and when they're on your ear, you can't tell if that's the "on" beep or the "off" beep.  So these tones were nice.  Next I fired up Pandora and was greeted to a rich audio experience with just the right amount of base.  Very nice.  The noise isolation, which isn't the best I've heard, is adequate for the most part I guess.  I switched Pandora station to classic rock and hammered the volume, "Let's see how loud we can get!"  Well, turns out not very loud.  The max volume is again, adequate.  You an hear everything and for the most part is enough but I would love to crank some AC/DC and get lost in an Angus Young riff but the volume just isn't quite there.  But oh well, if the rest of the headphones are as good as I'm expecting them to be, it's a small price to pay, right?  Then a track came up that I didn't much care for so I thought I'd advance to the next one.  Turns out the volume buttons double as the FWD/NEXT buttons.  Do a long-press on the volume up button and it advances to the next track.  To pause/play the music you tap the power button.  Clever.  I'm happy with this interface.  But as I'm listening to the music I realized that the headphone cushion is round and not oval shaped as most over-the-ear headphones I've used and is pushing the top of my ear against my head.  It was kinda annoying but figured the designers knew what they were doing.  Well, after two full days of using these headphones the tops of my ears hurt and last night I had a head ache I feel was caused by the pressure.  So even though I like the ease of use, sound quality and controls of these headphones the rest of the experience is annoying and even painful, it's too big a price to pay.  My search for decent bluetooth headphones isn't over yet.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column8:
These headphones are a great substitute if you don't want to spend $400 on Beats or the Parrot Ziks.  They are not bass heavy so if that is what you like, you may want to go with the Beats.  These headphones give a nice clean sound and they are very comfortable.  As a kid, I was always teased about my big ears. I was shocked at how comfortable these headphones fit over my big ears.  I use them for roughly 5 hours a day at work and have no complaints.

They are well constructed with a great rubbery/plastic feel which is hardly a problem.  They are very easy to sync with any Bluetooth device and the features to answer and end phone calls if using a cell phone works great.  The only draw back I noticed is that when I answer a call using the phone and not the headphones, the music does not restart in the headphones but comes from the phone's speaker instead.  So, it's best to use the button on the headphones to answer and end calls.  As far as distance goes, I was able to walk 27 feet away from my phone before the music began to cut out.  I'm not sure how that stacks up against other Bluetooth headphones.

I am very happy with these headphones.  I saved myself a few hundred dollars by not purchasing the higher end sets.  You won't go wrong with these.

column4: Skullcandy Hesh 2 Over-Ear Wireless Headphones, 15 Hr Battery, Microphone, Works with iPhone Android and Bluetooth Devices - Black
column7: Waited for bluetooth headphones this good.
column8:
Update: Still feel the same 2+ years later.  Holding up great, still charges well.

Anyone else not impressed by Beats or their prices?  Bought some beats and now want wireless?  Lost or broke your existing headphones?

These are your headphones.  You can pick them up for around $100 most of the time vs the Beats bluetooth for around $350.

I bought these at a brick and mortar because Amazon didn't have these headphones when they first came out, and I searched.  Sorry Amazon :)  If you have heard the Skullcandy Aviators, then you know the kind of headphones this company can make.  The Hesh sound like bluetooth versions of the Aviators to me.

Pros:

Sound
Range
Passive Noise Cancelling (not active but does well enough for use during mowing and yard work)
Connectivity (I have a lot of issues with my Plantronics earbuds with staying connected or re-connecting, these are great)
Controls on the right ear cup are usable and function reliably
Volume up and down are in fact volume up and down (also fwd and back for audio if you hold the button longer than a tap)
Comfort (I wear these for 4 hour stints with no issues, this beats out my old Sony wired headset)
Battery life is good, no problems yet, haven't had them turn off as I charge each night
Nice charging port on top of the left ear cup (behind the arm)
Will play while it's charging, not a standard feature in this genre
Materials/feel/design is all very modern and pleasing

Cons:

Not as loud on Bluetooth (using the cable isn't terrible and boots the sound noticeably)
They don't fold for storage or travel
Fabric covering the drivers seems to be loose after just a few uses
No easy way to check battery level with any accuracy (offers flashing LED response but only when battery is low, give me a 100/75/50/25/10% check voice or LED)

Overall these are amazing headphones and I couldn't be happier that I didn't fall in to the Beats trap.  I shopped, listened and waited for the right thing.  These look and sound right.  I listen to a little of everything and this handles it all cleanly.

Great for anyone who loves music, podcasts, audiobooks, or just watching some video on your phone/laptop/tablet.  These even pair nicely with my Dish Network Hopper so that I can watch loud action movies/tv shows at a good volume while my 22 month old daughter sleeps.

I'll be taking these on a business trip next month and won't have to worry about looking like a kid with bright colored crazy headphones (I'm in my mid 30's)  Skullcandy does offer the crazy colors if you want that too.

I've had these just over a month and will update with more info.

Ladies and Gentlemen of Amazon, these cards are released on June 10, 2016 at a $449 price point for an early release "founders edition"

The "HYPE" is real! It is an amazing card, hence the 5 stars, it's faster than the Titan X... HOWEVER!!! READ ON!!!

This means their cooler design with the "Vapor chamber" that they try to upsell you to the $449 Founders edition for IS NOT WORTH IT EITHER!

PLEASE WAIT UNTIL THIS CARD DROPS TO THE REASONABLE $349 MSRP THAT IT SHOULD BE!

On a side note,

THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO DIFFERENCE IN ANY MATERIAL OR DESIGN USED, BETWEEN THE FOUNDERS EDITION CARDS, AND THE REGULAR CARDS SHIPPED SHORTLY AFTERWARD.

The Founder's edition is another way of saying Reference Card and another way to charge those who want the card on the very first day, an extra 100 bucks.

Partners like EVGA will come out with Custom Cards with liquid cooling and so forth, for around the same price point.

These cards will come factory overclocked and superclocked, and will have different types like the "Kingpin" edition which uses premium copper for heat dissipation on the 980 Ti

Please wait, be patient for 14 days, and then order a custom card from NVIDIA partners.

That is my best advice to you Amazonians.

Good luck and happy gaming

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Great card at an exceptional value
column8: I spend a lot of time building/fixing desktop PCs. I have several I have built that I use at home, and at work. It has been a hobby since about 1994. I used to surrender to the urge of getting the very best component you could possibly get when building a PC or whatever electronic system. And if that is what you want, there is nothing wrong with that. But in the last few years, I have made it a goal to make the best desktop PCs for workstation, and gaming at the lowest possible price. This card is amazing for how cheap it is (yes 380 dollars plus tax is cheap). I spent $400 on a card back in 2006/2007 just on the cusp of AGP going out and PCI-E coming in, and that wasn't even as much as I could have spent back then. So this price for what it can do is insane. There is not a game that requires 8GB of video RAM. Sure some games are made poorly and require a lot of power (Kingdom Come: Deliverance) and if you enable certain graphics options it can get up to the 8GB maybe... but in general it isn't necessary. The difference between the 1070 and 1080 is small when comparing the price difference ($100-$200 depending). In this range of cards, the 1070 is in a sweet spot. So unless you plan on spending 1000 or more, this card is the best for the price in this range.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Great Card in a Itx case!
column8:
A very quiet card that does well in a warm 25C ambient room. Overclocked out of the box, it reaches 1974Mhz. I gave it a +136 offset and it reaches 2050Mhz on average now so it probably has some more overhead in a cooler room, or if you put the fan speeds up. The asynchronous fans are awesome for noise levels, with the gpu core fan on the left usually spinning at all times. Temps never get above 73C.
.  Having shoved this card into a Bitfenix prodigy case, I don't have a lot of height space to work with, on account of the optical drive. If you were to forego the optical drive, if would fit just fine with some height to spare. I also have a 200mm front intake and I was able to fit the card without any clearance problems on the front. Considering the small size of my case, you can expect temperatures well below 73C with proper airflow in a bigger case.  I have seen this when I had lower ambient temps in my room, when cranking the ac.  I imagine a mid-tower case would see this thing being very quiet and keeping good temperatures, even at full utilization. A great buy. Although the current shortage has lead to a inflated price. Might be better to wait out the current market.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: You will be happy with this 1070! (Most reviews about thermal pads are old.)
column8:
I bought mine as a 1st of many part upgrade so it was paired with a 8370@5Ghz. With the fx chip it didn't do so good. But once I upgraded my machine to a i7 7700k@5.1Ghz w/32Gb 3200Mhz ram this card really showed potential. I have 2 1080p freesync (Yes Freesync) displays that both run @ 75Hz I use upscaling on them to play my games. Which with this card every game I've thrown at it plays maxed out. I hope to get better monitors soon but for now everything's works as it should. This card says max boost is around 1750-1800Mhz but most card I've seen max boost out around 2000Mhz benchmark wise my card sits close to a stock founders 1080 for 20% less cost I'll take it. :-) Buy this if you can't justify the price hike for a 1080 especially if you own 1080p monitors go for it. Beats out my crossfire rx480 I sold for this plus way less micro stutters.

The thermal pads issue was with the 1st stock of these cards all card now are sold with Thermal pads plus a new bios. Don't let old reviews hinder you away from buying this brand of 1070.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Bought a new item, but received used one :(
column8:
First of all I want to note, that this feedback is not related to EVGA GTX 1070 graphic card or EVGA brand itself, but to this particular item. I have 4 EVGA PSU-s (G2, G3, GQ) and 4 graphic cards (GTX 1070 SC and SC2) and quite happy with all of them so far.

Why 1-star? because...
1. Item bought as new, but the factory seal was cut (image is attached).
2. There were no plastic coverings that should be on the new item (e.g. on back-plate).
3. There is a label stuck to a box with the text "LPN RR 30236 0026"(image is attached). I googled a little bit and found that this kind of labels are stuck to a !!!RETURNED!!! items. Maybe I have wrong info regarding LPN abbreviation, if someone can clarify what does it mean, please let me know.
4. And finally... the card does not work and I'm starting the return/refund process from the next Monday. A sad thing is that the card is outside of the USA and I have to pay for the shipping (to USA) and take care that the card will be in USA within 30 days return period.

Very disappointed this time.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Great Card without breaking the bank
column8:
This card is crazy good.  An excellent price point with excellent performance. This card handles all current titles with reasonable frame rates 30+.  While it may not provide the crushing performance of the 1080, it gets the job done without totally blowing the budget, maybe just a little stretch.

If you have the money, the 1080 is a much better card and will run games faster, farther into the future than the 1080.  Also if you already own a 980 TI, R9 295X2, R9 Fury X, or better, the 1070 will not be an upgrade and you should consider the 1080.
http://amzn.to/2upKr7U

I purchased the FTW with 1797 clock, the 08G-P4-6276-KR version. EVGA makes several versions of this card and it can be difficult to determine what the difference between them is.  I will try to do so here.

Glossary
Blower Cooling - Cooling that uses a blower style cooler and heatsink.  Economical design.
ACX3.0 Cooling - Advanced cooling system using variable speed fans and heatsinks.  Good design.
iCX Cooling - Evolution of ACX3.0 including additional thermal sensors and technology.  Best fan and heatsink design
Hybrid Cooling - Closed loop water cooling that requires mounting a radiator on the back of the case.  Very effective cooling

Backplate - A metal sheet that is placed over the back of the card further protecting the electronics, and improving heat handling capabilities.
RGB LED - An LED that can change color programmatically to any color.  Easily match the color of other items inside your case to maximize flexibility in design.

10 Phase Power - An enhanced power supply design that will deliver more consistent power to the graphics processor to insure reliable operation.  More phases means cleaner power, and greater power capacity.  The other design is a 4 phase design.

8 pin connector - Add in graphics cards need additional power provided to them.  This is typically done with an 8 pin connector from the power supply.  Some older cards used 6 pin connectors, so some power supplies provide 6+2 connectors, while others provide 8 pin connectors.  You need to make sure that you have the proper number of 8 pin connectors (or 6+2) or you will not be able to power your graphics card and it will not work.  A 6 pin connector will not work, it does not supply enough power, or fit for that matter.  If you do not have either 8 pin or 6+2 pin connectors available, you will need to upgrade your power supply.  This is common in older computers, as well as name brand computers from Dell and HP.  The power supplies were not designed for high power add in cards.

08G-P4-5170 1683 MHz boost with blower cooling, requires only a single 8pin connector and draws 150W, no backplate (Blower)
http://amzn.to/2v2fkms
08G-P4-5171 1683 MHz boost but adds ACX3.0 advanced cooling requires one 8-pin and draws 150W, no backplate  (uncommon model)
http://amzn.to/2hsIA14
08G-P4-6170  1683 MHz boost with blower cooling one 8pin 150W White LED, adds backplate  (Founders Edition)
http://amzn.to/2v3WauV
08G-P4-6171 1683 MHz boost ACX3.0 cooling one 8pin 150W  adds White LED (REF)
http://amzn.to/2vnJPV9
08G-P4-6571 1683 MHz boost iCX cooling and thermal modules single 8pin 150W White LED  (Not on Amazon)
08G-P4-5173 1784 MHz boost (super clocked) ACX3 cooling, one 8pin, 170W power White LED, no backplate  (SC Black)
http://amzn.to/2v2iDKF
08G-P4-6173 1784 MHz boost (super clocked) ACX3 cooling, one 8pin, 170W power White LED (SC)
http://amzn.to/2v2t3tm
08G-P4-6178 1784 MHz boost Hybrid cooling, one 8pin, 170W power White LED (HYBRID)
http://amzn.to/2vnDrNt
08G-P4-6573 1784 MHz boost (super clocked) iCX cooling, one 8pin, 170W power White LED (SC2)
http://amzn.to/2v2oOhN
08G-P4-6274 1683 MHz boost ACX3 cooling, two 8pin, 215W power RGB LED, Enhanced 10 Phase Power Supply for overclocking (FTW 1683)
http://amzn.to/2v2G0DF
08G-P4-6276 1797 MHz boost super clocked ACX3 cooling, two 8pin, 215W power RGB LED, 10 Phase Power for OC (FTW 1797) (The card I purchased)
http://amzn.to/2v2pDHp
08G-P4-6278 1797 MHz boost super clocked Hybrid cooling, two 8pin, 215W power RGB LED, 10 Phase Power for OC (FTW HYBRID 1797)
http://amzn.to/2v45O0t
08G-P4-6674 1683 MHz boost iCX cooling, two 8pin, 215W power RGB LED, 10 Phase Power for OC (Not on Amazon)
08G-P4-6676 1797 MHz boost super clocked iCX cooling, two 8pin, 215W power RGB LED, 10 Phase Power for OC (FTW2 1797)
http://amzn.to/2upMLMp

I chose the model I did, because it had ACX cooling, and the 1797 clock with the 10 phase power and RGB LED.  The more expensive cards offered very little benefit.

If the 1070 is just too much of as stretch for the budget consider the 1060 at 6GB (not enough savings to go to 3GB).  Be aware that the 1060 is comparable to the 970, 708 or Titan.  It is also comparable to the Radeon RX580/570/480/470, R9 390/290 or Intel HD7990.  If you own one of those it will not be an upgrade.
http://amzn.to/2vyqP6K

If the budget is really tight you should look at the 1050.  Be aware that the 1050 is on par with the 950, 760 or 660 Ti.  It is also comparable to the Rx460, R7-370, R9-270 or Intel Hd 7870.  This card will not be an upgrade if you have one of those or better.
http://amzn.to/2v4S4CO

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Stays cold under very heavy loads!
column8: I run this card for 2 different reasons: 1 to game with and 2 to Mine some cryptocurrency. During gaming I don't even need to overclock it as Witcher 3 with Ultra settings (I disabled hair works) on 1080P runs in the 100-150FPS range on stock clocks. For mining I have it overclocked to +100mv, core +125mhz, Mem +675mhz in MSI Afterburner. The memory clock is too high to game with as you'll see artifacts, but for mining it works out to 30.5MH/s with ETH without difficulty. The card runs nearly 24/7 and I've never seen the temps exceed 45c even after 16+ hours of load. When I want to overclock for games I usually do a mild OC of core +125 mhz, Mem +400-550mhz. I could push it higher but I'm running on a 1080p TV at 60HZ. In Far Cry 4 and Just Cause 3 the FPS on max settings is in the 150FPS range so I turn on Vsync to keep it consistent and the GPU never goes above a 50% load. I don't regret this card one bit, and since it can mine decently it will eventually pay for itself (6+month for ROI atm). I've played with my friends GTX 1060, but this 1070 walks all over it. My setup is: GTX 1070 (this card), Ryzen 5 1600 OC'd to 3.925ghz, Samsung 960 evo M.2 SSD 250gb, 2TB seagate drive for my games, Team Dark Ram 2 8GB sticks running at 3066 mhz, Corsair RM100x 1000 watt PSU, etc. This card scores a 12563 on passmark with core +125 and mem +550. Overall I'm happy with this card as I came from a GTX 950 and the difference was astounding. You won't regret this card!

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
This card has overheating issues.
They were acknowledged by EVGA and a "fix" was announced on their website.
My cards (Purchased late April 2017) apparently has the "fix" installed. I put the quotes because my machine keeps rebooting due to overheating GPU. Now i have to deal with EVGA support because i can no longer return it to Amazon.

I would not recommend this card due to the overheating issue.

EDIT:
I've been working with support. Turns out that the reboots i experienced during gameplay were not due to overheat (actually the card is capable of operating in the ~95 degree range). My issue was with the computer PSU - under heavy load it would not supply enough power. I replaced a PSU 2 weeks ago and no issue seen since. Therefore i am adjusting my score from 1 to 4.

column7: Less wattage, Less weight, Less temperature - Best Graphics Card as of 2017
column8:
Purchased as upgrade from my old GTX 570 SC.  Although I have 7 case fans, I will always purchase a blower type graphics card rather than open air.  Open Air type graphics cards disperse hot air inside your computer case.  I prefer to blow hot air outside the case.  Prefer Founders Edition.
Compare the difference of these blower type graphics cards:
GTX1070 purchase date 2017,  50 watts, 2.2 lbs, avg temp over 8 hours=35C, 1920 CUDAs, 8192mb, HDMI 2.0b, 1x8pin connector
GTX570  purchase date 2012, 219 watts, 3 lbs,  avg temp over 8 hrs=42C,  480 CUDA's, 1280mb, HDMI 1.4a,  2x6pin connector

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Decent Performance but EVGA Features are Lacking
column8:
Let me start off by saying I received a card that was in need of the thermal pad mod and BIOS update. Free from EVGA, but still a pain. The thermal pad issue was announced by EVGA on November 1st of 2016 and my order was placed on February 3rd of 2017. 3 months and they apparently hadn't cycled out their inventory yet. What's worse is that there's a potential fire hazard if you don't perform the mod and outside of personal research, EVGA has no system setup to notify owners if their units are affected. One star down for that.

As far as card usage goes, I've been getting pretty great gaming performance using my 1st gen Razer Blade Stealth and Razer Core. I don't have all the latest games, but it runs Doom, Fallout 4 and everything else I've thrown at it on ultra without a problem. The bottleneck I experience on some games is the CPU in my laptop (i7-6500u), but I still stay well above 30 FPS no matter what.

I've also started stressing the card by folding proteins (Folding@Home) and it's not performing  as well as I thought it would. I'm currently in the process of figuring out why... I suspect it's due to the limited bus bandwidth of the Razer Core's Thunderbolt 3 connection, but I haven't confirmed yet. I know this card is capable of 600k PPD (I'm only getting ~100k) so I'll try and update this review once I've learned more.
5/24/17 Update:
I got it folding correctly. Getting over 600k PPD now. Also running the card at 2.1GHz with some slight voltage bumps. The limit of PCI-e 3.0 x4 doesn't seem to be a problem at all with FAH. The bus only runs at about 20-25% usage while folding full throttle.

The other reason I dropped a star is because the EVGA Precision XOC software is pretty craptastic. It crashes and hangs more than it should, but also has a poorly laid out interface. I realize this isn't going to affect most users as the card will function just fine without the software, but for me, it is a part of the product experience and is marketed as a feature from EVGA.

If the EVGA software gets an update and starts working better, I'll bump this review up to 4 stars. nVidia has made one hell of a graphics chip and it deserves better vendor support.

column7: This GPU is a beast!  Great value at an affordable price
column8:
Purchased as an upgrade to an EVGA GTX 970 for my gaming rig.  Running games at 1080p, I maintain a consistent 60 frames per second in most AAA games at maximum / ultra settings (vsync enabled) without breaking a sweat.  When I ran into issues with my PC that I suspected was the GPU, EVGA customer service was friendly and helpful in helping me diagnose my problems (ultimately not the GPU).

Although I have the version without replacement thermal pads, I haven't noticed temperature problems in the GPU.  However, I would recommend downloading and installing the latest firmware from EVGA to be on the safe side.

My only complaint is with configuring the EVGA Precision XOC software.  Recommend using MSI Afterburner or similar monitoring programs

Highly recommend for 1440p and good 4K (low to medium settings); it's a little overkill for 1080p.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8: I replaced 2 AMD water cooled R9-290s with 2 MSI 1070 Hybrids watercooled and I must say this is the best video card I have ever Owned (I have been building my own machines since the early 90s). First off the hybrid version is a good inexpensive nice feature. When I water cooled the R9-290s, it cost me an additional $90.00 to upgrade each card with the AMD metal plate, fan and radiator. This is a steal compared to doing it later. That said, I use the cards for Prepar3d flight simulator in SLI mode ( CrossFire not supported) and this is the first time I don't have to overclock the video Card to get good performance in my sim. I will overclock it but this is the first time I can just plug and play and the settings are maxed out. When I am in my aircraft sitting in LAX, my frames are at 25fps. That is outstanding. These are great cards thay are quite and perform well. Write now without overclock my temps are in the low 40s at full load. I did some small overclock tests and already I know I have a lot of headroom when I do overclock these cards. The hybrid is the best price value card in the group, powerful, good price over upgrading later, and what I have seen and heard,  overclocking these boards are a snap and good performers. I recommend and I have been using AMD graphics for years. I feel terrible about abandoning AMD but until AMD's Crossfire work in Windows mode, I had to make the shift. Good luck and I hope this is helpful.

column8:
I upgraded my Windows 10 Build 16188.rs_prerelease. 170430-1928 (i.e. released and installed today 5/5/2017 for me) on an AMD FX9590 (8 core 5GHZ) from my former graphics card Sapphire Radeon HD5870 to this EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Super Clocked graphics card.
Following the instructions that came with the card carefully, the installation went flawlessly! That makes me pleased! No troubles!

Everything came up running - not even a single icon on any of my three high resolution monitors was out of place (well relatively high these days, 2560x1600). Nothing needed to be configured. I did download the EVGA latest drivers (issued a few days ago on 2017-05-01), and did a normal driver update by going to the Settings/Display/Adapter/Properties/Update Driver selection, and then providing the c:\NVIDEA directory where the downloaded EVGA updates were loaded on the C:.  All went perfectly, now with driver version 22.21.13.8205 (as shown on the Properties screen).

I am totally pleased with the installation, and everything is looking very good.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
Wow, what an improvement over my last card. I am by no means an expert, but I did my research and found that the 1070 was probably best suited for my needs, and having used several EVGA components in the past I decided to stick with what I felt was the best.

I am so glad I did.

For starters, I built my daily driver PC roughly 1.5 years ago and it started life with an EVGA 750 SC TI. For what I was doing at the time it worked well. It handled most games I played in the medium to high range with some settings adjusted, and I thought I would be happy. I thought wrong. The FTW2 model I purchased was and is as the kids put it eloquently "Off the chain". Now, all current games I play are ultra settings, and it just churns out those precious FPS. I paired it with an i7 4790k and it works like buttered toast.  Wait tastes like buttered toast. no... erm.. Its just great.

Installation was a breeze, although I did end up pulling my system apart to clean and perform some wire management. This card is long, so make sure you check specs and measure before you purchase so you aren't stuck needing to buy a new case or move other peripherals around. I only had to move my HDD to fit it. It does require two (2) eight (8) pin power connectors, so make sure you have those available. I currently use a fully modular 650watt PS from EVGA, and it works just fine.

Running the card was as easy as booting my system, ensuring settings in BIOS read everything correctly and then booting to windows. I found on initital startup the login screen was not nearly as harsh on the reds. Don't know why it changed, but it changed for the better. Currently I am running three monitors with this setup and configuration was already set. I downloaded the precisionOC from EVGA (protip: make sure you have your cards serial number ready, as its needed to download) and fired it up. The interface is clean, with each item able to be hovered over with the mouse for a small description of that item. I have not messed with the overclock functions yet, but it is as easy as moving some sliders around and letting her rip ( did I just assume your GPUS gender?!?!)

I am super super happy with this card, and feel pretty confident that  I won't have to upgrade any time soon (we all say that, right?).

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
Unless you're futureproofing for 4K gaming and/or multimonitor gaming, this thing is overkill. Delicious, delicious overkill that requires only a single power rail. Temps stay cool at stock clocks with some definite room for overclocking. The single-rail requirement makes it very SLI-friendly as well to even more modest PSUs. There's a high likeliness your motherboard is going to be bottlenecking this thing rather than the other way around, and that's good.

Room to grow is always good.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: It is not the top quality product
column8:
This timing is very mature to comment on the product after using it for 8-9 months. I can say that performance is good compared to competition.
You know the cooling fiasco of VRMs in EVGA ACX cooling. They tried to solve it somehow. I think they were concerned about life span of the chips therefore suggested pad mod and vbios updates. Eventhough they listened to customers and reacted very fast, they should have seen this issue before starting serial production. Therefore they lost 1 star in my mind.

Overall performance and core cooling are very good.
With fan speed at %100, core temps doesn't go ever 59C in furmark stress test which is very good

OC performance differs very much based on your luck. However if I am buying FTW version, I would expect card to achieve certain OC numbers. My card didn't go over +125 core and +550mhz VRAM (Samsung), not even top voltage and power (%120). Card supposed to have more power phases than normal 1070 therefore I would expect higher voltage and power limits. Otherwise what is the point in buying FTW?

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
Not the best card, and also not the most expensive. I've purchased this to hold me over until AMD releases it's Vega Cards this summer and this card has not dissapointed. I run any game I want on max settings, 1080p from 60-100fps all day. This card puts out a small amount of heat but that is to be expected from a high performance GPU. The fans on this card are very quite and I am happy with the noise level. Installation is a breeze and it comes with a cool poster for your wall. The reason for 4 stars? Overclocking.... This is about as overclocked as it gets right out of the box. Ive had some success in ramping up the settings, but the benchmark results from any increase in Frequency or voltage are not enough to justify doing it. In most cases, an increase in frequency or voltage had reverse effects and I saw a decline in bechmark scores. That being said, straight out of the package its a great video card, and will play all games with ease right now so I would suggest buying it. On a side note, I received a version with the thermal mod already installed and it was ordered in March of 2017, so they might be out of the bad stock by now.. Specs on my build below

-ASUS X370 Prime MOBO
-AMD Ryzen 1700X CPU
- Corsair H110i cooler
- 2x Samsung 850 EVO SSD
-1x WD Blue Slow but large HDD
- EVGA GTX 1070 SC ACX 3.0 Black Edition GPU
- 16gb G. SKILL Trident Z 3200 DDR4 (F4-3200C14D-16GTZ)
- EVGA Supernova 650 8-+ Platinum Power Supply
- TP Link Archer 1900 AC Wireless PCI card
-  Thermaltake Core X5 case

Stable Overclock to 4,0GHz with 3200MHz ram, temps 65 Celsius and below.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: I just upgraded from a GTX 750 Ti to this beast and I am beyond happy. The price was right
column8:
Solid card! I just upgraded from a GTX 750 Ti to this beast and I am beyond happy. The price was right, and the increase in performance has been awesome. Be warned that it is a pretty long card. Make sure you have room in your case for it.

Using EVGA Precision X, I have been able to get this card to run stable at about 2075+/- MHz on CPU clock and 4330 MHz+/- on Mem clock. That is +100 to CPU and +250 to MEM for those interested. That is with Power Target set to 110% and Temp Target set to 90deg. I suggest turning on fan control and setting the fan curve to Aggressive if you plan on doing this. If the card gets too hot, it will start crashing out of games, and you could damage it. Make these changes at your own risk and risk of voiding your warranty.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: The 1440p Sweet Spot card for gaming
column8:
I knew that when I was shopping for a GTX 1070 card that I wanted EVGA for a very simple reason - I've heard many legendary stories about their US-based customer support.  Another reason I gravitated to EVGA was the aesthetic of the card - the FTW and FTW2 cards have the full RGB lighting on the side with the fans plus the logo lights up - this is a plus for me.

I installed the card in my system without a hitch and it runs perfectly.  This card is a BEAST and will handle gaming at 1440p with little to no issues whatsoever, depending on what game you are playing - the ones I've tested so far have no issues.  Running the card while gaming and monitoring with MSI Afterburner, the temperatures stayed within good limits, so you won't have to worry about any thermal issues.  If you have any worries, the Precision XOC software you can download from EVGA offers options for your card, like controlling fan speed, overclocking, and customizing the LED color on the card.

I know there are cheaper 1070 cards out right now, but I wanted the latest offering from EVGA, and honestly, I am not disappointed one bit.  I may buy another one to run SLI, or maybe upgrade to the GTX 1080ti FTW3 when they come out someday, although that may be a while.  For now, I can say that this card for 1440p gaming rocks the pixels just fine.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Does the 1070FE card experience micro stuttering?
column8:
Hi, can anyone with the 1070FE card let me know if they are experiencing micro stutters with this card in the comments section on the review.

(also applies to the 1070)
Since I can post links in a review, you can find 75 pages worth of this issue on the nvidia geforce board by searching: gtx-1080-high-dpc-latency-and-stuttering/1/

I currently have this: EVGA SuperClocked+ 02G-P4-2684-KR GeForce GTX 680 2GB and it's been ROCK SOLID for years (also have a 10 year warranty on it,) and just wanted to upgrade just for more ram (and better performance), as GTA V plays well on the GTX680, but I want the extended draw distance (2GB is very limiting), and wanted to skip Volta, so this would be a more affordable solution, skip 1080, skip Volta, and get the 3070/3080 when the 1070 becomes too under-powered for a 4K screen (currently using 1080P)

I bought the EVGA 1070FE a few days ago from Amazon and it's still sealed (it's a lot of work of setting all 4 monitors up with DP to HDMI connectors and annual cleaning of the machine, so I held off) and now after reading the stutter issues, I'm hesitant of trying it out since Amazon charges a 15% restock fee on opened PC parts.

It seems some amazon reviews also report stuttering, so if anyone can comment on this, I would greatly appreciate it.

Also, this is not an EVGA issue, but a Nvidia issue -- I just posted this here because I did buy the EVGA 1070FE from Amazon.

Thanks!

column7: Getting more powerful while taking less energy
column8:
I ordered four of these to all work in the same PC. I ordered a year ago and after putting them through the paces, I'm finally going to review them.

If you have no issues with a $640 (at least at the time I ordered them) video card, than I suggest you get this. You won't be sorry with it's 8 GB of DDR5 RAM. Now multiply that times four and you get so much power. I have my DELL 5K monitor hooked up to this PC and I can run Battle Field 1 on ultra at the 5K resolution at 94 FPS. Just make sure that you get a power supple that can feed these beasts. Four of any graphics card will test your PSU.

I think you have a video card that can support games for the next five years with this bad boy.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Tougher, Quieter, and Cooler Than My EVGA 970
column8: Bought this to replace my EVGA 970. The 970 used both 6-pin and 8-pin for power. This one just uses the 8-pin. If that is an obvious indication it uses less power, then that would explain why my case is noticeably cooler as well. I'm using a case that is literally as small as you can get while still using standard PC parts. I'll include a photo (970 is shown). Before while gaming the case would get HOT to the touch at the top/front (exhaust end). Now the case just gets warm after hours of gaming. I get more power, less heat and less noise. Yes it is even more quiet. Was all that worth $400 more when I already had a 970? It's debatable I guess, but my first reaction is YES.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Huge performance jump, even from a 970 to this.
column8: Card handles everything I throw at it.  paired with an i7-4790 and 16gb of DDR3-1600, makes my 970 look like intel hd graphics.  it's that big of a jump. options I wouldn't dare try to turn up/turn on before now run smooth and fine. somehow crysis on ultra at UHD doesnt keep 60fps (drops to 20-45 at times of action), but I think that's more of engine limitations than a fault against the card, like fallout 4's jumpy framerates in quite a few areas of the game when maxed out, but anything actually optimized and not kitbashed like fo4 or not updated since 2009 like crysis will run flawlessly. MGSV, Witcher 3, BF1, Shadow Warrior 2, etc.  You can max them out fine and do 1080 Full HD 60fps with a great amount of breathing room for high refresh rate/above FHD render scaling.  I bought this card late december 2016. EVGA serial check shows it has both the thermal pads and the updated VBIOS pre-installed.  I'm not sure if all cards do, some who bought even as late as january still recieved the earlier versions, but mine is good.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
1st) My biggest complaint point blank is that the Warranty expressly state's they can refuse an exchange for dust/debris/smoke and I personally got the EVGA GeForce 1070 SC because the black edition has NO backplate. Same thing I told EVGA, we don't game in clean rooms...don't sell a WHITE card and void Warranties for dust...seriously?

2nd) Amazon, although directly linked from their site, did not Honor the 'For Honor' game code (pun intended lol) and neither would EVGA. I honestly don't care much for either free game honestly, but I don't like getting yanked around by the chain over stupid BS either.

3rd) It's WHITE and dust void's the Warranty lol...sorry, still a little peeved about that one.

Pros:

Great Customer Service so far--will change this review if thing's change.

I was offered an iCX Upgrade immediately after purchase for $99 buck's. (read fan con's below lol)

NOTE: The iCX upgrade option was over as of writing this.

iCX Upgrade or not, 90 day Step-Up Program to get a better model (at a cost, of course...but nice regardless) is a pretty sweet deal.

In my I-7 6700K
MSI Gaming M7
32GB DDR4
Toshiba P300 7200rpm HDD (Yeah, I know...lol)
144Hz DAS (Dynamic Action Sync) LG Monitor

My never overclocked build kills modern console's easily..

Cons:

Precision XOC crashes almost every boot (likely fighting MSI Command Center for control) so I can't say if it's common or not.

Had to run DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) and even after that, my less graphical HDD (VS 10) has blue dots I never seen before loading Win 7.

At default fan speed (with Precision X) it make's a squealing noise, was givin suggestions to losen screw's AND even offered a replacement on spot. Guess that's a Con and a Pro really.

You have to pay up-front for 'Army' (get your card before returning defect's) within 90 days, and the iCX has no option for it even if you did. BS

I want to lose the squeal and it's pay $100 for ship first, or pay $100 for a new cooling system, and it's STILL white haha. WTF EVGA?

All in all if you don't mind the horrible color or the even worse warranty deal about it, it run's everything I throw at it at 1080p 144Hz. Lost a star for the idiot who gave a white card that kind of warranty...and for the pay first to ship first where a dusty white card may get rejected ANYWAYS and you lose the money flat out. Other than that, it's actually a really good card.

No major complaint's, so far at least. The customer service does make up for most of the minor issues and hopefully will be considerate if the card does happen to get a bit dirty. Time will tell.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Get 'blower' or 'hydro' versions if you're going to install multiple units.
column8:
I'd recommend the 'blower version' or the hydro version if you plan on installing multiple units into a system. When installed side-by-side, these fans expel the waste heat back into the interior of the case and the fans of the unit next to it suck that waste heat back in.

The blower versions vent the wast heat to the exterior of the case. The Hydro versions run much cooler.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: The best bang for the buck
column8: The 1070 is the best bang-for-your-buck video card in the GeForce upper-tier of graphics cards.  Sure, the 1080 (and upcoming 1080Ti) are faster, but they also cost far more.  In fact, if you break down frames-per-second per dollar spent, those higher-end cards are a terrible value.  The 1060 is also a great card, but has limitations.  I purchased the 1070 and have been very happy with it (this is my 4th eVGA card, never had an issue).  It's powerful enough to run anything I throw at it, but was 60% cheaper than a 1080 when I purchased it.  I use it to run Steam VR and my HTC Vive, and I've never had any frame rate issues.  I also play a variety of games (FPS, MMORPG, Racing) on max settings (1080p) with 60+FPS with no problem.  Gaming at 1440p is also quite smooth, though for 4K you'd need a beefier setup.  Video card upgrades are one of the easiest and most effective ways to upgrade your PC, and this card is a worthwhile contender.

column8:
I don't get anything out of writing this except maybe to vent. My computer shut off, didn't know what it was. I initially thought it was the psu. I quickly found out that it was not (gold rated psu 600w). I removed the ftw and it was able to turn back on. I put the ftw back in just to confirm and upon booting i saw a quick spark and small puff of smoke and the remnants of an electrical fire. Yeah, i'm pissed. Amazon is as great as always, still doesn't take back the frustration and time wasted.

I don't know about you, but when I buy a product I want it to work. At least for a year. The price is already justified in these products so why go through the extra hassel of rma, contacting support for thermal pads (i did this after the fact), reading EVGA rep responses on forums doing their best to denounce these issues. Yes there are internet trolls, but normal guys like me who just want it to work don't have time for all that trolling bs.

Now you're coming out with updated products, ftw2 sc2, for what? Are you serious? You should've gotten it right the first time.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Solid GPU; stays very cool under load!
column8:
I was skeptical about spending the money but I am so glad I did! I upgraded from a Radeon R9 200 which isn't a bum (except for the software/drivers) I've had an 860M in my gaming laptop and it's still going strong 2 yrs later.

I ran this GPU under Passmarks bench tool and it scored in the 99th percentile. Now I take that with a grain of salt but given it had absolutely no issues with the 3D DirectX 12 test I can't complain.

I play Final Fantasy 14 and constantly had issues with the R9. Artifacting, freezing and crashing in the normal AFK zones like Idyllshire. I couldn't go from the aetheryte to the vendor without a freeze. I had my graphics set to basic and FPS at 30. Still crashed.

I did nothing else but swap out the GPUs and now I'm on max settings and I've limited it to 60 FPS. The card stays a cool 45c under load and no more freeze ups or crashes. I run two clients on max setting at the same time and have yet to feel any stress from this card.

I absolutely love NVidia hardware; I could never go back to Radeon. I've had nothing but issues with AMD the last 4-5 yrs and some longer. If you want a hard that stays cool and performs as expected, get this.

You will need a full tower. I have the Raidmax Augusta case and it fits perfectly. Because I'm water cooling the CPU I chose to modify the front of the case and place my graphics card cooler there. No problems whatsoever.

My setup:
i7 4790K
GTX 1070 FTW
Corsair 32 GB ram DDR3 2133
Samsung 850 Evo
ASRock Z97 Extreme
Corsair 1300 watt Platinum PSU
Corsair H110 CPU cooler
Basic Samsung Blu-Ray Drive
Toshiba HD-DVD drive

I will update this review if I find any negativity and/or if it performs solid for a few months.

Last thought: cooler and lines feel solid. I just can't believe how impressed I am from the get go.

Update: 3/13/2017 - card has been fantastic! I built a new PC with an Intel i7700k and DDR4 @3300 MHz ram. I bought a second card to go in the new build and my temps never reach above 55c. At idle they're around 22c. Love the built in water cooling and the Precision X software made changing the LEDs easy. See my newest photo!

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Comparing 1070 SC with GTX 1080, GTX 770, and 9800GT (!!)
column8:
I have an i5-2500k @ 4.5ghz (can't bear to part with it), DDR3 @ 1866 16GB, dedicated SSD for games. Rather that focus only on this card, I'd like to give potential buyers some perspective by sharing my unique experience of comparing three different GPUs over the course of one month. I started with a GTX 770, then bought this GTX 1070 SC, then very recently upgraded to 1080 SC (all EVGA).

1. GTX 770: I had great framerates (~50-60) in BF1 on med-high, similar on Witcher3 on high and no hairworks. Tomb Raider 2013, 60+ no tressfx. In short, a very happy gaming experience but just no extra-fancy bells & whistles. I had an ASUS 1ms 60hz 1080p monitor at this time.

2. I gave away 770 to a deserving student of mine (I'm a high school teacher) and bought a 1070 SC as well as an ROG swift 144hz GSYNC 1080p monitor. BF1, ultra @ 70-85fps, W3 65-80 w/ hairworks, R6:Siege 80-95fps on ultra. GSYNC on all. A extremely satisfying experience, to be sure. BUT - it's worth noting that I really didn't see/feel much of a difference between my experience on the 770 and on the 1070. Other than slightly smoother minimum rates, I never really noticed all the extras that much. Yeah, if I looked I could see them, but do you really count how many rocks there are on a patch of ground as you run past it? I'd say that I got about a 25% increase in satisfaction over the 770. No coil whine, either.

3. Well, I gave that 1070 away to another (really!) deserving student and got myself a 1080 SC for my birthday. BF1 @ 95-130, W3 75-95, R6:Siege @ 120-140. I actually didn't expect such a jump in numbers, I'd thought it'd be minimal since my CPU stayed the same. But you could definitely feel the difference in minimum frame rates compared to the 1070, and having the games run close to my refresh rate probably was noticeable too. I'd say the increase in satisfaction over the 1070 was about another 20%. Yeah, statistics from Duenor's school of analysis. If it wasn't for a coil whine problem, I'd be supremely happy since I had expected hardly any difference. Oddly everyone says that BF1 is CPU dependent but in my experience it was W3 that had the least improvement over the 1070. BF1 I could definitely feel it being smoother. Yeah I know people will try to tell me that I'm wrong, it's all in my head, only fighter pilots can tell the diff between 60fps and 144fps let alone 85 and 130, but that's how I feel and I'm sticking to it.

Anyway, I'm totally happy with the EVGA treatment of the 1070 and 1080 SC (non black edition, I like my backplates) in build & performance. Right now as I'm going through RMA for the 1080 I'm using an EVGA 9800GT from 2008(?). You know what? I'm pretty happy with it, too! I'm playing Enslaved: Oddyssey with a great FPS, playing South Park, playing Ori:Blind Forest. I might play CS:GO in a little bit and I bet it'll run great, too. UserBenchmark says my gaming rig is now a "Surfboard", which is one step above "Tree Trunk", haha. But I'm getting plenty of enjoyment out of this, too. So the moral of all this is that I don't think one should look too much at numbers. If you're happy with your card, that's all that matters. If you're not, it's hard to go wrong with either the 1070 or 1080 - and I can definitively say that the 1080 is noticeably better than the 1070, even on the humble 1080p that I prefer.

column7: Holy crap. Two of these in sli
column8: Holy crap. Two of these in sli. Its bottlenecking the crap out if my cpu (i5 3570k) but managed a 17,151 firestrike score. These things get hot like they radiate so much heat its like a large capacity space heater. Placing two of these in a case is lunacy, but i never said i was sane. Fits in a corsair carbide 540 just fine. Fitted an msi gpu bolster in there to keep everything on the level. Works fantastic. Hottest theve gotten is 54 degrees C. Which isn't bad at all. The fans push a decent amount of air thru the radiator, though im considering getting higher static pressure and flowing fans to upgrade to. They are super quiet on max fans in precision software, it makes virtually no sound difference, they're low rpm fans going from 1200rpm to just over 2000. The cards themselves are beautiful, like fine art beautiful the lines and the metal on the backplate and fan cover are amazing in person. Pictures do no justice. Gaming im getting around 90 to 160 fps in elite dangerous maxxed out with supersampling to 2.0 dropped to lowest of just under 70 where my dual 970s would drop to 40 and stay under 60 in alot of cases (on an AOC 35" 2560x1080 21:9 160hz monitor), haven't tested much else yet. Fantastic buy and would do it again. Highly recomended

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8: As soon as I received it I had to order a mod kit for it as it has a recall for overheating. the company has already shipped the kit but considering it is brand new and the issue has been known of for over a month it should not need to be fixed by the customers. All EVGA 1070s and 1080s using ACX 3.0 cooler have this issue and also need a bios update which the master bios is easily repaired but the slave bios is a bit trickier. For the slave bios update boot the pc with master bios and then flip the bios switch to slave and update the bios then switch back to master and reboot. I am a system builder so it was easy for me to figure this out but a novice might easily brick the card. This is where EVGA does stand out above other companys. If you tear up the card with mod kit or bios EVGA will replace your card.

column7: Awesome Card, AND 24/7 lLive Customer Support
column8: My husband researched this one for me for use with Photoshop.  The deciding factor was the quality of the card and the reputation of EGVA customer service. This card is paired with a Dell UltraSharp 34" curved monitor and the results are spectacular. Two days after it was installed, my computer "lost" it during a Nvidia  driver upgrade. My husband called EGVA 24/7 live customer support and spoke to an American representative within 5 minutes. He knew exactly what to do, our problem was fixed quickly, and the rep told us how to keep this sort of problem from re-occurring in the future when Windows decides to update a driver.. Since then, the card has worked flawlessly. It manages 300 - 400 MB graphic files as easily and fast as it does an email.

The only semi con is that I get coil noise with this card. I don't dock the card, apparently this is a power supply issue (from what I've read on the forums), so my usually quiet machine gets a little rowdy when I first start up a game. Not a biggie to me, just a note.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
I received this for Christmas from my wife. I was running an EVGA GTX 950. With that I couldn't set any current games to ultra and get a playable frame rate (intel i7-4790K 4ghz, 8 gig ram, Asus 144hz gaming monitor, Coolermaster HAF X case). I could play games on high and some ultra settings and get 30 to 50 frames per second. Here's a list of some of those games for reference:

Skyrim Special Edition (heavily modded)
Far Cry 4
The Witcher 3
Dragon Age Inquisition
Dying Light

Now... same computer, but with this card... I am playing all of those games (and more) set to Ultra settings on all features, and I'm getting 50 to 100+ frames per second. I'm even playing The Witcher 3 with everything including "hairworks" set as high as possible. It's amazing.

I'm not interested in 4K gaming right now. I run 1080p... so I see no need for a GTX 1080. The 1070 is a sweet spot for me. My games have never run better and I'm having a blast.

It's not running hot (it's a newer one) and it's quiet. I love the look. I have been using EVGA cards for many years now, and I continue to be very happy with every one I buy!

Great Card.

column7: Amazing card, but AMD CPU OWNERS BEWARE!
column8:
Great graphics card. One little word of advice to anyone who is looking for a new graphics card and is currently running an AMD CPU, DO NOT UPGRADE TO THIS CARD. You are gonna want to upgrade your processor, motherboard, and ram if you are gonna want to be able to support this graphics cards' horsepower. I run an AMD FX-8320 and I only get 45-50 fps on max settings in some games that would usually hit 60 easily according to benchmarks online. I made the mistake of not upgrading my CPU first so now my games are bottlenecking. My old graphics card (GTX 770) was a good card, but the 2GB of ram was not enough for the types of games I played, so I thought it would be a good idea to upgrade in 2016.

Anyway, if you have the right rig, go for this card. It is defiantly worth it over the GTX 1080 in my opinion.

column7: [1070 FTW Edition] Great performance with the cost of coil whine.
column8: I love the aesthetic and amount of performance this card has to offer, but the card I purchased in specific suffers from coil whine unfortunately. Performance wise, this card will give you greater than 60 FPS on many of the current flagship games like DOOM, Fallout 4, GTA 5, etc. on High - Ultra settings in 1080p. Furthermore, the aesthetic this card shows off it great. It offers RGB for its entire LED array, which allows it to stand out or blend in with your theme of choice. Other than the coil whine (which is disappointing), I'm pleased with this card overall, and I'd recommend it anyone who wants an RGB card with great performance. In the event you plan on purchasing it, know there is a chance you may get a card with coil whine, and it's fairly prominent with EVGA FTW 1070 cards. If you have loud case/CPU cooler fans though, I wouldn't worry about coil whine.

column7: doesn't fit in Dell precision T3500 case - but still great card!
column8: Excellent card.  Purchased in brick and mortar store for same price as Amazon, but wanted to leave this review.  The profile of this card is larger that the GTX 970 I replaced and so ran into case issues.  I have my rig built into a Dell Precision T3500 case and the drive tray folds down.  The 1070 is longer than the 970 and the power supply cable for the 1070 is located underneath the drive tray in such a way that I can't fully close the drive tray.  Not that big a deal, but not a clean install.  I'll need to move the rig to another case if I want it to be clean and pretty.  For now it's functional.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: EVGA is having a bad year.
column8:
The Nvidia made parts are great. Solid performance and a huge upgrade from 700 series like I had been using. EVGA's parts on the other hand are terrible. With any of the ACX cards you either pick poor thermal performance, or deal with extra noise (both electrical and fan) by adding the thermal updates. It's a shame considering EVGA's past of having the best and longest warranty. Now the warranty is much shorter, and it really shows in their design and build quality.

I opted for better thermals without knowing the electrical noise could happen. My guess is the thermal pad placement is causing it, but EVGA can't fix it for everyone without a full recall. Maybe they'll extend everyones warranties for free like last time a similar situation happened.

Currently, I'm suck in an RMA loop with EVGA.
RMA 1 which swapped a pre-thermal problems card for a card with the updated VBIOS and thermal pads.
RMA 2 swapped the thermal pad and vbios updated card from RMA 1 due to a loud clicking noise that exceeded the noise level of the fans as fast as I've seen them go (about 30-40%)
RMA 3, if approved, will be the same as RMA 2 since the new card has an identical, though slightly quieter noise issue.

Luckily the RMA's have been with the advanced RMA system with cross-shipping, but I'm sure EVGA will stop doing that if more RMAs are needed. It's just not viable for them, or really for me either. After enough RMA's the cost quickly approaches the difference in price between the 1070 I bought and a 1080 without the issue. Without some sort of consumer protection laws though, EVGA can get away with leaving customers with cards with shoddy solutions to serious design flaws that are capable of severe damage (and not just to the cards).

I really hope EVGA will work on redeeming themselves after this. Sorting out these issues out for everyone is a must. If it is a case of the extra pads causing this sort of noise, then EVGA should find a better solution. If they can't, then offer refunds or a modified trade up program to cards without the issue (ie designed for proper thermals instead of modded for proper thermals).

Such a large drop in consistently and quality from EVGA is out of character when remembering their past. It's very close to, or already at, the point where me and many others are no longer considering EVGA, and rightfully so. These sorts of components aren't cheap, and no one in the market is happy to buy ones that may blow circuits or catch fire. The current issue also hugely effects resell on these cards, which used to be an area EVGA cards were strong in.

column7: great for gaming but has one issue...
column8: This card works great for gaming (playing the Witcher3 maxed out in 1080 with flawlessly smooth framerates). BUT there is one very annoying issue.  This card has a DVI, HDMI and 2 display ports out of which I'm only using the HDMI port.  for some reason on boot up this card ALWAYS picks the DVI port first even though there's nothing plugged into it!  so my screen is completely blank until windows comes up.  I cant see bios, I cant see the bootup progress etc.  if anything goes wrong during bootup I have to get a DVI monitor out of my closet, pull the computer out, hook it up and see why. SUPER annoying.  sometimes my computer is just installing updates or running checkdisk or maybe it didn't shut down right so I just have to hit a key to continue but you cant see anything to know that! then after hooking that all up just to push a button to continue I put it all back away.  ARG..  I'm running the latest bios for my MB and latest driver as well.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: EVGA GTX 1070 FTW = Outstanding Graphics Performance
column8:
I have been doing research on purchasing a new video card since the GTX 1080 and GTX 1070 launched last Spring. I was quite frustrated with the lack of AMD Crossfire support for the R9 390X in Crimson software, and as of this writing, Team Red has nothing to offer at the "high end", although I know Vega is due out shortly. Since I recently purchased a new 32" 2560 X 1440 VA Panel Monitor (for all purpose, including some FPS Gaming), I needed some new Graphics Horsepower.

The GTX 1070 offerings are many, but I chose this particular Card due to the high quality of construction, EVGA Customer Service and Support, and I received a significant and stable overclock out of the box. The Marketing was not just hype, but the performance is truly there. With no adjustments, Nvidia Boost 3.0 has my Card running at 2012 Mhz in Game. I did apply a custom fan curve through MSI Afterburner, and my fans start up at 45 C. I never saw the temperature go above 65 degree C., and the fans are quiet. I am not getting any coil whine, and everything just works. My results at 2560 X 1440 in CRYSIS 3 and Metro Last Light are on Par with what the major reviews have already benchmarked for this Particular GTX 1070 FTW Card. I also like the 10 phase power, and the larger fans over the SC version. I have not Overclocked any further than the out of box settings thus far, but since I already have a significant overclock, I am not strongly compelled to test this further to obtain very small FPS gains. I would rather just move up to a GTX 1080 for that.

I can't comment on the EVGA Precision XOC Program, as I am not using it. I will stick with MSI Afterburner for now. While I think the idea of RGB lighting is pretty cool on the Card, I am personally satisfied with the pale blue color of the default LED color, and I am more satisfied that I do not have to run Precision XOC software just to fiddle with the RGB lighting. I am also staying away from the Nvidia Experience Software. I just do not need it.

I would like to add that I purchased this card, well aware that there have been some expressed concerns about the VRM cooling. As VRMs do run hot, (VGA Card, Motherboard), I do believe that cooling is important. I did go ahead and order the free thermal pad kit available from EVGA, and I will go ahead and install them. EVGA is also offering a BIOS update to address and remediate these concerns. I am pretty comfortable tearing down my PC equipment, and I build my own custom computers. I really like EVGA's approach to this concern, and it is one more reason why I am buying this particular video card from EVGA.

So, for me, it is EVGA FOR THE WIN.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Great card and great product support from EVGA
column8:
This review is for the EVGA GTX 1070 FTW ACX 3.0

You can get any 1070 and they will perform about the same.  Here's why you should still pick an EVGA card.  They support their products even if they make a mistake.

Problems and mistakes can and do happen to anyone, even the best of us.  Great customer service is put to the test when problems arise.  I have always gotten great service and product support from EVGA which is why I will keep using them again in the future.

If you don't know what I'm talking about... cards shipped from EVGA before Nov 1st will need a BIOS update to address an overheating problem in the VRM.  Cards shipped after this date are fixed so do not let the "VRM overheating issue" scare you away from buying an EVGA card.

I bought one of these affected cards so I can speak for the level of support EVGA has gone above and beyond in my opinion to support this card.  Many graphics card vendors have terrible support and if something like this were to happen in manufacturing you would be stuck with a dud.  Luckily I picked this model and they were able to make everything right.

They fixed the issue reasonably quickly with a BIOS update and furthermore offered affected customers free thermal pads if they wanted to mod the card to fix the issue.  EVGA offered to do both of these for me if I shipped my card back to them, but I elected to do it myself.  I performed both the BIOS update and the thermal pad mods.  The BIOS update was simple and the thermal pad mod was only slightly more difficult than installing a CPU cooler.

Apart from EVGA's service here's my thoughts on the card itself:

Just tweaking a few settings without spending too much time on it I was able to overclock to about 2100mhz so I feel pretty comfortable with the "silicon lottery" on my specific card.  The RGB lighting is a nice touch.  It's not too obnoxious looking, but the lighting is on the bottom of the card on a standard ATX install.  The backplate at the top of the card looks really nice and adds a polished touch.

The fans are quiet, even with the BIOS update I did not notice any difference in the fan noise.  You can hear them when they are at their max, but I wouldn't call them loud.  The Precision X software for overclocking is pretty easy to use.  It was difficult to figure out how to change the RGB settings but you can do it two ways: through Precision X or by downloading a separate (hard to find) app from Nvidia called the "led visualizer" which was for some reason taken out of the most recent version of GeForce experience.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: EVGA always knows what they're doing.
column8:
Well made GPU.

UPDATE: Those who have heard about the overheating GPU's with the ACX 3.0 on the 1070FTW as well as the 1080FTW know that NOT ALL THE CARDS will have the issue. My card has run at a stead 70C while running BF1 on Ultra settings for over 3 hours. I got in contact with NVidia and they told me they would send me the Thermal Pads free of charge to fix the issue or I could RMA it as well if I ever had any issues.

Anyways;

I recently picked up this card to replace my GTX970 SC as I thought it was time to upgrade to something that would allow me to run 4K at a decent FPS although I don't have a 4K monitor... yet.

The card itself is awesome, right out of the box, EVGA has the core notched up from 1,506MHz to 1,607MHz, while boost frequency is raised from 1,683MHz to 1,797MHz. The card while playing on BF1 rarely went above 600RPM's on the fans maybe because the H440's fan setups is allowing for optimal airflow which keeps the card cool while gaming on ultra settings.

The card itself is designed amazing as always by EVGA's standards and it just simply put amazing in any case that you can see the "blind" on the inside. The software provided by EVGA allows you to mess with the card (I don't suggest anyone OC'ing the card if you're new to over clocking although they do have a warranty which they always stand behind) settings such as the fan speeds, over clocking and even the RGB colors (Only on the FTW editions can you change the RGB on the card, most other cards are standard white)

All in all a solid build, runs amazing FPS on almost any game. GTAV ran a solid 60fps with no issues what soever while I rarely had a drop of below 90fps.

column7: Card works great when it doesn't crash my computer. EVGA customer service isn't much help
column8:
I bought this card to replace an older GTX660.  Shortly after installing this card, I started getting blue screen errors.  I did some research online and found the DDU program to remove old drivers - so I ran that twice - once to remove and the second time to verify.  Then I reinstalled the new drivers from the evga website.  Continued to get blue screen errors every other day or so - and the code indicated it was due to video hardware.

I submitted a support request to evga - I chose evga because I'd heard what great customer service they had.  The first tech said it could be hardware or software, and he suggested I run DDU to remove old drivers.  I replied to the ticket, saying that I'd already run DDU twice.  Three days later a different person replied with "Thank you for the reply, yes please try to used that software again, it does help with clearing the older drivers or some files that was left over. But if the same issue occurs, try to replace or put the video card onto another system to see if same issue occur or not."

If I had another computer system sitting around, maybe I wouldn't be as concerned about buying a faulty video card.  So much for EVGA's "awesome customer service."  I'm glad others have better experiences with them, but I won't be buying anymore of their products.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
I received the EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 SC GAMING ACX 3.0 Black Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) 08G-P4-5173-KR and spent 4 hours that evening trying to get it to work. I've built a few custom gaming computers in the past, so I'm not a novice at this, and I could not get the computer to recognize the card was there.  I tried moving it to another PCI-e slot, using different power supply cables, with the 6pin-8pin adapter supplied with the unit and without, updated the BIOS and motherboard drivers.  Nothing worked.  I deleted the old card (an EVGA GTX 670 FTW) and manually loaded up the new card drivers.  Nothing.  Well, almost nothing...the only thing that works is the LED for the name on the side of the card...no fans.  The computer recognizes there is something there and I get the BIOS welcome screen, but that is it.  The computer would get to the BIOS welcome screen and freeze there.  When I put my old card back in, even with the drivers deleted, the computer booted right up, found the right drivers, and the card worked flawlessly.

My conclusion is I got a bad card.  This is not the first time I've gotten DOA parts, but it is the first time from EVGA.  Reading some of the horror stories about the EVGA GTX 1070 cards overheating and even smoking, this may be for the best.  Thankfully it's DOA instead of working for a few months before dying resulting in me having to RMA it...what a hassle that is.  I'm just returning it for a refund, and will look to see what other options are out there in the GTX 1070 range.
