column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
Well... it is a great vid card. I use it to play Battlefield titles mostly. So since BF1 is a new game there are inherent problems in the game itself and I am trying to differentiate those from the card.

I have a very solid system Corsair 16gb ram, i7K processor, Samsung 500gb ssd, and a Corsair 850watt PS. My previous card was/is an EVGA GTX 780.

All temps are really low (EVO cpu cooler) - none of my hardware temps ever go above 45C - 48C. No overclocking on the vid card. CPU is overclocked to about 4.7 (had it over 5.1 though) - so good hardware.

I know that some people are having issues with heat.

However, I am not one of them. Under full load and stress testing, my unit NEVER goes over 48C (even after hours of playing BF1 on Ultra settings, 144Hz, about 85 to 110 fps). Currently I have on K Boost (have been leaving it on continuosly) and I am at 30C with 34% fan speed.

BTW my card has the dual BIOS and I flashed a BIOS update 4 days ago, it was super easy being done in Windows, and I have had no issues.

Another BTW, DX12 causes issues in some games - this is not the cards problem, it is a game code issue that is the problem, just use DX11 like I do in BF1 and all is good. I can't tell any difference any way.

I am writing this because I am concerned about future issues with the card. I can't afford to dump $400 bucks on a vid card that is going to break.

I don't really want to pay for the Extended Warranty/Enhanced cross shipping but maybe I will.

The only issues I have had is with nVidia GeForce experience and with a couple of aspects of the EVGA software.

nVidia software always causes shutdown issues (memory reference errors). I have only installed exactly the drivers I need which is the vid driver itself and the Physx software (custom install -> clean install). I think the nVidia Experience is buggy as heck, but it is ultra convenient to capture in-game video. But... if anyone has another solution, let me know.

EDIT: Seems like EVGA and nVidia have taken care of these problems since the last updates - do clean installs on all the software.

With the EVGA software I don't like the way the options are laid out for the lights - I can get the 2 demos to run, I can get the solid light, but not the breathing, etc (i should just work shouldn't it). Also it is REALLY irritating that I can't find more skins for the software AND it would be awesome to have some kind of instruction manual for overclocking. I can't even seem to find a video  on how to use the software to overclock.

I have had many EVGA cards and in the past I have had no issues teaching myself how to use the software.

Come EVGA gives us a tutorial and some nice skins. I know you like to make it look cool, but having everything so buried and hidden is NOT cool it is insipid.

Any way, I hope the card lasts, the video drivers will mature for the new games, but I too have had a video card go up in flames MANY years ago and it fried my motherboard also. So... if there is a real issue with this and the problems are not related to unskilled builders and cheap equipment, then not only are your risking a hassle with a vid card return, but if that PCI lane fries you are replacing a mobo also AND maybe other system components.

What say ye EVGA?

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Doesnt come included with wires to install it, finding proper wires seperately is a huge pain and expensive
column8:
Didn't include the correct wiring to connect the card to a power supply unit.  I know, they want you to buy a new PSU every card upgrade, but my psu is well over spec, but still 6 years old.  I'm not sure how they can just toss in a couple of extenders, which didn't fit.

I ordered the exact wires to install the card to my psu at an additional cost of about $25, which had a small bridge in the 8 pin to gurantee it cant fit my psu.

I actually might return the card just because I cant install it.

Maybe its a sign to wait on upgrades until I can do my whole system and have a new psu with all the connectors ready to go.

Be warned, if you are going from an old 6 pin x2 connected GPU and upgrading for this, and you don't have a full set of PSU modular cords...you won't be installing this card.

Will hunt around for more wires, though its starting to get rather expensive to get this card installed....why the fck couldn't they just provide two cords to connect it to a modular PSU?  Such a small thing that is turning into a massive pain in the ass for me....to the point where I'm about to just return the card and wait for a full build....never had this issue before typically I can either reuse the cords from the old card or something is provided to connect.  The tiny 8 pin to 2 6 pin splitters are far too short and occupy way too many 6 pin slots (4 total)

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8: This is a BEAUTIFUL 1070. Unfortunately, it has a design flaw--the cooler does not directly cool the VRAM/VRM. That area of the card has been shown to hit temperatures of about 100 degrees Celsius under extreme loads at factor clock speeds(Furmark benchmark). EVGA is giving away thermal strips that you can apply yourself to the problem area but these only reduce the temps to the 80s. The worst part is that the card's temperature sensor will only tell you the temp of the gpu's main core so you will have no idea if the hotspot is in the danger zone. Anyone considering this card with it's extra powerphases and binned chip should definitely be hesitant given these troublesome temps are recorded at factory clocks. The cooler should really be redesigned but it's unlikely that the redesign would be given away for free. That I why I personally decided to return this. Oh, and I also had one of these literally start on fire. I didn't know about the design flaw at the time and thought it was just a lemon. Who knows, maybe it still was but I don't want anymore fires in my computer.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Arguably overpriced, still an amazing card
column8:
Although this card is arguably overpriced (with the MSRP of the reference GTX 1070 sitting at $379) it's still an amazing card.  The ACX cooling keeps it nice and cool and it has the build quality I'd expect from EVGA.
The 2x8-pin connectors are probably overkill but I've still gotten some decent overclocking out of this card. The biggest issue I've had is that EVGA switched to Micron memory for the second wave of these and as a result you can't overclock the memory anywhere near as well as you could with the old Samsung memory. There's supposedly a BIOS update coming soon to help address this issue.

Amazon/Nvidia/EVGA all sort of want to bounce the blame around which makes it even more difficult for a customer in this modern age of "customer support."  EVGA support has been most helpful so far and I hope to get this issue resolved wherein I can update this review, because the card is great.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
The 1070 is an awesome card for the money. For most people, the 1080 is overkill and the 1060 might not be enough, but the 1070 sits in the middle at a great price point. It can easily handle games at high settings at 2160x1440. I have tested this with Overwatch, Hitman, Mankind Divided, and Rise of the Tomb Raider.

Test bench specs:
i7 6700k @ 4.5GHz
16GB DDR4 @ 3000Mhz
Gigabyte Z170N-Gaming 5

Overwatch - 144 FPS
Hitman - 71 FPS
Deus Ex - 49 FPS
Tomb Raider - 77 FPS

All tests were done on stock speeds with AA turned off. The only one that stands out is Deus Ex, which is the newest of these games. I think the card might benefit from newer drivers, but it is a very demanding game. I'm currently using this card in my mini-ITX gaming/streaming machine, which doesn't require anything crazy. On idle, it hovers around 30C, and during gaming loads, stays in the mid 70s. This is using the default fan curve. This is a great card at the mid $400 price point, and since there aren't really other choices at the moment, your decision is made for you. Pascal is a great architecture, and it shows which each 10-series card.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: GIGABYTE SUCKS. EVGA and this 1070, however, are awesome.
column8:
My last card - a Gigabyte R9 390X - died from a cracked core due to the extreme heat it was producing and I assume a defect in the stock heatsink. GIGABYTE, upon receiving my card, was nice enough to void my warranty without reason and refuse to provide any support for their product.

But on to this EVGA GTX 1070. I had decided that for this build I was going Radeon since my monitors are FreeSync and I've had good experiences in the past, but the ordeal with GIGABYTE and the uninspiring performance of the RX480 convinced me to return to Nvidia.

So far I have been pleasantly surprised. This 1070 runs exceptionally cool and quiet, and while I'm not the type who wants my PC to drill rainbows into my eyes, the lighting and effects are clean, subtle, and easily disabled.

All in all a great performing card that will only get better as drivers improve.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
I could not be happier with this graphics card. I upgraded from the gtx 950 and saw very noticeable improvements.

A few months ago I decided to build my own gaming PC with the help of a friend. Here are my specs:

Introducing GLaDos to all my geek friends out there!

Intel Core i7-5820K Haswell-E 6
ASRock Fatal1ty motherboard
Ripjaws 32GB DDR4 ram
480 GB SSD
4 TB HHD
Noctua NH-D15 6 heatpipe CPU Cooler
9 cooling fans (5 radial, 2 Graphics, 2 CPU)
Thermaltake VERSA N21 Snow Edition Case
EVGA 850 GS 80+ GOLD power supply

With all of that and the 1070, I am getting 60 and over frames per second and near ultra setting for most games including witcher 3, GTAV, and my MMO of choice Elder Scrolls Online. For the price, this card blows other out of the water. I have run some performance benchmarks with very good results. Will it be as good as running a 1080, I think only slightly less. Do you need multiple 1070 cards in your build? Not unless you want to be ridiculous. This card will beat any console out there and keep you gaming in top spec for a long time.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
Have had this card for a few weeks and it's working perfectly. Even under load it's quieter than the old GTX 660 was at idle, so very impressed by the thermal management. Have not tried overclocking it beyond how it comes out of the box.

It's a big full-length card so be sure you have room for it if you're upgrading from something smaller.

The 8-pin power jack had a molding problem that prevented inserting the power plug all the way, but I was able to nibble away a bit of the jack and get it to latch properly after finally figuring out what the problem was after a half-hour of trauma. Hopefully not an issue that will be common.

Very happy with it so far.

G.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8:
Switched over from a 960, entirely worth it!
I won't bore you with the details that everybody else will throw in your face, but here's some tidbits I learned:
- Having 3 monitors connected raised the gpu clock from 240 to just below 1000. Idle temps rose about 3-5C for me. I'm told it's due to different refresh rates of monitors, however disconnecting one of the monitors (60hz) and leaving two connected (60hz and 144hz) allowed the GPU clock to go back to 240.
- Custom fan curves only seem to work when EVGA PrecisionXOC software is open. Don't set it to 100% unless you're interested in sitting beside a small jet.
- When installing the card, for your own sake remove the old graphics card drivers. Saves the headache of defaulting to integrated (where available, and where not available the screen should just be black) graphics or the card just refusing to output anything.

Hope this helps!

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: I was skeptical about the price at first since it ...
column8:
I was skeptical about the price at first since it was a bit intimidating. After purchasing it and waiting for the card for about a week, I installed the card and the first game I wanted to heavily test it on was Ark Survival Evolved and holy cow, I couldn't believe how immune the card was to such a demanding Alpha game. It didn't matter what I threw at the card, the performance is just so smooth and stable. I even bumped some games to 1440p and still locked at 60 if not higher! Ark was a different story since its Alpha and I don't have today's latest update due to my Internet temporarily disconnected. Ark was running at 40 to 50 fps on all Epic Settings.

Not to mention the LED Lights makes your PC look classy.

Was it worth the price? Yes. Yes it was.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: More than what I was expecting based on the listing details! Very happy.
column8:
This card is awesome. For comparison, I upgraded from a gigabyte 7950 so of course it performs better but the design & build quality is noticeably better. For example, there is a supportive back plate. My last card was visibly sagging and that caused issues with the fans.

Focusing on this card, it runs quietly (please note that this card only runs the fans when needed and they'll be off otherwise). When the fans are on (under a game load) they are super quiet. The card boost itself past specification (I understand this is part of GPU Boost 3.0). For me (stock, mind you) the card is running at just over 1900 MHz. It's rated to boost at 1797 MHz and run at 1607 MHz.  These values are already higher than a reference 1070 and yet it performs better than it's advertised values.

This card has a lot more features too - things I hope to take advantage of but haven't yet due to time.

In summary, the card is not just what I expected based on the listing but way more. Highly recommend if you're in the market for a 1070.  If you are in the market for a 1080, I'd suggest you look at the 1080 version of this card. I'm sure that is just as awesome.

column8:
I won't be buying another poorly made product made by EVGA with shady warranty practice and I'm hoping there's someone else out there feeling the same. I bought my GTX 580 from Amazon's Warehouse Deals that's supposed to have a limited lifetime on it back in 2012. Limited lifetime if I had registered 30 after I have purchased it. When I went to file a RMA, you handed my case to a stupid Chinese customer service. I'm Vietnamese and my case was handled by a Chinese? You can look up who he is by using this serial number 1210611584000327 of my GTX 580. A supervisor name Jaeson Wilda tried to smooth it over by making it into a charity case as a one time offer to send me a replacement card. Well, frak EVGA and his offer. Limited lifetime warranty shouldn't be this difficult. I have a receipt of the legal purchase. So now with this GTX 1070 you're trying to put one over to your customers again with a long list warranty individually for every card? https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81tcHmtlitS.pdf

Bye bye EVGA. My one time GTX 580 became my last time buying a EVGA product. I hope others will catch up to your deceptive practice and leave you before you file for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: A major step forward with the 16nm Process
column8:
Perfect. An incredible card that runs fast and incredibly cool. Nvidia knocked it out of the park. It overclocked automatically to around 2042 mhz, and dynamically allocates based on both temperature and processing power needed. You can push it farther, but I haven't found any reason to do that yet.

This card was capable even at 4k. Alien Isolation maxed out with no frame dips. Fallout 4 Maxed was around 40-60 frames. I typically game at 1440p and haven't come across a game that isn't max at that resolution with no sweat. Temperatures are at most high 60's C at all times. I don't think I've seen this get close to 70 C. Amazing how cool it is.

Now the question is, is the 1080 worth it over this card? The question you have to ask then is the 1080 has about 10-25 more frames per second compared to this card. However, when this card is running at 100+ frames at 1440p and can run some games at 4k maxed out and can overclock fairly well, you have to ask if its worth it. It might be for some people. It wasn't for me, 650+ is not worth it. You just have to decide for yourself.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: DO NOT BUY! A DEFECTIVE CARD CAUGHT FIRE AND RUINED MY MOTHERBOARD, POSSIBLY THE REST OF MY MACHINE
column8:
As the headline states, a defective card that I received caused a spark which started a small fire in my machine, ruining my motherboard and possibly also ruining every other component connected to the motherboard. I had initially tried plugging in the card in my brand new build, but the computer would not power on with the card installed (although it could without it installed and with another GPU installed). To troubleshoot the problem, I tried installing the card in another machine. That machine caught fire immediately upon turning it on.

I was immediately suspicious upon receiving the card, as the box had already been opened and the manuals, posters, stickers, etc. appeared to be bent up as if the card had been used or refurbished. Since the serial number checked out though, I went ahead and tried installing it. I thought that spending extra money on "reputable" hardware would protect me from hassles. Now I need a replacement card and I have to rebuild my other computer.

EDIT: I was issued a full refund by the seller, Amazon.com, LLC for the defective card. However, neither Amazon nor EVGA could help whatsoever with the costs that I had to put out for the replacement of the rest of the machine. I may have been sold a botched refurbished card as new, the card may have been damaged during shipment, or it could have simply been a rare defect. I will never know. You can read other reviews and make your own decision, but beware. I have since purchased an ASUS GTX 1070 STRIX and installed it with no complications on the original build.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: I would absolutely recommend this card to anyone pondering and this was a ...
column8:
This is a review of the EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Graphics Video Card (O8G-P4-6276-KR)
(Comes with the video graphics card, two dual 6 pin to one 8 pin power adapters, software disc, poster, case EVGA bage and manual.)

Summary  This is a replacement of my GTX 970 and speed difference as well as rendering is night and day different! I have yet to find anything that this cannot handle.  I would absolutely recommend this card to anyone pondering and this was a perfect install with no issues on my Windows 10 64 Bit O/S. I searched high and low and compared cards until my eyes hurt and this one truly is the best bargain. This is also higher specs than the Founders Edition if you were looking. Founders Edition has only one bios vs. 2 like this card has and this card is over 100mhz slower on clock. Nothing negative to report and this would be a great card to get your system current and give you many years until something else may be needed.

Features
-Can support resolutions up to 7680x4320 and has HDMI output, 3 Display Port outputs and a DVI Dual Link output.
-8192MB (8GB) GDDR5 Memory.
-1607mhz base clock. Boost is 1797mhz.
-Uses an efficient ACX 3.0 Cooler.
-Has adjustable ERGV Led. (Needs EVGA PrecisionX OC installed.) This is great as you can adjust the settings of the card and fan speed. Oh and the led lights look awesome of course.
-Max power consumption is 215watts. (Power phase is 10+2).
-Requires two 8 pin feeds.
-Has two bios vs. one.
-1920 Cuda Cores.
-Runs on PCI E 3.0 bus.
-2 Way SLI Capable with HB Bridge Support.
-Supports multiple displays, is VR ready, Nvidia Ansel, SLI capable with HB Bridge Support, Nvidia G-Sync, NVidia gamestream, GPU Boost 3.0, Direct X 12, Vulkan API and has open GL 4.5 support.
-Memory bandwidth is 256bitt at 8000mhz and 256.3 gb/s. (.24ns speed.)

Rig Specs Now After Update.
-Gigabyte GA-Z97X-UD5h-BK Black Edition motherboard.
-Intel Core i7 Devils Canyon 4GHZ LGA 1150 Processor.
-Corsair H80i Liquid Cooling.
-GeForce GTX 1070 8GB Video Card.
-Samsung Evo 850 250gb SSD main and Toshiba 3TB storage.
-LG Bluray M Disc Burner.
-Asus Bluray Burner.
-32GB Corsair DDR3 Memory. (8GB x 4) DDR3-1600  PC3 12800.
-Thermaltake Armor Full Metal Case.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: EVGA 1070 FTW... what's not to like?
column8:
There's such a different vibe in the air around these new graphic cards. The 10 series seems to have many folks in a frenzy to purchase before they're gone. I've watched prices go up/down and back/forth. Gives me whiplash to watch it all... yikes! Glad I can stop now that I got mine. I was holding out as long as I could to possibly get this GPU with a free game, but since the supply and demand effect is so evident it doesn't make sense. NVIDIA likely won't have a need to push sales with the demand around these cards.

I have owned the Superclocked version of the 1070 and now FTW edition. The SC edition came with White LED's with zero customization. The FTW edition uses RGB LED's and can be customized using the EVGA Precision software. You must have an account, although it be free, with EVGA to get this software and you must have the FTW card to use it. I will say the ability to customize the LED's is pretty slick. It adds absolutely nothing to the performance of the card as its pure cosmetics. That being said, watching your card look like it's breathing as you're playing a scary game is downright chill. The option to choose the LED's to light up with the beat of your audio/music is quite cool too.

The FTW edition does use dual 8-pin power connectors while the SC uses a single 8-pin. I can tell you the performance is not noticeably different after running both cards. The heat generated is identical, but the FTW has slightly higher frame rates (6-8 FPS) due to its slightly higher clock. Again, nothing you'll see by just gaming unless you've got an FPS counter up and running. I personally use FRAPS which tends to be the norm other than Shadowplay. If you're on the fence on which edition to purchase, just watch prices like I did. Got this bad boy for $439.99 which is what the SC card normally goes for. To get the FTW specs at the SC price... I'm down. :)

I purchased this card to get ready for the new BF1 Beta (Likely being released at the end of this month) and the official release in October. I've also played BF4, BO3, Squad, DayZ, ARK and ATS (American Truck Simulator... LOL). This card doesn't break a sweat at 1080p gaming. Everything on all games maxed to the hill. There are some early Alpha games that aren't optimized that well and the card still pulls incredible frames.

I personally believe all computer components are overpriced so if you can get a good deal on this card, it's a no brainer. I haven't heard much whining come from the card although others have mentioned this. Can't wait to see what this card will do with BF1. BF1 FTW! :)

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: The gpu is pretty great. It's a big upgrade from my GTX970 ...
column8:
EDIT*: After 2 months or so I've been getting much driver instability and issues using this gpu. After swapping out everything from operating systems, power supplies, memory, hard drives, cpu's, motherboards I'm still suffering with the same issue. Driver wipes help the issue temporarily. I disabled aspect scaling, set the gpu to prefer maximum performance in it's control panel, disabled nvidia shield and reduced the clock a little. Still no luck.

Some drivers work better than others though your mileage may vary. I will say that it worked spectacularly in the first month, however this seems to be an issue plaguing many other users. If I load into a game I can play endlessly but the real problems occur outside of windows. I updated the bios with no effect.

EVGA is a great brand no doubt but it appears that myself and others are having similar issues. Perhaps my unit was faulty although there's speculation over which manufacturer memory was used in its production. Hard artifacting, restarts, blue screens and freezing in windows are all due to an extremely high latency.

This being said, buy the card, if it treats you badly, return it. I'm not in the business of paying shipping to return it as I currently do not reside in the US.

END.

The gpu is pretty great. It's a big upgrade from my GTX970 which treated me well in the short time I had it.

I took a star off because there is some coil whine coming from the unit (which is apparently common). It isn't extremely noticeable but at this price point it really shouldn't have been present. The lighting looks great and even though it isn't RGB it goes with pretty much every theme. The lighting is adjustable eg. breathing, flashing, brightness etc.

If you have an i5 4690k/6600k or equivalent the gpu will be of use to you with minimal bottleneck in most cases. It may not be worth the upgrade if you play at 60fps with a 60hz monitor and already have a capable gpu (gtx 980 or higher). All in all it's a great gpu, the back plate looks amazing and the performance so far has been great. I'd recommend this to anyone who's in the market for a high end gpu or upgrading from a gtx 960 or 970 equivalent.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: UPDATE. Sold build and never buying EVGA again.
column8:
New edit: I never had any heat issues with the card. However, EVGA releasing so many versions and a trade in program to their icx version makes it pretty obvious that there is a serious problem that effects the majority. I would not recommend another EVGA card for that reason. Their customer service is awesome, but clearly their quality control is all kinds of tarded. Anyone who would buy these cards must like the odds of playing lottery. I ended up selling the build and built a itx Fracta Design Define S with an ASUS 1060. I rarely game, so its more on my level, and just an all around nicer card. This sucks, i used to love EVGA. Their new line of PSUs states that there are no interchangeable parts, and they use an odd sized fan. This is just evidence they are trying to make things non replaceable and want to give you the heartache of dealing with them and returning or paying more money for warranties. No thanks. Ill stick to a different brand from now on. Plus, i never really liked the look of the card :(

The new 1080ti looks even fuglier. Its a gpu EVGA, not a space shuttle. Cool your turbo jets and keep it simple.

EDIT: I swapped my SC for a 1070 FTW. MUCH BETTER!
stable at 2100 flat! Don't even need slave bios to notice better settings. pics will follow soon.

This is my first build and I am able to play on highest/ultra with 60fps. Temps are amazing. OC to just barely over 2GHz and it's perfect. I play at 2560x1080 currently. If you are on 1080p, No doubt this card will annihilate your games. If you are on 1440p, maybe wait for the 1080ti because even the 1080 struggles with that and for 'future proofing' - if there is such a thing (there isnt!) you would be wise to wait a while longer. As for 4k, probably not going to enjoy this card at all.

Temps are great. Under load in "The Division" and "GTA V" I get 60fps with some fine tuning the temps never get above 65. Idle temps are great too around 27-35 depending on room temperature. I use MSI Afterburner (after using buggy Precision X and only getting problems) for the fans (since the default fan temps are outrageous and do not even kick on until 50 degrees) and to lock the clock speed in during gaming. Also, make sure you go into Nvidia control panel and change the optimal power mode, to maximum performance. It dies throttle a bit from 2.03-2.06. It has been stable like that for extended periods. Some people are benchmarking just for the scores and have to constantly adjust for each one. This is a stable clock for everything. You can use the NCP optimal power under global settings, and choose specific programs to alter settings on. That is the best bet to ensure when you are not gaming, you are not idling the gpu at full clock or using unnecessary amounts of power.

I did a lot of tweaking and have finally found the prefect set up for my use. Gaming, HTPC, Browsing, School, etc etc.... Pretty much everything I will ever need from a GPU. This is my command center and it runs well. I wanted to leave a positive review for what this card is, but I would still advise you to wait longer and just get a 1080 or better. These card manufacturer's are holding back and playing the marketing game to squeeze every penny (not private sellers, the actual manufacturer's) and I believe this card has a lot more potential than they are giving it, especially for the price. If you can, save a little more and spring for the 1080 once prices drop or if you already have a 9 series or even something older, just wait for the ti versions or whatever comes next to last you just as long as your old card did. If you have your heart set on a 1070 regardless, wait for the FTW versions. They should overclock a bit nicer, hopefully to at least 2.1GHz.

UPDATEL it appears the FTW cards do not overclock any better according to EVGA's forums. Since the new driver came out I downloaded it and have not noticed any fluctuation of clock speed during play since. It starts out a bit high then drops to a solid 2063-2068. Even with the slave bios most FTW's I have seen still only get about 2088 stable. It's still pretty good considering the stock clock, but there is more potential than they are giving us, especially in the $400 range. At this rate, the prices will only continue to go up.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: Glad I chose this over the 1080 (for now)
column8:
Coming from my old GTX 780 ($650  3 years ago) I have to say I'm impressed with the performance so far.  I've been able to get stable 2000 Core (Boost) and 4000 Memory.  Temps idle around 33 with no fan (same as 780 with full fan) and haven't gone past 65 under load (Witcher 3, Metro 2033).

Everything is able to run ULTRA at 1080p 60fps and the extra RAM is usable by my Adobe apps (which in theory should help somewhat).

The ACX 3.0 cooling is efficient and quiet, which may not be as important as it was for the 780 I had (reference cooler) it would hit 96-99 on some games where this chip runs cool to begin with.

The new EVGA Precision OC tool made for Pascal is better (for me).  It clocks easy, OSD works unlike the older one and just seems a little more stable.

I was tempted to pick up a 1080, but figured I'd wait for the Ti and I'm glad I did, this runs everything i throw at well enough and in six months the Ti will likely be out.  Pretty sure this won't last the 3 years my 780 did with the way VR and Unreal 4 engine games are looking, but at least the price is tolerable (actual retail not the inflated nonsense going on here and other stores)

Was hoping to give AMD a try, but they just don't stack up in the high end arena right now...I hope they catch up soon to keep nVidia honest.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column8: The GTX 1070 Founder's Edition from EVGA EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition Graphic Card 08G-P4-6170-KR has a lot of hype surrounding it, does it live up to the hype? To jump straight to the answer, it's yes and no. The card itself is very well built, the design is sleek and modern. Love or hate it, it does use the blower style cooler. I personally have no problem with this cooling method as my case is well insulated and a good distance away from my sitting area since the PC is part of my entertainment center. The noise from the blower is not that noticeable at high load, I am coming from an Asus GTX 970 Strix OC which ran way louder. Coil whine was not present at the time of my benchmarks, or if it was, it was very minimal. The only thing about the presentation that I wasn't the biggest fan of was the green LED for the "GTX 1070" lettering, I wish there was built in software to change the color of the LED to match with my color scheme. Performance wise the card is a beast. Straight out of the box I tested some major AAA titles and did a FireStrike benchmark, the results did not disappoint, without overclocking at all the card surpassed expectations and chewed up anything I threw at it. Here are the specs of my build: Intel i5 6600k 3.5ghz 16gb Corsair Vengence DDR4 2400 Gigabyte z170 Motherboard EVGA GTX 1070 FE Corsair Hydro H60 Corsair CX 750M Power Supply Bit Fenix Mini-ITX BFC Pro-300 Samsung 850 EVO - 250gb SSD (All clocks were at base for testing, no OC present) FireStrike capped out at 13,983 out of three runs, this was the best. I tested it on the following games in 1080p with every setting I could possibly max out: Doom (2016) - Peak 212 FPS, Average 121 Lords of the Fallen - Peak 130, Average 82 Rise of the Tomb Raider - Peak 124, Average 68 The Witcher III - Peak 132, Average 63 The idle temperature never exceeded 42C, at full load I would top out around 54C. The card is wonderful for 1080p gaming, but I have mixed feelings about the 4k options, I do not have a 4k setup and do not want to invest in a monitor for it due to high costs, the performance is just middle of the road and doesn't to make sense to jump in just yet on a single card. Final thoughts, the GTX 1070 is a nice jump from the Strix 970, however, the performance jump was not as shocking as a jump from a few generations ago. The price is a little hard to swallow for the FE, but I really do like the design and did not want to wait for the after market cards. Once a good after market that is sub $400 comes out, I will pick that up and move this one into my PC in another office. I think overall the card is a solid 4/5. It would have been a solid 5 if the LEDs could be changed via software and if the FE were not priced higher than the standard 970. The reviews on Amazon do not accurately reflect the feelings of people who have legitimately purchased these due to resellers marking up the prices. It's not a fair representation of the actual product, but this is the only way people can vent their frustrations about the reseller problem that plagues Amazon. Amazon definitely needs to make it more clear that the listed price when a reseller is selling it is NOT from Amazon directly and differentiate their listing from third party. The people who buy from these resllers are equally to blame. Stop buying from them and they will go away, end of story. The only reason to ever buy from a reseller is if it's preowned and it's cheaper than MSRP. Sorry for the rant, but enjoy your new card, hope the review helps. I'm pleased with my purchase and can't wait to see games like Battlefield 1 running on it in the near future.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: An originally buoyant card that now fails to sell.
column8:
Man, thus is probably one of the most hyped cards on the planet! For sure, this is going to sell well anyways since it's made by Nvidia. However, there are multiple green traps that you can fall into this card, so you might as well buy from the red lava company, known as AMD!

The Nvidia 1070 is considered to be one of the fastest cards to date, and it shows in it's strong 1080p gaming. You can obviously so 1080p gaming at max settings at 60+ FPS. 1440p isn't that horrible either, at around 60 FPS on medium to high settings.

So, if all of the 1070 is good, then why is it only 2 stars in my book?

First things is, the rise of 4K gaming is one the rise, and more gamers are gaming on 4K televisions that have HDR compatibility. However, the 1070 doesn't quite have that horsepower to meet the demand of 4K gaming on televisions. Also, the 1070 hasn't been polished on the Dx12 side, which is what happened to the 970. It just seems like that Nvidia just doesn't know that DX12 is extremely popular. The 1070's Dx12 performance is quite similar to the R9 390X's performance in Dx12.

So far, I am not quite impressed with this card. It just feels like Nvidia completely just wanted to get this on the shelf as soon as possible just to make some thousands of dollars. No wonder the price is currently $450, when the 1070 could be easily improved if Nvidia waited a little longer.

column4: EVGA GeForce GTX 1070 Founders Edition, 8GB GDDR5, LED, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) Graphics Card 08G-P4-6170-KR
column7: It is an amazing card, hence the 5 stars
column8:
DO NOT PURCHASE! THIS CARD WILL DROP SIGNIFICANTLY IN PRICE POINT AFTER 10-15 DAYS!

Ladies and Gentlemen of Amazon, these cards are released on June 10, 2016 at a $449 price point for an early release "founders edition"

The "HYPE" is real! It is an amazing card, hence the 5 stars, it's faster than the Titan X... HOWEVER!!! READ ON!!!

This is the first time NVIDIA will be competing against partners like EVGA to sell the card directly.

This means their cooler design with the "Vapor chamber" that they try to upsell you to the $449 Founders edition for IS NOT WORTH IT EITHER!

PLEASE WAIT UNTIL THIS CARD DROPS TO THE REASONABLE $349 MSRP THAT IT SHOULD BE!

On a side note,

THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO DIFFERENCE IN ANY MATERIAL OR DESIGN USED, BETWEEN THE FOUNDERS EDITION CARDS, AND THE REGULAR CARDS SHIPPED SHORTLY AFTERWARD.

The Founder's edition is another way of saying Reference Card and another way to charge those who want the card on the very first day, an extra 100 bucks.

Partners like EVGA will come out with Custom Cards with liquid cooling and so forth, for around the same price point.

These cards will come factory overclocked and superclocked, and will have different types like the "Kingpin" edition which uses premium copper for heat dissipation on the 980 Ti

Please wait, be patient for 14 days, and then order a custom card from NVIDIA partners.

That is my best advice to you Amazonians.

Good luck and happy gaming

column4: Lamicall Tablet Stand, Adjustable Tablet Holder - Desktop Stand Dock Holder Compatible with 4-13" Tablet Such as iPad Pro 11, 9.7, 10.5, 12.9 Air Mini 4 3 2, Nexus, Tab, Silver
column7: Takes me back six decades to my "Morning News" newspaper holder.
column8:
I don't often give 5-star reviews, but this product deserves it. Six decades ago, when I was a kid, I'd start my morning off by propping my St. Louis Globe-Democrat on this aluminum "Morning News" newspaper holder. Now that I'm in the digital world and no longer get my news squirted on dead trees, I wondered why nobody had come up with a good holder for my iPad.

When I received an offer to review this stand for a modest discount, I jumped on it, expecting to be disappointed with a light-weight piece of junk.

column8:
Update: The seller contacted me to see if they could resolve any concerns with me. It makes me want to leave them positive seller feedback without changing anything regarding the product. They make the product and are trying to back it up and that may be worth changing 3 stars on the product to 4 stars. Sort of makes me feel like I'm playing into the gaming of reviews but at the same time this is them backing up their product which means a lot.

A value at 10 bucks and a bargain at 8. I paid 17.

Basically two pieces of metal with a hinge holding them together for 17 bucks. It doesn't lock into place. With only one hinge you are stuck at the one height and a way to change the viewing angle. It is too big for my phone and too small for my tablet. It works for both mostly. You see a half inch of the stand on either side of the phone and it is shaky with the tablet because the base is too small especially if you have to tap even lightly on one of the upper corners.

It is certainly not junk and it I like it more than the 5 dollar stand I bought at the same time that doesn't elevate the holding position above the table. It makes it so that I can plug it in portrait mode which is great. In spite of not locking into position the hinge is sturdy enough to hold up to everything but playing games. Playing games on the tablet with the narrow base is out of the question anyway. No big deal there.

Probably sounds like negative criticism but it is a cheap metal stand for 17 bucks and I find it a poor value. They probably have good customer service. Their marketing team is aggressive so you'll get an email asking for a review and you'll find them addressing concerns in the comments on other reviews. Good marketing is how companies game the reviews on Amazon.

That is my 2 cents. A value at 10 bucks and a bargain at 8.

column8:
Best Alternative to More Expensive Brands

Youre probably looking at this stand because it had some of the highest ratings while also being relatively inexpensive. I did too, which is why I bought the stand for my iPad Mini 4. It arrived within two days and was packaged well. The stand looked fine (see pictures below) except for one barely noticeable scuff mark on the upper-back of the neck. Although initially disappointed, I remembered only paying $15.99.

Made from brushed aluminum, the stand comes with several additional replacement rubber feet (see pictures below). The hinge is solid and is flexible enough while maintaining its structure as to not fail under the weight of a device.

You definitely won't regret getting it.

column8: Very happy with my purchase of this iPad stand. I have an iPad Pro 12.9, and my only complaint would be that it is not the strongest stand for that size iPad in portrait mode. I have yet to find one that accommodates the portrait mode well. Dont get me wrong, it is a durable standjust not for the larger iPad portrait angle. For 10.5 or smaller iPads, it would be perfect on either mode. As far as landscape mode on the 12.9, it is perfectvery durable. You can adjust the angle where you need it, and I have had no problem using it with my case still on the iPad. It also holds well to the table or desk top without sliding all over. When I am not using it for my pro, I use it for a picture stand! Its a multi-task item! Got the silver to go with our keyboard, and it is very nice looking. I would highly recommend this stand.

column4: Lamicall Tablet Stand, Adjustable Tablet Holder - Desktop Stand Dock Holder Compatible with 4-13" Tablet Such as iPad Pro 11, 9.7, 10.5, 12.9 Air Mini 4 3 2, Nexus, Tab, Silver
column8:
I'm not blown away or honestly real impressed with this product. Maybe my expectations were too high due to the insanely high ratings. The basic, simple stand I received is slightly bent and leans enough to the left that it is impossible not to notice. It is relatively strong and is not without its merit in terms of providing a simple very basic stand for your tablet or iPad. It does its job pretty well and no more.

I'm leaving my original review up but amending a few things.

First and most important is how impressed I am with Lamicall customer service. Shortly after reviewing the product which I don't feel was overly critical I was contacted by Lamicall and offered a full refund without returning the stand. I did not ask for anything much less such a generous offer. I never contacted them and aside from the lean in the stand had no reason or issue to warrant contacting them. I feel like this is far above and beyond the norm and very much worth mentioning.

2nd thing is being a bit unhappy with a bent or leaning stand I did not focus much on the positive aspects of this product. After the refund I figured I had nothing to lose and put some serious weight into trying to bend the stand back into position. It worked, not perfectly but good enough to use. The fact that it took the force I applied and is now still functional speaks volumes to the durability of the stand. It retained its ability to be adjustable and remain strong in holding any position. I like this stand quite a bit. Plenty of room for my iPad regardless of if its wearing a fat otterbox case or a slim folio case and is always securely able to hold the iPad in place. Overall for my needs and expectations it's an awesome stand.

column8:
I got this on a flash deal, so it was cheap to take a chance!
It is perfect for my kindle!
Wherever I'm reading, I get tired of holding my reader up to my face (I'm old, but I prefer reading without glasses:that means one foot away, which also means elbows bent uncomfortably). Now I don't have to hold my kindle forever!
Particularly, I put a Velcro dot on so I can even tilt it over vertical.
I probably would have contrapted something like this out of popsicle sticks eventually, but this cost less than those couple of hours, and the dot keeps it from falling, so, happy happy!
Hint, stand makers, toss in a Velcro dot or two for a five star gravity defied (also, hint: soft side on the device and you will never notice it!).

column7: A high quality stand for your Amazon Fire HD10 that looks like it belongs on your office desk.
column8:
I am very, very happy using this stand with my Amazon Fire HD10 tablet. The build quality is professional and doesn't look like a cheap stand. The anti-skip mats work well with a very low chance of the tablet slipping out. The adjustable hinge is easy to adjust with force, though I wonder if it will wear out over time. But for now, the stand keeps the tablet in place, even as I tap on the tablet.

I paid full price for this product and still wrote a rave review, though I wouldn't mind getting another one of these for a discount....*wink*

column4: Lamicall Tablet Stand, Adjustable Tablet Holder - Desktop Stand Dock Holder Compatible with 4-13" Tablet Such as iPad Pro 11, 9.7, 10.5, 12.9 Air Mini 4 3 2, Nexus, Tab, Silver
column7: Small but strong, saves your neck
column8: There sure are a lot of small adjustable stands available, and I think I looked at most of them.  This one appeared to be the sturdiest, and had slightly bigger measurements in it's design to achieve it.  I chose it also because of the larger 'feet' that support my device, in case I decide to get a thicker case for it.  I've used it a number of times already, with the iPad Pro 10.5" in both vertical and horizontal positions, and am definitely pleased with the stability.  The question is how long any of these stands maintain their ability to hold a position, which could be a problem with the iPad being held vertically.  I'm a chicken, and will probably provide a soft surrounding on the table if it starts to show signs of loosening.  I'm surprised someone hasn't come up with a small locking mechanism to hold the angle.  In time, I'm sure.

column7: Solid and versatile, although it might scratch up your iPad Pro
column8:
I needed a stand for my iPad Pro and this looked good.  What I particularly like is that (1) it's substantial -- I have a few iPad stands and while they're nice, they're a bit light and thus easy for a clumsy oaf like me to knock over. Even better is the ability to choose virtually any angle of tilt.

Only four stars because according to the manufacturer -- they emailed me -- it scratches up iPad Pros now and then.  I've not yet had the problem but it would have been nice to have a "MAYBE DON'T BUY THIS IF YOU HAVE A PRO" notation in big letters.

column7: Terrific minimalist yet practical design, sturdy, great value
column8:
If you are looking for a stand for your iPad or iPhones this one is it. Its made of super sturdy frosted aluminum straight out of the iMac or MacBook series. The same color Grey and even space Grey. Easily adjustable with soft thin rubber pads on the bottom and where your device will rest. Thankfully it also has a space carved out of the bottom for the lightning port (for iOS) so your device can charge while in use.

Lightweight and simple lines; but not designed to be stationary or stuffed in a backpack. Much better than the stability or sturdiness of the smart covers you can get for most iPads.

column8:
Update to my review!  LamicallDirect contacted me directly and was very kind and refunded my purchase- even though I could have looked at the description better before I purchased- and did not even want me to return it. They just told me to use the money on something that works for me. Refreshing to see a company that not only cares, but puts their money where their mouth is.  Im amazed.
Back to the stand review:  The stand is really well made. The hinge that moves the angle of the iPad is very smooth and stable. If you are only using it at home or work desk- it's wonderful. But if you travel with it, it's inconvenient because it does not fit in a case because its very sturdy metal.

column7: Small, sturdy, adjustable, stable and nice looking
column8: I wasn't sure this would do what I hoped, but it's exceeded my expectations. This well designed little stand [it looks like the base of a desktop Mac] can hold a phone, Kindle, small tablet or even a large iPad Pro in it's case, without wobbling or threatening to fall over, even when touching your screen or turning off your device.  I can't believe how stable it is just sitting on a table, yet it's not heavy. The angled device rest has thin protective padding pieces wherever your device touches it, to avoid scratches and the pads provide a bit of friction that help hold your device steady. The tablet holder is adjustable up or down so you can view your device at any suitable angle you set and once adjusted, stays there until you change the angle. The base [with more of those pads to avoid scratching surfaces] doesn't move around. The hole in the rear upright allows neat cord management. All in all, it's a very impressive, deceptively simple little stand I can recommend without reservation.

column7: [REVISED REVIEW] Useable for the iPad Pro 12.9"
column8:
[REVIEW REVISED] Originally this review had four stars, but after posting it, Lamicall contacted me to note they were aware the stand wasn't the best for my giant iPad Pro, and issued a full refund, while allowing me to keep the stand. I have added a star for the prompt and courteous customer service alone. That is rare in today's digital commerce environment.

Here is my original review, which I stand by, but I am looking forward eagerly to a larger Lamicall Tablet Stand and will buy it without hesitation.

I wanted this stand to be awesome. When it arrived I was impressed with the build quality, etc. But when I put my behemoth iPad Pro 12.9" on it, it toppled backwards. So, here are my current options: 1. Stand the iPad almost vertically. 2. Use my iPad in landscape view only. 3. Weigh down the base or put double sided tape on the bottom. It appears that with just a little more "practical experimentation" they could have designed this slightly differently and accommodated the iPad Pro perfectly. Don't get me wrong, every other tablet I have fits solidly on it.

column7: Great at first and then you begin to notice some problems...
column8:
Rather disappointed with this after using it for the past couple months. It was really great at first, but then as I used it more heavily, I began to notice various problems.

One is that the upper rubber pads are sliding down and just will not stay up. It leaves it looking rather poorly as the adhesive is sliding down and is somewhat unsightly.  I suppose the real problem here is that they misadvertised the color of the pads. In the photos they provide above, they appear black / dark grey whereas in reality they are clear with white adhesive under them. If they had provided black pads with black adhesive, this would never have been a problem or at least not a visually pronounced problem.  I still don't like them riding over the rotating joint though as I feel they're going to cause problems there as well at some point.

Another problem is that the base is not quite heavy or wide enough and so when you sit the iPad into the base it moves around a bit and requires the iPad to be nearly centered in order to not fall over.

Just a little more thought and testing would make this just about perfect.

column7: Yes, a 5 Star Review for a Stand I Returned!
column8: This is a VERY NICE stand, but I returned it... Here's why:  I have a 12.9" iPad Pro.  Got this to set the tablet at just the right angle for typing, reading and diagramming. For any other tablet, this stand would work great. But with the size and the weight of the Pro, tapping on the screen produces a giggle in the stand that takes a while to go away, even after you stop touching the tablet. The stand is just too "springy". As an engineer, I can tell you that if the aluminum base was thicker, this would not be an issue.  The rest of the stand is built stoutly. The angle adjustment is firm, smooth and infinite. With a Pro, I would also be a more comfortable with a little wider base - just a little more side stability with a big tablet. I really hated returning this but it just didn't work out for my tablet.  If you have an Air, Mini, smaller Galaxy, etc. I would highly recommend this stand.  If the manufacturer comes out with a similar stand that fits the 12.9" iPad better, I'll buy it in a heartbeat! Also, kudos to the seller and Amazon for a smooth return.

column7: Well constructed and nice looking stand. A+
column8:
This is one of the best iPad stands I've ever used. Really. But that's kind of subjective, so let me give you some objective reasons. It's made with good materials (metal), and it's construction feels really solid. The hinge mechanism is sufficiently stiff, but not so stiff as to make it difficult to adjust. It's quite pleasant to manipulate to different angles. It holds the adjustments too. Ergonomically, it's a nice height for viewing and using your device. I've also found it to be very nice with an external Bluetooth keyboard, it feels like a proper writing setup. Aesthetically, it looks very slick. The angle and design of the base is reminiscent of an iMac's stand. In fact, it looks sharp next to my iMac.

Overall, this is the best iPad stand I've used, and it's well priced.

column4: Lamicall Tablet Stand, Adjustable Tablet Holder - Desktop Stand Dock Holder Compatible with 4-13" Tablet Such as iPad Pro 11, 9.7, 10.5, 12.9 Air Mini 4 3 2, Nexus, Tab, Silver
column7: A nice stand that will make your iPad look like a baby iMac
column8:
I got this for a 2017 iPad so I could have it on my desk as a device for reviewing my schedule and track my inbox.  The stand is very nice looking and looks very "Apple" in style.  From my perspective it is very sturdy and solid in construction.

The foot has 4 rubber pads on it to give very good traction between the stand and your desk.  If you intend on swiveling it left to right then the traction on a smooth surface desk (like a glass desk) may be more then you expect.  I personally love it because I do not want my iPad sliding around while I am swiping and tapping things on the screen.

The only (and this is small) reason why I removed 1 star was on the claw part of the stand.  The place where the bottom of your iPad comes in contact with the swivel part of the stand.  In that area there is a rubber pad on each side to protect your iPad but it does not extend over the edge so you could (if not reasonably careful) scratch your bezel.  It would be nicer if the padding extended a bit higher on the "claw".  The risk is low if you take care when seating your iPad but not zero.  Hopefully the designer of this will improve this very small point to get to 5 stars.  Once in place, your iPad will be safe and secure.

Even with the knowledge I have, I would buy another one because it does a very nice job and meets all my needs.

column4: Lamicall Tablet Stand, Adjustable Tablet Holder - Desktop Stand Dock Holder Compatible with 4-13" Tablet Such as iPad Pro 11, 9.7, 10.5, 12.9 Air Mini 4 3 2, Nexus, Tab, Silver
column7: UPDATE// Reliable //  Black and white rubber is just terrible... terrible.......
column8:
As the stars state, I HATE the product. I received the product today and as soon as I opened it I was so disappointed by the rubbers. ITS WHITE. It seriously distorts the slick black color with trash white rubber pads. When I first saw the pictures on amazon, I thought they were stickers covering the actual 'black' rubbers, but they are not. It is exactly like the picture, but even worse in person. The entire stand feels solid and seems like its made of high quality but the color of these rubbers seriously diminishes the value. It looks terrible... terrible... If i had known earlier, i would of never purchased this product. What a waste of 'great' stand.  (It also looks terrible on my desk.)

UPDATE///  After I left a review, Lamicall instantly responded by offering help. They were very open to customer criticisms and were willing to fix their design to better suit their customers. What a wonderful mindset for a company to have... They did everything they can to fix my issue. Also, my only gripe was the white rubber on black stand. However, after couple uses, my iPad stays solid on the stand. It doesn't wobble at all. It's very firm and reliable. I would have to use this stand for a bit more to leave a thorough review, but for now its perfect (other than the white color of the rubber).  If they do listen and change the color, i would definitely purchase more for my family. For the perfect customer service and their almost flawless stand I've updated my review to 4 stars.

column7: Very sturdy aluminum stand. Excellent for the price.
column8:
I purchased this item in an attempt to help unclutter my desk. It was getting bad and was impacting my productivity. I needed this for an Asus S3 10 inch tablet with slim case.
  It arrived in perfect order in in uniquely shaped box. It had very little documentation with it, but do you really need it?
  I, like many other reviewers here, was concerned with the strength of the hinge and would it hold a 10 inch tablet securely enough that I could still find it useful. I can assure you, this is one extremely sturdy stand. It hold my tablet wonderfully as you can see from the pictures I am including. It will hold my tablet in portrait or landscape orientation. The hinge is very secure and it's hard to describe, its ease of movement is perfectly counterbalanced with its ease that it won't move. I don't think I will have any problems with this stand.
  If your tablet or phone has a port on the bottom the stand will accommodate that as well.
  I chose the black color because it matched everything on my desk and the tablet. For $19 this is a good buy. I would highly recommend this if you need to get things off your desk and would like a cleaner appearance.

column7: Not as functional as I thought
column8:
Customer service from Lamicall is excellent.

Pros:  It matches with your Apple gear and has a modern look.  Good if you need it to just watch videos or have a minimal need to tap on the tablet.

Cons:  It didn't meet what I was looking for in a stand.  Specifically, I'm using a Microsoft Surface Pro 4 and wanted something to hold it in portrait mode as I used the Surface Pen to take notes.  Two issues are why this is not a good solution.  1.  The stand itself is not study enough to hold the tablet for you to write on or even tap on.  It wobbles when you do this.  2.  The stand will hold the Surface 4 Pro with the keyboard cover but it does not go in the holder very well.  I eventually purchased a wooden book stand.  Although its larger, it is much more solid and fits my needs better.

As a sidenote, the unit I received had a slight tilt.  So check yours to make sure it is level.

column7: Sturdy, well built, Perfect for my IPad Mini 2
column8:
Perfect for my IPad Mini 2.  I looked at several different types of stands and I am delighted with this product.  I channel surf while watching tv and use the touch screen for web surfing.  The stand stays in place.  Well built product.

Pros:
small footprint
can use landscape or portrait
works well with device plugged in
many adjustable viewing angles
sturdy, well built

Cons:
none

***Update 05/20/2017
Still loving it. Well built, sturdy, easy to use, easy to move to another room. Holds the IPad Mini at the perfect height, love the adjustability in viewing angle.  A great example of a cost effective solution to a problem. The silver color and design also fit well in my décor.

I checked items and read hundreds of reviews before deciding to purchase this tablet stand.  Just wanted to let you know in an update that all is well and working as expected.  I expect the stand to last for many more years. Great brand at a great price.

Hope it helps to know how well the product has stood up under daily use and that I am still a fan of the product..

column4: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 10.5-Inch Tablet (16 GB, Titanium Bronze)
column7: The best tablet I have used so far..
column8: Update 7/23/2014: reducing to 4/5. Battery life (and charging) is not as good as iPad or for that matter, for a device that costs 500 bucks. A few issues with Android as well (but then I have my own gripes with IOS as well). The microSD slot was hard to use. I use a Transcend 32GB MicroSDHC Class10 UHS-1 Memory Card with Adapter 45 MB/s (TS32GUSDU1E), but it is quite difficult to insert and keep it locked; had to use a tool (I used the microsd adapter!) to push the card in. This card does get recognized and I can use it well. Old Review: My iPad 2 broke and I was looking to buy an (a second one in the household) ipad air; got this at the right time, and am in tablet heaven... I did try a Dell Venue 8" - my first android tab - a while ago and it was a disaster (turns out there are display and hardware issues with that model). So when I got this, I was a bit skeptical - only for the first 10 minutes, though! Let us get to details then... Summary of differences with ipad: 1. MicroSD slot! (up to 128Gb capacity) 2. Better and bigger display 3. 3GB memory for running applications (compared to 1GB) 4. Camera 8MP compared to 5MP 5. Fingerprint sensor! Size and handling: At 10.5, it is bigger than ipad air. Even thinner than iPad at 0.26 inches; smooth surfaces, and as with iPad Air, it is a bad idea to handle this beauty without a case; it is quite easy to drop these, and they are not made to hold in hand for long hours without a cover, either. So, please buy a good cover to go with this. Display: At 2560x1600 it is about 25+% more than iPad air in terms of resolution (287ppi compared to 264ppi) - and it shows! Beautiful Super AMOLED display beats out the LED displays. It is reported that AMOLED displays are usually not bright enough, but on this model, it is more than enough - even in bright outdoors. The settings entry for brightness has an 'auto' mode, but that doesn't seem to work fully well (an android issue or Samsung issue), and it is still bright in the night. I had to turn off auto and reduce the brightness manuallly for night time viewing! The display is gorgeous, to say the least, and the best part of this tablet. Battery and charging: Battery life is quite adequate at about 8+ hours ( I did run through several episodes of burn notice with netflix streaming on one charge). Charging with the included charger does take longer than I expected - several hours for full charge. In addition, there is ultra power saving mode you can turn on from 'settings -> General' menu - this mode takes you to a black and white screen mode and allows basic web surfing, email and a few application that you can choose to add. In this mode, it can last quite a few hours with just 10% charge remaining. Bloatware: Contrary to some review, there is some bloatware that is pre-installed but not much. There are two boxes that show up in the second screen - Galaxy essentials and galaxy gifts. If you go in to this, you get to choose what bloatware you want :) But there are some good ones such as wall street journal or Economist 3 month subscriptions for free, GQ and other free issues, as well as some free games. There are 2 apps - Samsung Level (for the soon-to-be-released Samsung headphones - to compete with Beats..) and Samsung Gear - pre-installed. Camera: 8MP for the back camera with a flash compared to just 5 MP in iPad - seems good. But this is the only feature that was ordinary in Samsung tablet. The pictures in auto mode doesn't look as good as a normal (cheapo) 8MP digital camera photos in auto mode - even to an untrained eye. (I put a Canon EOS 7D to good use and I can spot a good camera when I see one; sadly this is not one of those..), but it is adequate; so is the front camera at 2 MP. WIFI - comparable; both support a/b/g/n dual band MIMO, but Samsung also supports 'ac'. Quite easy to setup/connect to home networks. So far there is not one hiccup with the wireless access. Excellent performance. CPU - While iPad only has A7 ARM cores, Samsung has 4 A7 cores and 4 A15 cores; it claims it switches the cores depending on the need/usage/power requirements. For all practical purposes, it is fast; there is some lag but not serious lag in using multiple apps and notifications and background tasks going on. Fingerprint sensor: It is all how you train (give samples) the sensor! It takes 8 samples to setup, and so use your finger in slightly different angles - tilting your finger a little from left to right before each sample. Settings screen and fingerprint setup also allows you to setup an alternate password in case you can't get through with your fingerprint. In addition you can always unlock with your google account. I am able to use the finger sensor almost without any failure so far and found this this to be way better than the one I have on my Dell Lattitude notebooks. Audio: has 2 speakers one on each side (unlike ipad air), and the audio is decent for this price, though I prefer to use earbuds for better sound. Watch On app and the IR capability: while new for Samsung, the app is still not ready; has several issues. It let me add my Denon receiver, dish receiver, sony bluray and panasonic tv etc., but I can't turn off or control all devices individually (no selection for device). Only volume, channel change etc work! Power button asks what device you want to power off - again didn't list bluray or receiver - only my TV and Dish. I hope this will get fixed as the app improves. But basic IR facility is great - worked from a distance of 20+ ft across the room. I absolutely love this. In terms of hardware, it scores a 10/10; fit and finish is great and I would expect this to last at least another 6 to 8 years (unless the technology obsoletes this hardware - which it will...); Apple has been trounced from the tablet throne with this entry.

column4: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 10.5-Inch Tablet (16 GB, Titanium Bronze)
column8:
For that and this is my toy that lets me do what I want.  I or my wife own I pads and Kindle HD and a galaxy tab pro and nothing beats the pleasure of watching movies on this (for a tablet-not that 60 inch curved tv at Magnolia). There is detail and depth and color. I use any content apps I want- Hulu, Netflix, Xfinity, it looks fantastic.  Amazon prime music app now let's you listen and download for offline listening if you have prime. I don't believe that prime video is supported on this device or any Android tablet. Not through a nonexistent app or the Chrome browser.
  The micro SD slot is important to me if I'm looking at photos I take with a separate camera and don't wish to use a computer to put them onto the cloud just to see them or jump through other hoops  or hurdles to look at my content.

  Speaking of pictures I worried that this display would over saturate the ones I took and give me a false representation or candy colors. I like to see how I'm doing on a larger screen and take a tablet along with me frequently and Samsung uses an adaptive display for your various content that tones things down depending on what your doing.  My photos look pretty  natural, but  very detailed.  I love this thing for a lot of reasons. There are plenty of things to customize and make your own. It will have been a good purchase.

column4: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 10.5-Inch Tablet (16 GB, Titanium Bronze)
column8:
This is my first Android tablet and I am absolutely blown away by the screen resolution! I had the very 1st generation iPad, but other than that I've never had a tablet before.

The first thing you notice when you turn on the tablet and play the sample video clip that comes on the tablet is how astonishing the screen brightness and clarity is! The video is so crisp and clear.  I was going to buy the Note 10.1 refurbished model because it was hundreds cheaper, but when I found out this tablet is Super Amoled display and all the tech sites said this is the best tablet on the market right now, I decided to fork up the extra money and get it. I'm sure glad I did!

I showed my friend at work who has an iPad, and the first thing he said "that blows my iPad out of the water!"

The finger scanner works flawlessly! The tablet asks you to scan your finger 8 times, and I've never had it fail me once and I've unlocked the screen 30+ times today.

The bezel around the screen is the smallest we've seen yet in a tablet and I love it! For instance, if you compare this tablet to the Nexus 10, the Nexus 10 looks so outdated because of the THICK bezel going around the edge of the tablet. You do NOT get that unappealing look with this tablet. This tablet is the sexiest one on the market right now!

Samsung, I love you!!

column4: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 10.5-Inch Tablet (16 GB, Titanium Bronze)
column8:
Let's review the specs.  For $500 you get a 10.5 inch screen, ultra thin body with high resolution screen, a stated 9 hour battery runtime, around 10 ounces in weight and 3GB RAM.

The new iPad?  Nope, it's the new entry from Samsung, the Galaxy Tab S 10.5.

But let's be realistic -- it's designed to compete with the iPad in an attempt to topple the latter from its throne so comparisons must be made in that respect.

As compared to the iPad Air, this unit has a slightly larger screen and maybe weighs a bit more, but otherwise they are nearly identical in these areas.  Both also sport robust construction although a few I know that compared this to the iPad state the Apple version has the sleek aluminum structure; however, there is no faulting the Samsung.

Unfortunately, both do share a similar trait -- forgo a case and you also forgo grip.  Both are so light and thin they are literally a drop accident waiting to happen.

And while both tip the financial scales at identical pricing, the Samsung has a few upgrades.  First, you get 3GB RAM instead of the usual 1 for the iPad, then you'll notice the rear camera has a flash and an 8MP rating as opposed to the lower resolution iPad version (with no flash), and, finally, you get a micro-SD card slot (something Apple has been ignoring for years).

However, it's the screen that will amaze.  AMOLED technology means colors are bright and blacks are, well, eerily black (almost new car, shiny black).  This is quite a contrast from the iPad's more sedate screen, although both are still amazing considering the technology from the earlier tablets, but the truth remains that side-by-side, the Samsung's screen really stands out.

In fact, after a short while I had to tone down the brightness some as this unit will actually light up a room.  Nighttime discreet is not in the cards here.

Performance-wise the Samsung gets the newer Android 4.4 OS which has a bevy of improvements over previous versions, too many to mention here.  Let it suffice to say that speed is not a problem here and I enjoy the interface over iOS versions which don't allow main screen widgets and much in the way of related animations.  In short, if you desire an OS that allows for streaming news and interactive widgets, this is the puppy for you.

However, there are some quirks here.  Android allows for folders to be created on the screen to house multiple apps and this is done by either moving apps on top of each other (ala' Apple) which creates a new folder or by holding a finger on the screen to bring up a submenu to create a folder; however, Samsung tweaked this procedure and has made it so the only way to create desktop folders is by holding an icon until a menu appears on top of the screen and then scooting the icon to that area to create a folder.  Time consuming and somewhat unnecessary.

Samsung added one perk to the mix, though -- a fingerprint scanner.  Swipe your fingerprint at the center bottom of the screen when prompted and it'll open the  OS as if you entered a password (word of caution -- remember the password in case your finger doesn't pass muster).  Although initially impressed, it some became apparent it had about a 40% success rate and is not for the impatient since it requires a slow, methodical swiping of the finger.

Sound reproduction is an ongoing problem with any tablet unless you opt for the headphones but Samsung hit it here.  Sound reproduction is great.

Performance, unfortunately, does come at a cost, though.  Although rated at 9 hours of battery life (down from an original estimate by some of closer to 11), those ignoring the battery saver functions built in will find themselves seeking an outlet at closer to 7, as in my case.  To be fair, I was running videos and jumping all over the internet so your mileage may vary.  For those that sometimes ignore the battery warnings, there is a power mode that turns the screen from color to B&W and shuts down all but the essential apps.  Hopefully you don't have to use this mode much since you're getting down to the critical stage by that time but you can technically turn it on any time.

On that power topic, I really couldn't find much that would cause this unit to lock up or slow down.  Even higher end, memory eating, games didn't seem to bother it much nor did forgetting to shut down the last 15 apps I opened while hammering away at another.  Guess that 3GB RAM does help a lot.

So, are there any downsides here?  As with any tablet, including the vaunted iPad, there are faults:

* Price is steep and encroaches on Apple territory.  Given the option of the Apple or Samsung at the same price, the vast majority chose the former.

* Accessories?  What accessories? Few companies are producing cases and the like at this time and you can easily dump anywhere from $40 on up at Samsung's site to get cases which, oddly enough, seem to be lagging behind the release date of the tablet itself (although I may has misread that).  Because of the odd screen size (larger than the industry standard of 10.1") you chance of making one of these fit into a generic tablet holder is about nil.

* No 4G (or 3G for that matter) yet and capable models will not be out until later this year.  Oops, that's a biggie.

* 16GB for main memory?  Really?  Yes, the Samsung does have a card slot that can accept up to 128GB, but not everything transfers to these cards (especially some apps) and transfer rates from these cards are still slower than the included drive.  Offer options here, folks.

* Bloatware galore, and gimmicky stuff at that.  Fortunately, most of it just sits there and does nothing until you command differently; however, I was hoping those days were gone when tablets came out.  Problem is, some of that 16GB onboard is occupied with this stuff but I do have to commend Samsung for leaving what appears to be the majority on their website for download if desired.

And, finally, there is the processor.  Instead of opting for the Intel Atom tablet series, Samsung opted to stay with the newest Enyxos quadcore version.  While wholly capable and probably just as appropriate as the Atom, the Intel name does carry cache over what was chosen.

However, all things considered, Samsung could have a hit here, especially with those users not quite accustomed to Apple's version of "take it or leave it" iOS and lack of SD card support.  For the same price as a base Apple unit, Samsung buyers get more RAM, an SD card reader, the Android OS, and cameras with flash and better MP ratings.

Update:  There have been a couple pesky little items that have cropped up that don't necessarily merit a drop in rating but should be kept in mind:

*  The charger is just as bad as the old Apple iPad pre-Lightning version; however, it's even smaller and more fragile.  Mine is already starting to show signs of fatigue and there's no way of gingerly putting one in.  I can see this as an accident waiting to happen.

*  Email notification is nothing short of lacking.  I have it on push yet this model is always behind my Apple  by at least a good couple minutes.  In addition, I'll delete an email only to have it suddenly reappear in my inbox.  Hmmm, something isn't right here.  Had to finally ignore the installed Samsung app and put in another.
