column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
This is an excellent unit when connected to an external self-powered USB 2.0 hard disk drive.  All operations (although not intuitive) work smooth and so far have been trouble free.  A USB flash drive (tested several) is not large enough nor have sufficient data transfer speed ability for smooth operation.  A USB powered hard drive stresses the units power supply and many have experienced premature failure using these drives.  Also, the unit will not benefit from USB 3.0.  This is the single biggest issue with these type of PVR units.

My elderly mother is using this, so I composed basic user instructions that others could also benefit from.  Please like this to keep it at the top of the list for others to benefit from too.

Basic things to remember:

EXIT takes you backwards 1 step and will be used often.

The VOLUME controls on the remote are dependent on the volume set with the TV.  If the TV volume is set to 0, the PVR remote will not change the sound.  If the PVR remote is at full volume and the sound is too quiet, the TV remote must be used to increase the volume more.

All times are based on 24 hour clock, so 8:00pm is really 20:00

Aim remote at PVR box and press button firmly.  If the button did not seem to do anything, wait a few more seconds before pressing it again or the next button.  DO NOT press a button a bunch of times.

If the PVR freezes on a screen for a few minutes, try pressing the power button on the front.  If still nothing happens, switch the power off with the power strip, wait a minute then turn the power strip back on.  (Don't have the hard drive plugged into this power strip)

Any timed recording supersedes a program you are watching live or from the DVR.  The recording mode will begin whether the unit is on, in standby, watching a time shifted live program or watching a recorded event.

How to record a show in the future (like an old VCR)
1. Turn on TV and set input to PVR
2. Turn on PVR
3. Press TIMER button
4. Press 1 to add a new timed program
a. If you want to EDIT an existing program, use the direction keys to highlight the program and press 2.
b. If you want to DELETE an existing program, use the direction keys to highlight the program and press 3.
5. Using the arrow direction keys and select the item to edit it.
6. When changing the date or time, use the arrow keys to get to the number you want to change, then use the number keypad to enter the new number.  After pressing the first number, the underline automatically moves to the next one.
7. Once all data is entered and correct, press the OK button to confirm, then press EXIT to return back to the previous screen.  If you are not going to use the PVR to watch TV, press the POWER button to put the unit into standby.

How to record a show TONIGHT (program guide)
This is useful if you want to record something at 11pm but do not want to stay up for it.
It is also useful if 2 shows you want to watch are at the same time.  Record one with the PVR and watch the other with the TV set to TV input.
1. Turn on TV and set input to PVR
2. Turn on PVR
3. Press EPG (Electronic Program Guide) button
4. Use the arrow keys to select the correct channel shown at the top of the screen
5. The guide will populate more items as they are received from the airwaves.
6. Use the arrow keys to select the program you want to record
7. Press OK to confirm selection, the OK to confirm recording.  Press EXIT then POWER to put unit into standby.  Change the TV input back to TV if you want to watch a live broadcast while the PVR records another channel.

How to Pause live Television (skip commercials!)
This is useful if you want to fix a bite to eat, use the bathroom or so something else while and later return to the program and skip over the commercials.  Remember that you cant fast-forward past live TV.
1. Turn on TV and set input to PVR
2. Turn on PVR
3. Set the channel with the channel keys
4. At any given point you want to pause the program, press PAUSE key.  A slight delay will occur while this puts the PVR into time-shift mode and the picture pauses with the time bar shown below.  To remove the time bar from the screen, press INFO.
  a. While in time-shift mode, you can fast-forward FWD or rewind REV from the point you first paused the TV up to live TV.  Press PLAY to resume playing at the selection point.
  b. Each subsequent time you press fast-forward FWD or rewind REV the speed goes faster, from 2x to 4x to 8x etc as displayed on the top of the screen.  Press PLAY to resume playing at any point.
  c. If you change channel, the PVR will cancel the time-shifted recording in memory.
5. Press the STOP key to cancel the time-shift and stay on the channel.

How to watch a recorded program
The recorded files will have a name that shows the channel, date and time.  Since your show may not be obvious you can play it on this same screen including fast forwarding.
1. Turn on TV and set input to PVR
2. Turn on PVR
3. Press the PVR LIST button
4. Use the arrow keys to select the a program and press OK to start the playback
5. If this is not the correct show, use the arrow keys to select a different one and press OK
6. If the show on the mini screen is the one you want, press the HOLD key to display it as full screen.
7. Use the PAUSE, PLAY, fast-forward FWD or rewind REV to skip around commercials.
8. To delete a program, return to the PVR LIST view, select the program you want to delete and press EPG.  Confirm selection with OK, and then confirm the deletion by pressing OK again.

column7: It Works Great, but There Are Drawbacks
column8:
I bought this because I was dropping cable and wanted to take advantage of the free, HD broadcast stations in my area. I could have use my HD TV, as it has a built-in tuner (most do), but I wanted to use the Personal Video Recorder (PVR) to occasionally record programs. As a tuner and PVR, this product works well. It produces a great picture and sound, and once you figure it out, it records to a USB flash drive perfectly. There are, however, a couple of "Cons": 1) It only displays a 24-hour clock (military time) and there's no way of changing it. Normally, this isn't a problem, but if you want to set up a PVR recording in advance, you'll need to translate normal (12-hour) time to 24-hour time. 2) The User Manual leaves a LOT to be desired. It is poorly written and doesn't cover all functionality. (I'm a technical writer, so I know what a good user manual should look like.) If you rely heavily on a manual, I would skip this product. If you're kind of "geeky" and are willing to try to figure things out on your own, this shouldn't be a problem.  3) The Antenna Power Switch, which can be used with an amplified antenna to boost the signal, doesn't work. Although I can turn it on in the Settings, it doesn't stay on. I contacted Support and had already tried their "solution." After some back-and-forth, they said they'd consider including the issue in the next firmware update.

UPDATE 3/2/2016: I've had this for a few weeks and have become disenchanted with it. So much so, that I completely disconnected it. There were a few local channels I watched regularly on cable that I could not receive via OTA using this product, even after moving my antenna every place possible. On a whim, I connected the antenna directly to my TV and they all came in perfectly. I weighed being able to watch the channels I want against having a PVR and the reception of all available channels won.

column7: Good tuner box for free local network shows
column8:
This is a very good tuner and recorder (on par with my HomeWorX HW-150PVR tuner box) - it does not pull in as many stations as my iView 3500STBII tuner box though. I have a 64GB USB flash drive connected to it via the USB port which allows me to take my recordings on the road. I don't recommend using platter-based hard drives as they take time to spin up, so you can miss the beginning of programmed recordings - unless of course you set it to record 1 minute earlier.

The interface is a little clunky and it does not have the bells and whistles you're accustomed to seeing on TiVo and cable boxes, but you do get an Electronic Program Guide (EPG) - which you can use to look up daily programs for a channel. Select the program you want to record as well as the frequency (once, daily, or weekly) and you're done. None of the brands I mentioned have a standard remote interface, so I have to review the buttons for the other 2 boxes as I don't use them as often, but once you get used to the remote layout, it will become second nature to use.

I use an external UHF/VHF rooftop antenna and get 30+ channels in the NYC area - some of them are total rubbish, so I just delete them from my channel listing. The image quality is excellent, so I have no complaints there. The great thing about the portability of the recorded media is that you can export the files to your laptop/desktop and using a video editor, delete commercials and anything else you don't want, and build your own video library of your favorite shows.

The best thing about these digital tuner boxes is that you don't have to pay monthly fees - you buy the box and an antenna if you don't have one, and that's the end of the charges: no need to pay for monthly TiVo or cable service to view your local networks. The fact that the box can also be used to freely record local network TV shows is absolutely awesome! One less bill to worry about.

column7: however if trying to record regular events - daily or weekly - you will be disappointed. Daily events seem to default the timer
column8:
Works mostly as expected, however if trying to record regular events - daily or weekly - you will be disappointed. Daily events seem to default the timer to weekly - and weekly seems to default to every 10 days -- neither of which is very useful. If you have the time and patience to correct the timer daily - then it does record and playback.

It also appears to "hang" almost daily - and accepts no input at all from the remote control until you do a hard reboot by unplugging it from the wall.

The picture quality from the tuner is excellent - far better than my local comcast cable signal.

Their website is useless for support - they seem to provide nothing more than some marketing information - no firmware upgrades or even a manual.

However, for the less than $40 - it's not a horrible deal - if all you want to do is watch the local channels and record now and then (with a lot of human input to make sure it records on time).

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:

I do not have cable any longer and most TV antenna's are a piece of crap.  I was fortunate to get two very good TV Antenna's from Channel 9 here in my city of Denver.  I took a chance on buying this converter box but I was wary because I had bad luck with homeworx and I brought two of them only to have to trash them because they did not work as advertised at all.

I am very pleased with the Viewtv box and the follow up I received from the seller.  Try it you may like it too

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Doesn't work right.  Bad Remote Design
column8:
The general idea of this product is good - convert digital over-the-air TV signals to play on your old analog TV with the ability to add memory and record TV.  I bought it to be able to continue to use my old (but great) analog DVR, and it works for that.

Unfortunately, it's difficult to operate and the software for it sucks.  For example, when you set a recording to repeat "daily" the software sets the next recording in the series to record 6 days after the last recording, not 1 day as expected.  So, every day you have to correct the recording date for the upcoming recording or miss a recording.  It displays program descriptions of programs that are playing but the text of the descriptions is all broken up.  Also, if you press too many buttons while trying to figure out how to use it, it'll crash and you have to unplug it and plug it back in it to reboot it.  I have to do that almost every day.

The functions don't map well to the remote buttons.  For example, to delete a recording you hit "EPG", to go to full screen from the record screen, you hit the "Hold" button.  Huh?  It's like they bought a 3rd party remote and mapped the functions they needed as best they could to the buttons available on the remote.

The remote design is also bad.  The labels for the buttons at the top of the remote are above the buttons.  The labels for the buttons at the bottom of the remote are below the buttons.  It's confusing.  See picture.

One good thing I can say about this receiver is that I can use it to boost the signal to my TV.  The TV signal is more broken up when I don't route it through this product.  But that's not what the receiver is intended for.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
Recieved this as a gift about two weeks ago.  Set it up the same day and added a 128G usb key. So far I have no complaints other than the remote. The tuner works much better than the built in tuner in my TV and offers more features. The on screen displays are nice and large so they are readable. The aspect ratio seems to auto adjust which my TV didn't. The tuner is pretty sensitive and is gathering a few more channels that I didn't have on the built-in.  I tested pause/play DVR functionality and it works as expected.  I haven't been able to fully test all the timer recording yet though.

The one big drawback is the remote.  The layout is not intuitive and the buttons are all just small squares so it's easy to lose what you are looking for. I may try to address this with a nice universal remote but that adds to the cost.

Still worth every penny compared to cable/sat.

For some reason while trying to record a weekly program it will record the program fine, but then apparently it thinks a week is 10 days and schedules the next program 10 days later. So every week I have to set each program back to the right date. And yes it only uses military time, but just remember that 6:00 PM is 18:00 hours and work from there.  Another issue, I record a 2 hour block on Fox one night and a 2 hour block on CBS another night. The 2 hour Fox program plays back fine, but the CBS block will freeze and crash the PVR. It eventually resets, but I can't watch the CBS block through the PVR. Fortunately I have a USB port on my TV that I can use to watch the program. It's just a pain having to switch the cable back and forth.

column7: No subscription Digital TV (over the air) recording
column8:
Edited 6/15/17: I've dropped my rating to two stars simply because it doesn't last. The power supply is built into the unit and fails, taking the unit down with it when it goes. When it works, it's good and does what it says, but when the power supply melts, there's no way to save the unit. At the low price, it's pretty easy to replace, but that's not the point. I'm currently trying the RCA unit from Wal Mart that has an external power supply. Software is nearly identical, but their remote layout is pretty bad. But if the RCA unit lasts longer than a year we're ahead. The original review is below, and I originally gave the ViewTV box 4 stars, but I won't be buying another one based on power supply melt-downs.

If you want something to record digital over-the-air TV programs, this is it. We bought it along with a 128GB USB flash drive and it holds more programs than we've ever had on there at one time. Playback quality is very good (as good as the original broadcasts) and the remote control buttons are well laid out and easy to use. It only gets 4 stars, however, because if you bump the USB flash drive even the least little bit or if the Converter Box loses power, you have to re-format the flash drive and you lose all the programs saved up to that point. How sensitive? We dust AROUND the unit so we don't even brush against the flash drive with a dusting cloth.

Having said that, I'm glad we bought it. We don't have TIVO and once purchased, this is free and without any kind of monthly subscription fee. That didn't make sense seeing as how we dumped cable to get rid of those bills. I'd recommend this easily - just be careful with the dusting cloth.  : )

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
This little converter/PVR has so much promise and potential.  Unfortunately, poor build quality and flimsy construction conspired to shorten it's life, in my case about 2 years.  It does its job pretty well, and the interface, though odd (press "HOLD" to go full screen?) works pretty well.  I was getting used to the non-conforming device when a modest storm took it out.  When nothing else was affected and no power outages were reported, the transformer in the input rectifier was fried and irreparable.  I don't think I'll buy another.

update 5/12/16:  I had noticed that fast forwarding was failing, and while that alone was aggravating, if it happened in the 45th minute of a 60 minute program, you were forced to start the fast forward search again from the beginning, and the image on the screen made this oh-so-tedious and time consuming.  Well it happened one last time and I pulled it out and stomped on it, putting it, and me, out of misery.  Don't bother.  One star... so much promise!

column7: CUT THE CORD! But wait... consider the facts.
column8: UPDATE: Warning the recording feature does not work properly. Set a show to record daily and it fails to record the next day, displaying the next record time as 6 days later, same with weekly. I contacted ViewTV (got product from SuperDeal), they have yet to return my calls for support. Reception people keep telling me they are taking messages for the support 'person', and then I never get a call back. With a good antennae, this converter adds the correct amount of something extra I had not anticipated. The box shows the signal strength it's receiving. In my living room, box #1 gets all the HD channels available over the air. From 2.1 to 65.4. That's all the channels you can imagine. Cooking shows, kids, movies (old and newer), craft, international... and more. The best part... it's FREE! ViewTV has that something extra I didn't read in the description and still don't know if it's there. It's a DVR man! Pop in a 32GB or better a 64GB flash drive and you can pause live TV. Record shows, and a full guide. This stuff is subject to your area and whether or not the channel broadcasts it's guide, but for free it's pretty sweet. I now have channels in HD that my cable provider only broadcasted in SD. I could get things in HD if I paid for it, but of course they don't tell you (this is some channels mind-you), are already free over the air in HD. This sounds like an ad, but it's not, I'm a real 49 year old dude in PA, USA, who has successfully cut the cord. To get some of the premium stuff, look in to *SlingTV, Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Fire. With these additions you'll have more than what you need. One small catch... you must have a good unlimited internet connection for the premium stuff. But not for VIEWTV! Viewtv At-163 ATSC Digital TV Converter Box and Media Player w/ Recording PVR Function / HDMI Out / Coaxial Out / Composite Out / USB Input * - Enjoy! https://www.sling.com https://www.netflix.com http://www.hulu.com http://prime.amazon.com

column7: Fairly good with a lot of bugs
column8:
Update 10/12/2015 More bad news: Series recording set to repeat Daily sets the next recording to 6 days out, WTF?

I fooled the system into dealing with the "recording after midnight" bug (never stops) by setting two recordings... like 23:35-23:59 and 00:00-00:37. But you miss a minute this way.
Changed to two stars

Original review:

Not bad for the price, but get ready to struggle  lot to figure out how to operate it without accurate instructions. It does receive and use the QAM in-the-clear (broadcast networks) stations on the Verizon Fios network in  the Tampa area. You can delete the unwanted channels (scrambled) after auto-learning them all but it is tedious. It took me about 30 minutes of clicking to get all the ones off I didn't want (scrambled or blank). The manual says to use the "04" sequence to specify deletion, but just the "4" key worked for me, so many fewer keystrokes were required.

Problems:
 Wont stop recording if the recording period spans midnight. This happens with the Tonight shows, of course (23:37 to 00:35). The result is that the next day, it is still recording and the file is huge in size. The box asks you if you want to exit recording...If you left it for longer it would fill up your drive easily.

No guide for the QAM channels on Fios.

You can rename the channels to something sensible like "CBS" but I find that the box sometimes renames it back to the original gibberish numbers the next time it's started. This only happens for some channels, don't know why.

column7: quality, well made digital TV converter box
column8:
Well made unit, all metal construction with rubber feet on bottom. Very nice remote, large with nice well labeled buttons. RCA jacks on back accommodate older tv sets. HDMI output for new HDTV's...Software is rather hard to setup options for someone unfamiliar with this type of unit.
I was able to auto tune quite a few local channels 2-13 on my cable connection, in HD. Beautiful picture on my Samsung HDTV.
My reason for not giving 5 stars is I could not record any program more than 1 hr without problems with siezeup of recorder needing power reset to clear. Also problems with playback. Tried several different memory sticks USB hard drives. I could not get a  3" USB powered hard drive to work at all.  Only a external powered large USB backup drive worked, but not reliably.
I suspect unit needs firmware & soft ware updates.  I have not been able to get updated files yet. I recommend this unit for someone that wants to eliminate cable co. set top box rental on basic cable connection. With updates this is a nice unit.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Not useable for a set and forget PVR. Requires constant attention. Try it - Amazon has a great (free) return policy.
column8:
I returned the device, as it failed miserably as a set and forget PVR.
There are some good reviews for this product. It could be that I received an outdated unit. Otherwise people are either not using it as a PVR should be used, or the good reviews where paid for by the seller.
A much better device is the Mediasonic HW180STB HomeWorx HDTV Digital Converter Box with Media Player and Recording PVR Function, Dolby Digital, HDMI Out. This device had many of the same issues before it was updated. Now works great as a set and forget PVR.

These are the reasons why I gave this product a one star rating. All these issues occurred within the first week of use. The main issue is that it is advertised as a PVR (Programmable Video Recorder) device, but that function is mostly useless and there is no support to resolve issues. If someone had listed these issues as shown here, I would likely have looked to buy another product. Some issues are very blatant while others arise due to temporary interference on channels. Unfortunately, there will always be temporary interference and PVR devices should handle that possibility.

Annoying problems:
1. Resets to factory defaults unexpectedly (about twice a week)
2. Fails to find recorded programs (about three times a week - Reboot fixes problem)
3. Fails to decode some EPG information that other devices decode w/o a problem
4. Cannot watch a recorded program while it is recording another.
5. It does not allow for programming just week days (skipping weekends), it can only do: "Once", "Daily", or "Weekly", AND WEEKLY DOES NOT RECORD EVERY 7 DAYS (SEE BELOW)
6. Sometimes the recordings abort prematurely (When channel signal has temporary interference)
7. Does not allow hiding unwanted channels
8. Creates cryptic file names instead of trying to use the names of the recorded program
9. Often locks up inexplicably then self reboots after 10 minutes
10. The digital display is pretty much useless, as it does not indicate when the PVR is recording a program nor does it show the actual channel the PVR is recording (ex. Channel 21.1 shows C001, which is useless)
11. It waits a minute before the recorder starts recording a scheduled program, thus the start of the recorded program is lost. Most programs today start right on time
12. It only allows 30 scheduled recordings to be "booked". When it does not allow repeat recording for certain days, 30 becomes inadequate
13. Uses only military time
14. Can only delete one recording at a time, after watching several hours of shows, you have to delete each watched show individually. Then after deleting, it always jumps back to the first page where you have to page down again to continue deleting
15. Mostly senseless remote button layout and senseless button functions when navigating menus (ex. Press <EPG> to highlight program to be deleted, then unspecified <OK> to delete and <OK> again to confirm
16. Sometimes get disk error when trying to delete recorded programs (Reboot resolves the issue)
17. It stops recording without notice if the device is powered off
18. Sometimes refuses record when record button is pressed (Reboot resolves the issue)

Showstopper problems:
1. Often fails to recognize the hard drive (about every other day - Reboot fixes problem)
2. Often skips recording scheduled shows (No disk Detected or when sitting on a bad signal where it fails to switch to the scheduled channel)
3. Does not list every HD channel when trying to "Add" (schedule) a program manually. Thus some channels w/o EPG info can never be scheduled for recording
4. When scheduling a program to record "Weekly", the device schedules the next event 12 or 13 days in advance. Clearly, this is a major showstopper, as it should count by seven days for weekly programs
5. No technical support - You can email them, leave them a voice message, but do not expect a response, as they apparently have no answers for the many problems

All in all, It works fine as a digital converter and on-the-fly recording, but fails miserably as a "set and forget" PVR.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
Nice idea, poor implementation.

If you are looking for a simple HD ATSC / Digital converter box for an old TV or computer monitor, this is fine.
If you want the DVR functions, think again.

I have owned a magnavox mdr557h (DVD/HDD recorder with tuner), a Tivo, and this.

The Tivo was the best until the tv tuner sort of died, and so did the "unlimited suscription" I had.  Out of warranty, out of luck.  The magnavox works more like old VHS VCR - you program by date, time and channel number, no guide, you provide the label for each recording (or set of recordings), the only difference is that it records to a hard disk (or DVDs) instead of a bunch of VHS tapes.  Also, it is SD only, downconverts HD signals to SD, which surprisingly is still very good quality.

Now on to the product - the ViewTV sounds good, if it actually did everything well.  However, for everything it does, there is a glitch:
1. Scheduled recordings - time: this thing relies on the tv-station's clock.  Unfortunately TV stations don't care much about the "time signal"  they send, so the time in this device keeps jumping.  It would be nice if it had its own internal clock (my cheap $20 casio keeps more accurate time than this).

2. Scheduled recordings - day: for some reason, if you select to record a program on a weekly basis, it makes it every 5 days or so (not 7 days!)  The calendar system on this is all screwed.  Again, if it had its own independent internal clock/calendar, this wouldn't matter.

3. Scheduled recordings - playback: Sure you can advance commercials, but frequently it gets stuck while doing it.  And it is not just a matter of hitting a button to "unfreeze".  You need to go to the device and unplug it, which in turn erases all your timer programming (scheduled tasks).

4. If you are recording, you can't do anything else with it.  Not even check/set your schedules or browse the guide.

5. You can only browse the guide for one channel at a time.  For example, you can see what's showing on ABC today, but you can't see what shows are airing at 8pm (not even for your favorites).

6. Incorrect date when selecting a program for recording.  If you choose to record a program from the guide, it will apparently set it right, but then when you check the recording schedule, it is all wrong.

7. Can't set a label for timer programming, nor does it set it from the guide.  For example, if you want to record Castle every Monday, the recordings show up as WPLG-201507202200 (tv station, plus date and time in military format).  If you record 10 shows a week, that's 10 lines of programming that you need to decipher if you want to find a particular show.

8. The user interface and remote are a joke.  Hard to find buttons, inconsistent labels, mispellings, conflicts with other devices (press "2" and my hdmi switcher changes device).

9. Support is non-existent.  For sales they sure answered one question I posted, but after that, nothing.

I give it two stars because as a Digital TV converter box works well and when it worked, it did record in HD, neat.  As a DVR it has potential.  But like similar boxes that seem to be clones (iview, mediasonic homeworkx, ematic) they all have the same glitches.  Once all the glitches are removed (if ever), this would easily be a five start product that would send ChannelMaster's DVR+ off the market.

I returned mine since DVR was the main purpose of my purchase.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
I attached an old 500gb HD in a OEM external case to the front USB port and went thru the PVR setting to find the hard drive and it worked fine but after 2 days the hard drive needed to be re-discovered again in order to record or watch my shows.
In general the ViewTV AT-163 works but I do get frustrated by those mysterious hangs where I have not choice but to power off/on the ViewTV box and start over what I was doing before the hang.
The remote works but sluggishly, you need to slow down and be very deliberate on your button depressions. Pausing will become a way of life.
Flipping to full screen from preview mode sometimes causes hangs and needs a power clear to fix.
Quality of the recordings are fine, but really depends on how good your antenna is and if it's pointed at the broadcasting tower correctly.  IMHO, I would switch to a Omni Directional TV antenna to pick up the signals from 3 broadcast towers that are at compass direction of 95,127 and 156 degrees.  The ViewTV signal receivers can not show a descent picture on your TV unless your TV antenna performs as well.  Lousy antenna means lousy quality on the ViewTV box.
I move my external HD back to my computer to copy the recorded shows (MTS file format. Delete what I don;t need while on my computer and re-attach my external hard drive with a re-discover process on the ViewTV box to be sure it learns of the hard drive and detected the amount of available drive space.
The EPG button gives you the upcoming shows and times but it seems to not show more than a half days worth.  I found that if you use the record weekly you in effect get to record a series if it's at the same time and channel each week.
This reminds me of my old tape VCR days but the ViewTV AT-163 is a better box.  I plan to keep this box and not return it, it's good enough to use as a back up  BASIC PVR with no frills.  I'll keep looking for another PVR that can record 4 shows at the same time.

column8:
Very interesting device, wish it would work without the "odd" errors.  I gave it three stars because of all the functions the unit has.  With all the operations this unit can do, one would think it would sell for a higher price.  Having the program guide is a big plus.  Being able to rename recordings is great.  A con on renaming is you can not rename the OTA channels it picks up.  Does very well in a scan to find what is in your area.  Another odd problem I discovered was with a 3-1/2" hard drive.  When recording a program, the drive made a loud clicking and the drive was very hot.  I switched over to a usb powered drive and this problem did not show.  I don't know if it had anything to do with the different drives, but I did not like the noise or the heat.  The most annoying issue is with play back of a recorded program.  If you fast forward past the commercials there are times when the unit will lock up and the only way to fix the problem it to pull the plug.  If you are going to stop playback when in the middle or so of a two hour recording, best to check the time mark.  Several times restarting the playback at a different time, it may jump to that mark or it may just start over  Then you have the problem of fast forwarding to where you left off.
The unit does the job for OTA viewing and recording to some extent.  The problems it has can get to be a drag.
No recommendation to purchase or not.  I will leave that up to you.  It is good and bad....

column7: A BATCH OF BAD UNITS ? APPARENTLY YES
column8: As a service tech with lots of experience I would say that a large number of these are suffering from a production problem. Lots of reports online and on Amazon.com that these units lockup after an attempt to fast forward. And it true as the unit I received would not fast forward at all. It would lockup so badly that the unit had to be unplugged to reboot and work again. Also many of the recordings did not complete or would not play past half of the recording. Bad batch of recorder decoder chips, its possible, or a program glitch. I have another brand that the software looks like it was written by the same company or individual and it works fine. Returned it and ordered another one. If this one does not work when I get it, that will pretty much say these are not so good. The unit is great had it worked and I love the remote as it is far better than the remotes to most of these units. My other units remote is horrible to use. UPDATE 7-6-2015 received a replacement item. IT WILL NOT WORK EITHER apparently what I suspected is true. All these units were produced with defective parts or programming. 2 OUT OF 2 DEFECTIVE I will not purchase another one of these that is for sure.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8: Good OTA recorder for the price.  The menu system is a little clunky but certainly navigable.  The system instructions say you can connect an external HD via USB (front panel).  I connected a spare 1TB drive, thinking "that'll do it."  The external drive was in NTSB format and the unit stores media in FAT32 format.  FAT32 is limited to 32GB partitions.  That being said, a flash drive of 32GB or less will be sufficient as long as the write time will keep up.  I placed an old spare 4GB flash drive on it and it worked perfectly.  It records 40 minutes of HD so, from that, you can figure about 10 minutes of HD per gig.  Therefore a 32GB flash should hold about 320 minutes.  Not bad for a (no monthly fee) OTA PVR.  I'm happy.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Great Value for a OTA recorder and digital channel converter
column8:
Chuck says:  Ok, I am impressed.  For the money this is a very good piece of equipment.  I recently "cut the cable" and moved my TV source to Over The Air (OTA) TV and internet services (Amazon, Netflix, Hulu, Sling, etc).  It has been an excellent choice so far, but I have missed my DVR for shows I want to see later.  So while researching antenna sourced DVRs/PVRs, my choices were $200 and up-  then I found the Viewtv AT 163.  While it is primarily sold as a digital converter box, it also has PVR capabilities through your own USB portable HDD.
  Out of the box, it was small and light (remote is so light weight that it feels toy-ish).  I did not need this as a converter, but I tested it and it works really well, with the exception that it cannot seem to find one of my local stations, but all the other digital/HD channels look really good.  It pulled in 27 channels, where as my digital TV found 28 using the same masted antenna.
Pro's:
  Quickly set up, searched and found local channels
  Has ability to exclude channels via manual set up
  Has ability to set "Favorites" for quick channel jumping
  1 button channel menu with limited current show info
  Another button with detailed show info and current/future schedule
  You can set recording for a future show (but not far future)
  Surprisingly good clarity and no obvious signal loss in channel reception
  Playback of recordings are just as clear as the original (just like your cable DVR)
  Has ability to pause live TV (via time shifting)
  Records to your personal Hard Drive.  This is a Pro because it lowered the initial price and gives the ability to change HDDs when needed and you can remove the HDD and take it with you traveling to watch on your laptop, etc.  I bought a 1GB Toshiba portable HDD for about $50 and I can use it on any of my systems.
  Connections out include HDMI (I get 720i HD picture on most of my stations), AV (L/R Audio + Video RCA pins), and RF Coax out.  Also there is a USB connection to connect a HDD or USB thumb drive.

CON's:
  Layout of buttons on remote not intuitive, will take time to get proficient.
  Guide/Schedule is a bit rough, but it is dependent on info encoded in the broadcast TV signal so it's more of an adjustment from cable than a negative on this equipment
  Recording, pausing and other similar functions sometimes take a second or two to kick in.  Response to using the remote control buttons are just generally slow.
  Records one show at a time (again, not fair to compare this to $300 multi-tuner DVRs)
 I deducted a star because of the remote feel and the slow response to button pushing on the remote.

OVERALL:
  I am impressed.  I expected this would be - at worst -a digital converter box for an old TV in the shop---and at best a cheap gadget way to record off the air- and one step away from my old VCR stored in the closet.  Instead it is a very workable recording option for shows or sporting events.  I have a new toy that turns out to be everyday useful and I can record my football without falling behind in my Saturday yard work.
  For $35, it is an excellent buy.  Yes, it does not compare with $300 DVRs or your cable/satellite company's set top boxes, but for OTA, it is an excellent value and a solid low cost/low frills option to the higher cost/higher frills Tablo or ChannelMaster DVRs.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
I have purchased this unit, based on reviews that said it had a sensitive tuner. I have  tried the iView 3500, the Homeworx 180.  The Homeworx died after 6 months of light use.  So I was looking for something to replace it.  The other boxes only picked up 24 of the 39 channels available, this one only picked up 18.  So I thought I'd use it on my QAM Cable channels, but it is not good at that either.  This is the only QAM tuner in my house, that doesn't filter out the scrambled channels.  So it finds all 500 instead of the 80 unscrambled channels.  In order to use this, you need to know the subchannels, the iview and my TVs all use the same scheme as my cable provider, but not this box, you need to know what channel is the clear qam equivalent of 13.  So you need to type 60-13 to get to 13.  Not a huge problem, if there were a way to use channel up and down to find them.  But you have to wade through 400 scrambled channels to find them!  The iView used the correct qam numbers, picked up more channels, priced lower.

Pro - Nice Remotes

Con- Weak ATSC Tuner
Doesn't filter out Scrambled QAM on cable
Doesn't use Cable numbers for tuning

Update:  I pulled this box out of storage to use it with a projector on QAM

The converter arrived on time and it was simply "plug and play". I bought it for my motor home multi-media system with surround sound. column8: It's amazing that you can get something this good for the price. I'll have to see how it holds up but it works for me. I'm in Southwest Florida. I'm using a Wineguard antenna with a built in amp and I get all my locals locked in. I use Comcast for my internet provider. I use OOMA for 2 phone lines and a Magic Jack for a dedicated fax line. I stream Amazon Prime, Netflix , etc. Now that I can record network shows, I am so done with cable.  UPDATE........I guess I was wrong about this item. It locks up and you have to unplug it to get it to boot up or do anything. It seemed to work great at first but now that it doesn't and I cant return it, It will become a paperweight. It's Pretty much useless. I'll try a more reliable brand ( and I'll pay for it ) like Channel Master. You win some, you lose some.  Part 3--- I started using it again. It works OK until you try to fast forward at too great a speed and then the box locks up. Sometimes you can't turn it off without pulling the plug. IT does record well but if you try to zip through the ads, you have to re- boot and start the program from the beginning. It's better than I thought it was.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Wish I'd Bought This One First
column8: This is an amazing digital converter and recorder with lots of output options.  I ordered a different converter first for the same price, and it didn't work at all.  I tried all of my antennas and TVs with it.  A light on the front just blinked and blinked and the box didn't connect to anything successfully.  I had to return it.  This converter worked immediately when I hooked it up.  It is currently connecting a digital antenna to a very old television.  The picture is even better than when I had cable.  This digital converter also has a program guide that shows you what is on each channel and what is coming up, which is amazing to me!  It makes me want to get one for all of my TVs with digital antennas now.  It also has a recording feature.  All you have to do is click on a program in the guide to schedule a recording.  It's a small box.  You can tell the box and the remote are well-constructed.  The output options provide ways to connect to even the most up-to-date devices with HDMI, and it comes with an HDMI cable.  The first one I purchased did not.  I couldn't be more pleased with this converter's performance and highly recommend it to those who are looking to cut the cord!

column7: Disappointing - did not record as planned and missed multiple recordings.
column8:
Very promising alternative to the channel master dvr, which is 10x the cost.  Good remote, easy setup, menu was good.  The USB port is in the front - I don't know why - and the display is arbitrary - channel 001 is the first channel it finds, not the actual channel you are on.

Tuning was great - it picked up multiple channels and the picture was great.  The EPG was decent, but scheduling took a bit of planning - it did not like a recording starting before midnight and ending after.  The big issue is that it consistently missed scheduled recordings.  The USB storage devices (I tried 3 different types) would randomly not show up while attached.  I set the unit to record NCIS every Tuesday for 3 weeks, as well as some random shows at 2am and 7am.  It recorded randomly - I got 1 episode of NCIS and 2 or 3 shows during the AM time frame.

I tried 3 USB sticks - ranging from 2GB to 16GB, a brand new 1TB WD USB drive (powered by USB), and an external 320GB USB drive that had it's own power supply.  After contacting Viewtv via email - I received no response and returned the unit.  Maybe cable/satellite have us by the necks for DVR - as tivo is $15/month for service and the channel master is $300.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
3/8/2106
I had to come back and warn everyone. DO NOT BUY this product. I've nothing but problems with this box. Now it refuses to power up if anything is plugged into the usb port. If you can't plug a flash drive you can't record. Worthless piece of junk.

I wish I could rate this box higher. But, it has a serious flaw. The tuner is sub-par. If you live close to TV stations you're trying to pick up, then this box should work fine. But, if you live some distance from the transmitters or live in a multi-city market (like I do) you may have some reception problems with this box. It only picks up and holds the strongest of signals. It has trouble holding any signal that falls below around 55%.

But, that aside the box works pretty well. I only bought a 3.0, 32g flash drive to use with this unit.

Some small things you'll need to know. The unit seems have some trouble figuring out daylight savings time. But,if you're using the EPG to set your recordings, you'll be setting it by program title and it won't matter. When setting a recording, be sure and scroll down and highlight "record" on the onscreen menu, then press "ok". If you don't do this the box may not record your show.

Also, when you call up the recorded programs list: after you highlight the show you want to watch, don't press "ok", instead press "play". Pressing "ok" makes the program play in a preview box. You're supposed to able to press "hold" to make it fullscreen, but this doesn't work all the time. Sometime the box will just freeze it you do that. And you'll have to unplug it reset it.

Overall, it works pretty well. Considering it records in HD and it's so cheap, making it worth buying. Just be aware it's not perfect.

Small update: DO NOT turn "Daylight Saving Time" on. This box is totally confused by daylight saving time. If you enable it the box will record one hour late every time.

This converter box is cheap and it works, but it's a bad design.  Worst is that Mute puts up a permanent, stationary, full intensity indicator on the screen that will cause burn-in effects.  The mute issue alone makes this converter box unacceptable.  Other than that, it takes 15 seconds to boot, the channel display is both annoying and useless, the remote control is laggy, and it forgets settings when powered off.

The burn-in issue can be worked around somewhat by using the auto-shutoff feature to make sure the display doesn't stay on for many hours with the Mute indicator on.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
I had to cancel my cable recently (suddenly had to find room in the budget for a car payment where there wasn't any room...).  I have a 15-year-old CRT television that was most definitely NOT digital ready.  I have Hulu and Prime instant video through my Wii console, but I wanted to be able to watch current news and local weather without being online.  So I ordered this converter.

This was a breeze to set up.  The instruction manual could be a little better edited (instructions for HDMI and other types of connections get mixed in together) but I was able to figure it out anyway.  I obviously can't use an HDMI connection with my old TV, but there is an included red-yellow-white composite cable and that worked with my TV (my TV is not capable of stereo sound so I just don't plug in the red plug and it still works).  There is also a "signal out" connector that looks like a coaxial cable would connect to it, so you can probably use that as an output option to your TV if you'd like.  (You'd need to supply the coaxial cable.)

When I first plugged this in, I got a screen prompting me to choose a language.  English was the default, so I pushed the "OK" button on the remote and this converter immediately went into scan mode and started picking up TV channels.  After that, I could just watch.  It set channel numbers up so they're all right in a row, so I don't have to skip through lots of channel numbers of static like in the analog days.  (On the other hand, you can forget about local channel numbers as the numbers on the front of the box don't match up to anything identifiable.)  Scanning was a little slow, but there was a progress bar on the screen.

You will need the following items to make this work:

(1) An antenna.  Amazon has plenty of these for sale.  I have one of the indoor HDTV ones and it pairs perfectly with this converter box.
(2) Two AAA batteries for the remote (it does not come with batteries).

At any rate, I've had the TV on for several hours in the background and I am getting the expected picture and sound quality for my television.

This unit apparently records video if you have a USB memory stick.  I have no interest in this function so I have not tested it (I generally only watch series television on DVD and, at any rate, I can catch older things with Hulu or Prime in most instances), but it is available.

The box is pretty small, about 8.5 by 5.5 by 1.5 inches.  It gets a little warm while running but not any more than you would expect from a cable box or something similar.

Overall, this does exactly what I wanted it to do and it was easy to set up.

column7: Good tuner, slightly quirky controls and menus, horrible 90-day warranty with $17 service charge.
column8:
Tuner is fairly sensitive and allows switching through channels quickly, which isn't always the case with many HD tuners or even old LD analog tuners except rotary mechanical ones (ask somebody over 50 what a mechanical tuner is).

Another sample of this same product would occasionally lock up when in a menu and required power down/power up to reset.

The channel setup menu doesn't include channel editing, which is found in the separate Program menu.  That caused me some frustration.

Many functions can be done without the remote, through the buttons on the front panel, but I couldn't figure out how to make timed recordings with just them.

The warranty is terrible, only 90 days and requires enclosing a check or money order for $17.  I think someone at ViewTV said the $17 was to discourage returns, but I couldn't understand their pronunciation.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
This is very nice converter box and has good sensitive tuner.
I got this at good price with promotion code making it excellent value.

Tuning is good, shows signal strength and also pulls EPG information very well. I was able to add an harddrive for recording and it works well with portable HDD.

Positives list:
1. Very sensitive tuner :
 Compared to all other tuners I have, LG TV Tuner, Boxee TV tuner, Silicon Dust HD Homerun(2 units), Pinnacle TV Tuner, Hauppuage WinTV PVR, this is most sensitive and able to tune most channels, some I did not even know that exist. I bought this for Theater room Projector to watch live TV while other.
2. Very small unit: Fits in very small places, behind TV etc.
3. Has pass thru output for RF. Means you can tune both this unit and TV connected to RF pass thru(There are few options there).
4. Able to pull full available EPG information available for each channel. Simple info can show current program info, and upcoming program info also.
5. Shows signal strength and signal quality info which lets you position antenna for your fav channels. My LG tv is does this, but it is buried so deep, and I need to go into manual tuning mode and select channel and wait for few seconds to show that info.  This unit it is much easier.

6. There is no monthly fee to see the guides like some units. For me TV Guide app in iPad shows all info I need. But this show todays EPG for given channel.

Coming to issues:

1. EPG information is shows for current channel that is tuned. That means if you are in channel 13, you can only see EPG information for channel 13.
2. Live TV pause is bit crude, it is lagging behind quite few seconds. When I click pause it takes a while to get into Live Record/Pause Mode and lags behind few second. This is not a problem with my LG TV(Yes my LG TV has built in PVR function with a small hack). Not a problem with Media Center from HD Homeruns.

3. Remote is so, so, (not too bad). But not a problem as I use my Logitech Harmony.
4. Upscaling is below average. It has problems esp with Reds. Some of the SD channels (sub channels of main channels) are transmitted in 480i, and this upscales to 1080i and reds look pretty bad with some tearing. But If this annoying I simply change output to 480i on those channel and let TV upscale that.

You might be wondering with all these negatives how it got 4 stars. The main purpose of this unit for me is Live TV feed for my projector. That it serves well, but because of other pit falls, I gave 4 stars.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
First off I would like to say is that yes you can use a hdmi to vga adapter to use this on an old computer monitor and turn it into an hd tv, just make sure you get a decent adapter with an audio out and externally powered is better but not necessary.  I used the PWOW 1080P Mini HDMI Male To VGA RGB Converter Video Adapter With Audio and it works great.
  Also this works excellently as digital media player and is capable of playing just about any video file I have thrown at it, including flv's.
  With that said this is not the most user friendly device but well worth the $48 it cost, and it is easy to learn after a bit of playing around with it.
  It does detect ALL cable channels encrypted and unencrypted but does not differentiate between them so you will have to delete which channels you cannot watch.
  You also might want to keep this device always on as it is somewhat although not to difficult to recover your setting once it restarts.  It does not delete your settings though, it just kinda hides them from you and is pretty hard to explain but easy to figure out.
  The games are kinda weird but cool, occasionally I will play the old-school tetris and such.
  This device can also be tweaked by electronics techies for purposes I will not mention here.

Normally I would drop down a star because of the nonexistent web support but this device way exceeded my expectations, it is very solidly old school constructed and I am very very happy with it and plan on buying another.

BTW WARNING remember to peel off the plastic coating or the device will most definitely overheat.

column8:
Don't actually own this product yet, however; I own two similar. Read the featured reviews...together they are very comprehensive.
Having it to use as a tuner is very useful. The PVR scheduler is VERY sensitive and DOES NOT allow you to change the name of the recording until AFTER the recording is completed.
Use computer to do multiple changes to a recorded program; including deletion. REMEMBER you can only do one things at a time.
TIME: you can not set the time...therefore you can't control the timer. It takes 10-40 seconds for you recording to START and sometimes, out-of-the-blue it'll run 5-mins ahead of the current time. The EPG is for the current channel and usually not more than 12-hours ahead of time. If the recording missed the "TIMED" recording, it's disappeared from the schedule. Think of it more of an enhanced VCR and less of a PVR, you'll be fine.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Great Value For the Price. Great High Def Picture Via HDMI To Your HDTV.
column8:
First I want to say that the first box I received did not work correctly immediately. The box kept failing to maintain recognition that my external drives were in fact present, no matter how many different types I used. There was surely something wrong with the ViewTV. (The ViewTV I received had software version installed from last month.)

I called the ViewTV company and they were really great. The nice tech support guy agreed I had to have something wrong with the unit...and he rushed me out a replacement. The replacement works much better...and interestingly its software version is dated 7 months ago.

I think the ViewTV at $50 is really a great value. (And I was impressed with the customer service the company provided.)

Running the antenna channel scan is relatively fast. The picture quality on my replacement box is stellar. Moving through all the settings menus is very easy and straightforward. Everything is easy to figure out.

When you think about the box's limitations, as pointed out by some very helpful reviews here, you must keep in mind the very reasonable price.

For $50 you get a good over the air box with a good tuner that sends a great picture via HDMI to your TV. You can time shift your viewing, if you plug in a drive to the USB port, and you can record programs to said drive.

For $50 you cannot expect multiple tuners or a great TV Guide. But at least you get to see the very basic guide info the broadcasters send down with their OTA signal. (My two HDTV's on their own do not show the OTA program info, which is very disappointing.)

For cable cutters out there on a budget, this box is definitely something you should consider. It delivers really well exactly what it promises.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8: I could not obtain HD TV over a satellite in my area so I wanted to convert non HD TV from my cable provider into HD TV. This little box works great! My only purpose for obtaining cable was to watch live sports. Everything else is streamed. So if you are using this and only watching TV it may not be exactly what you need. It changes around all you channels from the cable provider as it searches for available channels, I made a cheat sheet so I would know to go to 32-3 or whatever for my favorite channels. 2. ESPN has their app for streaming. Overall it did the trick to get my HD Sports on the major broadcasting channels.

column7: Pay Extra, Looks Alone Are Worth It
column8:
Gorgeous picture. But very distracting. Every pimple and facial irregularity. Even could see ear fuzz (outside the lobes) on a Law and Order close up.

The receiver is very sensitive. I have a whole house antenna system with this guy second in line after a two way splitter.... splitter, DVD recorder, ViewTV, computer HDTV tuner card. The other side of the two way splitter... Channel Master 7000Pal, TV

Great looks that beat the cheaper competition. The seven (7) buttons on the front panel allow basic operations without the remote. Well worth the extra ten to fifteen bucks.

And yes, the user manual is crappy. And yes, it's so light it can be pulled off a shelf by the weight of its cables. That's what cable ties are for. Anchor its cables to a heavier machine... Channel Master 7000. Don't like the internal clock and channel display but I'm much happier with its recordings than I am with any of my other recorders... computer internal HDTV tuner not included.

column7: Highly functional, but cheap. Died after 6 months. Bought another.
column8:
UPDATE: The unit just died. I used it for about 6 months. All of a sudden, the power won't even turn on. But it's only $35, so I just bought another one. I almost got the $300 upgrade, but that one doesn't have an antenna pass-through. It's nice to be able to use the tuner on this and on my TV so I can record one thing and watch another.

PREVIOUS REVIEW: This device is working great. Been watching all my TV through this. The tuner is better than on my TV, so I get channels I didn't get before.  I can set it to record shows while I'm away, and while I'm watching live TV, I can pause it, which I love because I never have to watch commercials again. I just pause it for a while, go off and do something else, then come back and fast forward through the annoying commercials.

However, this is a basic, bare bones, and pretty "cheap" piece of equipment. First of all, you have to get some sort of storage, which adds to the cost considerably. I got a 1TB hard drive because I got tired of running out of space just using a flash drive. Now I'm able to record a whole weekend of football, but it cost like twice as much as I had planned to spend.

The other thing is that it it feels cheap. The buttons on the remote are really strangely labeled and don't correspond with the commands you want to use. So, in order to go from the menu window, where you select the show you want to playback, to full-screen playback mode (watching the show), you have to hit a button called "hold". To delete a show, you press button "EPG" (???) Couldn't they have just put different labels on the remote buttons? It's weird. But the directions are clear on the screen which button to press, so it's not a problem.

Finally, the USB port was just sort of hot-glued to the circuit board, so when I tried plugging in my hard drive, the socket pushed back inside the unit. I had to open the case and find it to plug my drive in. Kind of janky. But still highly functional!

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Great little unit overall, but why do I keep getting something different from what is pictured?
column8:
Let me start off by saying I am giving a 4 star review for the product, but I am currently trying to get the product actually pictured. What is pictured looks like a white text display, "modern" looking button symbols and general attractiveness. What I keep receiving is the 2nd picture which is an orange text and a display that is not as attractive looking. I was more upset because the first picture looked great and I was let down when I opened the box. Working with seller, Amazon and contact on View TV site now to resolve.

That aside, I really don't understand some of the negative reviews. I think the user interface is quite simple to use. I did not look at the manual at all, so I consider it somewhat intuitive. Want to record a show? Press the EPG button for the guide, select the show and record. Really that simple. Want to make it "complicated" go to the menu, then USB, then setup recording through there (still simple). Before that all I had to do was setup what I was going to record to and run the auto-tuning. I installed a jump drive, formatted it via the View TV interface and set that as the recording media.

I did the TV scan, it picked up all the channels my TV could and reception was great. I see reviews on here talking about issues with the reception, but there are so many variables that go into this that I have learned in the process of "cutting the cord" with cable. Granted, there could be issues with the box causing this, but there is a good chance there are issues with how people connect these (types of cables, splitters, routing, etc.). These issues can come with any device. I went from 22 channels to 30 channels on this same TV setup the day I installed the View TV only by changing my TV cable to a quad shield RG6 with some good compression ends, then I put a new compression end on the cable in the wall and removed my 90 deg turn. My front room had less than 16 channels and I changed from RG59 cable to the same quad shield RG6 to get up to 30. If people are using incorrect cables and splitters in an area that picks up a lot of noise, this can cause a lot of problems.

If you want to view the program you recorded, press the USB button, find the show and start playing. Again, very simple. For those looking to purchase a low cost option, I think this is a great piece for $50. Now I can record OTA programs with this at weird hours and still have shows to watch when I am wanting to.

My first interaction with recording was looking through the guide, finding some shows I liked that came on 3 hours later and then setting it to record (2) 30 minute segments. I turned everything off and left, when I came home the flash drive was flashing and it was recording. I checked the files on my PC as well as through the View TV and they played great (haven't watch start to finish yet only a few minutes). You will have to manually change DST if using the automatic clock so the times are right.

Edit: I was able to find the pass through option for cable in the settings after opening the manual (shame on me should have looked there first). I just was not clear on the terminology.

Overall this does exactly what I need it to, minus needing to split the signal coming in. Luckily I did not lose too much signal. I am impressed with the interface and features of this for the price. I would (have have) definitely recommend this if you are not as picky as I am about getting the "cool" looking one.

column7: Great digital tuner that can record and pause tv shows
column8: My trusty Samsung SIR-T165 terrestrial receiver finally died, leaving my home theater without any OTA media.  I found the ViewTV AT-163 that kind of looked like my old T165.  Noticing the great reviews, and the pics look similar to my old box, I ordered the AT-163 without hesitation.  I knew the box would be small and not rack mountable but upon arrival, I was shock at how small the actual device was.  I was leery of the quality but proceeded to hook it up to my receiver and scan channels.  Any suspicions I had quickly melted away.  The tuner was more sensitive than the old T165.  Channels that came in on my other sets are now available in my HT.  The OTA viewer guide is very useful, giving you similar experience of Dish with upcoming shows and descriptions.  What I like the most is how easy it was to add time-shift and program recording.  All you need is a usb hard drive and you are all set.  Pausing live tv is a snap though initially a bit slow as there is a need to spin up the HD, but once paused, you can play and pause the live event without noticeable delay.  There seems to only be one digital tuner in the box thus you will not be able to watch one show while recording another.  Given the fact that my HT is mostly for movies and sports, that limitation will not be that big of an issue.  So far the AT-163 is a great buy, hopefully it will be a reliable piece of gear.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: This product does what it promises to do.
column8:
I'm a recent cable cutter. I am now watching HDTV OTA via a Mohu 50 powered antenna and streaming thorough a popular streaming device. After I cut the cable, I have to admit I did miss the DVR my cable company provided so i did some research on an alternative. My must haves was that I wanted the DVR to do most everything my cable company DVR did but without paying a monthly charge. The Viewtv does mostly that. I had to buy a separate external HD USB device to complete this package. Set up was relatively simple however you do have to manually do everything to schedule a recording, meaning you have to tell the machine similar to an old VCR what day and times when you want it to record. Once you connect the Viewtv to your TV, you will use the Viewtv remote to change channels. Channel changing is crisp, however the same cannot be said about entering any menu guides within the Viewtv. There is a lag when you press the button to record or schedule a recording that can be annoying. I used to have Verizon Fios DVR which was similar to Tivo's DVR.

If you don't mind working a little to schedule your recordings and don't want to pay a monthly subscription, and want to spend around a hundred bucks, all in... then this DVR is for you. As with everything there are pros and cons.

Pros:
-This product is one of the cheapest I have been able to find and has worked reliably for the time I have been using it. (Since 6/9/14)
-The Viewtv converts (using HDMI) and displays my OTA powered antenna assisted HDTV signal beautifully. OTA TV Image quality is equal to my old Verizon Fios cable HDTV image quality. (no exaggeration.)
-The actual Viewtv box is very small, about the size of an average hardcover book.
-I can record on the fly if I need to take a phone call and record future shows with a little effort.
-Although the remote button layout is a little clunky, once you memorize what buttons does what, you should be ok.

Cons:
-Annoying lag time when you want to view shows you've recorded or want to schedule a recording. The Viewtv needs greater processing power to fix this issue.
-Viewtv comes with only one tuner so you cannot channel surf and record a program at the same time. (at least I haven't figured out how to do this yet.) For me this is huge. I will probably eventually upgrade to a more expensive DVR in the future to a device that can record multiple programs at the same time. If this is an issue for you, this Viewtv isn't for you.
-(For those new cable cutters:) In general, TV broadcasters are only required to display future programing 12 hours in advance in most cases. You have to go online to get the TV schedule for the week and know what day and time to record. Viewtv will display the schedule 12 hrs in advance only. This isn't Viewtv's fault, I just thought people should know.
-This box is not TiVo!!! I am spoiled when it comes to recording programs, I liked being able to ask my DVR to find a show by name and easily schedule a recording. Viewtv does not do that. Viewtv DVR is more akin to an old VCR, (for those old enough to remember those). I must admit I do miss that feature. It makes recording shows so much easier.
-The Viewtv does not label your programs once they are recorded on your external hard drive, it only labels recorded programs using the channel (CBS, NBC, etc...and the time and date recorded. You can rename shows afterward but its kind of a pain to have to keep a notepad by your couch to keep tabs on this.

column7: ViewTV At-163 Digital TV Converter Box and Media Player w/Recording...
column8:
I really wanted to give ViewTV the full five stars on the basis that it does what it claimed it would, but there's no way an electronic product with no web presence and an unknown manufacturer can get five stars.  I have only had my device for two+ weeks.  All's well so far, but what if I need help?  The warranty sheet lists an address for returns (163 Imlay St., Brooklyn, NY 11231) but that appears to be a stationery store.  It also lists a Customer Service number, 1-866-948-6079, but there is no answer.  It's hard to feel confident about a product the makers and distributors hide from.  BUT...myViewTV is working and doing what they claimed it would.  Here are some must-knows:
a.) You must provide your own antenna.
b.) If you want to record shows to watch later, you must attach a USB storage device. Some people have external hard drives; I'm using an ordinary 32GB flat Sandisk inserted in a USB converter drive ($15).  I recorded from my TV and played back on the ViewTV.  There was plenty of space left on the disk after three movies and five hours of TV shows.  If you store  a lot of media, you might consider more gigabytes.
c.) If you don't want to record but you do want to pause, rewind and fast-forward live TV, you must attach a USB external storage device.  (See b)  Your storage device is where ViewTV buffers the live signal until you are ready to watch again.
d.) This is not your cable company's DVR box.  Things will work differently.  You'll get used to it.

The following is my attempt to address the chief complaints given by reviewers who gave ViewTV a one-star score:

1. It did not record, even when TV signal was strong
--Did the person have an external storage drive attached to the device or not? ViewTV has no internal storage.

2. ...it accepts only NSTC signals that, of course, are no longer broadcast OTA.
--It does indeed accept ATSC (digital) signals over the air.  Either this person received a dud or the settings aren't correct.

3.  piece of junk...not worth the money. I have a new TV that does not need the box to receive digital channels...
--Well, this person had no need for the ViewTV box, but you might. I also picked up the same number of channels, but I needed it for its PVR function, so it's not junk to me.

4.  Sound stopped working..The problem is not with the TV since the HDMI port is shared with a three-way adapter and sound works fine from the other two.
--There's something to this. My sound stopped working, too, after I programmed my Harmony One universal remote (a 2-star product at best) to take over commands from ViewTV and let the receiver handle sound. ViewTV may not like multiple interfaces.  After applying several strategies, I finally gave up and reprogrammed the remote to bypass the receiver. Now my sound is back.

5. Recording looks like a pixelated mess.
--If the OTA signal is a pixelated mess, so will your recording be a pixelated mess. ViewTV cannot de-pixelate a bad signal.

6. The remote also is one of the worst I've used.
--There is a learning curve you will need to work through.  Two examples: (1) the Guide button is labeled EPG for Electronic Program Guide.  (2) You must press the Hold button after you press Play when watching a recording.  Otherwise, it will play in review (small screen) mode. It's important to note that ViewTV does not have its own guide.  Your guide will look like what your networks are already broadcasting OTA.
