column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Tuner wasn't good enough -- and I worry a bit about the switched power supply.
column8:
This is a FASCINATING device in so many ways. It's pure Chinese manufacturing of absolutely the lowest possible quality (one of the four base pads was missing), but it's only of interest to the US market. The rest of the world doesn't need this -- they simply stick USB devices into their TVs and record directly. It's only in the US that a combination of cartel patents and corrupt politicians makes recording of OTA TV extremely expensive and difficult. When we buy a Samsung TV, for example, the recording features are disabled.

In China this is probably used to convert digital signals for the few analog TVs left in China. It probably costs $10 to make, including what I assume is a very low quality (risky!) internal switched power supply (no power brick). In the US it's sold, somewhat covertly, as a low cost no-subscription simple digital TV recorder.

The good news is that if you ignore the manual, and work through the incredibly crude displays hacked to to show English labels, and convert from the strings on the weird remote to the screen, it's not hard to configure this. You can even set up the antenna as pass-through so the signal goes to the ViewTV and is also available for TV input. It does record (!) and you can play back the recording. It even shows a list of available TV shows.

The bad news is that the tuner in my device sucked. OTA Digital TV barely works in many US settings -- we need top notch tuners. The one in our Samsung Smart TV gets barely enough channels to meet my son's sporting thirst. The tuner in this device missed most of them.

I also do worry about the internal switched power supply. This ships with all the usual inspection/certification labels, but I'd be amazed if any of them were legitimate.

If only they'd shaved their profit margin a bit. It costs nothing to build what's in this box. We actually own a decent (Chinese made of course) Digital TV converter box that cost $45 -- it's far higher quality than this with a far better tuner.

I hope someone else will do that -- but we have to remember the reason these features are disabled from US TVs. Anyone doing this properly is going to be hit by the US OTA patent cartel -- and forced to charge high subscription fees.

There may not be anything better in the near future. So if you have a strong antenna and good signals, and you're feeling lucky, it's worth a shot. Just be ready to return, and  if you're feeling nervous leave it unplugged when you're not using it.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: We use it in our theater
column8:
We use this in our home theater, so that we can watch local television over our projector.  It works well.  I have not used the DVR functionality, so I cannot speak to the quality of that aspect.

Only complaint that I might share, and that caused me to give it four stars, instead of five, is that the unit gets very hot.  Very hot!!  But it continues to run, and has not burned out from the heat.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Exactly what i was looking for
column8:
Operates as advertised, but a few kinks.

1.  My intention was to use this on the TV in my basement so I wouldn't have to have it on my main TV, adding yet another box on my entertainment center.  The plan was to use it to record, and then carry the recording on the thumb drive to my Western Digital Media player to watch.  As it turns out, the DVR records in "blocks" of 511 megabytes, so recording the 24 series opener gave me 25 files.  Only the first file was named with a ".mts" extension.  That one plays fine.  All the rest of the files are named ".mts1" ".mts2" ".mts3" and so on.  So, to play each of the files on any source other than the DVR, I had to rename all the files to ".mts".

2.  File naming.  The recorded files only show the station ID and time stamp.  It makes no sense to me that if there is an electronic program guide and the ability to rename files manually (both of which work great by the way), why the unit can't name the recording using the name of the show.

3.  Clunky remote.  I'm never lost because the on-screen prompts that show what you can do, but seriously, why would I press "hold" to go full screen?  how about a button that says "full screen" or something intuitive.  I bought this as a test for my Mother in Law, and she will eventually pick up on the visual cues, but it needs to be made more user friendly.

All in all, a good buy.  I'll probably be buying another one shortly.

Update 5-13:

I gave it another go with a faster USB hard drive, and this time, the entire program recorded in one file.  It would be nice to know why.  I can only speculate as to why.  I hope the manufacturer is reading this.  Anyway, MAKE SURE you have a fast flash drive.  My original USB drive gave hiccups every few seconds.  Now it works fine.

Update 1/21/16:

unit has been having issues for a while now.  About two months ago, the coax input quit working, so I had to eat up an HDMI port to support it.  It quit turning on with the remote, although turning off and all other functions were fine.  It has frozen up a couple of times in the last week or so, and finally just shut off with no sign of life.

I still recommend this device.  I bought it on May 3, 2014 for 59.99.  That is still less than one month of service with any cable provider and has provided me nearly two years of good service.  I just ordered another one to replace it, and now they're 32.99.  Good going ViewTV :).

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8: I like this little OTA DTV tuner box as it's pretty compact and you can easily set up your recordings. Good sharp picture and sensitive tuner. It would be nice if they also included a usb port on the rear of the unit instead of just the front. The other thing that I did not like was the fact that when you want to scan any new over the air digital tv channels into memory there is no feature that lets you 'add' those new channels in - it just overwrites everything all over again. And one last thing - if you have an Android media box, like the G-Box MX2, I noticed that some of the IR remote control buttons are of the same frequency as the IR remote of this tuner which means that you are accidently 'doing things' (changing channels, settings, etc.) to this or that box. However a situation like this can easily be 'fixed' because the G-Box lets you use a 2.4 ghz RF remote instead of the IR one - all you need to do is put a piece of dark tape over the IR sensor on the G-Box to prevent it from picking up the IR signals from the tuner IR remote to solve the problem. Overall I would recomend this product to a friend.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8: This review is for a Viewtv model AT-163. Although tedious to program a recording, it's a great little device to watch TV with. Not only will it convert ATSC signals, but it also provides an HDMI and component output with excellent picture quality. However, on the down side, the remote is very awkward to use, often requiring several key presses to do a simple task-very tedious. Remote operation can lock up and it's functions are not intuitive. It often fails to record as scheduled, and sometimes it will stop recording after a few minutes, while at other times, it records as planned. I've tried various recording media with the same result. I've also tried two HomeWorx units and they share the same faults and attributes. I returned the Viewtv unit and may do the same with the HomeWorx units. These different brands also seem to share the same electronics which may explain why I experienced the same characteristics with both brands. Now, other features that are hard to deal with: A 24 hour clock; Recording names are by date and time only, not the show's name; Odd, remote function names that make for awkward use. And finally, this could be a five star device if the remote and other soft spots were corrected. All considered though, this is still a very useful piece of equipment.

column7: HDTV Digital Converter Box for Older Television
column8:
The ViewTV unit works great for watching the digital signals from local television stations on older (non-HD) television/video devices.  The ability to record live broadcast to watch later at my convenience is SUPER feature!

The ViewTV device can record to a USB device (such as a USB thumb drive or external USB hard drive).  You can watch the recorded programs later or that USB drive to my desktop/laptop computer and watch them on a computer (even Windows XP plays the recorded programs with no problems).  Cable (coax) playback output is through channel 3 or 4 (like the old VCRs).  With the HDMI output, you can connect to the current HD video devices (including some computer desktop monitors accept HDMI Input).

While the ViewTV user manual gives you the basics for operations; however, it could be more user friendly!  It needs to give better, clearer instructions.  Some of the operations are intuitive while some are not...so you have to experiment to get familiar with the menus and remote control features and options.

So, if you got an older television or video device that needs a HDTV converter box, I definitely RECOMMEND the ViewTV converter box!

The EPG makes it very easy to set up at timer recording for the next day.  You can select the resolution, at the full 1080p setting the picture is indistinguishable from the original.  The remote might seem less than intuitive at first, but you will get used to it.  It can convert digital stations to analog for use with older TVs.  I don't have anything negative to say about it.  I've used it about a month.  It arrived sooner than the expected delivery date.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8:
Downgrading this from 5 stars to 1! (after much fiddling and resetting over the last week, it's now recording my scheduled show but locking up 99% of the time. My original unit would record reliably until the disk filled up)

The first one lasted almost exactly one year so i thought I'd buy a replacement and it would work the same. Opened the old failed unit and there appeared to be traces blown open on the PCB in several places.... my initial guess is that the trace widths for the 5V USB are barely sufficient. So I thought even if I have to buy a new one every year, it's still better than supporting the morons at TiVo who have made it nearly impossible to bring a competitive product to the market. Alas, the replacement arrived and things are not looking quite so good
- the remote uses different IR codes so it no longer works with my universal remote (is spent quite some time finding an equivalent device for my remote and I'm just not prepared to repeat the exercise)

- I don't know why they redesigned the it.... is worse than the previous generation and even more directional (which is really saying something)

- the new unit wouldn't play any of my previous recordings. Well, it did play one once, but never again.

- then the schedule no longer works (this is the sep 3 2014 firmware). I've tried reformatting, deleting and reprogramming the recording schedule, all to no aval. I only have a single item on my recording list and it's supposed to record every day - it recorded once on the first day, but never since. It still seems to record OK if I program a once only recording, but that isn't really much use particularly when the previous version worked fine.

- this one locks up even more than the previous version. I could power down and back up again using the remote to recover on the previous version, but this one locks up on reboot almost every time when I use the remote. Now I have to get up, walk over and pull our the power cord virtually every time I try to get this thing working.

-the main reason for my downgrade (apart from the fact that this is no longer fit for use!) Is that this company actually had a really good product which they've turned into a really crappy product through "upgrades", all of which appear to have contributed to an inferior product. Oh, I also resent the already marketing pretending this is reduced from $99 and is therefore a great value. I got our for $50+ a year ago and it was actually worth that price. This time it's being sold for $34 and it's now worth $0 IMHO.

Unfortunately I threw away the packaging anticipating the same product, so I'll keep experimenting with USB drives/formatting etc and update this review if I can get any normal functionality out of this thing. What a shame.

when TiVo tried to extort an extra ~$6/month in order to record in HD (the guide information provided by the service would have been identical and I owned the player outright) and removed my recording ability because I was two weeks late on my annual renewal, I decided I'd try and fine something ....anything....to prevent feeding this litigious monster which has deprived the marketplace of any serious competition. Other than eyetv or setting up a computer to record OTA broadcast, this little beauty came to my attention and I was finally able to free myself from the mafia tactics of both comcast (with their asinine encryption of OTA broadcasts and resulting inferior quality than I get with a $20 antenna) and the ludicrous business model and bullying tactics of TiVo. Good riddance to both of them. btw I didn't even know that tv guide/recording schedules were broadcast ota for free until I got this - I was paying TiVo roughly $150/year for something that's in the air we breath. It does lock up occasionally, but I can handle that better than extortion :-)

column8: I have had I believe 3 digital converter boxes, and I'm usually not that satisfied, I'm going to be real. One died after about 2 weeks, another just had s***ty reception, and one was incredibly old school. This one has probably the nicest remote out of all the ones I've tried (I know, petty, but it's weird having an ancient s***ty looking remote that comes with most of them) and is overall simple. I like that I can either hook it up with USB or the video cables, because my new TV doesn't have as many options as my old one and this makes it easier to fit all my devices. I like that you can set "favorite" channels, because then I don't have to remember all the channels my favorite shows are on. You can also rename the channels, which is convenient. The one thing I don't like is that I can't seem to figure out how to change the time from military time, but otherwise a good box with great reception. I haven't tried recording yet but I like that it has the option.

column7: Excellent value for what it does
column8:
As others have written, this unit is not perfect. But with a $30 pricetag (after $30 promotion which was applied at checkout) I really can't argue too much against it.

Setting it up and programming it took a bit of time since the manual is pretty useless, but I was able to figure it out.  The remote is weird, but if you have a learning remote you can map the keys to ones that make more sense to you.  The tuner is less sensitive than the one in my HDTV, so rather than using the loop-through function (and thus bypassing the tuner in the HDTV) I used a splitter to split the antenna feed to both tuners, which is working really well.  The EPG is pretty good.  For reasons unknown, the display shows a sequential channel number instead of the broadcast channel number; not sure what thinking was in that decision.  I bought this unit for the recording capability, not to use as a primary tuner, so the channel number doesn't bother me.

I like that it can record in 1080 if desired, and will also record in 720 or 480 to save space or for older shows.  A half-hour show at 480 uses about 2 gb of space.  I plugged in a 16 gb flash drive, let the unit format it (FAT32) and set up some shows to record.  With a flash drive, the unit is COMPLETELY SILENT when it turns on, records, and turns off, which I really appreciate for night-time or early-morning recordings (the unit is in my bedroom and I am a light sleeper).  The display is a bit bright so I put a piece of cardboard over it to block it when the lights come on at night.

For those who are not techy at all, this is not an easy plug-n-play unit, so you may want to look for something else.  To be honest, I looked at units costing over $200 (such as the Magnavox HD/DVD recorder, which records to DVD ONLY in SD) and decided the hassle of this unit was fairly minor.  I was prepared to pay $60, but this really is a steal at $30.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Using a ViewTV At-163 with a 250 GB, 2.5" Apple Hard Drive
column8:
ViewTV At-163 ATSC Digital TV Converter Box.

It can be used with old 4:3 Aspect Ratio TV's and the newer 16:9 Aspect Ratio High Definition TV's.

The ViewTV At-163 is capable of using an external USB hard drive to save TV Programs (the manufacturer claims that USB flash drives can also be used).

I am using a ViewTV At-163 with a 2.5" Apple Hard Drive, and it works without problems.  The ViewTV At-163 feeds enough power to the Apple Hard Drive via the USB connection, and there is no need to use the Apple Hard Drive's power connector.

The ViewTV At-163 is easy to program for TV recording, by just pressing the TIMER button on the remote, and setting up the TV program information.  TV program recording can be set up using the following frequencies: Daily, weekly, and once.

The TV programs that have been saved on the hard drive will appear by pressing the MENU button on the remote, and selecting the USB menu, then the PVR menu, and last the HBPVR folder (this folder is automatically created by the Converter Box).  The TV programs that have been saved in the HBPVR folder are listed using file names which include the channel's name, the date: month, day, year, and time (24 hr format time in which recording was started).

The Hard Drive must be formatted as an NTFS file system, formatting the hard drive as a FAT32 file system will save the TV Programs in multiple segments, whereas NTFS will provide a single file.  I formatted my Apple Hard Drive using a PC.

After connecting the Hard Drive to a Computer running Video Processing Software, I could determine that the ViewTV At-163 connected to a 4:3 Aspect Ratio Projection TV saves TV Programs using the following:

Video Format: MPEG2, at a Display Resolution of 704x480, at a Bit Rate of 2984 Kbps
Sound Format: AC3, at a Bit Rate of 192 Kbps
A 1 hour recording requires approximately 1.34 GB.

The player has fast forward and reverse speeds of 2X, 4X, 8X, 16X and 32X.

The time is automatically set by the converter box, and one of the menus has a Daylight Savings Time function that must be set to 'on' accordingly.

The files saved can be seen neatly, and without lag.

The ViewTV At-163 is a 5 Star Product.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Exactly what I was looking for!
column8:
This unit is not perfect, as others have pointed out, but it really is exactly what I was looking for.  Here is my criteria:

1. Must be able to pull in weak signals from an outdoor antenna - Check.
2. Must have HDMI output AND Component outputs - Check.
3. Must have the ability to force the HDMI resolution to 720P - Check.
4. Must be relatively inexpensive - Check.

I have had several external HD tuners over the years (first to feed an HD monitor, and then a projector), and all have konked out or had various issues.  My latest tuner works fine for most stations, but then failed to receive the local Fox station that should have been no problem.  So all I was really looking for was a good, solid tuner, that just works.  I don't need the recording functions so I haven't even tried that part.

There are three ways I use this unit.  One is to feed the TV, so I use a short HDMI running 1080P for that.  The second was is to drive a projector that has a long HDMI cable run.  And with that run, it sometimes streaks when I try to push 1080P, so I drop it back to 720P for that, since the projector is only 720P anyway.  Then it works perfectly.  Third, I sometimes host a superbowl party with my projector at a different location from home, and when I use even a short HDMI cable, I sometimes get dropouts (the jack on the projector is most of the problem, as the cable has to be connected just right).  So for that, I use a component cable since it is rock solid and never drops out (and no one can tell it's not digital from 30 feet away).

As others have noted, this unit does have some quirks, but I expected that based on the cheap price and being an off-brand.  But I expected that it had some good modern chips in it, and that it my work for what I needed, and that turned out to be true.  The user manual is awful, of course, and the front panel shows a sequential number for the channel number instead of the actual channel number (there may be a setting to make it show the channel number, but I didn't find it).  The online program guide is actually pretty good compared to other units I've had.  The interface to set up recording appears a little clunky, but I haven't actually tried that yet, and don't plan to.  And note that to record you do need an external storage device of some sort.  When I went to set it up on my Harmony One remote, the manufacturer was not listed, so I had to set it up manually, which still wasn't too bad with the Harmony interface.

So, if you're looking for a super do-all device that is easy to use, this is not it.  But if you have specific requirements as I did, it may just be the perfect unit for you.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use

We watch over the air channels and have been using a Toshiba DVD recorder connected to a HDTV tuner as a DVR.  It only records in 480p and is limited to what the digital tuner feeds it.  This unit replaced it and is doing a stellar job.  The recording quality is excellent and is only limited by the capacity USB stick I use. The only negatives I have are:

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column8: I purchased it after reading reviews for less expensive models such as iView and Homeworx. I wanted something of a better quality and more reliable. Right out of the box I noticed that the unit had light scratches on the top. I wonder if it had been returned previously. Batteries were not included with the remote (a bit cheap on the manufacturers part). Included HDMI cable was very short (~3ft). If you have a large screen TV and want to use this cable, converter box has to be placed right next to the TV or just below it. This renders the supplied cable useless to me. Converter itself was easy to set up and I compared it with reception I got from my 2009 Samsung TV and Magnavox SDTV converter box. I used an old indoor RCA amplified antenna (RCA ANT 200). I also have an amplified Philips antenna of the same age (~10 years old), but RCA has much better reception. With Samsung TV I was able to get ~50 channels (counting 2.1, 2.2, 2.3 etc. as separate channels). With Magnavox converter box I got a couple fewer. Viewtv apparently received 54 channels. When I went through them I noticed that some I was not able to receive (no signal), some were pay TV ("Scramble Channel" - actual spelling on the screen) and some (Ion, qubo, QVC) were acquired twice at different frequencies. Overall, I was able to get ~40  different channels. I still intended to keep this unit, even though it may not have been the best purchase. However, I noticed that every few minutes the reception was lost. The picture would get pixelated and the sound was lost. That did not happen when I was using Samsung TV or Magnavox converter box. Finally, as I was switching antenna between different units, I noticed that this converter box was rather warm. After I let it run for ~1h it got so hot that touching antenna input or output could burn my hands. I am returning this unit. It is possible that I have got a defective one, but I don't think I will take chance with another one. I will probably try one of the less expensive models.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: Descent for the price (while on sale at least)
column8:
First off, "Andy T. Knote"'s review is pretty spot on, check that out if you want specific details.  My primary use of this product initially was for recording of OTA TV programs, however the tuner is better than the one in my TV.

Pros:
- HD recording is seamless as long as the antenna signal is good.  Recorded onto a 2TB hybrid drive (8GB SSD cache) in a USB 3.0 enclosure, playing, pausing, skipping forward and reverse all performed well.  Note that any ticker info (such as weather alerts) that are added by affiliate channels will show in recordings, as well as the network identifiers in the lower corners.
- Can rename recordings unlike other comparable units, can't use spaces in names for some reason, but can use just about any other character as well as upper and lower case letters.
- Does not output much heat (however the plastic on top of the metal casing was VERY hard to peel off).
- Price: $70 on sale from $100 at time of purchase.

Cons:
- User interface is clunky and occasionally has delayed responses.
- Front channel display is of an internal identifier number, not the actual channel number, making it effectively useless outside of determining if you are watching a recording or live TV.
- Remote has un-intuitive button layout, when pausing a PVR recording or using timeshift, I have to look at the remote to find the play and pause buttons (which are separate), and they don't have common button shapes or locations on the remote (they are both buried in a 3x4 grid of 12 total buttons.
- Did not work well with my Yamaha RX-V473 (via HDMI), though that may be the receiver's issue.  Receiver wouldn't always find input, and when it did, it was pink as if the RGB levels were messed up.  Works fine when connected directly to the TV via HDMI.
- USB port is on the front.

The cons listed above aren't necessarily "killers", hence the 4-star rating.

column4: Digital TV Converter Box for Analog TV - AT-163 OTA DVR, PVR Digital TV Recorder and ATSC Tuner Features A Built in USB Port, HDMI and Coaxial Output, Bright LED Clock and is Easy to Use
column7: How to Fix the Daily Recording Bug!
column8: The main problem with this unit is it has a bug which prevents the daily recording function. I found a way of getting around this bug. You will need to program 7 days in sequence. For example: May 1, May 2, May 3, etc.. For each of these 7 days set your channel and time you want to record then select "Weekly" for each of these seven days. When the May 1 recording finishes, it will reprogram itself for the same day the following week. Same thing for May 2 and so on. What you are having to do is program each day individually and set them to repeat the same day the following week. It is a bit frustrating having to do this 7 times instead of being able to simply select "Daily," but so far it is working fine for me. For the price, I will happily spend the 5 extra minutes setting it up this way instead of shelling out nearly 7 times more plus a possible monthly service charge for a name brand unit. Hopefully soon they will address this bug in an update, but until then hopefully this will help many of you enjoy your very inexpensive alternative dvr unit! :)

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Like many folks, I pre-ordered the D800 the same day it was available.  Alas, Nikon totally blew the market analysis vs production vs. supply chain formula.  After waiting 2 months, I had to leave the country before Nikon got it's D800 act together. I needed a beat-up D90 replacement camera, and the D3200 seemed like a decent place-holder.  I quickly ordered one before they were back-ordered too!  Sure, the D3200 is DX, not FX.  Sure, it is not nearly as flexible.  Sure, it can only AF with newer lenses.  BUT, you can buy about 4-D3200's for the price of a D800, AND it comes with a decent kit lens for $699!

The tutoring graphical-based menu system is geared more to beginners, which I am not, so I find it maddening.  Most will love it, since it is somewhat educational, and offers a great variety of pre-sets to take creative shots easily.

It is amazingly light weight - lighter than most lenses! It is very quiet. The AF could be faster, but it's plenty fast enough. When you dig deeper, you shockingly find that the D3200 has many advanced internal features from the highest-end cameras (D800 & F4). The high-res LCD rear screen, the EXPEED 3 image processing engine, and a new 24MP sensor.  The EXPEED 3 image processing engine allows the D3200 to perform at an altitude unheard of for a so-called entry level camera.  Nikon's Active-D dynamic range enhancement at 24MP at 4 frames per second requires substantial in-camera processing power.

I bought this camera primarily for still photography. With the proper lenses & technique, the results are stunning.  Low-light/high ISO performance is far beyond what you should expect at this level camera. Candle-lit face images are noise-free, and look great. Still life's on a tripod at ISO 100, have more resolution that ANY DSLR I have ever used, with very little shadow noise.  In short, I might not accept my D800 when it becomes available.  I might use the D3200 longer than I thought, (waiting for the 24MP FX D600 for $1999 later this year -- my guesses on price & stats & date)...or, just keep using the D3200.  If it breaks (I'm hard on cameras), I'll just buy a new one.

Bottom line -- the D3200: super light-weight, very quiet, super high resolution (& low noise, high dynamic range, superb colors), incredible HD video with slow motion.  It is no doubt THE most amazing DSLR value on the planet!

5/14/12 UPDATE: I've now shot 100s of images, using lenses from 11 mm to 600 mm.  I've learned a lot.  Super-high resolution cameras are a new arena for most of us. On the surface, one automatically thinks you will get images with twice the resolution (12MP vs 24MP). Not so.  MP resolution is measured linearly, so the increase while significant, is less than doubled.  More importantly, when you enter the hi-res camera stratosphere, photographic technique & lens choice are critical. While these high MP cameras are capable of amazing results, you have to work to get absolutely ALL the MP's this camera has to offer.  Do not blame the camera if your initial results are less dramatically sharper than your old 6-8-12MP Nikon. It's probably you...
BTW, the Nikon 18-55mm is a decent lens, but it doesn't do this imager justice.  You can get better results, with better glass.  The excellent f1.8 35mm DX Nikon on this camera makes a super-light weight compact package you can carry all day long, producing super images.  A 60 year-old Nikkor Q 200mm f4, $70 or so on eBay, produces stunning results if carefully used on Manual, on a tripod.

Set-up a table with clean background and a few artifacts on it.  Use the sharpest lens you have,  at f 8, on a sturdy tripod, perpendicular to the table, Shoot the scene with the in-camera flash on both old & new camera bodies. You will see the difference easily when images from both cameras are compared side by side, enlarged to 100%.

How does this translate to everyday casual shooting?  Not easily. Sub-par technique still results in sub-par images no matter what camera is used.  If you are a beginner looking for the best entry-level DSLR ever made, all of this won't matter -- grab a D3200 and shoot away!  Just note that the D3200 is capable of world-class imagery.  If it takes more effort to take photographs of this caliber, it's a good thing -- the D3200 forces you to up your game to get there!

5/5/13 UPDATE.  It's been a year.  I have a D800 and a D3200.  Yes, there are many differences between the two.  One is at the high end of the spectrum, the other, entry level.  When I'm shooting commercially, or seriously in any way, it's the D800.  It is a superb camera, if you own glass that can fully exploit the 36MP sensor, and your technique is solid. For everything else, I use the D3200.  Why?  It's light and compact.  You can easily carry it around all day, with the f1.8 35mm, and hardly know it's there.  If that lens isn't wide enough, shoot a 3-frame series and stitch them together in Photoshop.  Again, with good glass and technique, the results are very, very good.  D800 territory? No, but few would notice. The D3200 is a pleasure to use, and handles fast enough for most kinds of photography. You can use old manual Nikkor lenses easily, albeit with a bit more effort.  With the focus confirmation dot in the viewfinder, manual focusing is easy.  Exposure can be guessed and adjusted using the great hi-res LCD.  I recently had to shoot an emergency-rush job covering a politician's speech. All I had in the car was the D3200, the 35mm f1.8, and an old, sharp 100mm f2.8 E Nikkor  -- my normal in-car-at all-times stash.  The setting was indoors, in a bright garden area -- no flash allowed.  I was surrounded by folks with Nikon D4's and $1500 lenses.  I got a few looks....LOL.  I boosted the ISO to 1600, used the $50 100mm @ f4 @1/125th, and the results were great, published in several places.  The D3200 is a great camera for the money, I like it more now than when I first bought it!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: 5100 VS 3200: Good Job Nikon! (ACR7.1 & LR 4.1 support RAW)
column8:
*** Update 6/12/2012 ***
After analyzing the result more, I found that, for this kind of camera, my Sharp lens at the sharpest aperture is required to get real amazing sharp picture to the pixel. My Tamron 17-50 VC F2.8 at F5.6 is required for edge to edge sharpness.
Also, Tokina 11-16 F.8 (which is manual focus with this camera), becomes more critical. Using the range finder mode is a must to get a tack sharp picture. That's new to me. But I am glad I learn the lesson. And now I am more happy with this camera (and lenses)...

*** Update 05/31/2012***
Update lightroom 4.1 today, now support NEF. And as expected despite the high resolution (24mp) cmos chips, the noise quality of D3200 is comparable with D5200.
Meaning that D3200 has advantage of having more real estate (meaning more room for cropping),hence still have the same IQ with D3200. And thanks to Expeed 3 (which is the processor they use in D800 and D4 and D3200), D3200 is a very responsive camera. Bravo Nikon!

************************

Just received this Camera today, and this is my preliminary Review (will update progresively).
Background: I have upgraded my Nikon Digital D100->D200->D90->D5100->D3200.
Okay, seemed I downgrade every single time, but actually not. (I also use D300, D3X, but those are different class of equipment). This path, is more for daily activity platform (lightweight).
D90 -> D5100: I actually considered to buy D7000, but chose D5100 simply because the price, and the articulated LCD because I use it 50% for Video. I am glad I did! D5100 image quality is SUPERB and on par with D7000. D5100 is lot FASTER than D3000 & D3100, but a little bit slower than D7000. From D90 to D5100, it has lots of improvement in image quality, low noise in low light, much better video (with 20 minutes max per session). The only drawback I can see, is the battery coverage is not long enough (on Video mode), but it is understandable, and the solution is add another spare.

D5100 -> D3200:
Other than the obvious layout design difference, the only thing I eager to know is the Low Light Noise!
So I am glad to report that IT IS COMPARABLE!

See my attached photo (The Costco Connection image) and judge yourself (both image are taken with the same setting at ISO 6400)

So, 3200 is a clear winner!

*** Update ***
I upload an image taken at ISO 12800 (Hi1). For me the image is very usable.
Will update the review in a couple of days, once I get the whole importance difference between 5100 & 3200 ...

*** Update After 200 shots ***
1. My copy of 3200 has slightly over exposure consistently (but not much, probably 1/3 ev, but I actually like slightly under exposed)
2. I noticed  a slight improvement of Dynamic range. I take a shoot at an overcast day, but surprise how it can capture the clouds, the trees and shadows
3. An improvement in response. It is slightly faster than 5100, but not in the same level as D7000.
4. Smoother Mirror, and quieter. It is noticable (but not sure if this is consistent between model, or just batch/production variance).

*** Update in Video ***
The Video is also amazing. It is comparable to D5100, especially the color rendetion is great!
The low light performance is on par with D5100.
The addition of 720p 60fps, and the Manual Audio Level control + Stereo Audio Meter is a real plus for Video Maker, making this DSLR a good choice for Serious Video taker. I wish it has a headphone Jack, but probably too much to ask for considering the price level. The focus tracking in Video mode is also improved, not substantially but good enough to be considered. I did 4 songs video clip and really satisfied with the result. Both the end result and the operational experience are great. I use the 720p 60fps mode for this project, and really like the result.
I noticed slightly longer battery time, but not sure whether this is consistent or only slight production/batch variance. (*** Update: I finally found that It is a batch variance, because the other battery I have give me noticable longer running time ***).

The additional Audio Meter view (press Info several time in the live view mode), is a really good addition for me, especially while attaching external Mic for Video mode (see my image). Also the option to set the Audio Level (Mic Input) is very useful. I took 10 Video clips already, and use the Mic Input to capture the Audio from A Mixer. The audio quality is SUPERB!

For all the test, I didn't use the kit lens, but use Tamron 17-50 F2.8 VC.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
After much trying and failing to get this camera, I finally lucked out and did from a seller here on amazon. The camera is scarce right now especially the red model. I have the pleasure of getting the black model and all my other slr's are black so why break the mold as they say...

First the camera looks very similar to the Nikon d3100 with a improvements to the sensors of course at 24.3 megapixel. The details and contrasts of the pictures taken are deep and rich and very beautiful on they eyes. The lcd screen on seems to be improved, much more clearer and in high contrast.

I have the Sony A77 and this is my second Nikon joining my Nikon d5100. Since Canon has not came out with a high sensor that is affordable such as the 24.3 megapixel that the sony and Nikon now have. In no comparison the Sony a77 is much more expensive and you get what you pay for with it. However the Nikon D3200 is the way to go right now with a much lower price and takes great quality pictures that are vast and rich. I recommend this Nikon d3200 to anyone who can afford there 1st slr or a beginner in the field of digital slr cameras.

column8: My boyfriend bought me this camera 2 years ago for Christmas. It started out as a great starter camera. I never had any issues with it until sometime last summer. 60%-90% of my photos have so much noise that theres hardly any detail. Ive tried changing many settings. My firmware is up to date. Ive contacted nikon support several times. They misheard me and thought I said my photos were coming out greenish (not sure why they thought that especially since I corrected them multiple times). They asked me to send raw photos to them so they could identify my problem. I sent them and they wrote back saying they didn't see the green issues I was having. I wrote back and said my issues noise not green that was at least 2-3 weeks ago and I haven't heard back. Ive talked to other photographers whove had this camera and a lot of them said they had the same problem after a while. They never could figure out what was wrong with it and were forced to upgrade. Its frustrating because I started doing photo shoots with it. Ive had to refund money and turn potential clients away because of these issues. On top of the terrible noise issue, My shutter response has become incredibly delayed. Sometimes Ill snap the picture and it will take right away. Other times itll take 30 seconds or more before it will allow me to take a photo after I first start trying. I was a die hard Nikon fan but after this experience I will never recommend this series to anyone.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I bought this camera for my fundamental photography class after looking all over Amazon and other online sources. WIth that being said I absolutely love this camera. It's build quality is that of any other good DSLR that I've used, and I can already tell that with proper care and maintenance this camera should last me a lifetime. Also, for this price I'm incredibly happy with both the lenses. The primary lenses that I use s the 15-55mm lens that has the VR on it, and I can tell you that you can achieve some amazing things with that lens when used properly. Also, the second lens that comes with this kit is extremely good for portraiture among other things that you would typically use long lenses for. however, I really wished that I had the Vibration Reduction on the longer lens rather than the shorter lens due to the shake you naturally get without a tripod with the longer lens. This is fine however, as long as you use this lens properly and learn what this camera can do this small fact isn't all that much of an issue at all. Overall, I've been told by my professor that a lot of my photos I've taken with this camera are professional grade, and there are many cameras that aren't as good as this one that're still being used in the professional setting. If you're a student and you want the best bang for your buck then I think you've found it, but if you're not looking to use this camera for a potential career then you can definitely get away with being much cheaper.

On a side note, if you don't know much about cameras and this is your first time buying a DSLR make sure to do a lot of research and at least have a vague idea of what you like to take photos of. This camera really suits me in the way that it's very good at portraiture with it's high MP, but also amazing at action photography. If you're looking for only using it for portraiture and aren't interested in doing any photography of moving things I think you'd be better suited with a Cannon DSLR due to their better lenses overall.

column8:
Purchased as refurbished, been using it now for several months without a single issue. Takes great photos, and as a camera to transition from point-and-shoot to full on DSLR to learn proper photography, it's superb! It does have a fully auto mode for those a bit nervous about going full manual, and for those experienced photographers I think this camera would be a nice addition as well. It doesn't have some of the flexibility as more advanced cameras, but I was able to purchase this camera with two refurbished lenses (18-55mm & 55-200mm), a nice carrying case, a modest set of filters with a lens hood, and an extra battery for $500.

I considered going with the newer D3300, but in comparing the two I didn't see enough of a difference to warrant the higher price for the newer model. All in all, I'm very happy with this camera.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Great Camera...But spend some extra and buy one with a VR (Vibration Resistance) lens
column8:
This is a great camera. I have one.
HOWEVER...beware that this bundle comes with a lens that is non-VR.
VR stands for Vibration Resistance.
Unless you plan on taking still shots with a tripod and remote, then the lens will prove itself useless to you.
To hand hold a camera with a non-VR lens produces images that look out of focus
That's because it is impossible to hold a camera without your hand having some degree of shaking/movement.
I recommend spending the extra for a VR lens.
In my opinion, I think that manufacturers should make it clear to consumers that non VR lenses have limited functionality.
I have known a few beginners who have put money into their cameras/lenses, not knowing the significance of
this, and so disappointed that their photos aren't crisp and focused.

column7: Great transitional camera for point-and-shoot camera to manual controls
column8:
Camera arrived just as expected. My wife loves it! It is easy to use and a great beginner camera. Now she wants more lenses........

It is only 24 megapixels which is way better than a phone camera, but not as high quality as professional photos for magazines like Vogue. Really the only difference where this comes into play is if you want to make a picture extremely large like on a billboard or zoom way far in and print that zoomed in portion.

You are able to manually control the aperture, shutter speed, ISO (sensitivity to light), flash, white balance, focus (with a ring on the lens or on the back of the camera), change to conious focus or single foucs, change to continuous shooting (so multiple shots), self-timer, the size of the files recorded (Camera RAW/JPEG Fine down to JPEG basic), and the color space.

This DSLR also includes video settings, which you can control to some degree as well! Pretty cool, and you can even go in and change the microphone settings at a basic level.

There is a flash on the top attached to the body, and it is fairly easy to switch out lenses and buy different lenses. It also has a hotshoe for external flash so you can add different lighting set-ups to the camera. It does have some automatic features, to help those who have no idea how to use the manual features.

It includes and instruction manual and the standard zoom lens. The instruction manual is actually really organized and clear/easy to understand. Although I still found listening to videos and practising helped my wife the most.

I attached some photos she has been able to take on this camera so you can see what this camera is capable of.

I am very happy with this. It takes amazing pics and videos, has all the features I could ever ask for and I am just loving the digital aspect of this yet with the feel of an old slr.

It is very easy to use, has great battery life, is lightweight. I highly recommend this to anyone starting out or like me going from old school slr to dslr, or someone that wants a versatile camera that can do many things well.

The one thing I really love is getting back to the speed of the button/shutter when taking pics. I had some point and shoots for several years, and they do take great pics, but, just so much lag when hitting the button to capture a picture.

column7: An Outstanding Camera At A Bargain Price
column8:
As of April 2016, the Nikon D3200 is available for much less than the newer Nikon D3300.  Both cameras are able to take terrific photos and there is very little difference between them.  As a result, the D3200 may be the best bargain in photography.  You can get a camera and zoom lens capable of taking "pro" quality photos for half the price of similar cameras.

A bonus is that the D3200 is much lighter than most cameras of similar quality.  That means you can carry it all day when you are traveling somewhere interesting, and not be tempted to leave it back at the hotel.  Its light weight and superb "auto" mode make it a good travel camera, but it also has advanced features that let you grow as a photographer.

Amazon has many camera vendors.  Some sell official USA Nikon cameras with a full USA warranty.  Other vendors sell "grey market" Nikon cameras that do NOT have the Nikon USA warranty.  That warranty is very valuable, so do not buy a Nikon camera without it.

column7: The Nikon d-3200 isn't too bad for an entry level dslr
column8: The Nikon d-3200 isn't too bad for an entry level dslr. It has six scene modes; portrait, child, landscape, sports, closeup and night portrait. These things are nice and this type of information can be found on any website about cameras. The thing that these sites won't tell you is that the menu (user interface) is a little confusing compared to the slightly newer models of this camera. Don't get me wrong the camera is pretty good although the fact that everyone I know who has a Nikon has a newer slightly more modern and better, easier to use lcd display makes using this camera a bit frustrating. The image quality lives up to the Nikon standard with no problems. The autofocus is relatively fast. I wanted to give this camera five stars but the menu system ( I'm a computer science type so I refer to it as the the user interface) leaves something to be desired.

column7: I really wanted to like this camera
column8: I figured it would be a great entry-level DSLR based on all the rave reviews. At first I was really impressed with the build quality, look and feel and ease of use. However, when it came down to actually taking pictures, this camera failed miserably. I'm taking close up indoor product photographs for website use, with plenty of lighting. Unfortunately every picture turns out blurry, looking like they've been shot with a circa 2002 3.0mp camera. They may as well have been taken with a potato. My iphone 5s takes better pictures than this camera. I've tried every setting possible, ISO 100, 200, close-up, auto-focus, the whole 9 yards. It came with a kit VR lens. I'm wondering what else I can possibly do, or maybe I just got a lemon. Looks like I'll be going back to a cheap point 'n shoot, they seem to work much better.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Dollar for dollar it's hard to beat
column8:
Probably the best starter DSLR on the market, of any brand, as of December 2015. Yes, there is a newer model (the d3300) available, but if you can save $100 I'd still get this one. The new model is unnoticeablely lighter, allows you to shoot 1 fps faster if needed, and gives you the ability to create panoramics in-camera (plenty of free software is out there for that already), and the ISO goes up even higher (although the image quality is terrible at those high ISO's on both models). Is that all really worth the price increase for an entry level crop-sensor dslr... most likely not.

Features: You get all the basic features you need. They don't overload this model with tons of features most people will never use. The omission of all the fancy, little used features unless you're into a specific style of photography creates a learning curve for this camera that is fairly easy, especially if you have any background using camera controls.
Side note: This camera requires AF-S lenses to autofocus since it does not have a built in-camera focus motor. Not a huge issue (both lenses that come with it are AF-S), just something to be aware of. The biggest complaint I read on lens reviews is certain lenses being only manual focus with this camera. That's because they bought an AF lens when they needed an AF-S lens, and really no fault of either product.

Build: Very quality build, both in materials and design. It's not weather sealed, but I wouldn't take my weather sealed full frame cameras out in the rain either if I didn't have to, so this doesn't affect me much.

Image/Video quality: Plainly put, both are wonderful. Full HD video with the push of a button is great, and still something a few pro Nikon's still don't do (I'm looking at you D7--).  The picture quality is wonderful in shooting conditions with adequate light. To be fair, any lighting issues with this camera tend to fall more on the lenses than the camera itself. 24.2MP is way more than you need to produce quality images. Megapixel count is more of a marketing gimmick nowadays unless you're blowing up photos to cover an entire wall in a house.

Lenses included: These are Nikon's plasticy kit lenses. Months/years from now if you move into full-frame phtography both these lenses will work on your new camera, just not well... but that's a big "if" you decide to buy that level of camera. With that being said, they are extremely sharp lenses that will cover an adequate range for most of your shooting. Don't forget, crop sensors (like this camera, and most other budget dslr's have) actually magnify the lens coverage (and not degrade the picture quality), so the 200mm lens you get will work more like a 300mm lens. that's plenty of zooms for what most people need. Both lenses included should treat you well.
A big bonus, this camera accepts all the pre-AI prime lenses Nikon made, some being 50 years old now! These are some phenomenal lenses you can buy on most auction sites for very cheap.

Overall: It easily earns five stars. Ease of use and image quality are all top notch. Owning Nikon's nicest DSLR's for my photography business (I currently own D4's, D810's, and a D610) I purchased one to test out and ended up using it for personal use for about half a year, loving every second of it. Would I recommend this to a professional? No. Would I recommend this to any of my friends looking for a great dslr without spending thousands of dollars? Yes... and it would be my first choice.

Just shooting the family? Are you a student looking to take a photography class? This might be your best choice.

WARNING: VERIFY THE MODEL YOU ARE BUYING IS A USA VERSION. Easiest way to confirm: 99% of these have a serial number (on the bottom of the camera) starting with a 3. Import (aka Grey Market) Nikon's are often bought MUCH cheaper buy non-legit sellers and then sold again to you. If they are the import model, you should be paying a LOT less. And keep in mind, Nikon's warranties do not apply to ANY import model. In fact, their service centers WILL NOT TOUCH OR FIX an import model no matter where or when you bought it... they will just mail it back to you, at your expense. If it breaks or has any issue, you have no other option than to buy a new camera.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: but you will need to upgrade to better lenses to get the most out of this camera
column8: I bought this camera for my girlfriend to take casual photos of the kids, or while we travel. This camera works very well and we have never had any problem with it. The two lenses that came with the camera is decent for everyday photos, but you will need to upgrade to better lenses to get the most out of this camera. I bought the 18-140mm DX lens to use with this camera and it is absolutely stunning. Photos are sharp and clear, with very low noise level. The 24 megapixel sensor in this camera will satisfy 99% of your photography applications with plenty of pixels to crop. The settings are relatively easy to use, but be aware that some commonly used settings (ex: auto focus mode) are still buried in the menu. Also, more focusing points can be nice welcome and will help you frame your subject better. I really like how light weight the camera is since this will be very good for travelling. Shooting with a heavier camera hurts my fingers at the end of the day. Honestly, I think this camera can easily rivals any other APS-C cameras in term of image quality. Since this is a consumer grade camera, it won't have the nice build of more professional cameras. But regardless, it is a solid camera and will get the job done.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Pretty good, with a few caveats
column8: Full disclosure: I really miss my old, fully manual, heavy, tough-as-nails camera that used actual film. Digital devices tend to make me angry. However, I took a leap of faith and bought this bundle, when the price was deeply reduced, because I am sick of the many limitations of my cell phone camera. I am pleased with my purchase overall, with a few caveats. Picture quality on this Nikon is excellent, the feel of the camera is comfortable and light in the hands (if a bit too plasticky), buttons and toggles seem to be in logical positions (for a right-handed person, at least). The lenses seem to be well made, but I'm not sure I can judge that, as my point of reference is the equivalent-length, pre-digital, fully mechanical lens that makes these plastic-casing lenses feel cheap. Once you know where everything is on the camera, and how to get the functions and images you want, it all feels very WYSIWYG. However, until you have learned the ropes, it is nearly impossible to see the icons on the different settings and functions. This camera is made for young eyes, which is annoying for middle-aged me. The printed instructions are written for an utter neophyte (how to hold a camera and stand to take a photo, for instance), so it's easy enough to find out what to do. But why go with an icon the size of an ant when you could use an easily-seen color, or letter? It's frustrating. The editing software that comes with thus is useless, so my husband told me after he tried to install it. He checked various boards online and found many complaints about it saying much the same thing, so I guess I'll be using another program. I do wonder, too, why these things are never sold with memory cards, or why Amazon doesn't link one in the "often bought together" option. I stole one from my husband's stash of digital goodies (he says to me, with just the tiniest bit of an eye roll, that memory cards are never included with these things, so silly me).

column7: That was good enough for me
column8:
I've always bought Nikon equipment since starting out in the hobby. The teacher I learned from only used Nikon because of the quality and reputation. That was good enough for me. I bought an Nikon FM. The light meter would drain the batteries whether on or off so I just stopped using that. Anxious to try the new digital format I bought a D50 DSLR when it came out..I loved that camera. DSLR was light years past film cameras! And no processing!  Sadly, that camera and my equipment was stolen. I bought a Nikon wallet sized camera for the time being.

When Nikon announced the D3200 and D5200 with 24 MP I went out and bought one. Almost from the beginning I had problems with it. It would often refuse to fire no matter what the setting or mode. I assumed I was the problem and thought "I really should read those instructions." I wasn't taking a lot of pictures. The problem persisted, even getting worse. It would focus in and out, then nothing. Sometimes I couldn't get even ONE picture. I took it to Nikon repair, by now out of warranty. They didn't find anything wrong but charged me 1$160.00 to clean it and align the mirror. That didn't fix it. It still wouldn't fire. I took it back to Nikon repair, this time taking the lens. It took weeks before it was ready. They told me the lens was bent and that cost me another $250.00 in repairs (I could have bought one online for as little as $25.00), And again, that did not fix the problem. I now have over $900 in a camera that won't take pictures!  Now I don't trust the Nikon brand and have to start researching, looking for another DSLR.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I love this camera.  I do not know a ton about cameras, but for what I do know the specific settings are great for certain environments, and then the auto is wonderful for when you're not sure what to use.  My biggest complaint about past cameras is how long it took between pressing the shutter button and it actually taking the picture, and also how long it took before you could take another one.  I often missed the shots I was going for, or they were blurry.  But I no longer have this problem.  This camera is priced just right to be a nice camera that I can easily take great pictures of my fast moving daughter instead of paying studios a fortune for, but is still simple enough and priced low enough that you don't have to be a pro photographer or takes tons of classes, or spend your life savings to afford.

column8: I can honestly say I wish I'd never purchased this. I was on the fence between this and saving up for the 7100 and I wish I hadn't bought it since it's barely better than a point and shoot. The new LG G4 phone camera is better than this! Within 90 days the mirror broke and had to be sent back to Nikon. I "upgraded" from a d80 to find that half the features on a camera almost 10 years its senior were missing. The body is plasticky, and to be honest the pictures aren't worth the 24MP. My d80 gets sharper, clearer, and better colored images, now if only they weren't so noisy. That's the only positive difference. The 18-55, well there's a reason you see them everywhere, ditch it. The terrible sigma version is even an improvement. Again, cheaply made, poor quality, and the glass is dire - photos lack color and have a bluish tint that makes them look washed out. Also it won't work with my older speedlites or manual ones either. I'm debating if it's even worth converting to IR as a spare body once I save up for something better.

column8:
This is my first DSLR but I used a film SLR for a while, then switched to digital point and shoot cameras and finally I picked this up.

I brought this with me on a two month bicycle tour from Canada to Key West; during that time it was banged and bounced around in my handlebar bag. It has also traveled around Europe and gone on a bunch of hikes and with me without any problems. The 18-55 kit lens produces some great photos and the whole setup is very reasonably priced. I'm very pleased with my purchase.

One thing that could be better - I was playing around with an entry level Canon DSLR at an electronics store a while back and I felt there was less time between pressing the shutter release and the camera actually taking a picture than with my D3200.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: It's a good camera, lot of good features. I am upgrading from a d60 so everything it new to me. It does serve it's purpose, and for beginning or casual photographers, this is perfect, better in many ways than the 3300 in a few points: 1. The 3300 is smaller, like the cannon sl1, and those are way too small for my hands (I am a middle sized guy) so I like the larger form factor, I hate the feel of mirrorless and the superlight cameras. 2. The low pass filter, while it kills a tid bit of sharpness, can lead to more appealing pictures, and without spending 2-4 times the price of the body on glass, you are not going to get more than 10mpx in sharpness in your shots anyway. It is good in terms of all the shooting options, the AF is fairly fast, not super sports fast. The kit lens with this kit is okay, I got a 55-300 (not much better I know) and they work well for my beginning work. Nice thing is, the sellback price is pretty high if I ever want to go full-frame, but also I would not mind passing this on to a friend, as it will likely last many years. The kit lens on this one is, to my mind, sharper than the kit lens on a 3300, just becuase it is more spread out in the elements and gives you room to get a hand on the lens.

column7: Good entry level DSLR camera for us beginners!
column8: I recently got a refurbished Nikon D3200 camera body on Amazon since I wanted to give a try at basic DSLR photography since I was not overly pleased with the limitations of Superzoom bridge digital cameras for a number of my photos. I was leery about trying a "refurbished" digital camera since in the past I have had horrible luck with refurbished electronic. Since I still had decent Nikon lens from my prior D3100 DSLR camera from several years ago [and that camera did a miserable job for me], I thought I would give the slightly updated D3200 model out using the lens from my old Nikon D3100 camera I no longer have. So far with some learning using Program and a little bit of Auto modes, my photos on this DSLR camera have been quite stunning with great detail qualities I was hoping for! Once you learn a bit about this camera, you should be fine. Lucky there is a full AUTO mode if you are leery about using some manual controls. I have various settings I mastered on my Canon SX-50HS super zoom digital camera and applied those settings on this Nikon digital camera with pretty good luck so far. Outdoor photos in the daylight are quite good once you get the right lens on the camera. Scenic photos outdoors are very good during the day. Indoor photos using flash are quite good, as long as you don't get too close to the subject. Overall the camera is easy to use and menu system is a bit complicated but not overly complicated. I have not tried video yet on this camera, so I cannot comment on that. I got a few extra batteries and 1 extra charger for this camera. Battery life on this camera is pretty good, especially for daytime outdoor photos. Batteries do take quite awhile to recharge....but lucky they last quite awhile in the camera. SD, SDHC and SDXC cards are used in this camera. I use class 4 or 10 SD cards of 16 gigabytes or higher with this camera. This is a very good entry level DSLR camera for those like me that is still learning more about the operations of DSLR cameras and if you want to enter DSLR photography & get pretty good photos, this camera is a pretty good one to get. Since I had Nikon lens from the prior version D3100 still, those lens fits on this D3200 camera perfectly and saved me quite a bit of money that way, avoiding buying more lenses. I gave this camera 5 of 5 stars.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I have a confession to make. I already had this in the black when I bought it in the red (not on Amazon). I was kind of embarrassed at my mistake, but so far I'm the only one to know about it. I figure I now have the added security of a backup DSLR and can get my old D70s converterd to IR once I have money for that.

My first DSLR was the D70s and I got that one when my daughter was a baby (she's now 9 1/2). I found a regular point and shoot to be insufficient at capturing those wonderful baby moments, so I forked over the money for my first DSLR and gave my brother my p&s.

This is considered an "entry-level" DSLR, but that doesn't mean it takes less than ideal pictures. It means this is what you start with, which is great, but if you suspect you're serious about a career in photography, you can test the waters by investing in a kit like this. At the very least you'll have a great camera to take on vacation.

I can't say enough good things about DSLR photography. Yes, it can be frustrating, but no more so than your standard p&s photography. There is a bit of a learning curve, but the pictures you'll be able to produce will be worth it.

column7: A GREAT starter DSLR for a good price.
column8: As an entry level camera you really can't do better.  The price makes it really accessible, it's very easy to use, small enough and light enough that it's easy carry around anywhere, and it take some really great images.  Not a huge improvement on the 3100 overall, but in some key areas it's much better.  Way more MP's (24 and change vs. 14), an infrared receiver for a remote, and it has a mic jack for recording video which for me made a huge difference.  The lens is ok, but definitely upgrade as soon as you can, as you start feeling the limitations of the 18-55 quick.  I needed a camera for a photo class that wouldn't break the bank and was good to learn on, and this really came through for all that.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: The pefect step up from a point and shoot digital camera
column8: I moved from a Nikon Coolpix point and shoot to this D3100 and found the advance features confusing with little help or direction from the included manual.  If I would have one recommendation for prospective purchasers, it would be to "first" purchase David Busch's book (Amazon) on the Nikon D3200.  In my case, the 18-55mm kit lens that came with the camera really wasn't the best for what I wanted to do with the camera.  So after purchasing an additional macro lens, I am taking great close ups.  Compared to the point and shoot, I am in awe of the image quality from this camera.  BTW, there's nothing wrong with the basic 18-55mm kit lens, it's great for general photography.  This particular camera was a Nikon "Certified Refurbished Product" at a lower price than a new camera.  Everything functioned perfectly and there was absolutely no handling marks to indicate it had ever been used.  However, the printing on the outside of the Nikon battery was well worn and I notice that it does hold a charge for as long I expected.  I guess they cut corners somehow to offer a reduced price?  All in all, I'm very happy with the camera and the price.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Great Camera For The Aspiring Professional Photographer
column8:
I've had this camera for a little over a year and I can say hands down its one of the best cameras I have ever owned! I'm a self-employed videographer that recently entered the world of professional photography. Being on a small budget as an aspiring photographer, I find that this camera perfectly meets my needs, earning me some good quality photos and income without costing me a fortune.

At first, I was an average camera user until my regular digital camera died on me. At that time, I was asked by clients if I do photography and so I said yes, and from there, I taught myself professional photography in just a few weeks on this wonderful Nikon series camera.

What's amazing is that I've bought this Nikon D3200 and using this for the first time, I must say it made a great first impression on me.

PERFORMANCE: 5/5
Nikon D3200 features great image quality with 24.2MP and a great ISO. It has a pretty fast shutter speed and it is great to be able to switch between manual and automatic controls.

Image quality: 5/5
Overall, good image depending on the lighting environment. Photo quality is great under a well-lit atmosphere using the built-in flash but I recommend using an external flash. Images aren't quite Paparazzi-worthy but the photos this camera takes will blow you away, nonetheless. It's a great camera for a first-time photographer looking to get their start as a professional. I'd recommend you use more than just the stock included OEM camera lens. I recommend zoom lenses and fish-eye lenses for this camera to create more eye-catching stunning photos. This camera is great for the beginner and intermediate, alike. But if you want to go bigger, do so. If you're a full-blown professional, more than likely, you'll buy a more expensive camera. The average price of this camera currently at the time of writing this review is $300. Professionals usually invest $900+ in their camera. But cost isn't everything. Each photographer must carefully consider a camera not just because its high price but consider image quality and other functionality.

BATTERY LIFE: 5/5
Battery life is impressive, to my standards. But as with anything, battery life always depends how much a device is used and what settings are used. Usually, I use this camera for weddings and receptions. I take an average of 300-500 photos per event day so using the camera from 1PM until about 11PM, I'm able to use this camera the entire event day without charging the factory OEM battery. (*Note: I usually do not use the flash for about 100 photos, as they are outdoor daylight photos. The rest of the photos are indoor photos.)

WHAT'S NOT SO GREAT: Small minor issue but I wish that DSLRs like these featured internal memory storage, instead of just relying on only external SD cards.

column8: I love this camera, Have taken over 7000 pictures with it over the last year and a half. The base lens that comes with it is good however, I ended up buying a 55-200 mm lens, later on so that I could take better pictures of animals at the Cincinnati zoo. The camera performs amazing with the extra zoom from that lens. For those of you that are looking for more features sure the 5200 or the 5300 might be a better deal for you at this point for slightly more money. However, for the average person that is trying to get there feet wet in the dslr world I think the features and performance of this camera is well above average for the pricing point and more than adequate for there needs.

This camera can be used by beginners and enthusiasts alike.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I purchased the Nikon D3200 with 18-55mm lens as a Christmas gift for my sister's boyfriend, who has an older Canon 40D SLR.  He LOVES it, and I've "converted him to the Darkside."  Even though his 40D is a good camera in its own right, the more modern technology, better out of camera color, and menu system of the Nikon D3200 have re-ignited his love of photography.  The D3200 is being phased out at the moment, resulting in great bargains for camera and lens kits.

With the capability to do both video and still photography, the D3200 is a great step for budding filmmakers and family photographers.  The quality of the images far surpasses what can be done with a cell phone camera, but at the cost of more weight and larger physical size.  The ability to change lenses to suit a particular situation is a huge plus, as well as the ability to control exposure.

The camera itself has a nice large screen on the back, a pop-up flash, and the ability to be used in all the camera modes you'd expect from full manual control to aperture or shutter automation to a program mode that turns the camera into a point and shoot machine.  A helpful guide feature in the menu system greatly assists inexperienced photographers, and the large screen on the back makes it easy to see camera settings (although I prefer a screen on the top panel, which this camera lacks).  You can shoot at up to 4 frames per second, which is as fast as expensive film cameras of the 1980's.

The drawbacks for this camera include its smaller size, which may not accomodate some large handed shooters; settings which can only be accessed via the menu instead of a dedicated button; and the fact that the newer D3300 offers improved performance and reduced size for about $100 more.

So, what to do with your hard-earned money?  As of this writing the D3200 is an incredible bargain, with features suitable for all levels of shooters from beginners to professionals.  Quite frankly, for someone who knows how to properly use a camera, you will only get better images from a more expensive camera in highly specialized situations (like virtually no light or where you might need 11 frames or more per second).  The feature set difference between the D3200 and D3300 is negligible, making the D3200 the better buy.  If you're in the market for a digital SLR and money is tight, look no futher:  The D3200 will re-ignite your passion for photography just like it did for my sister's boyfriend.  He's already bugging me for lens recommendations.

column7: WARNING read carefully before purchasing - Pretty dissapointed with this Camera.
column8:
I originally ordered this in December of 2014, then within 2 weeks the shutter began acting up
on non-flash and auto shoot mode. Each shot started to develop blury on day or night shots without the flash.
So I sent out for an exchange and they were pretty hassle free on the replacement. However, the replacement camera
right out of the package was a lemon too, it did not shoot properly shoot at all on any mode.
It kept displaying <Error. Press shutter release button again> which did absolutely nothing.
I had to do a master reset of the shooting mode and it worked properly for a few days.
And then again randomly did the same thing but this did not properly reset the shooting mode and still displayed the error.
I'm not sure if these refurbished or what, but for over $500 this is ridiculous. I'm not sure who to blame Nikon or Amazon.
Either way this is unacceptable.

Only two things I don't like: is too small for my hands (initially considered buying a D90, at last picked this up because it's a newer model), and don'like the way the green color is pictured, specially in jpeg seems yellowish (don't know if it's just me, or is a particular problem on these cameras). Anyway, is the best choice for beginners
