column7: Great Camera Blows All Others Away
column8: Great camera.  That should be the review. A lot people don't know what an SLR is let alone a DSLR. A DSLR you are totally in control. The D3200 is so easy to use. The interface is so user friendly. It has a built-in guide to give you an idea about the shot you are trying to shoot. It also has an auto feature so you can use it as a point and shoot.  It has a manual mode to put you in total control. The D32 has no effects mode. But for the money not to mention this is a SLR not a point and shoot. So effects would be useless. Just read about what an SLR camera is. These type of camera does lot more than anyone can write on a review page. The 24 maga pixels are outstanding. This would make being your first SLR an excellent choice. This is not a professional grade camera, it is consumer grade. The kit lens isn't the best but it will get you started on photography and it will do intil you can upgrade to a better lens. Overall this camera is not a five star camera it is a million trillion star camera.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: and had a much better idea of what she was doing
column8:
I gave this camera to my girlfriend as an anniversary gift.  I've never owned a DSLR camera before - heck, my only camera for the past decade has been a cell phone.  She had dabbled in SLR film photography prior to this, though, and had a much better idea of what she was doing.

My first impression of this camera was more or less "wow... I can actually take pictures in low light without a flash."  The ability to actually capture what one sees naturally is a pretty huge deal.  This may seem pretty stupid to more experienced photographers, but it was a brave new world to me.

The instructions which come with the camera are very clear, and seem definitely written for someone who has never played with a "real" camera before.  There is not only a good explanation of the mechanical features of the camera (ie, which buttons do what) but also contain a decent crash course on manual photography.  They explain the basics -  aperture, shutter speed, ISO, and how each of the different settings configure these settings to produce a different quality of image.  Starting with zero background information, I was able to develop a decent intuition based on these descriptions and some trial and error (ie - just taking a lot of pictures).  Coming from a film background, my girlfriend had the same reaction - "It's nice to just be able to practice with the camera, get instant feedback, and not have to worry about film."

One of the complaints I've seen about this camera compared to the slightly more expensive models, is that the single thumb wheel is limiting, and slows down the photography workflow.  I sort of disagree - at least for a beginner.  First of all, the camera has a number of well placed modifier buttons - so if you set the camera to "manual aperture" mode, the thumb wheel will control the aperture by default and use the magic of DSP to set the shutter speed, exposure compensation and ISO.  However, if you need to override one of those settings, all you need to do is press the correct modifier button, and the thumb wheel will then control the corresponding setting until the modifier button is released.  It works the same way in full manual mode, except then it then turns off all the automatic compensation features as well.  I sort of like this mechanic, as each partial-manual mode provides a single dimension of control (for simplicity), but still allows the user to easily and quickly override the other settings if necessary, without turning the mode dial to a different position.  I think it is a great mechanic for beginners since it provides a clear and easy to understand distinction between the various shooting modes, while still providing quick access to the rest of the settings.  In that sense, I don't see it as a limitation, as much as I see it as a somewhat simpler way to learn the camera while also learning the finer points of photography.  However, if you are already an expert, and understand the ins and outs of the Nikon hardware and software, then I could see it being a bit frustrating.  I haven't had to play around inside the menus to control basic settings at all though, as some have suggested in other reviews.

In terms of build quality, what more can I say which has not already been covered?  You definitely are not sacrificing mechanical or ergonomic quality when buying this camera over some of the more expensive ones.  It feels solid, but light in the hand.  All the buttons have a nice, firm, satisfying snappiness to them with no softness or ambiguity, and they are all placed in a way which makes sense.  The action on the lenses feels like butter, and even though they are plastic - they feel sturdy and high quality.  From what I understand, one's ability to shoot at low shutter speeds and small aperture is directly related to one's ability to balance and control the weight of the entire kit, so the attention to weight reduction which Nikon has put into this body and the lenses should directly translate to better pictures.  Even the Nikon branded bag which comes with the bundle demonstrates an incredible attention to detail, as the interior is completely modular through clever use of velcro dividers, which allows the user to easily move and re-size the various compartments.

The photographs themselves are stunning.  It's really difficult to put the experience into words.  Just the ability to reliably capture and record what one sees opens a whole world of possibilities in terms of shooting.  It is liberating in a way.  Even if your goal is not to have your photographs published in National Geographic, and you just want to document your vacation for posterity, being able to do so simply and reliably makes casual photography much more enjoyable.

In conclusion - this is a great camera for a beginner, and has a ton of room to grow with the user.  Sure, there are better sensors out there, and more feature-rich cameras, but for someone who's primary interest is to learn the basics, take fantastic pictures, and develop the hobby beyond what is possible with a point-and-shoot camera, it really seems like this would be difficult to beat in terms of price, quality and performance.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I am not a professional by any means (yet), but I am working toward it.  This camera is considered an entry-level camera by most professionals and industry insiders, and its true.  But don't let that fool you.  This camera takes amazing shots on Auto.  With just a little bit more knowledge, you can produce truly memorable photos.

I used this to shoot a wedding (the first one I have ever shot).  I shot everything in Aperture mode, in the JPG format.  I recently switched to shooting raw.  I use Aperture for post-processing and the flexibility raw provides is great.  Now that Apple is not continuing development of Aperture, I am switching to Lightroom.

The included "kit" lens is ok.  It gets you going.  I recommend getting a prime lens if you are interested in crisp shots.  My favorite photography is portraiture, and the Nikon 50mm f/1.8G AF-S NIKKOR FX Lens has made a huge difference in my photos.  Because this camera is a DX camera (also called crop sensor), 50 mm is actually 75mm, which puts you close to the sweet spot for portraits.

I chose this over the D3300 because the D3300, while having a faster processor, did not have enough improvements to justify the extra cost.  I took the money I saved by buying this instead of the D3300, and purchased the 50mm lens.

This is a 24 megapixel, lightweight (relatively) tool for beautiful photos.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Nikon D3200 First Choice for SLR  creative camera users.
column8:
After being a professional wedding photographer for over 23 years. (retired now)  Using a heavy 35 mm manual camera and miles of film.... This Nikon D3200 was my first choice for a digital SLR updated camera.  Being fairly  new to "digital" SLR. I caught on to the instructions  pretty fast since it's almost the same as it used to be on my old camera.  The concept and rules of photography didn't change....  I found that using this camera was pretty easy after going through the instruction book, plus trial and error, just taking photos with the camera.  This camera has all the features that I would use.... even has a photo editor in the menu... color enhancer, crop, red eye corrector,  change photo to black and white, even has a star filter add in... warming or cooling effect,  lots of added stuff.. I used to do in the darkroom with color prints, manually.

This camera comes with a lens 18 to 55 mm witch to me is a great small zoom lens, but it  wouldn't be my prime lens.  I would use a straight  35 mm for all around use, can use the lens in much lower light without a flash,  and the 18 to 55 mm for other things like family gatherings where you don't have to step around to get your shot,  just zoom in or out to make the frame fit the subject being photographed.

The camera has a pop up flash witch is real handy and easy to use, good for about ten to twelve feet.  Notice the flash is slightly higher then the lens.  You are more then likely going to get red eye pretty easy if the subject looks at the camera lens while being photographed ... The fix is having a TTL. external, dedicated  flash on the hot shoe that bounces off the ceiling ....much better results.

My research  home work paid off,  I believe ..... I was looking at the D3300  newer camera model,  and the specs. didn't change much, but the price went up for the newer model... so I saved about sixty bucks buying the older model camera.  The D3200 started new add on's after the D3100  like one I noticed,  would be the wireless controller remote shutter  ML-L3
Buying the VR lens was worth the extra money.  They do sell this without the VR lens.... for less $.  You need V R on your lens,  when you use any kind of zoom lens..... Keeps the vibration down for less blurring on slower shutter speeds or fast moving objects.  VR = Vibration Reducer

Overall This Nikon D3200 was my First choice for an all around SLR camera.....  Once you get your SLR camera in your hands, your pretty much will be commented to it.  Then it starts to be a collection of "products to fit"  and add on to the camera.  Since you can do so much more being creative photography with this camera, over a point and shoot camera.  I gave this 5 Stars.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: D3200 bundle with 10/55 and 55/200 non-VR review
column8:
The Nikon D3200 is a solid camera. It basically allows anyone entry into the world of DSLRs for a fraction of what many good cameras cost. It has a large screen for easy use that you can turn off if you dislike it, and easy use buttons to cycle through light, flash, ISO, and so on. It clocks over 24 megapixels, which is quite a bit and allows you to play with image size. I like that it has a button I can hit to remind me of what settings I am currently using, allowing me modifications on the fly, and you can set it for a load of changes. The grip is not that bad, although this body style certainly does make for a different style of handling. In addition to the neck strap, I use a hand strap as well, mostly because I have long, skinny fingers.

For the beginner, there is a guide setting in addition to the auto features, allowing the user to easily set their camera for moving pictures, reduced blur, portraits, landscapes, and so on. There is an advanced guide setting as well, allowing a user to not only do something easily but to understand how this is accomplished. That is something I liked about this setting; oftentimes a person flips to a specific setting but does not understand how shutter speed or light allows that setting to work. You have an auto function as well, plus settings for portraits, no flash, landscapes, and so on. The manual modes also allow for different levels of control, allowing the user to manipulate shutter speed, aperture, program settings for ISO control, and manual mode for doing it all. Basically the camera caters to all levels, but it allows beginners to walk through everything.

The kit lenses in this set are pretty good, actually. People need to note that they do not have VR (vibration reduction) so you get shake. This is not such a big deal with pictures but taking good video will require the use of a tripod. The kit comes with an 18/55, great for doing landscapes at the lowest setting and good for doing portraits. It works as a carry lens, although the 18/55 is not my lens of choice by any means. The 55/200 allows you to get out further, giving you distance to take pictures of animals and people enjoying activities. The 55/200 does have a pretty good distance to it  you can photograph buzzards in flight, for example, although the VR does come into play with longer distance shots.

The bag is not bad, although I did encounter a few issues with it after time. The stitching on mine popped apart in places, which I did not like on something that essentially prices at around 40 USD if purchased separately. It has a zipper mesh pouch inside, a zipper pouch on the front, an area for storage on the back, and two side pockets. I like the zipper for things like my remote control (purchased because then 10 second timer on pictures is sometimes way too fast for me) and filters such as UV, macro (also purchased separately).

Note when you review this the body type and what that means, including what lens you can use. You need AF-S lens because of the type of camera, otherwise you end up with lens that only do manual focus jobs. You also should look up some videos taken with the camera because the D3200 picks up A LOT of background noise with the internal mike and it also picks up the sounds of the camera focusing. You might also want to look into getting a better flash for your camera depending on why you buy it; the kit lens with the camera flash will do well in normal light but indoor light will come up a little dark. You can buy external gear to remedy this for a good price, and you can buy lens to fit this that do all sorts of things like macro (I love taking pictures of insects), landscaping, portraiture (lenses with better aperture, basically), and so on. Nikon makes great cameras and really like the D3200. It makes taking pictures fun.

All I can say is that a NIKON DSLR has been on my wish list since I had to put my Pentax film SLR on the shelf years ago (nobody develops film  -- or even sells it  -- anymore in my area). I used (and still do use) my little NIKON Coolpix as an everyday camera, but yearned for the control that you can only get from a true SLR -- to experiment with exposures and so forth. So, I saved up to buy this baby. I am just in the baby steps of learning. I will probably be learning for a long time. The camera rather overwhelms me. However, I will learn and I will get as good as I used to be.  I am in 7th heaven. Now I just need to get enough time away from writing work load to spend time getting to know it.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: The perfect beginner's SLR - NIkon quality at a remarkable price
column8: I am amazed at this little bundle. If you are new and want a nice, inexpensive DSLR but are drowning/hesitating among all the options and prices, don't. Just buy this, you will not regret it. I picked up this refurb kit a month ago for $365, and I did a double take because I couldn't believe everything I was getting. I personally shoot with my trusty old D90 still, but this was for a specific project that needed a dedicated camera. I have to admit that this shoots way more reliably than my D90. It's focus is incredibly fast and the metering is Nikon perfect. It's amazing what half a decade in technology leads to both in quality and in price. This D3200 bundle is the ideal camera for someone who is looking to step up from point-and-shoot cameras and phone snapshots and get started with digital photography. It is pretty full-featured and has amazing picture quality for a fraction of the cost of the more expensive models. Basically, this is a way to get into the hobby or dramatically improve the quality of your pictures without breaking the bank. I couldn't even tell that it was refurbished. It looked brand new to me. Not a scratch or a nick anywhere, and the LCD was bright and crystal clear. With this, you can produce stunning photos (and videos) without being reduced to tears if you drop it on accident or be too afraid to hand it to a friend/relative to take a picture for you. As is often said, having the best (read: most expensive) camera in the world is useless if you're too afraid to take it outside and take pictures. The lens on this is a perfect first lens. It's 18-55mm, which means it's a zoom lens (you spin a ring on the lens to select the region you are capturing, zooming in one way and zooming out the other). It's sharp, fast, and handles low light decently. I'd of course recommend the spectacular fixed 35mm for its tack sharpness and to shine in low-light as well as the 55-200mm to give you some telephoto (serious distance zoom) coverage, but these lenses each cost half the price of this camera kit! You can see how photography can become a very expensive hobby very quickly. I'd hold off on those as a first purchase and wait to see how things go. But this is why this kit in particular is a great starter package. You get an entry level, but still very solid camera body and a decent zoom lens. Don't let the term "entry level" make you feel cheap, this is still a Nikon camera with a legitimate Nikkor lens. It is categorically different and more capable than any point and shoot or pinhole phone camera. Period. End of discussion. If you find that you want/need more, Nikon will be more than happy to sell you more lenses or step up to a more expensive camera body later. For the first step though, this is ideal. I should note that in addition to taking ridiculously high quality photos, this also does quite well with video. It can do 1080p video at up to 30 fps or 720p at 60 fps. I'd have loved to have seen 1080p at 60fps, but you don't get that unless you go to the D3300 or D5300 which cost tons more than this D3200 kit. That's just not worth the extra cost. In practice, I've been amazed. Even under terrible lighting conditions (e.g. indoor low light under coiled fluorescent lights with completely mismatched color temperatures and an LCD as an intended capture target) I can get remarkable photo and video quality with perfect color reproduction. Nikon's white balance settings do sheer magic where even a prosumer camcorder just fails miserably (I'm looking at you Sony). Sure, some of the knobs and dials are tucked away in menus and not as easily accessible as on the more pro-level cameras, but for the price, I'll deal with fiddling with the menus on the few times that I need them (honestly, my D90 was overwhelming for months when I first got it). For the vast majority of the time, I just set it to program or manual mode and fire away. It's beautiful.

We purchased it on the back end of the lot, right after the D3300 came out, so color choices were a bit limited at the lower price point.

This is an improvement over the D3100, in terms of image resolution.  It takes great shots.  My husband is having great luck with it, right out of the box.  It probably helps that I know a bit about photography, so he's not forging new skills alone.

It's quite a bit smaller than my D7100, and lacks many of the features of the D7100, but for the entry level photographer?  Really can't go wrong.  Great, great camera.

column7: Great Camera for Beginners to Experts
column8: I bought this camera about a month ago. It's my first DSLR or what I call "real camera". I went with the bundle because I didn't want to buy just the camera and 55m lens and have no bag. The bag is a nice size, light, durable zippers, and appears to be pretty durable. It comes with Velcro dividers so you can separate everything however you'd like. I haven't accumulated too much for mine yet. The bundle is well worth the extra $$$. The 55-200mm lens is valued around $200.00 by itself if purchase separately. I'm pretty impressed with the zoom on it as well. One thing I didn't like is that this bundle only comes with one lens hood (I bought a second on here for $3.00). Now on to functionality... I began shooting in "auto" mode, which is recommended to get a real feel for the camera. The AFS (autofocus) is a great feature for new photographers as well. Luckily both lenses are AFS in this bundle. The fact that this body allows 24.2 megapixels is insane. I can take a photo with little zoom, crop it, blow it up, and have very little to no blur whatsoever. I have taken several photos, from car shows, to concerts, to NHRA races and they have all turned out great. I'm not a big fan of the Nikon software that comes with the camera. I would recommend Picasa as a free download for editing and affects. There are a lot of features on this camera that would definitely need some studying to figure out when/how to apply correctly. I'd brush up on some basic DSLR info on Google so you will understand focus/shutter speed differences. I wish the wireless connector for this camera wasn't so expensive either ($60 range). A wireless remote can be picked up for less than $10 and I have found a 50" tripod I plan to purchase here soon for $9.99. Overall, I REALLY like this camera and don't have any dislikes at this point. Maybe someone with more experience would disagree, but for now, I am thoroughly impressed and would recommend this camera to anyone.

column8:
I really wish I could get to the ISO settings as easily as I can get to the exposure and aperture controls.

This really is my only complaint with this camera; beyond that it handles easily (my hands are, I suppose, average size), the flash is bright, and if you, like me, want a camera capable of taking great images without a terribly high price tag, my experience says that this is better than its competitors.  The lens is also a winner, creating consistently sharp images at all zooms and apertures.  True, even wide open at 3.5 the amount of light available makes indoor handheld photography a tad challenging, but with a little practice the settings can be reached which make it possible to achieve stunning results.

Learn about the settings!  They all matter, and do plenty.  Also, learn about lenses.  They also do plenty, but can be plenty expensive if you need to get more specialty results.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Although I know my review will fall between the other high-rated ones eventually, I thought i'd share my positive experiences with this camera.

PROS:
-Price. $500 is cheap in comparison to other similar (albeit lower quality) cameras, like the Canon Rebel T3i, 60D, or even the newer T5i.

-Build Quality. This camera is built in Thailand to the extent of my knowledge but the quality control on mine is absolutely incredible. Doesn't feel cheap or flimsy. Has nice grips and a comfortable weight to it. Not an overly bulky camera either.

-Image quality/sensor. At $500, you get a true 24.2 megapixel DSLR camera. SnapSort in their comparison of the D3200 vs its direct competitor, the Canon Rebel T3i 18 megapixel DSLR, stated that the image quality on the D3200 is over 20% better as attributed to the D3200's 10% larger image sensor and higher true megapixel count, which accounts for 30% more detail in photos. The image sensor is very high quality and this camera consistently takes incredible pictures. I'm not a professional photography by any means, this is simply a great hobby of mine, but I am a perfectionist about pictures. The ability to easily take awesome pictures with this camera is second to none.

-Ease of use. I am an amateur photographer who was looking for a nice upgrade and I made sure to do my homework when it came to selecting a camera. I ended up on this camera because of what everybody else said, it's ease of use was a major selling factor in the purchase. I've had this camera for a few weeks and I still haven't even figured out everything it's capable of-- there's quite a bit! But the guide mode helps you with some basic and advanced photography.

-Nice lens kit. Out of the box I'll admit the 18-55mm is quite limited in what it can do, especially as somebody who enjoys macrophotography, but it'll be able to do most of the shots you'd like to take. The VR feature is nice as well.

-Nikon brand quality. As always, Nikon has delivered a high quality product. I've owned a few Nikon products before and they've never failed me. I prefer Nikons to Canons in the world of DSLRs anyway.

-Ability to save as JPG/Raw.

-Out of the box: comes with body, lens, strap, battery and charger, etc.

CONS:
-I can't really seem to think of any that aren't dumb little nitpicks.

Final thoughts: This camera is perfect for the beginner and good enough for the master. It does it all!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I'd been in the market for a camera for some time, researching, reading, talking to family and friends. I ended up buying this one after another model I wanted ended up being sold out. I'm new to the hobby of photography, but its always something I wanted to learn more about.  So far the camera is performing very well, its fast and does a good job of taking photos, it has a fair amount of settings that I really need to learn, but so far the auto setting is doing a good job with the photos, I got some beautiful shots of local snow covered mountains, so the photo quality seems quite high to me, I was able to resize pictures to a more manageable level and still keep the resolution.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: This camera takes beautiful pictures and it is very easy to operate. Its pact with features and its not too big.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I've got friends with cameras that cost two or three times this one, and their light balance isn't as good as this camera.  I've really never seen anything like it.  I'm definitely not a pro photographer, so likely don't have experience with a wide array of cameras, but if you're looking to impress but don't have thousands of dollars - this is the camera to get.  If you add the $400 18-200mm AF lens, you'll be ready for many more photo shoots than the standard lens will allow.

The HD video is decent, but has some buzzing even in no-wind that I find distracting. I wouldn't recommend this if you're looking for HD video, but the photos this thing takes are truly stunning and require little or no color enhancements or light balancing.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: Although my son previously owned an Olympus for his underwater pics (he's a scuba instructor) he researched and decided on this camera which I bought for his birthday in February.  He's delighted and thinks it's the most professional camera for a regular user and I have no regrets with the purchase from the reports he's been relaying to me.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: for the price - and for a camera - wonderful
column8:
I teach photography and we used to use the D3000, and have recently added several 3200s. It is great. I think that if you are looking for a high quality camera and this is your price range - it is easy to recommend. I have shot with this many times. It is not my primary camera outside of class - but I think you could do almost any style/genre of shooting with this.

Advantages of higher end cameras are small, like being able to use a higher iso while maintaining quality, or being able to just use manual modes (like the D700/D800) but you do have the options on manual, of course, here.

This is a brilliant package. The price makes it even better.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Bought the one lens kit from Roberts LP and I LOVED IT
column8: This is my first DSLR camera, I'm amazed by its quality. 10/10 with Roberts LP and AMAZON! I did a LOT of research (about 3 months of it) since I wanted to make sure that I will be buying the best out of the best according to my money range, and I'm pleased to say that I made the BEST decision. The User Manual is great, tells you everything that you need to know, it's like your wingman for the camera. You gotta love what Nikon did with this product, it has an amazing resolution (I'm talking about the 18-55 lens) and for a beginner like me, it's perfect. I will buy better lenses in the future. Oh by the way, YOU NEED TO TRY THE VIDEO OPTION, the recordings are incredible, If you have an independent band, know how to work with Adobe programs, know a little about lighting and setting a good background, this is the camera for your first professional video. Cheers!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
My husband and I are both advanced amatuer photographers. We met while working at Ritz Camera almost 20 years ago now.  While he still clings to his beloved Hassablad cameras, and his Nikon f3hp, and f5 cameras, he uses his digital cameras more and more.  I have always been a Canon girl.  My film cameras are way behind me now.
So when our daughter decided she wanted to get into photography, I was all set to give her Steve's F3hp, and a few lenses to take to her photography class.  Hubby was not impressed.  He went out anf got thios kit at BJ's and gave it to her for Christmas.  Immediately, she was taking pics with it, and uploading them to wherever.  She started a seperate instagram page so she could share her photos, and show her learning curve.  With a little help here and there from both her father and I, she is blossoming into quite a little photog. The whole setup is quite easy to understand.  It points naturally, and the photos are crisp, and clear.  With a few add ons, she has become even more impressive.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I do like it. It really is a glorified point and shoot. If you want it to shine get some really good lens.  Reality is lens make the camera more than camera makes the lens. Good lens will cost about or more than the cost of the 3200. My advice if you hate changing lens is to get this then the 18-300 macro zoom. Yes it is heavy but you will not have to carry four or five lens like I do.  That lens is a decent all around but not a good anything. Also get either a GOOD monopod or tripod. I have one of each but use the monopod more than the tripod. Remember their is a limit to what you can carry and you will miss a lot of great pics changing lens, putting on a tripod etc. The VR is terribly over rated. Take every photography course you can, learn you camera and how to set up your pic.  BTW Canon makes a camera that is similar. And cannon, usually has better lens though pricy. Also get a body only and save your real money for better lens.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Here is a good digital SLR camera with one of the highest mega-pixel available today (February) in the market for the non-professional hobbyist. By non-professional hobbyist I mean those for whom photography is not their means of income, but who cannot remain without a camera. I belong to that category.

The pictures, as is expected from Nikon DSLRs, are exceptional clear. If clarity is your concern, here is the camera for you. However, if zoom is your concern, you will have to buy zoom lenses because the standard lens (18-55mm) gives you a maximum of 4x equivalent optical zoom. Zoom lenses can be expensive and you should be ready to spend at least half of what you pay for the camera for your first zoom lens, with progressively more for longer focal lengths (= greater zoom values).

Overall this is a good machine from the the D series of Nikon DSLrs

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: this camera caught my eye a long time ago and i finally purchased .. i was between this one and the cannon beginner model. i don't have any regrets. this is user friendly with a auto setting and a guide setting. perfect for beginners . not that intimidating or overwhelming!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I messed with a D3100 before I bought this, and I almost didn't buy this because I couldn't take a decent picture with the 3100 to save my life. I am not a professional photographer, but I understand the basics, and have been learning... and needed something to handle a couple tasks. I am a pilot and like to do some aerial photography for fun, I needed something my GF could pick up and take some nice shots while we are out flying. And also other simpler tasks like taking pictures around the holidays etc.

This gets the job done, has enough advanced features to keep me busy trying things and learning about photography, good battery life, pretty straight forward to operate...  you get quality pictures for a good price. Lots of available lenses and goodies to go with it too...

I read the reviews on this vs. the Canon T3... similar price range (canon being a little more expensive) and the majority of reviews favored this Nikon. I came into this neutral, no brand preference, just wanted something good for what I could afford to spend, and slightly over half the reviews I read favored the 3200 (though they are both considered to be great cameras). So I went with this one and I'm happy...

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Amazing entry level DSLR camera! Definitely worth the money!
column8: I am by no means a professional photographer. In fact, I'm just barely getting into it and I have to say, the money I spend on the Nikon D3200 is well worth it! The camera is very easy to use and has great manual features. Camera feels solid while holding it in the hands and doesn't feel cheap. Most of my family has Canon DSLR's and I was going to go with Canon, but took the risk and got this Nikon camera instead. It has not disappointed whatsoever. The images come out unbelievably crisp. It's not the megapixels that count, but rather how you shoot with the camera and the techniques. Of course, having 24MP's are great as pictures come out razor sharp. For those that just want to point and shoot out of the box, you can with the D3200 with the guide mode. Makes taking quick photographs easy and you learn to dive into the camera at the same time. The shutter seems fairly quiet when taking shots. Buttons are well placed and adequately labeled. Wish it had a touch screen for quicker selection and settings, but thats being nitpicky. Getting to the setting is quite easy and fast. Already bought some filters, a tripod and extra batteries. I'll be going to a wedding soon, so I'll try and get to know the camera better so I can take some great pics. Again, this is one of the best enrty-level cameras you can buy.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I have had Nikons in the past and last camera was an Olympus E420. First let me Say glad to be back to Nikon!. Buy this camera! I had trouble with my Olympus indoors in low light. This camera does the low light flash flawless. I am impressed at ease of controls and menus are much easier and straight forward. I went on a photography outing to Some ice castles that were lighted with LED's inside the ice and I tried Portrait in low light setting which worked fabulous lighting my wifes face in the low light and not washing out the ice sculpture lighting. I tried Auto shutting the flash off in the dark with the LED ice lights the only lighting and I was excited and amazed when I got home to view them at home on the computer!! They came out excellent. This is with the standard zoom kit lens. I didn't take as much pictures with the Olympus because of limitations in low light and confusing menus. Even the digital screen iseasy to understand what setting your in and how to get where you want to go. No going away from Nikon for me anymore!! This camera is just new for me so I will update my review when I try more applications.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)

Amazing camera and easy to use, however if you want manual controls they are just a spin of the dial.  Here is my first serious short using this and you can see how clear the film is.  I would recommend this camera as a serious contender for a filmmaker.

[...]

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
My Kodak got drowned in a surprise T-storm.  I fished it out of about 2 inches of water.  I tried everything to dry it, but it was history!

I am a professional, but no longer as a business, so I cannot see spending the thousands of dollars on a camera that I have to be so very careful about traveling with me everywhere because of the liability.  Still wanted a great camera that would be easy to take with me everywhere and is fairly easy to use, but also gives me control over how I want my photos to look.

I searched high and low, comparing many options, scouring Consumer Reports, checking out many online blog reviews, etc.  Finally I decided on this model for two reasons.  One, my favorite film camera is my Nikon and I have the AF lenses and flash that go with it and this model has a hotshoe for an external unit.  Two, I still like the viewfinder on my cameras!  Sometimes the sun or light glare prohibits using the screen.

Even great for someone who isn't a professional.  I wouldn't recommend it for a beginner or a point and shooter because the controls can be a bit confusing to someone who has no knowledge of photography or the how and why for each of the settings.  I didn't give it a full 5 stars because sometimes it takes too long to start up when I power it on.  It's a little technical when you want to switch from the viewfinder and the screen....can't just change in quick second; you might lose your shot!

Great photos, great video's, so far!  Love playing with all the gadgets and settings!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I bought this for my wife and she is getting used to the menus and creative ways to take pictures. It can be set up as a point and shoot camera or set up to give very professional looking pictures. So many whistles and bells. It is not overwhelming to operate. There are menus that give suggestions for shooting different scenes and setting of the aperture and shutter speed and focus to produce really professional looking high quality pictures. And the SLR feature allows you to purchase different lenses for different applications. Really nice sturdy feel to this camera system.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I did a lot of research on which digital Nikon to buy.  For my price range, it came down to the D5100 and the D3200.  I believe the D5100 had a few more advanced features but the flip-out screen just seemed like an accident waiting to happen.  I tend to crop my photos so the extra MP should help.

  After spending 2 months with this camera I absolutely love it and know I made the right decision.  The photos rival DSLRs 2x the price.  I have not read much bad press about this camera and for good reason.  Buy the camera body then go out and buy the best glass you can afford.  I matched mine with the new 18-140mm and 35mm prime.

  Cons:  Body is a little small for my larger hands
  ISO in increments of 100 with 100 being the lowest
  No in camera panorama
  No multi-exposure bracketing

  Pros:  Image Sensor
  Shutter Speed
  In Camera HDR
  Button Layout

There are a few more pros and cons but for the money, you can not beat this camera.  Overall a better value than the D5100 and quite possibly the D5200 IMO.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Excellent camera with a couple of drawbacks
column8: I bought this camera over a year ago to replace my Samsung HMX-R10 and it works brilliantly as a movie-making camera and as a still camera. Naturally, as there is a focus ring the D3200 is not focused to infinity so when you're lining up your shots, be it video or stills, you will need to take a bit of extra time. This wouldn't be such a hassle if there was a pop-out reversible screen (as featured on the Nikon D5100 model) but there isn't, which means if you are out shooting on your own and want yourself to be in the shot then you are going to run into many logistical problems. Quite annoying, but it's my only real gripe with this model. There IS auto-focus, naturally, but you can't be sure that you're actually in the shot and in position without a reversible screen. The quality of the pics, at 24.2 megapixels, is amazing, with very deep colors and bold contrast. When loaded onto your computer you can zoom-in many times without losing resolution. It's great. There are a few picture editing tools but I've never really experimented with them as I prefer my shots to look as natural as possible. The long-exposure feature is capable of creating night shots with amazing light effects. The video can record in 24fps, which is a major plus if you want your movies to look as film-ic as possible. Obviously setting it to 1080p is the best option. I wish that it shot in 2k but simple 1080p is all that it offers. Still, the quality of the video image is excellent, and a huge improvement on simple camcorders. There is an audio-in jack for attaching externals mics, and a shoe on the top for securing it (or an auxiliary flash), but when taking pics the built-in flash will not fire properly with a mic loaded. The strap is a bit of a gamble. Twice now the clasps have given way when I've been carrying it around my shoulder. Luckily, I was quick enough to catch the camera in my hand, but it's just too heavy. I'd recommend using vinyl tape or staples to bind the cord and ensure that it does not come undone. The 18-55mm lens is pretty basic, and you will have to stand very close to anything that you want to shoot, but it works perfectly with the 52mm Wide-Angle Lens if you want a mini-IMAX feel to your shots, and can also be used with the AG-LA7200 Anamorphic Lens to frame your movies in full 2.35:1 widescreen. The stills have a native aspect ratio of 1.55:1 and will come out in 2:1 with an anamorphic attachment that has a 1.33:1 squeeze. The camera uses SCHD memory cards that are loaded into a little slot on the right of casing, but the door that closes over this slot feels a little flimsy. It's never once broken on me, but it's one of those things that once broken can never be repaired which means that a new camera is on the cards if it does snap off. A very good camera, despite the drawbacks I have listed, I'd recommend this camera to newbs and novices as it is very easy to get familiar with. I love the red color and can stop polishing it whenever I get it out. I don't want any marks or fingerprints. Just keep an eye on the strap.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
This is my first SLR digital camera.  It was a little intimidating when I first got it a year ago and I put it away for almost 8 months, preferring my Pentax point and shoot, because there were fewer settings.  I took this one out of the back pack again in November and determined to learn how to use it.

It takes fantastic low light shots and it gives great product shots for my website using the product tent with full spectrum CFBs.  I'm a total noobie with Digital SLR, even though I used to take photos with a Pentax K1000 and develop my own film.  Digital SLR is nothing like the old Pentax.

I also use this camera to take landscape shots and live animal shots.  It does a really good job with both.  Some of my landscape shots look like paintings, the focus is so crisp, and the light play with the camera is really attractive.  It has a fast shutter speed for action shots and to catch moving animal shots, like seals leaping to grab a herring out of your hand.  I haven't mastered the grandchild shots yet, though.

The pictures are 6 to 8 mb in size and give lots of room for editing using the built in editing tools.  The video is good and the built in microphone is better than the one in my Flip video camera (which stopped working this Fall).

The camera has a learning curve.  I'm not going to outgrow this camera for a long time.  I'd recommend getting one of the camera guides to shorten your learning time, if you've never used an SLR digital camera before.

I still haven't learned how to fully utilize all the bells and whistles, but now I'm determined to learn.

Buy a sturdy tripod for it.  I got an aluminum tripod and the wind blew it over in the first 5 minutes of trying to shoot a video with it.

The red colour is the best.  It was the reason I decided on this camera over the alternatives.  And after a year, I still love it.

column8: Still learning to use all of the features and trying to improve my skills.  Very easy to use if you're not already experienced, easy to catch on and learn

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I did a great deal of research before finally choosing the Nikon D3200.  In addition to the megapixels, it had a few more improvements over the D3100, and I decided I was willing to shell out the extra dollars for the improvements.  I've only had my camera for a month.  I have no prior experience or knowledge with things like aperture, shutter speed, ISO, etc.  I'm slowly learning through research and playing with the camera.  I had read this camera was great for beginners, because the LCD screen is very visual as you are making changes.  For example, when changing the aperture, there is a circular image that gets smaller and wider showing what you are doing, etc.  The product came with the standard 18-55mm lens as described.  I haven't really used the lens much as I purchased an additional lens when I purchased the camera.  I've read the lens is a good beginner lens.  As you learn more about how to use the camera, you'll eventually desire other lenses.  The camera comes with the rechargeable battery and charger, a camera strap that says NIKON and a lens cover.  There is as small built in flash that you manually turn on and off. If you are new, take the time to read the instruction manual and then get on the internet and read, read, read.  It might seem very overwhelming at first as you hear terms and numbers that you don't even kind of understand, but once the basics click you'll open up a whole new world.  If you've been wanting to invest in a camera, I can't imagine you would regret this one. There are reviews all over the internet that confirm this is a good, quality camera.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: D3200 Great for Both Beginners and Moderate Photographers
column8:
I purchased this camera to get some professional quality photos at a reasonable price for a beginner. I must say that the D3200 well exceeded all my expectations for spending about $550 on the body as well as the kit lens. However, I will update this review over the life of the camera, so you can get an accurate review to make an informed decision.

Let's begin...

So far, the camera on auto is great, but it's true beauty lies when the user tries to mess around with the manual settings. I've been able to achieve some fantastic photo effects by changing the features from the shutter speed to the ISO settings.

Based on my pictures (and one video) thus far, I can definitely say the following:

1. Auto Mode is okay. Honestly though, if all the you want to do with a camera is take pictures on auto., then purchase a cheaper digital camera since you won't be utilizing the D3200's full potential... or any DSLR for that matter.

2. The 18-55mm kit lens takes great pictures, but its certainly not professional quality; Let alone designed for professionals. I fully intend to learn the camera and master it's settings before committing to a more expensive (professional quality) lens, which can amount to quite an expensive sum.

3. The video visual was amazing, but the video audio was not. The camera does have a external mic input, which I intend to take full advantage of. TIP: Make sure to purchase a class 6 memory card or higher or the video may turn out "laggish." I purchased a class 10.

4. The 24.2 Megapixels was great if I wanted to crop without ruining the quality of the photo, otherwise it didn't make much (if any) difference when compared to 12ish megapixel photos.

To sum up my experience, the D3200 is a great camera for beginners. I would even say the it's well suited for moderate level photographers if the camera isn't used on auto. mode. If anyone believes that they aren't getting great pictures, then I would say that the problem is most likely the photographer... not the camera itself. The camera truly does take fantastic pictures, yet it's less likely to happen on auto... and forget about professional quality with this 18-55mm lens. To truly take great pictures with this camera, you'll go far by going out one day to take a ton of pictures on various manual settings... then see for yourself what the effects are.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: A Very Good Easy To Use Tool For Taking Very Good Pictures
column8:
I have been an avid amateur photographer since I was young.  For many years I used various 35mm cameras and one medium format one that take film.  I took thousands of slides and pictures.  When digital started with Sony floppy disk cameras I bought one.  I used the digital cameras with my work in heavy machines.  I graduated to more Sony digitals.  I always had high end phones, and those started having better and better digital cameras.  I never got rid of my favorite film cameras.  These include a 1953 Voightlander Prominent, Olympus OM2n, Olympus XA, Olympus Stylus.  I learned to edit pictures early on using Photoshop.  I have used Picasa since introduced.  I really like Picasa as it is OK for the thousands of pictures of machines I need to quickly edit and add to web sites.  Recently I have started using iPhoto.  iPhoto IMHO is much more capable than Picasa.

I stopped using film a few years back and have started back using film in the last two years.  I started to try and get better pictures with my digital compact and phone cameras.  Those work well with scenery pictures at a mid level of quality, but were hopeless taking pictures of pets or children or any action.  When I saw the Olympus OMD in chrome I immediately wanted one of those.  Looked my my 1980 Olympus OM2n which I have always thought was just about a perfect camera and beautiful.  Mine works perfectly after 33 years BTW.  So I did months of research on the OMD and then tried to see and hold one in person.  There is only one Olympus dealer in San Diego and they kept selling out of them.  Once I got to see a black OMD but no chrome.  Then Oly started the on again off again sales.  I was pressured by going on a long trip last summer so I wanted to get a new DSLR.  This was complicated by the fact that Olympus is a smaller sensor format that not everyone likes.  No actual live viewfinder.  And it costs a lot more than Nikon 3200.

The other camera I considered extensively was the Sony Nex 6.  In the past I had only bought Sony digitals and consider them a superior product.  The Nex 6 was less money than the Olympus OMD.  What turned me towards the Nikon was recommendations.  On line recommenders like Nikons.  The Sony early last summer had a limited selection of lenses like the ones I wanted.  Olympus had want I wanted, but I never could hold one in my hands and it was twice the price of the Nikon 3200.  I drove several times to the local camera store to see the Olympus, but no luck.

So I ordered the Nikon and two additional lens from Amazon.  As usual Amazon delivered everything fast and in perfect condition.  The Nikon has worked flawlessly from day 1.  The 3200 is fairly easy to learn.  The adjustments and controls take a little time to get used to but are relatively easy.  It takes very good digital pictures without much effort.  Those who just want to take pictures that are pretty good should just take the standard 18-55mm lens with image stabilization and leave it at that.  It works fine for pictures blown up on my 27" computer monitor.  The only annoying thing is that with a lens as slow as this one the built in flash is always popping up.  Even in shots that don't need a flash.  So I find myself setting the camera flash off frequently.  I have not used the two additional lenses I bought much.  The longer lens a few times for distant scenery.  I thought I would use the much faster 35mm lens all the time.  So far that is not the case.  Before I bought it I did not notice that the 35mm lens did not have image stabilization.  When I have used it that has not been an issue.  I come from many cameras that did not have IS and always instinctively hold my breath and stay still when shooting.

The Nikon is much larger than my Olympus OM2.  I would prefer the OM2 size.  But I find the 3200 very comfortable in my hands.  Yes it is big, but the size and weight works well.  It is a plastic camera.  It is well made but very plastic.  Much more so than my last Sony compact camera.  The Sony has a much more pleasing quality look to it.  The comparison between the Voightlander or OM2 in quality appearance and feel is vast.  In the distant past I owned a Nikon FM SLR and can attest that Nikon knows how to make a very high quality look and feel camera.  The Nikon is not cheap plastic feeling, but rubberized sorta cheap plastic feeling.  If you really like Apple products like Mac Books, iPhones, iPads you may not like this product.  It is in no way a jewell like thing of beauty like Apple products.

But it takes very good pictures easily.  It focuses fairly quickly and comes up with very good color balanced shots on automatic.  It has a small view finder.  Much much much smaller and less useful than my 33 year old Olympus.  For me the viewfinder size and lack of light is the worst feature.

I have most of my film cameras on display in a glass cabinet in my office.  The Voightlander is a thing of beauty.  It still works well after 60 years.  The last time it was cleaned and worked on was 1979.  It is hard to use.  Mostly because of it's small and dull view finder.  Maybe some day I will buy a Leica M3 for the finder.  The metal working and gorgeous glass lenses on the Voightlander put a smile on my face just holding it in my eye or hand.  The Olympus OM2n is only slightly less so.  The metal on the Oly is not as nice but the Olympus easy operation makes up for it.  Both the Voightlander and the Olympus are about the same size.  The Nikon 3200 as a tool to take pictures is a good camera.  The shots I have taken with it at the highest settings on the sharpest (35mm) lens are very good.  They are not as good as shots taken with my OM2 and it's 50mm lens with good film in color or detail.  However, the Nikon is much easier to use and get good shots with.  But I feel absolutely no passion for the 3200 and good photography demands passion.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
It is easy to get tunnel vision with all these glowing reviews on Amazon.  However, this camera really doesn't have any standout features.  Its the same old technology that has been around for years.  You are still going to have to wait a ton of time between shots, the burst mode is slow, and the burst mode does not support focusing between shots.  The view finder is not going to actually show you the picture you are going to get since it is an optical viewfinder.  And the viewfinder is going to black out when you actually take the shot.  Sure, all these traditional SLR cameras take great pictures, but really, what camera at this price doesn't.  What are you really looking for at this price point?  For me, it is fast between shots and can burst fast so I am sure to get a great shot.  I hate cameras that make me wait between shots until the camera is ready to take another picture.
If you want the hidden gem in the SLR camera world, check out the Sony SLT technology.  It is a new technology that is much faster and allows the viewfinder and focus mechanisms to function like they should.  I have the SLT-A57 and I think you can tell from the reviews that it is as good or better than any of these SLR cameras.
No, I don't work for Sony.  I just think that someone should point out the fact that there are other options out there and better technology available.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Much better than you expect of an entry-levelcamera.
column8:
I own a Nikon F2 Photomic, made in 1971. Forty years ago, this was Nikon's top-of-the-line camera.

 Between my F2 and this D3200, I have a variety of much-lesser film and digital cameras.

 I've long wished there was a digital back available for my F2, to convert it into a DSLR. The advantages of digital photography over stone-aged film photography are tremendous, but nothing else that I had before the D3200 could take pictures nearly as good as what I could get with my F2.

 This D3200 takes great pictures, easily in the same league as my old F2.

 This is actually Nikon's current bottom-of-the-line (they prefer the term entry-level) DSLR, though quite a stock still seems to be out there, being sold in stores, of the now-obsolete predecessor to this camera, the D3100. The experience of using it sure doesn't feel like what you expect of bottom-of-the-line. It certainly does not feel like a step down in any way from my F2.

 This camera seems to do an amazing job of striking a balance between the needs of the rankest novice, and those of the most experienced, discerning professional or skilled amateur. It has fully-automated modes that implement an amazing degree of intelligence in determining the nature of the scene before it, and picking the optimal settings to photograph that scene,and it has fully-manual modes that allow the photographer to exercise complete control over every parameter.

 Although the manual claims that non-AI lenses (any F-mount lenses made before 1977) cannot be used with this camera, I have found that all of my old non-AI lenses that I have for my F2 work just fine on this camera, albeit with some obvious and expected limitations.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I have had this camera for about a month and made about 400 exposures.  Many of the frames were different exposure situations to test the metering system.  Shooting digital is similar to shooting slide film, i.e., an under exposed frame contains more information than an over exposed frame and by default this camera under exposes.  Every frame needs a little PhotoShop work to make it look its best.  The lens is not very sharp, but, that has always been the case with zoom lenses.  The lens does not do justice to the 24.2 MP sensor.
I see the D3200 often described as an entry level DSLR and I agree with that summary.  The camera is adequate for my applications and I am satisfied with it.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Before buying this DSLR camera, I used a new Cannon T2i (from a friend) with kit lens for three months. And I am quite impressed with the image quality and response time of the camera. So I decided to upgrade to a DSLR camera myself.

I decided to go with Nikon because some online information suggests that Nikon lens can produce pictures with "more color" than comparable Cannon counterparts.  However, after used this camera for sometime, I found it response quite slow. In some cases, not much better than my digital card camera.  The pic quality is okay, not impressive at all.  I am not sure if this is because the kit lens is not good.

Anyway, this is totally a disappointment to me. I probably should have chose Cannon.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I've only had this camera for a few weeks after a couple of months of research online. I am new to DSLR but have used Nikon D40 before. So this review is for novice. D3200 is a light weight, small camera that packs many features. I use it for my kids primarily. The picture quality is very crisp and clear. The 24mp thing doesn't make much difference to naked eyes, but sure is nice when you need to blow up the pictures to print. We had some portraits done by a photo studio and some pictures look blurry at 12x12. Even with my cheap inkjet printer at home, there's a difference when I print pictures from various sources.

I noticed after a few days that I don't like the color saturation of the pictures. The colors don't "pop". Found out online that D3200 does not saturate the colors as much as other DSLRs in its standard mode. If you like more vivid colors, you have to adjust the image quality under Shooting Menu in one of the manual modes. I cranked up the contrast and saturation in Vivid mode and the colors came out a lot better. Some reviews complain about its tendency to overexpose, I wonder if that's what they're talking about. Kids don't look very good if they look pale.

I also noticed that it performs more like a point-n-shoot camera under indoor low light while using one of the preprogramed settings. The light compensating bulb in the front is very, very bright. As I'm getting more comfortable with the various settings, I find myself moving toward the P, A, S modes. I haven't had time to use it on landscape. I look forward to using it during our trips this fall. I haven't used the video function either. Looks a bit too complicated for me. I've got a point-n-shoot camera for that.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Awesome camera great features/settings/controls with WiFi
column8:
Ok. First off I bought this at Costco as a Nikon boxed kit... Came with a Roomy Bag , WiFi adapter and an additional 200mm Zoom lens... Around $750 with tax after a $250 rebate.
I'm selling my D40 on eBay this week... With the addition if WiFi and 1080p video, this camera now has everything I could ask in an quality vacation accessory. The only concern I have is the thickness of the camera body. It seems they used a lighter  and thinner plastic that my D40. That makes it lighter, but it also make it feel a little cheap... But it's not a cheap camera.  The features and functions are all well thought out and there's probably little a novice could ask for.  Have not used the wifi yet but I read there is a learning curve and mobile phone software needed. The kit comes with a great bag and the only thing about the bag I don't like are the "clinky" sounding snap connectors that keep it closed. The additional lens is NIKKOR. I've seen kits on Amazon with a Non- Nikon/NIKKOR lens... They are not the same, lesser quality... The NIKKOR lens is standard issue on all Nikon cameras.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I bought the Nikon D3200 bundle from another retailer including 18-55 & 55-200 VR lenses and the wireless adapter. I have had film SLR and point-n-shoot digital cameras before but this is my first DSLR. I have had it for two weeks and I am very happy with my purchase.

The camera body w/ lens is very light compared the film ancestors. Controls are logically placed. It offers a variety of options for the serious as well as point-n-shoot amateurs.

Menu settings are easy to follow though the accompanying guide was not very  elaborate. You need to download more detailed reference manual from the Nikon USA site for more detailed help.

The camera has manual(M), aperture priority(A), shutter priority(S), program(P), auto with and without flash and various scene modes. All the non-auto modes work great and offer you a lot of flexibility. I did not use the auto or preset scenes modes I found most of what I needed in the other modes.

The auto-focus has a variety of options to suit various situations & scenarios (all the way from single point focus to wider area for focus. However I found the exposure metering options to be somewhat limited. The AF-L/AE-L button allows you to lock auto-focus and auto-exposure as you pan the camera. and it is useful when you want to focus on the subject on the side of the frame.

The wireless adapter is a useful addition to the camera as it lets you take pictures on the camera remotely or download or view pictures from an Android phone. I only wish they had more control in terms of exposure time or aperture control in the app while using the camera in the manual mode.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I had been shooting 35mm B&W for some time, but wanted to get a little more modern system. It was a jump from 35, but the D3200 is fantastic. I'm getting great details and vibrant colors after just a little time shooting. The images are clear and crisp from 100 to 3200 ISO/ASA with slightly noticeable noise around 6400.
One thing to note is that, if you don't know how to completely utilize the camera, the images will be bad, or underwhelming. I recommend trying to familiarize yourself with some of the slightly more advanced features. After using a completely manual 35 I had no problem diving into some of these features and they helped a lot. Try to stay away from the auto features and go into shutter priority, aperture priority, and manual shutter modes.
The image effects are present, but I wouldn't say any of them are particularly impressive. Yes you can give your image a sort of older appearance, but if that's the kind of shooting you go for regularly, I would recommend just using an old camera and some expired film.
I would recommend this camera to most people who are looking at entering the DSLR market. I take that back. If you'rte looking to get into DSLR, this is a great choice. One note, just because the MP is twice some other cameras, doesn't mean the pictures are twice as good right away. You need to get comfortable with changing settings you normally would just leave alone.

I ordered it here at Amazon, price is really awesome: http://amzn.to/19M6oBq

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Add a battery grip, some very good to excellent glass, and you have a fantastic combo for serious, professional quality workflow.
Add Photoshop CS 5 or 6 and you can adjust, fix, embellish, spectacularize almost any RAW image from your D3200 at a fraction of the cost of obtaining a "full Pro" platform. What few features are missing in the D3200 you can find and fix in PS CS.
Really?
Really.
So save your bucks. Take some (more) photo classes, those heavy on "seeing" and capturing. Then head out and use your imagination and creativity feature set to the max and pat your D3200 on the tippy-top and say, Thanks Nikon.
This cheap "entry level" DSLR really rocks!

The only downside is that this camera was that it uses only original nikon bateries ($ 70 each), as D7000 can use regular chinese inexpensive batteries

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Sensing that Nikon had exiting new prosumer cameras in the pipeline I decided to sell my D7000 and D300s before their used prices plummeted and got the D3200 the week it came out.
While I miss some of the dedicated buttons, bracketing, and the availability of a true battery grip (the ones that exist require a short cable between the port and the grip, making ergonomics lousy) I do NOT miss the weight of my previous cameras.

Picture quality is outstanding and even the little 18-55 turned out so great I left it on most of the time during a four week trip.
Using superb f2.8 lenses I had outstanding results at concerts, church services, indoors and outside.

I'm especially happy that the HDMI output allows a clean feed to my Blackmagic Intensity Extreme and my Macbook Thunderbolt for video capture. And if you're just filming to card you now have more options and 20 minute runtime. Battery life is good but only half of the D300/D7000.

The experience convinced me to keep it for now while I jump ship and switch to Panasonic GH3 Micro43. The reason I'm keeping the D3200 is its outstanding low light performance which the M43 systems, at this point, can't deliver.

Then the rep just hung up on me the customer, really? LoL.  This went on for a couple of hours. The last phone call was Fed Ex trying to find the address and gave my address Again!  I will not deal with OneCall again but i will be a continued customer thru Amazon  As far as the D3200 refurbished Nikon camera  it works great! I have been a photographer for many years and DSLR cameras are the way to go! My advise just purchase thru Amazon or the Nikon or Cannon website to get the cameras. I would not recommended OneCall/Huppins.

I work in a ghost town and use it everyday. And I added duel battery holder(25.00) and hand strap with LCD Shade (10.00)> looks and fells professional. And I love the red chrome look. I can actually find it. It has multiple screen viewers and multi targeting in 3D. I am still learning all the features but was able to use it in 5 mins. Files are really compressed in JPEG FINE.
I use for people and landscapes. for real crisp photo's and on enlargements and blowups-no resolution loss. Sometimes seems clearer. I use corel photo ,free photoscape (good program for free).I bought 5 crappy digi cameras till I bought this one. I should have never wasted my money. This is a good investment for many years of shooting. Next model up was 5999.00. And its getting almost as good as a hassleblad. I use an Epson Artisan 13x19 printer for killer prints.

That being said if you get the exposure right when you take the photo the D3200 outshines the T3i in sharpness and color depth!  And cropped photos turn out better due to the added megapixels! If I didn't own both of these and had to choose one I probably would pick the Canon because I take a lot of low light photos, however they are both very nice cameras and the Nikon has integrated guide mode to help beginners take good photo! column7: Interface Clunkier Than it Needs to Be
column8:
I've had a Canon Rebel XT for years. I decided it was time to upgrade to a newer camera and had heard some good things about Nikon. I found the D3200 and bought a bundle at a local warehouse store that included two lenses. I spent quite a bit of time with the camera and found that the photos actually turned out quite nicely. The auto focus was fast and the camera was pretty quiet. If you are new to DSLRs or are used to Nikon then I am sure you would be happy with this camera.

For someone who is used to working on a Canon, this probably is a camera you would want to stay away from. I found the menu to be clunky. The settings weren't very easy to change in manual mode. I ended up with pushing far more buttons to change settings such as the ISO than I do with my Canon. The shutter/aperture wheel was a lot more awkward to reach with my thumb than with my index finger as I am used to with my Canon. If the camera would have been more intuitive to use, I think I would have loved it.

column8: Hi Def movies look great. There is a lot to learn. You can use a wireless remote for shutter release (optional) it has a built in flash and a hot shoe. The red enamel is very  nicely done, I usually am a black fan on camera's -but something about this one drew me. You need a SD card, I went with a 16GB which will do a thousand pictures at high resolution. I also bought a macro-zoom lens, took a picture of one of our cats and zoomed the image using the button on the back -to the point where the entire lcd showed just a green eye-and it wasn't taken as a close up-the whole cat was in  the image taken. I imagine the capability to zoom and crop with 24 megapixels will afford the capability to make pic's that were a little off, quite usable. First DSLR I have owned, I have had some large zoom fixed lens point and shoot units and just wasn't happy with the pictures. You can make adjustments that mimic changing film speed in a 35mm SLR. This is making photography fun again like it was with my old  SLR film camera

I purchased two of these for my teenage daughters and they like them very much.  They have been using them for 6 months and they are both happy with the quality of the photographs.

The Nikon D3200 is lightweight and simple to use.  It is also great for taking action photos.  I used it to take photos of my daughter during a soccer game and I was impressed with the speed of the succession of the photos and how well it captures things in motion.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: Camera and lens delivered in a timely manner.  First photos were well exposed and very sharp.  It is light, versatile and ideal for all day walks and/or hikes.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
After using a Nikon D50 for several years I wanted a replacement with more megapixels and video capability. The D3200 fits the bill nicely.  The D3200 is a "starter" DSLR that is loaded with features. For the nearly newbie, the guide mode will help take some of the mystery out of a camera with more buttons, dials and settings than the typical point and shoot.

The D3200 has several automatic settings for the typical shooting situations that will set the likely settings needed for the shot.  This will allow those of you who want a nice camera's quality without spending too much time learning speed, aperture, f-stops and the like.  Switch selectable modes include night portrait, portrait, landscapes, kids, sports and macro. The experienced photographer can configure the camera with full manual settings, shutter priority, aperture priority and the like.

I find the D3200 fits nicely in my hand and makes it easy to position for the shot.  I like having the eyepiece for the viewfinder as I'm often shooting outside. LCD displays are often overpowered by the ambient light which for me is the reason to consider this camera over some of the similarly priced compact cameras. Being bigger than a point an shoot, means you'll need to plan on taking it along instead of just keeping it in a pocket, however.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)

I rated this camera 4 stars because it lacks commander mode that would come in handy for doing off camera flash. You can still do off camera flash but you will need to buy some wireless triggers to do so.  I have had this camera for a couple of months and I am ready for an upgrade.

column7: I love this camera but it has focusing issues
column8: i love this camera but it has focusing issues. When using certain modes and sometimes in manual modes as well, the camera fails to focus.
