column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I finally decided to upgrade from my D40. I figured having a camera and video camera in one would make it easier to take video of our kids, especially #3 who was sorely lacking in the video department compared to the first two. I was debating between the D5100 and the D3200. (The D5200 was just announced when I made the purchase and had forced the price of the D5100 down to about the same as the D3200). In the end, I decided the only thing I liked on the D5100 that wasn't on the D3200 was the swivel screen. And I figured the newer, higher megapixel sensor would make this one last longer before it was replaced with a newer model. Pretty soon the D5100 wasn't being sold by Amazon, so that sealed it since buying from Amazon would get me a free SD card, backpack, $100 off the 55-200 VR lens (also an upgrade from my non-VR 55-200) and 2% back plus downgrading from Prime shipping even netted me $3 to spend on Amazon Instant Video.

Since getting it, I have loved it. I'd describe myself as an "advanced" novice photographer. The Guide option has been really helpful to get at some of the settings on the camera. Decided to go with the red body, and I kind of miss the texture of the black body, as the red is more smooth and "plasticy" feeling. But so far the red does make it stand out and easy to tell which one is mine among the crowd.

The video by itself would probably get only 3 or 4 stars. It took some figuring to place the camera in AF-F mode to get the focusing right. For the first few I was pressing the shutter half way down to force the focusing. The sound of the focusing motor is noticeable most of the time. The shotgun hot shoe microphone might help with that according to some reviews of it. But having a single device that can do both has definitely made it possible to get more videos of the kids. Picture wise, the video has been fantastic.

Definitely worth the price. Not sorry at all the I didn't go with the D5100.

I was at 16megapixels on point&shoot, but D3200 has 24megapixels, which isn't necessary a benefit of quality, but more size of the image.  My other option was The D5100 which looks attractive, too (esp. $50 cheaper than this D3200).  From research, the D5200 is coming out soon & this product should be much cheaper next year. Also, The Canon is a great competitor with each brand having its own advantages & disadvantages from color, accessories, & quality.  SInce I needed video, the Canon T3i & T4i was my second choice.  Since I was offered free 1day shipping, this concluded my search & within 14hrs, I had my new NIKON camera!  Great deal Amazon!  I look forward to learning this camera & moving up to something greater, later.  Best camera under $600!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Being our first DSLR did a lot of research before selecting the D3200.  When the price dropped and Coke spilled into our Point and Shoot the time was right.

Have been playing with it for about 10 days, the menus were pretty easy to figure out once I learned about basic camera settings.  The Auto setting produced some of the best pictures I have taken, though considering what I was using before that may not be saying much.  Did not play with the guide mode, thought I would but we dove directly into the Manual mode which forced us to learn the settings.  The adjustments took reading the manual to figure out, but once we learned them they were easy to adjust on the fly (ISO, Shutter Speed and F-Stop).  As we worked through the settings, we were able to improve our skills and see the D3200 really shine.  Seems to take excellent low level light shots, and high speed action seemed to be no problem.  The detail was great on all the shots.

The setup menus were easy to figure out, thought they were quite intuitive.  Also the build quality is great, it was smaller than expected, but fits in the hands well, and has a solid feel.  The rear display looks great and is a good preview.  Data through the viewfinder was also easy to read and great as we learned how to adjust settings without using the info page.

Overall I would recommend it.  Through all the research I found that the more knowledgeable people were who reviewed it, the more they found that they complained about.  Now that I have it in hand, I realized that while what they are saying may be true, this is an entry level DSLR, and to the target audience, it does not matter.  Enjoy the Camera!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: My first DSLR, I am very satisfied with the body and the price for the kit

Regardless, it is an excellent platform for high quality lenses and is compact enough to come with me in my bag. I have had excellent results shooting in lots of lighting conditions. column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Nikon D3200: Good Shots, Simple to Use
column8: While the D 3200 is marketed as an entry level camera, you can also shoot in aperture, shutter  priority to advance your knowledge. With the 18-55 MM kit lens, the D3200 takes incredibly sharp  shots in many different shooting situations, and you can shoot in RAW and JPG. This is a whole lot of camera for not much money. It's good for family shots, travel, but not so great with fast, fluid action (sports). This camera performs exceptionally in low light. The image quality with the 24.2 MP sensor is rich and very detailed. If you are just starting out, there's a handy guide to tell you some techniques and ideas. Whether you are just picking up your first DSLR or you have a lot of experience, this camera is a pleasure to use. I haven't shot video yet, but when I do, if it's of use to anyone, I'll update.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Toyish plastic - made for a the $400 point-shoot crowd
column8:
I sent it back and got the D7000 - wow what a difference.  Thank you Amazon!

I'm disappointed at some of the reviewers boasting they feel they got a D800 at a D3200 price.  This is STILL a D3200, and is meant for a very large, but very neophyte audience.  Nikon knew there were millions looking for a DSLR for $500 - maybe so they could say they had one.  Well here it is, and believe me you get what you pay for.  If you believe the egos of the prior reviewers, you'll certainly be disappointed when you try take this camera out of the simple, picture-led guide mode.

True, this camera is very much entry-level, but it's REAL entry level.  And the 24mp does not look like 24mp - unfortunately the way the computer processes the image it ends up looks more like 8mp.  The images are hard to describe - it's like they're synthesized or over manipulated.  Even the RAW seems compressed and lossy.  I saw a side-side close up analysis/review of the image, and although it's 24mp, most of the pixels in, say, a 20 pixel radius are all the same!  The camera doesn't have the power to distinguish the pixels for clarity like the higher end cameras.  Point and shoots do this as a matter of course, then they brag they have "24mp" etc which may be misleading some into thinking "well 24mp is still 24mp".  But it's not.  Go do your online homework and look at the analysis photos from this camera.  You'll see what I mean - and that pans out in real life.  Just one step up, the D7000 is 10x the camera, and yields much brighter photos.  It's sort of like an old round 50's style TV vs a new 90" hi res LED TV.

It's plastic case gives it a chintzy feel, it's VERY slow at shot acquisition (you will certainly wait a bit till it's figured out how to take the shot), autofocus is awful even with $3000 glass, metering is whacked, short battery life you name a bad trait and this camera has it.  Oh - and don't get caught in the rain with it either.

However, it is lightweight.  And to some that's quite important.  Like a tourist that has to lug a his new SLR all over creation, when they're used to a little pocket camera.  This camera is 1/2 the weight of any DSLR.

And it also has a real dumbed-down "guide" that takes about 30 seconds to setup a shot - so that whole sophomoric 7th-grade level guide thing is a bust.  And the scene selector on top doesn't help at all either.  In both my wife's, my 24 yr old son, my and my Mom's use, about 30/50 shots were blurred, mis-flashed, mis-exposed to WAY out of proportions etc.  So why have 24mp for a camera that can't handle it?

The lens that it comes with (mandatory) is just more cheap plastic mess.  If this camera was sold w/o the lens it would be in the $299 range.  We put a $3k lens on this camera with little improvement - it still just can't cope.  Don't fool yourself into thinking you're clever by purchasing a $4000 camera for $400.  You've got a $400 camera.

But I wouldn't waste your time/money - get the D7000 and be done with it.  If you're that hard up for $$ where you can't/won't shell out another $200 for the pro camera, then go back to a point and shoot

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
1) Picture quality: Exceptional for a supposedly-for-amateurs DSLR. I compare pictures taken with our Nikon D800, D300 and D40X, and our D3200 easily beats our D300 and D40X in terms of details, clarity and color depth, although still visibly not comparable to our D800 (which also benefits from its superior FX lenses). But with Photoshop on a 28-in HD monitor, besides the visibly more brilliant colors of the D800, I can only discern the D800's higher quality at 200% or higher magnification. At 100% (or Actual Pixels View) seeing the differences between our D3200 and D800 does require some careful examinations. It is no wonder DXO Marks ranks the D3200 among the best of Nikon professional and semi-professional DSLRs (Best of the Nikons: D800E (Best and also Industry Leader), D800, D600, D4, D3X, D3S, D3200, D3, D700, D7000; [...])
2) Ease of Use: The D3200 is so easy to use; there are many shooting modes to choose from with its top Dial. I typically only stay with Manual, Aperture-priority, Shutter-priority and (if in a point-and-shoot situation) Programmed-auto modes. But as with other (amateur's) Nikon DSLRs, the D3200 offers point-and-shoot (Auto, Auto Flash Off) and preset modes (Portrait, landscape, Child, Sports, Close-up, Night Portrait). And then there is GUIDE mode (with on-screen guides) as well.
3) Focus: There are many focus modes to give the maximum flexibility. However, I tend to stay with Spot (Single Area) Focus as I find with this much resolution, in high-magnification scrutiny, the Dynamic Area and the 3D Tracking Focus modes tend to give me a "softer" image.
4) Working with Nikkor DX lenses: The D3200 pictures are pretty much comparable in resolution with the D800 in DX mode with most of our DX lens collection, the only differences (visible at 200% or higher magnifications) are with our Nikkor DX 35mm F2.8 and Tokina DX 11-16mm F2.8 (which requires manual focus), where I can see better details than the D800 in DX mode (with DX lenses).
5) Working with Nikkor FX lenses (Manual Focus): Under very controlled situations and with a rigid tripod, the D3200 gives higher-detail results than the D800 in DX crop mode with our FX lenses.
6) No Auto-Focus with FX lens: Without an internal motor, the D3200 cannot auto-focus when the (superior) FX lenses are mounted. This manual focus requirement is not an issue for me - I just use the D3200 electronic range finder to focus my FX lenses.
7)Adjustments of Picture Quality: You can also choose how your picture quality can be controlled: Standard (default), Neutral, Vivid, Monochrome, Portrait, Landscape.
8) Active D-lighting: Very nice results when I face situations of high contrast. This is almost High-Dynamic-Range (HDR). However I usually have this off since I do post processing of the raw images with Photoshop.
OK, now some notes:
9) No bracketing: This is not an issue for me (personally I think this is an over-exaggerated feature anyway, I rarely use this capability with my D800, D300)
10) Light Metering: The D3200 Matrix metering has a tendency to overexpose a little in bright conditions; luckily it also offers exposure compensation up to a generous +/-5EV. I do advise that you take plenty of pictures in all metering modes as well as in Manual so you can tally up the effects and set the exposure compensation to get your best pictures results. Maybe Nikon will update the firmware to fix this.
11) SD Card: Please make sure you use the fastest card you can afford. The D3200 files (especially if you shoot RAW (NEF) and JPEG Fine together) are large and the camera does take time to store and display images.
12) HD Video Recording: The D3200 new 1080p25 and 1080p30 modes in addition to 1080p24 produce very nice videos - Live View is great - I find the continuous focusing during movie recording not only visually distracting but noisy and I just avoid it altogether and use single AF (AF-S) or manual focus for movies
13) The tabbed menu system with long pages does take some getting used to (it does appear cumbersome at first).
---Update---
5) I've found no auto-focus issues with the majority of my FX lenses (AF-S and AF-I). However, besides the 1.5X factor, the minor issue is the D3200 does not quite cover the view 100% in its viewfinder; please keep this in mind when composing your picture with the FX lenses, as your actual picture will be not be as large as what you see in the viewfinder.
10) After careful note-taking for a couple hundred photos, I've found that setting the D3200 to -1EV has yielded results pretty close to manually compensating the exposure via the viewfinder in most cases, including the case of the subject against strong bright background.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Excellent camera, going to be a great entry DSLR
column8:
I recently bought the D3200 and have run a couple hundred images through it.  Long exposure night shots have been great, both with the kit 18-55mm lens and the Tamron 70-300mm lens.  I wish it did have some effect modes like the point and shoot cameras have as well as other brand DSLR's (IE sepia mode, etc..) That can also be done in post processing though.  The software that comes with the camera also seems to work great for some minor post processing work, especially just shifting white balance and things.  I picked up a wireless remote and corded shutter release at the same time as well as polarizing and UV filters.  Focusing could be a little faster, but at this price point I am not complaining.

The camera itself is very light, so a large lens throws it a little off balance.

My biggest complaint is the optional wireless adapter.  I bought it because it said you could use it as a shutter release.  You cannot use it as a shutter release if live mode is active, and you can only use it to trigger the shutter, you cannot use it to do a long exposure in bulb mode.

The app is also a little flaky, if you let your tablet/phone go to sleep while you are transferring photos from the camera it cancels the transfer.  I installed an app called "Wake Lock" from the Google Play to keep the tablet awake, once that was done images transferred fine.

I hope to update this as I get to use the camera more.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Fantastic choice for someone upgrading from point and shoot
column8: This camera has been termed "entry level" far and wide.  So be it.  I find it to be a wonderful camera for what I needed:  A camera that had fast, crisp autofocus and could take shots at a speed faster than every 3 or 4 seconds (which seems to be the typical recovery/ready time for most point and shoots in my experience).  Plus, I am rediscovering the joy of artistic photography with this camera.  I'll let the professionals argue over the value and performance for them, but for me, this is a winner!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: 24 MP ?? Must be a great camera
column8:
Well I ordered this camera because the temptation was too great. I already have a SONY NEX 5n and a PAnasonic GF3 and for the price i thought this camera was a great buy based on reviews I have seen on the web. I think this is a good camera for the entry level range of users who are upgrading to a DSLR. I see a lot of people boast about the size of the camera being a lot smaller then most other DSLRs and all I can say is the other cameras must be monsters because this is not a small camera by any means.
I gave this camera 4stars because i think it is a very capable camera for the price and I didn't think it fair to give a lower rating because of my bias towards the Micro 4/3 cameras. I am not a professsional but I am getting into photography more and more. To be honest I didn't think the video when taken in lower lighting indoors was that great and every picture taken indoors with fairly well lit lighting during the day wasn't the most crisp pictures i have taken. I used Aperture priority without a flash and had the aperture open fully and let the camera do the ISO and shutter. My Panasonic GF3 and SONY NEX seemed to get better results. I have to say it was nice to look through a viewfinder again as my last cameras were all in a LiveView type of config.
As far as the build and fell of the camera it seemed pretty cheap feeling. I had to go for the red color because i thought it was nice to have a different look to it other then black. Hey, if you want pretty picture you ned a pretty camera right? lol. It has a cheap plastic feel to it but it wasn't a show stopper by any means. I don't see myself dragging this camera to get pictures on a daily basis. More of a specialty kind of usage because of its size. The Micro 4/3 i can take anywhere more easily and it does the same thing even better.
I just want to say after reading a lot of reviews on AMazon and elsewhere I truly believe that only a couple people mentioned that you can take great pictures with a point and shoot and a DSLR for everyday use. If all your doing is going around taking shots of your friends drinking beer and partying then most cameras would do the trick but if you want a night shot of the moon or fireworks or Christmas lights you will need a DSLR with all the programming modes. One other key thing i have heard people preach about photography is it's all about the glass in front of the sensor. Mostly true as a good lens can make a difference.
My next purchase will be a mid range camera or high end one when I get better at picture taking. I dread trying to find a camera when I am ready, 16, 18 , 24 megapixels.. this one has external mic, this one doesn't, this one has bracketing but why did they remove it from this camera, this one has 1080 in 30, 24, this one has noise at 1600 ISO.. blah blah blah. OMG shoot me now. Too much choice clouds judgement.
If I owned a camera company i would make two types of  cameras, one entry level and one Pro with all the features. It's crazy all the different models every manufacturer has out there, ridiculous.

In the end I returned this camera because i like my two Micro 4/3 cameras and well.. I didn't feel that spending $600 was worth it getting a camera that does the same thing as my other two.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: This camera is freaking incredible! The image quality is incredible and you can basically shoot any image from far away and still create an up close blown up version of the image and have the quality still be incredible!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: NIKON D3200 24.2 MP CMOS DIGITAL SLR
column8:
Took this out of the box...shot my usual known test photos. I looked at the file sizes and they are not 24mp but 20mp.
So Nikon has truncated the file size. You have to look at the file sizes in your PC or Nikon instruction book to discover this fact. The point is that what is advertised is not so. Also when you bring the camera up to your eye the glare from the monitor panel is disburbing. Looks like the only way to get around this is to turn off the display. All in all my personal opinion is that the Nikon D5100 at todays prices is a better bargain and better operating camera all around. Image quality was okay but no noticable differences compared to Nikon D5100 which I made several hundred exposures with. I am returning this product.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: An excellent camera, an adequate kit lens.
column8: This is a very good camera with terrific resolution (24 megapixels). An ideal entry level DSLR camera. I just wish that the kit lens was sharp enough to take advantage of all those megapixels. I did also purchase a 40MM F2.8 Micro Nikkor lens to do some copy work and this lens seems to be tack sharp when used with this camera. I am still exploring and learning all of the features this camera has to offer but my present feeling is that the camera deserves the five star rating with the caveat that it could be even better with a higher quality lens (read expensive!).

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Only as Good as Your Technique
column8:
The sensor is all you'd expect it to be, and will deliver poster-size enlargements with no apparent pixelization; but when it comes to image quality, the sensor is only part of the pipeline.  The kit lens is all very well and plenty-good-enough for casual shooting, but making the most of 24 megapixels suggests the use of better optics, such as the fixed-focal-length Nikkor 60mm f/1.8, and flash or a tripod.  Older lenses won't autofocus with the D3200--you need the newer AF-S models--but you can focus manually with any lens using a built-in rangefinder function which is buried in the menu system.
There are compromises with the D3200, just as there are with any entry-level camera.  The autofocus hunts a little in low light and with low-contrast scenes, burst mode isn't that fast, video playback flickers, and the memory chip needs a little time to swallow each RAW shot.  If you're not a pro, you don't need a camera that grabs each shot with the voracity of an Australian salt-water crocodile.  If you think you do, the D800 may be worth your kilobucks.
You can take this camera out of the box, charge it up, fire away in auto mode, and get 16x20 enlargements of excellent image quality--just as photographers have been doing for years with 5-megapixel point-and-shoots.  Don't stop there.  Sweat the details and make photomurals that knock your socks off and curl your toes.  The technology's there, but mastering it is something only you can do.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: An entry level camera, not as impressive as it could/should be (+ some recommendations)
column8:
UPDATE March 2014: Please note the date of writing the original review. Many things have changed since then, including the price and the competition in the market. END OF UPDATE.

I had a chance to try this camera for two weeks with my Nikon lens collection. I compared it to my D5100 and a D7000.
I skip repeating the features and specifications and just mention my final impression after using the camera in different conditions and with various lenses.

1. It is getting too small. A DSLR should be comfortable to hold. D5100 was on the small size too and now this one is a bit smaller. i use a battery grip with my D5100 for maximum grip and comfort.

2. Photos, out of camera, are not as smooth as those taken with D5100 and D7000. The extra megapixels didn't really add to the final picture quality, in my opinion.

3. Exposure is unpredictable and often on the overexposure side. I tried it in various lighting conditions. I am well aware that they are fixable both in and out of camera, but is it too much to ask to have nice photos when I pay quite a few hundred dollars?

4. Video quality is comparable to D5100. 60fps is a welcome change though.

5. It is expensive for what it is. It is perhaps targeting the first-time DSLR buyers with the wrong price tag. You can do much better if you are willing to spend that much. (I am referring to the price as of August 2012. Its price may be adjusted in near future.) You are better off buying less expensive DSLR and save money to spend on better quality lenses. Keep reading below for recommendations.

My recommendations (These are in case you have decided to buy a Nikon DSLR):
1. If you can, wait for D5200 (it is not out yet as of August 2012),
2. Get a D5100. It packs an impressive array of feature for the price,
3. Get a less expensive one if an entry level camera is what you are looking for. D3100 should be on sale these days,
4. I do not recommend D7000. It is a nice and able camera, of course. And I know that it has an impressive autofocus system. The difference just doesn't justify the hefty price tag for me. D5100 sports the very same sensor and produces identical picture quality for much less money.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Great camera - Entry level with Pro features.
column8:
I started looking for a camera for less with lots of MP to replace my old D70, this one's got it.. 24MP and raw images are awesome, JPEG are great. I recently, left for a trip to India and took some 2000+ photos , bird sanctuaries, himalayas etc.. Photos were amazing, I will have to admit i used 70-200mm Nikkor lens (its about 2399). Photos were amazing. Live view is wonderful with 1080p HD vidoes camera does some wonderful things.. I wanted to buy D800, with are the reviews about focus issues , I have lost faith in Pro model from Nikon. This one is awesome. This little camera might not have all the features that D800 boasts about, but Hey, I can buy 4 3200's for the price of D800 and don't have to return to Nikon and wait with the tounge hanging out for it to return from repairs.

Update -- 01/03/2013

Now that the camera has been used for 6 months, buttons on the back are loose. Compression of images produces a pink bar on the Right hand side of the image. Continious frames are the cause of that pink bar. Its very prominent in RAW files and not much with JPEG.But i can live with it since, I crop my images. But that should not be happening. Next is Focus sometimes it misses it completely and try to focus on another focus point even though its not selected. Still, a good camera for the price. But, don't expect to work like a semi-pro. Will replace it with D7000. I know, D7000 is due its replacement. But,my rule of thumb is never buy something thats not tested. Expecially, when 600 and 800 has shown its ugly faces of oil spots and left focus issues respectively. Happy clicking.!!!!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I had been shooting 35mm B&W for some time, but wanted to get a little more modern system. It was a jump from 35, but the D3200 is fantastic. I'm getting great details and vibrant colors after just a little time shooting. The images are clear and crisp from 100 to 3200 ISO/ASA with slightly noticeable noise around 6400.

One thing to note is that, if you don't know how to completely utilize the camera, the images will be bad, or underwhelming. I recommend trying to familiarize yourself with some of the slightly more advanced features. After using a completely manual 35 I had no problem diving into some of these features and they helped a lot. Try to stay away from the auto features and go into shutter priority, aperture priority, and manual shutter modes.

The image effects are present, but I wouldn't say any of them are particularly impressive. Yes you can give your image a sort of older appearance, but if that's the kind of shooting you go for regularly, I would recommend just using an old camera and some expired film.

I would recommend this camera to most people who are looking at entering the DSLR market. I take that back. If you'rte looking to get into DSLR, this is a great choice. One note, just because the MP is twice some other cameras, doesn't mean the pictures are twice as good right away. You need to get comfortable with changing settings you normally would just leave alone.

I know I listed some negatives, but it still gets 5 stars because it's good at what it does. If you're filming, spend $600 on a video camera, and you'll be pretty good for the civilian market.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I love the camera and I'm happy I purchased it. It's really a lot of fun to use and feels well built.

I got the D3200 a few months ago. The picture quality is excellent but video recording is no good. Video focusing is the issue. The focus is very slow, and the stock lens makes a lot of noise when focusing. When I record moving people I usually resort to manually focusing the lens. Also, the D3200 also can only record 1080 at a maximum of 30fps, which is very noticeable when compared to 60fps - especially when recording rapidly moving subjects. At 30fps moving objects seem jittery and move unnaturally. Due to these issues, I use my iPhone almost exclusively for video. I didn't expect a DSLR to take perfect video, but I assumed it would be better than my cell phone. I break out the D3200 usually only in low light conditions. I also feel that the videos are soft.

The extremely slow focusing has made the camera useless for recording video. Imagine this, you are focused on a subject and the person moves two feet farther from the camera, the camera does not realize this and does nothing. So, you hold down the shutter button which tells the camera to refocus. Now the camera cycles through being completely unfocused to properly focused - this gives me a headache when I watch it later. So obtrusive.

The photo quality is excellent. The only gripe I have is the custom white balance - you must go through numerous menus every time you want to adjust it. I have a simple canon point and shoot camera that allows me to customize the white balance with two clicks.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
Background:  I currently own two other cameras, a Pentax K-5 and a Panasonic Lumix FZ150.  In the past, I've shot with Sony, Canon, Fujifilm, Mamiya Sekor, and some others that I can't remember.  I have no brand loyalty; I will use any camera that is able to generate good images on a consistent basis.  Most of my shooting is outdoors, daytime (dawn to dusk) using burst shooting and telephoto at or near 300mm (450mm ff equivalent), but of course there are exceptions.  I do a lot of shooting in very high-contrast situations (brilliant white sunlit foam against a dark blue sea or shaded cliffs, for example).  I do a lot of cropping and/or enlarging for prints up to 20x16in or larger.

My comments on the D3200 are based on expectations and comparisons with results obtained with other cameras, mainly the K-5 (using kit lenses) and the FZ150.  I also did the same shots fairly recently with the Pentax K-r (which I sold to upgrade to the K-5) and a Fuji S100FS (superzoom bridge camera with 2/3in sensor, 11MP and 14.3 optical zoom, which was great but not quick enough in burst mode), and those results also enter into my evaluation.

My purpose in buying the D3200 was:
1. Get higher resolution than I have with the K-5 or FZ150.
2. Have something that would be a bit lighter than the K-5, while matching it in IQ.
3. Have decent burst speed and depth.  (With the K-5 I shoot a lot at 7fps; with the FZ150 I alternate between 5.5 and 12fps.  All at full resolution, RAW.)

Beyond this, I was going to be pretty easy to please.  I don't do much low-light shooting, and I don't mind doing PP.

The good:
--The D3200 is a nice camera in terms of design, pretty well laid out.
--The D3200 feels good in the hand, is well balanced, and light yet solid.
--The kit 55-300 lens functions well and smoothly, and is solid, with a metal bayonet mount that works easily and firmly.
--The LCD is a real delight.  Very bright, good resolution and contrast, very easy to read.  (And I am a committed VF user. ;0)
--Battery and memory card doors are light but don't feel flimsy; they are well designed for quick opening and closing.
--The burst at 4fps (RAW or JPEG) is acceptable for many action shots, and steady.
--The VR (anti-shake) works very well and hand-held full-zoom (300mm) shots are clear at 1/180.  (I didn't go below this shutter speed yet.)
--AF is quick and reliable.  (In a complex physical environment, it's most effective if you select single point focus as otherwise the camera may focus on something other than your intended subject, but this isn't unusual.)
--Color and WB are very good right out of the box.

The not so good:
--Unfortunately, at present there is no substitute battery available, so you must pay between $40 and $50 for a Nikon battery.  Both Pentax and Panasonic also charge a lot for their batteries, but other totally acceptable options (which I have as backup) are available for a fraction of the price.
--Another drawback is the NEF Raw format used in the D3200.  Unless you have CS5 (or maybe CS6) or equivalent, you can't process D3200 NEF images in Photoshop.  (You can process earlier versions of NEF, but NEF keeps evolving.)  Luckily, there are free programs like Raw Therapee, Irfanview and FastStone which do read NEF from this camera.  Of course, there is also NX2 (Nikon PP software) which you can download off the internet or from the CD with the camera.  It's a good program for  improving image IQ, but lacks layers and other features found in PhotoShop.  You also can convert to Adobe DNG (which is read by PhotoShop and other programs); the free DNG Converter may be downloaded off the net.  Be sure to get Version 7.1; earlier versions will not work with D3200 NEF (I found this out the hard way).
--There are a couple of shortcomings in the controls, but most of the main functions are quickly accessed and changed by pushing the "I" button on the lower left of the back of the camera (below the lower left corner of the LCD).
--The camera has an irritating eagerness to make you use the LCD to view your settings.  It would be nice to have full information easily accessible through the viewfinder, instead of having to take the camera away from your eye.  Example: to switch to and from burst shooting, you have to use the LCD screen to make changes; when you push the burst button (which is a very nice thing to have), the only change menu appears on the LCD, not in the viewfinder.
--The D3200, like many other cameras, has a tendency to overexpose.  This is easy to remedy by setting EV at -2/3 or so.
--Leave the in-camera sharpening on; images are very soft without it.
--Bracketing, histogram, DOF preview: all missing.  These aren't fatal flaws, but the rest of the camera had better be very good to compensate.

The bad:
--IQ is a major disappointment.  I have a number of standard shots that I take with every camera I try or buy; I have done this so many times that I have a very clear idea of what is possible and what reasonable expectations are.  Again, I'm comparing this camera specifically with the K-5 (16mp on an APS-C sensor, kit lens 55-300mm) and the FZ150 (superzoom, 12mp on a small 1/2.3 sensor).  Recent experiences with the K-r (12mp, APS-C), the Canon T2i (kit zoom lens) and the Fujifilm S100fs (11mp, 2/3in sensor, bridge zoom camera) also enter into my appraisal.

In every one of my standard shots, the D3200 performed worse (in terms of IQ) than the K-5 (and K-r) and often worse than the FZ150.  When shooting at full zoom, definition was poor and fine details were often fuzzy or smeared.  With in-camera noise reduction turned off, noise was often evident.  With either of the other two cameras at full zoom, you generated an image that allowed you to count the roof tiles on a house well over half a mile away, and read license plates at 400 to 500 yards.  The K-r was the same, and the Fuji S100 was close.  The D3200 does not have this capability.

You might say, well, sure, it's probably the fault of the kit lens.  But my K-5 has a kit lens, and the FZ150 itself IS a kit lens, as was the Fuji S100fs, and they all did better on the same shots.  At any rate, the D3200 doesn't seem like a hot enough camera to warrant spending serious money to put top-quality glass on it.  And again, the K-5 didn't require this, nor did the K-r.

You might also say, well, yeah, but who shoots all day at 300mm?  I don't know, but why limit yourself right from the start?  If the camera/lens combo can't do this, I'm going to miss out on a lot of shots.

Apparently, I'm not the only one who is underwhelmed by the images from the D3200.  Here's what dpreview had to say on the subject: "resolution and detail aside the Nikon D3200 has no image quality issues of note."  Hardly a ringing endorsement of the camera's IQ.

Bottom line: the purpose of making pictures is to get good results, and the main ingredient is IQ.  I will take a couple of days to try some adjustments and see if I can get better results, but if it's this much harder than it is with my other cameras, I'm not optimistic.

IQ is closely related to pixel size; in general smaller pixel size can be detrimental, and the D3200 has pixels that are quite small for a DSLR.

Larger pixels offer enhanced light gathering ability and a higher signal-to-noise ratio.  Higher pixel counts on the same size sensor create a tradeoff.  To use one common metaphor that equates pixels to light-gathering "buckets," having more, but smaller buckets (pixels) on the same surface area (sensor size) doesn't mean you can collect more water (light).  In fact, the shape and necessary circuitry of each pixel create wasted, non-light gathering areas in addition to generating electronic noise.

Here's how Wikipedia puts it:  "The size of the image sensor, or effective light collection area per pixel sensor, is the largest determinant of signal levels that determine signal-to-noise ratio and hence apparent noise levels ...more pixels within a given sensor area will make the image noisier."

Here's a comparison of pixel sizes for a number of DSLR cameras.  The D800 is a full-frame, 36mp camera; the others are APS-C (a generic term which includes slightly differing surface areas and proportions).

Pixel size in microns (m)

Pentax K-r - 12mp - 5.42 m
Nikon D3100 - 14mp - 4.94 m
Nikon D800 - 36mp - 4.88 m
Pentax K-5 - 16mp - 4.8 m
Nikon D5100  - 16mp - 4.78m
Canon Rebel T3i - 18mp - 4.3 m
Nikon D3200 - 24mp - 3.85 m

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Beware, older "Nikon" lenses may not work...
column8:
We've had a Nikon in the past and it was time to upgrade to something newer.  I purchased this camera purely out of my wife's reaction to it (she loves red), and the fact that it did 24.2 MP.  This was a lot compared to my old Nikon D100 that was only 6.1MP.

I have some nice Nikon lenses that worked with the D100 but don't work with the D3200 as I intended.  Basically I've read up on it and the D3200 doesn't support metering... so now I have to purchase a new set of lenses to make it work seamlessly without putting the D3200 in "M" mode and adjusting the aperture manually (keep in mind this is for my wife and she wants simple).  More can be found here, ug! [...]

If I would've known this I may have opted for a Canon.

The red is nice, but my wife already put a very small chip in the paint (and we don't know how as she's normally very careful with it).  Basically the black camera housing on our past D100 was way more durable and even after all these years - has no chips in it what-so-ever and looks entirely brand new.  Not sure if this speaks for the quality of the housing but it should as it's lacking.

It takes great pictures, and we're not professional photographers.  However, compatibility would've been nice to have baked into every Nikon without having to worry about bleeding their customers over options that make the lenses compatible.  Especially for the price we're paying... even at $699.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)

AFTER 130 PHOTOS the camera fail. metering malfunction detected.
beware don't buy it. now i have to send it to nikon service...

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
This is a wonderful camera for the price. While it looks almost the same as the D3100 on the outside, it's a whole new camera on the inside. Greatly improved video. Various feature improvements that I'm sure everyone knows about, and of course, a 24 megapixel sensor.  My biggest concern when deciding to buy this camera was noise - however, Nikon has done a great job on this sensor coupled with the new Expeed 3 processor.  Noise is LESS than with the D3100 and it "only" has 14 megapixels.  It is MUCH better with noise than the otherwise fantastic Sony A65, also with a 24mp sensor (and better than the A77 as well). Dynamic range is better than the D3100 as well.

Yes, it still lacks some of the bells and whistles you expect to get with pricier camera bodies, and certainly noisier than full frame sensor cameras, but that's a whole different ball game. For the price nothing else can touch this great little camera at the moment, in my humble opinion.  If you're buying an entry level Nikon at this price point it might be a toss up between the D3200 and the D5100 now that the latter has dropped in price. The D5100 has more operational features, an articulating LCD panel and similar video, but the D3200 has 8 additional megapixels of resolution and somewhat better dynamic range with very similar noise profiles. While some people many think 24mp is too much or unecessary, I love it. Detail and resolution with a decent lens is fantastic and gives you many more options for cropping, printing, etc. You can produce amazing results even using the Kit Lens with a little care. Nikon has shattered another barrier with this great little camera and I couldn't be happier with it.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Nikon D3200 is a 5 star camera!
column8: I replaced my Nikon D40 with a new D3200 about a month go and have not regretted it. The D3200 has some advanced features over the D40 that make it easier to use and it also seems to have more accurate exposure metering, especially when in the "auto" mode. I like the fact that the infrared remote shutter release that i used with the D40 also works on the D3200. The camera is light weight and compact for a DSLR, so it is well suited for hiking and biking. The photos are superb! Very sharp and crisp! I only wish it had a timer which would take a photo every so many second or minutes, etc. It has excellent build quality and feels good in your hands. It is well worth the money, which is very reasonable. I do not care for the "Live View" feature. This camera carries on with the traditional Nikon quality and I highly recommend it!

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: A Video Review of the Nikon D3200 Camera
column8: I will have to warn you, before investing too much time in this review you should understand that I have geared it for the novice/Intermediate photographer and not for the advanced user. I say that because the D3200 is certainly a camera that is worthy for an advanced or professional photographer. In fact, the D3200 is a marvel since it is possible for a novice to take professional looking photographs with only a few hours of study, but it will also allow a professional all of the capability that they would want for premium quality prints. Notes - Image Quality - Absolutely top-notch - the Nikon D3200 takes super crisp photos with excellent color representation. The additional functionality allows more advanced users to maximize light, shutter speed, and zoom/focal points. Why 24.2MP? - Why does someone want a camera with such high resolution? Well the answer is pretty straight-forward. A high resolution camera will allow you to zoom and crop any portion of your photograph without worrying about the image becoming grainy. This will allow you to zoom to a small area of interest and blow-it-up to a full scale print. Multiple ISO Sensitivity Settings - The various ISO settings allow for changing light sensitivity without loss of image quality. This is similar to the "speed setting" of film cameras and the 100,400, etc films of previous years. - Fit and Functionality - The Nikon D3200 feels great in you hands. While it is not *pocket sized* compared to the cheaper smaller cameras it is still light enough that you will not be fatigued after a day of shooting. - Outputs/Inputs - The Nikon D3200 has inputs for a mic and GPS and it has HDMI and a standard AV output. - VIdeo - The D3200 will take up to 20minutes of video at 1080P - the video quality is excellent.... I am not sure I would call it the equivalent of a full 1080P camcorder (Due to image stabilization and frame speed) it will certiainly work in a pinch. - Burst Mode - The camera will take 4photos/second in a burst. This will help you find the *right* shot even during an accidental blink. If you have never used a camera with burst mode you will be amazed at how much easier this makes in taking photos of children. Buffer - The Nikon D3200 has an internal buffer of (up to) 100 photos. This will allow you take a multitude of high resolution photos without having to wait for the camera to write to your memory card. On the topic of memory cards you will certainly only want to buy class 10 memory cards. Camera Modes - - Portrait - Used for Portraits with soft natural-looking skin tones. If the subject is far from the camera the background details will be softened. - Night Portrait - Use for a natural balance between the main subject and the background in portraits taken in low light. - Landscape - For vivid landscape shots when ample light is present. - Sports - Fast shutter speeds freeze motion in order to capture fast acting sports moments. - Close-up - For close up photos of flowers, photos, and small images taken at very close range. - Child Use for snapshots of children. Clothing and background details are vividly rendered while skin tones remain soft and natural. Final Verdict - Whether you a re a novice, intermediate, or advanced photographer you will likely be very pleased with the Nikon D3200. While you will need to spend a few hours with the manual all levels of photographers will be able to take stunning photographs. Highly Recommended! 5 Stars

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I am not comparing D3200 with any other camera since tons of such comparisons and detailed product reviews are freely available by now, including the DxO Lab one.

Things I liked about this camera:

Small, light weight, fast and delivers straight out of the box

Comfortably fits into mine, my wife's and son's hand (Personal choice)

Great image quality

Excellent color

Great detail, especially when that 24 MP turns in our favor (by using right lens and technique)

Very good video quality

I had checked the specs before I placed the order and hence I already had an idea about what is there and what is not there as far as features are concerned. Investing on a 35mm/50mm prime lens is worth considering for no-flash shoots at low light.

Overall, Nikon D3200 is an excellent DSLR

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Best value of Nikon DSLR's. But check out the Sony NEX 5n
column8:
Recently I had a weekend opportunity (borrowing from friends) to get my hands simultaneously on this D3200, a new D800E, a Fujifim XPro-1 and a Sony NEX 5n, and I was able to compare them all, head to head on the same scene at the same ISO, both JPEG and RAW. Of course they all had different lenses, but I tried to minimize the variance by shooting at f8.

As expected, the D800E was the best IQ, but the differences are subtle. At ordinary ISO, the D3200 was not as far behind as one might expect. Entry level DSLR's are a very competitive market segment and Nikon went all out in trying to pack in as much as they could for the price. The D3200 falls behind mostly at high ISO (3200). But of course the D800E costs more than five times as much as the D3200; is it really five times better? No, it is maybe 50% better for five times the price and twice the weight. Also the D3200 is much smaller and uses smaller, cheaper lenses. So the D3200 wins in terms of value for sure, especially if you plan to take most of your pictures in good light - those images were excellent, sparkling and clean.

If you are interested in the other results, you can check out my XPro1 review linked below. The XPro1 images were remarkable; except for pixel count (16 MP vs. 36 MP for the D800E), the JPG's were almost as good as the full frame Nikon. Of course the XPro1 is also very expensive and idiosyncratic in other ways and it doesn't really compete with the D3200. It is a camera for rich dentists, not ordinary folk. The Sony NEX 5n on the other hand, is about the same price as the D3200 and is also impressive. At high ISO, the NEX gives nicer results than the D3200 but not quite as nice as the D800 or XPro1. If you want a camera which is much smaller than the D3200 but has comparable or slightly better image quality, check out the Sony. But there are many more lenses available for Nikon, and the SLR type viewfinder is still the easiest to use in my opinion (the NEX 5n LCD is better for street photography because less intimidating).

Bottom line is that D3200 is excellent and a bargain, and most people will be very happy with it.

http://www.amazon.com/review/RZFD6T3DK37ED/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8: I ordered this for a backup to my D300S Nikon.  Figured I'd double my mega-pixels in the process.  I have since returned the item the day after I received it.  It's like some little toy camera.  I should have downloaded the camera's manual at the Nikon site prior to ordering it.  It doesn't allow for bracketing of shots and anything you need to change seems to have be done through the menu screen in the camera.  It is very light.  My 10-20mm zoom was heavier than the camera body.  I'm sure most entry level people will like it.  For the money you get a lot of mega-pixels.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Great camera - haven't used it yet
column8:
6-15-12. I wanted a D3200 in RED but they are unavailable still, so I opted for the black. Only difference is case color. I've been too busy to really learn how to use the tools well, as photography is a hobby for me, not a profession. The D3200 has a lot of features and my first DSLR.  It's physically smaller and lighter than I had expected and that is a nice feature. I bought an optional hand strap attachment (Opteka Professional Wrist Grip Strap for Digital & Film SLR Cameras) that helps me, as I have large hands. The D3200 kit comes with a 18-55MM VR DX lens but no lens hood, so I elected to buy the Nikon HB-45 Replacement Lens Hood for 18-55mm VR Lens. Good choice. The hood fits perfectly and doesn't block flash.  The optional AC power supply and adapter cord set is not currently available (Nikon EH-5A AC Adapter and Nikon EP-5a Power Supply Connector for EH-5a AC Adapter) in the US at this time.
I'll update after I use my new "toys".

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Despite some weaknesses, an outstanding camera
column8:
Whether this camera's for you will depend on your needs.  Here's my bullet-point run-down of the good and the bad:

Good:
- 24 megapixels
- Good low-light performance, ISO goes to 6400, Hi1 (12800): ISO 3200 image here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-media/permalink/mo2U3CW1XBEB88Q/B007VGGFZU/ref=cm_ciu_images_pl_link
  (see DxOMark's Web page for details on the signal-to-noise ratio of this camera's sensor)
- HD video capability (improved since the D3100) plus microphone jack
- IR remote sensors on front and back of camera
- Active D-lighting
- Small size and light weight
- 4+ frames per second

Bad(ish):
- No bracketing
- JPEGs are a bit soft, even in "Fine" mode (only a concern if you are cropping heavily)
- must buy with kit lens (18-55mm with VR- not a bad lens)

For context: I am an experienced amateur photographer.  I like the capability, small size and low weight of the D3200.  I have large hands, but do not have any trouble using the D3200.  The large number of megapixels will permit extra cropping, but Nikon's JPEG compression limits how much you'll want to do this (unless you shoot in RAW, of course).  High ISO settings permit shooting in our middle school auditorium without introducing too much noise.  Note that, as with all entry-level Nikon DSLRs, the D3200 does not have a motor drive for autofocusing lenses, so all lenses without an internal motor will be manual focus only.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I bought one of these a few weeks ago from elsewhere because Amazon was out-of-stock and had no anticipated date for when more of these cameras would arrive.  Well I figured out why they were out of stock because it is a very nice beginner to intermediate level camera.

I have already taken a workshop with a professional on how to get me shooting in the Manual mode for most of my shots and use the other modes when circumstances call for it.  I strongly suggest that any beginner take some form of class from someone and learn that your particular DSLR camera is much more than a snapshot point-and-shoot camera.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: MOVIE WARNING: Non-Fluorocent Red channel flicker visible even at ISO 200
column8:
Set image contrast to -3, the RED FLICKER is very visible in dark area even at ISO 200!!!!
(Now I rate it 1 star from 2 star)

ISO 100-400: Good image & Video (ISO-200~400)quality [Update 2012-07: BUT ONLY in Well-lit area]
update 2012-07: WARNING: Got red-channel flickers in dark area.
ISO 800-1600: Unusable video.
ISO 3200 beyond: Utterly, everything unusable.

Dark side:

Canon T2i's video at ISO 800 is even stable in dark area than that D3200's video at ISO 200.

Shooting D3200's video indoors at any ISO settings is quite unusable. DUE to RED-CHANNEl flickers
Outdoors are OK.

- - - - - - - -  - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - -
Bright side: 24MB, higher pixel. Good even with kit lens. (but... only up to ISO 400)
- - - - - - - -  - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - -

Conclusion:

This camera is very good in good light/F1.x lens, unusable in dim light.
If you are concern in ***LOW light*** videography, never choose this camera.

Its video will have red-channel flicker in dark areas. Even at ISO 200.
This is not caused by fluoroscent light. It is a crapped in the camera design.

If you don't shoot video often, can buy this camera.
But if you do, you will regret.

I really regret to buy this camera from Baun Le Sibu. (tipu saya)

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: Well, I guess the pictures are enough not to say any other word
column8:
I was very interested since it was announced and finally sold my D90 which I love forever and was my best nonliving friend since my son was born and bought this. although I was hesitant to sell D90 but I guess now the new little brother has a lot to say comparing to it.

Pictures are really vivid, great colors and much more closer to real colors of the environment, focusing is not different from D90 although is accurate and fast enough, it is very handy and much more lighter than D90 and handling is quite easy. the settings are very easily adjusted and lacking the other dial is really not making any difference to me at all.

I did not even use the 18-55mm lens and since I opened the box I added my Nikkor 35-f1.8 which is a huge addon to this camera.

resolution is interestigly not double but triple or more of the D90 actually. I know it is only twice of that but really much more improvement you'll see when compare those two.

colors, colors, colors, I love those. I am sure no other camera with in this price range can be compared to it. and even better ones can pass the scores in a hard way.
it is magnificent and no one will regret buying it.

Thank you Nikon.

Update 06/08/12:
I can't resist my temptation to state that it is more than what someone can expect from a $700 DSLR. the pictures are magnificent. Focusing is really fast and accurate even in total darkness. I love this box and happy for exchanging it with my D90. Resolution is unbilievably high and colors are really vivid. I have uploaded a few flower pictures in full resolution.

Best purchase ever for $700.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I just received this camera 3 days ago but have already run at least 250-300 frames with it.  The performance is amazing in addition to the 18-55 kit lens being outstanding.  I also purchased a Nikon 35mm lens to go with the camera and will review it after working with it.

All of the controls on the D3200 seem to be placed with care and are so intuitive to use that I feel like I've had the camera for years.  The menu system is also quite intuitive and anyone who has ever used a DSLR before (whether Nikon or not) will find it very easy to work with.

The material the camera is made from appears to be quite sturdy as does the construction of the camera.  A typical Nikon product...excellent.  The feel of the D3200 is quite good.  The only thing I'd change is the grip.  As other reviews have stated, it appears to be made for smaller hands.  But certainly not a deal breaker.

I'd recommend anyone interested in using a great camera to buy this model.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: A decent DSLR overall with a couple of issues
column8:
In terms of photographic usability... the Nikon D3200 is excellent. It's fast, comfortable to hold and shoot with, the menu system is intuitive, and LCD is much improved over the D3100. It feels solid and well-made and could stand up to the weight of a more pro-grade lens.

The camera has solid image quality but perhaps slightly inferior noise performance when compared to its predecessor. If you are an everyday, casual shooter and not shooting much at ISO1600 and above (and not blowing your images up to huge sizes or doing heavy cropping) you will be perfectly happy with the picture quality from this camera. Especially if you're stepping up from a point and shoot. The camera displays good color reproduction, and the 18-55 kit lens is probably one of the best kit lenses to be offered by a cameramaker out there in terms of its optical performance. Dynamic range is excellent. It does overexpose some, so you might want apply some negative exposure compensation in bright conditions (other Nikon DSLRs have had this issue in the past as well).

One disappointing feature that was on the D3100 but not of the D3200 is the drive mode switch on the top of the camera near the mode-dial. Also the switch between movie and video has been replaced with a button.

The video is pretty good on this camera. I have not messed around too much with the video but from the footage I have taken so far, the video has been sharp and clean.

Even though there is a slight drop in the imaging performance on this camera (again, unlikely to be noticed by casual shooters and even enthusiasts), I still reccommend it over the older D3100 due to the increase in performance and the higher LCD resolution. A very enjoyable camera to shoot with and will provide many years of great photos and dependable operation.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
D3200 is a good entry level camera. 24MP may be too much at this level, however. Even when using a prime lens (35mm/1.8 in my case) I can still see noticeable softness when viewing images at 100%. Even more so when using the 18-55mm kit lens. Still, there is more resolution in images under ideal conditions compared to the D5100, which I also own. Overall I prefer the D5100 images for sharpness, dynamic range, colors and low light noise.

One other thing I noticed with my D3200 is that the VR on the kit lens can introduce blurring of images. Shooting at 55mm and 1/100 shutter speed (which Auto ISO and auto min shutter speed option will select and should be considered sufficient to eliminate camera shake) causes shaking which is visible in images. Only when switching VR off that blurriness is gone (this also means I can hold the camera steady enough). Also, I could observe the same with the 55-200mm lens at 55mm. So I don't think it is a lens issue. So I will keep VR on the kit lens off when shooting in good light. For the 55-200 however this is more complicated as at the 200mm tele end the VR switched on seems always better.

Edit: upgraded the rating to 4/5 stars since there is a workaround to the issues I found. Also, I didn't want this review to be seen as negative.

Update: The image softness at 100% pixel level is caused by the in camera jpeg processing. I just developed some of the RAW/NEF images taken with the 35/1.8 lens in good light and low ISO and they come out clear and sharp at the pixel level (with a little extra sharpening applied). Also there is more detail in areas of lower contrast from the NEF developed images compared to the jpegs from the camera.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: A lot of value for the money
column8:
The D3200 is a brilliant camera for intermediate to advanced users. Beginners can of course use it too due to the pre-programmed shooting modes.

Besides the pre-programmed shooting modes it is literally loaded with advanced features which is a huge advantage for the experienced user.
The Info screen gives quick access to often used setup items like image quality, white balance, release mode etc. and the programmable Fn button on the left side
on the front gives quick access to setting the ISO (by default).

So don't get fooled by the low price, this is really a great camera with excellent output and I would say that it could easily be used by professional photographers
with a good lens mounted (at least as a backup camera).

I have owned several Nikons including the D700 and my conclusion is that you can't go wrong with this camera, but be aware that the image files are quite large
especially if shooting NEF (raw).

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column7: An excellent camera but a questionable upgrade from the D3100
column8:
This camera looks and feels just like the camera it will ultimately replace, the Nikon D3100.  The major difference between these two cameras is the D3200's new Sony sensor with much higher resolution; 24MP vs 14MP for the D3100.  The LCD screen on the D3200 also appears brighter and sharper than the D3100 LCD and about the same as the D5100 (but not movable like the D5100 LCD Screen).  Notwithstanding the different sensors, the photographs taken with each camera (especially at lower ISO settings) look almost identical.  I have reviewed the D3100 seperately here on Amazon.

  Photographs taken with the D3200 are richly saturated and highly detailed.  An external flash with bounce capabilities (ie SB-400) greatly enhances expsoure and color indoors.  The only quibbles I have (and this is also true for the D3100 and D5100) is the automatic white balance bias towards yellow under incandescent lighting resulting in an artificially warm look. Manual adjustment of the white balance provides better color accuracy under artificial lighting.  There is no dedicated white balance button or white balance bracketing option.  Also, the D3200 tends to overexpose quite a bit outdoors (similar to previous lower end Nikons) but doesn't underexpose indoors as the D3100 sometimes does.  The overexposure is easily fixed by adjusting the exposure compensation or by spot metering. There is no exposure bracketing option.

  The AutoFocus on the D3200, like every other Nikon DSLR I have ever used, is very quick and accurate under all lighting conditions.

  This camera (as does the D3100 & D5100) uses the EN-EL14 battery.  Only a battery actually manufactured by Nikon ($40+) and not a generic 3rd party battery will work.  Consequently, having a spare battery is a bit of a luxury with this camera.

  The megapixel count of the D3200 may be overkill for most people especially this camera's target audience.  The D3100 14 megapixel count (D5100 16 MP) is more than sufficient unless you plan to print highway billboards. The file size of .jpg files generated by the D3200 is over 12MB (almost the size of the D40's raw files).  An advantage of these larger resolution files is the ability to crop photographs without any issue of having a small remaining file size.

  The extra megapixels does NOT improve the image quality or amount of detail being captured.  The dynamic range of this camera (the difference between the brightest and darkest part of the picture that show detail) for .jpg files is excellent and appears about the same as the D3100 and D5100 at base ISO using the kit lens (and Active D-Lighting turned on).

  There is a downside to the D3200's higher resolution; a bit of increased visible noise at high ISO levels specifically at ISO 1600 and 3200.  Comparing photographs taken on identical subjects at identical conditions using the same lens at 1600 or 3200 ISO on the D3100 and D3200, shows a little cleaner photographs on the D3100 (and the D5100).  Reducing the file size from "Large" to "Normal" does improve things a bit; perhaps this setting lowers the MP count.  In this context, it would be helpful if there was more than one ISO stop between 800 and 3200 (there is just one stop at 1600) as well as a dedicated ISO button so that one didn't have to navigate through a menu to adjust the ISO.

  In summary, the D3200 is a very nice camera capable of taking very sharp photographs.  Like all cameras, the most important component is the skill and imagination of the photographer.  The D3200 is not a worthwhile upgrade in my opinion from the D3100 unless you place great importance on the ability to crop a very small portion of a photograph.  The D3100 and D5100, which are both less expensive than the D3200, are simply better cameras for most people. Incidentally,  I did not use the video or live view so obviously I can not comment on these features.

6-4-12 UPDATE:  Within the last day or so, CNET and Cameralabs.com have each issued their respective comprehensive reviews of the D3200.  These are the first actual reviews by a major web site of the D3200 that I am aware of.  These reviews confirm that although the D3200 has some improved specifications over the D3100 (higher resolution for sure), the image quality of the older (and less expensive) D3100 is better than the D3200.  Specifically CameraLabs rated the image quality of the D3100 18/20 and the image quality of the D3200 17/20.  Consequently if image quality and value are important criteria, the D3100 should be given strong consideration over the D3200.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I purchased this camera to use it for landscapes or situations where high resolution is really preferred. The 60fps video is awsome for slow motion video.

Overall, it's a pretty decent camera with crazy resolution at a very nice price tag.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I had no plans to buy this camera, but eventually had to find a solution while waiting for my D800 to be delivered. I kind of felt, I could get some training by shooting high megapixel images on this entry level camera.

My first outing after the camera arrived was to some birdpark with absolutely no prior preparation. The manual is still in the box, only charged the battery overnight and brought a selection of lenses in addition to the kit lens.

First surprise, even the kit "plastic" lens performs really nicely on this camera. Due to the nature of the objects of interest, the remaining shoots were done on a 28-300mm.

I was accompanied by an experienced bird photographer and we took turns with the camera. Both made the following observations: From the angle of experienced Nikon users, this camera offers everything in terms of menus and dials to set the camera up the way one is used to from D90, D7000, D300s level cameras. This came as a surprise, as the D3200 does not have the front dial that we both were used to and familiar with. Nikon has done an surprisingly good job in making the menus very easy to access and after a short while, we where entirely concentrated on the shoot and only occasionally reminding ourself that this was "only" an entry-level DSLR.

At the same time, we were impressed how nice the software is tailored to the needs of a potential beginner, gently guiding him towards to goal of making better photos along the way.

The LCD screen on the back is a huge step forward from previous models, as it allowed to effortless pre-screen the shots taken. I was even carrying a laptop computer to better inspect the initial images, but after a short while we only resorted the the built-in screen.

The biggest surprise was however the image quality after we analyzed our initial >350 photos on a large monitor. The yield of usable photos was right out of the box very high, which reiterates the ease of use of this camera and the great auto-focus system (despite only 11 sensors). Also the smallish size of the body turned out to be less problematic, even with a bigger lens attached to it.

We found the image quality obtained to be absolutely stunning, the sharpness of the images was "picture perfect". Colors just the way one would expect them, as is the hall mark of any Nikon camera. Even small birds could be cropped from the 24 MP resulting in usable 7 MP images. Post-processing was a thrill and resulted in a substantial number of images clearly qualifying as publication quality.

Having seen both, the best and the worst in Nikon cameras, I can verify that this entry level DSLR is a keeper. Even though never planned, it will stay in the collection as a second body and now serves as the main camera until the D800 arrives.

If an entry level camera already is this good, what may be expected of the upcoming updates of the other DX models, the likes of D5100, D7000 and the D300s?

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I am going to be honest, I have never owned a digital SLR camera (30 years old) even though I am very fond of photography as it is was my grandfather's profession in the early 20th century in Iran. This review is for those SLR beginners like myself. I have never had the money to spend on a digital SLR but since now we have twin boys at home and D3200 finally came out I felt justified to spend the extra bucks. Specially after being disappointed by and returning the Canon S100.

I have had the D3200 for 5 days now and even though I have not had the chance to take it outside that much, here are my impressions:
1. Pictures are amazingly crisp and true to the color, simply beautiful
2. FPS is fast and satisfying (although, with flash, not always fast enough for two 14 month old boys!). Now I find myself capturing motions that I could have never done before (compare to S100 of course)
3. Takes Amazing videos with great sound
4. Love the view finder, specially, since in this camera it's smarter and more detailed/informative than most LCDs
5. The manual booklet is a good start for someone like me, but you will have to do additional research and playing around to understand all the available options in the Menu
6. The Modes are quite useful once you understand them
7. The LCD screen is so well pixilated that you can see the quality of your pictures right there and then
8. The camera is the perfect size (specially if you're on the move and have your hands full already like me), light wight and grips well
9. Battery is still on the original charge after about 200 pics and 10 videos

Finally, I ordered the Wifi module last week but seems like Amazon is not going to get it anytime soon! I can't wait to try this functionality with my android. I will update the review once I get that but overall we love the Camera as is.

===================================================

Update 6/24/12 WMAU review

After waiting for 2 months on Amazon I finally got the WU wireless module from somewhere else by paying an extra $25 and cancelling my order on Amazon.

The module is pretty useful. Super small and comes with a cool case that attaches to your camera strap. Connects via WiFi to your phone (Android for now) and the associated wmau App (Wireless Mobile Adapter Utility) gives you the following 4 functionalities once you are connected Remotely:
1. Use the Camera to take pictures that will be downloaded and to your phone instantly. Take about a sec per pic.
2. Use the phone to take the pictures. can see the camera view live. Only provides the shutter options but it could come handy for taking family pictures on a tripod.
2. Downloads the pictures (temporary memory) for viewing on your phone in seconds. I had about 200 pics that were downloaded in about three seconds. From there you view and select the files that you actually want to download to your phone. Every time you close the app the temp pics will go away. You can select a picture or multiple pictures to download permanently to your phone.
4. You can "share" the downloaded photos. The share option gives you all the usual suspects, Facebook, Gmail, etc.

I like the last two option as I am betting all my techie friends on Facebook are wondering how I posted a family picture via mobile with this quality! :) Little secret iphone10!

Also, overall now that I have taken over 2000 pictures and 20 videos with D3200 all I can say to convey the quality of pictures, ease of use, speed, and other utilities made available in this camera are WOW and Love it! Money well spent and kudos to Nikon.

column4: Nikon D3200 24.2 MP CMOS Digital SLR with 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 Auto Focus-S DX VR NIKKOR Zoom Lens (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column8:
I only really purchased this as a studio cam. Don't need AF performance for that, nor high ISO's, but do need great resolution. So, with trepidation and reserve, I decided to try this one. I am coming from D700's, D3's, D7k's and other as my point of reference. I shoot for a living.

The good:

Resolution is excellent, especially when coupled with the 40mm macro from Nikon. I have shot a few hundred shots now and am very happy in that regard. The menus are simple enough that you can work them out if you already know Nikon's systems for menus. AF performance is great for this kind of body. Using my 17-55 with it, I could acquire focus only slightly slower that with the D7000. I tried in lower light to see how that worked, and while you could tell it was slower, it was not too bad. Every shot I have taken bar one (black dog in a dark room), was in focus as intended. So, AF is good for this kind of body. I like the layout of the controls too, everything was where it was expected to be.

The bad:

Small body means uncomfortable grip. However, that is what was expected, so I don't really think this is a "bad" for this camera. I expect a person with smaller hands will thoroughly enjoy that aspect. Lenses (all but smaller ones) are front heavy and fell off balance. Pop a 70-200 VR on this and it is silly unless you carry/hold it by the lens primarily. Lastly, there is no AF fine tune, but.... I have not found the need on even one of the lenses I will use it with to make any adjustments, so not too bad a thing.

Conclusion:

Get one if you want it for landscape, low speed portraits (esp families) or for product/architecture. I highly recommend it.
