I can wear the headphone and even pause my music and have full conversations as if they weren't even there.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: I don't typically leave Amazon reviews, but i had to for this product.This is my 2nd Tozo headphones. I've had the Tozo T10 for 5 years and it is still going strong.The headphones I previously had broke so I was in the market for a new one. I had first purchased the Beats Solo 3, but had to return it due to how uncomfortable it is. It doesn't go around your ears, instead it presses against it. I also wear glasses so it pressed so hard against my ears, giving me headaches.So I was back in the marker until I came across the HT2! Obviously I've owned a very reliable Tozo product in the past, and decided to give this a try. Man I am not disappointed!It is extremely comfortable! Sometimes I forget that I have headphones on.The ANC is on a whole new level. When I accidentally turned it on, I wondered why it was so quiet in my house which it never is until I realized it was on.The sound quality is fantastic! I'm a Bass guy, so I love thr ability to change the EQ. I was excited seeing a Bass+ EQ option. It is amazing. I am hearing sounds in my music that I never heard before.All in all... a wonderful product. My only gripe would be that the HT2 does not come with a Case. My previous headphones always have. It's not a deal breaker though. I can always order one online.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column7: Great addition to their lineup. Surprised it took them this long to get over the ear headphones.
column8: Once again Tozo takes care of their customers and offers free products once and awhile. I paid for these upfront and will get refunded by Tozo except tax and paypal fees. I only have used over the ear headphones with my PC that requires you to use a usb dongle. The HT2 you can use via bluetooth (primary way) or you can hardwire with wires provided for headphone jacks or through a usb to a computer. I was surprised my computer just starting playing music when I plugged them in via usb. Sound quality and depth is great. I don't know how more expensive headphones perform but these are probably as good as my ears can really perceive. These are my first impressions and need to use them for a bit to see if the battery life and other aspects hold up but they seem well made and good value. The noise cancelling is quite impressive. These beat out my other gaming headset in that regard. The fact they are bluetooth means I can use these more often and looking forward to using them on an airplane. I will still use my T20 headphones for exercise and ease of use. My T6 headphones as backup and for the bedroom. These will be for when I want to be totally immersed.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column7: Comfortable, Great Noise Cancellation, & Deep Bass
column8: These are incredibly comfortable. Looking at them, I initially thought they'd be too tight on my head, but the ear cups are incredibly soft and compressed to the point where they fit very well and form a fantastic seal for noise cancellation. Along with the active noise cancelling, I can't hear anything going on around me at all. And when I want to hear people because I'm in a store or talking to someone, and the pass through mode lets me hear clearly without having to take them off.The sound is very crisp, with a really strong bass, which is an area that I think can sometimes come up lacking on wireless headphones. I listen to a very wide array of music, and I've yet to have a song come up on my mix that sounds less than stellar on these headphones.The battery life is incredible, and they fold up well for compact storage, which makes them great for commuting and traveling with.And on top of all of that, it's a small detail but the fact that they have a 3.5mm audio jack and can just be plugged in is really convenient, so I can keep them connected to my phone on bluetooth, and plug them into my laptop to use without having to disconnect and reconnect them.All in all, I cannot recommend these enough.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: Got theseTOZO Noise Cancelling Headphones in hopes that they were as good as their earbuds I have.I am hoping these work well enough to use on a plane.They did not disappoint.They provide a great amount of noise reduction.They are lightweight and comfortable.I would say after a while they can be warm to wear.Obviously as you have something on your head verses an earbud.They fold flat as seen in the photo and you gotta love the large L and R for which side is which .Controls are easy to use.I would say if you want to transport these, I would get a case for them.One downside I found was the wired connection does not allow for noise cancelling.So if you are connected to something like a laptop that doesnt have Bluetooth, they will then work like regular headsets. So you may want a Bluetooth adapter in that case.There is also a TOZO app that allows you to configure the sound cancelling and by going deeper in the menu, you can set the equalizer or select a music genre to get different levels of sound adjustment.Overall, I think these are a fabulous value.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: Similar to other tozo headphone products the sound quality for what you pay is pretty great. You can pay 100 dollars more and get boosts in quality but at the time of writing this these headphones are 50 dollars and sound like 90 dollar headphones. Noise canceling is the same route you can find better but only at much higher price points. It's actually pretty great on these, although harder to gauge because they are over the ear headphones. Bass is fine and unable with the app which is always nice. Only complaint is I wish tozo consolidated all of their apps into one for ease of use. Other than that great headphones, body build quality does match price point which is fine but sound and NC unmatched for the price.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column7: These are well made, high quality headphones that have great sound reproduction.
column8: I don't think that you can beat the quality of these headphones at this price point anywhere in the marketplace.They sound great and all the function buttons are easy to access and work like a charm.I have several in earTozo earbuds and have been happy with them as well.....I wanted a set of over the ear phones and thought I would try Tozo - I'm glad I did.I've tried to run the batteries out of power but have not succeeded - they last a long time.The packaging is fine and comes in a high quality box with molded cutouts for the earpieces - anyone opening this box will feel they are first class phones.My only 4 star rating, above, is that even though the noise cancellation is VERY good, they don't cancel the noise like my in ear Tozo earbuds - but I guess that is to be expected since the earbuds block the ear canal - don't get me wrong the noise cancellation is just fine in most environments.Personally, I don't think you can beat this quality for this price.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: For the price ($39 with coupon), this is an excellent value. Noise cancelling and sound quality are very good.I'm not sure what the max battery life is, as I used them for maybe three or four hours on a couple travel days, and had no issues. I also didn't use them as a headset for talking, as that's not what I wanted them for.One small drawback is that you can't use them as wired headphones and use noise cancelling. So if you don't have or don't want to use Bluetooth on a particular device, you can't use noise cancelling. Adding a small travel bag would be a nice touch also.All in all, I'm pleased with this purchase and recommend this product.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: These headphones really exceeded my expectations for the price!! They sound amazing, connect with Bluetooth very easily and the control keys are super simple to use. I bought these in the beige color hoping they would match my new Google Pixel tablet (porcelain color) that I recently bought and they match just about spot on with it so I'm very happy about that! The material on the ear cups themselves is SO cute and comfy and I really love the more oval shape of the over ear cups, as they fit over my ears perfectly. Solid packaging as well. This is my first TOZO product and I'd definitely consider buying another product from them!

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: I am absolutely thrilled with my TOZO HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones! The hybrid ANC algorithm and three ANC microphones provide exceptional noise cancellation, creating an immersive listening experience whether I'm on a plane, in a busy office, or just trying to enjoy some quiet at home. The 60-hour playtime is a game-changer, lasting triple as much as other Bluetooth headphones, making them perfect for long trips or extended use. The ability to switch seamlessly between wireless and wired connections is a fantastic feature, ensuring uninterrupted listening even when the battery runs out.Moreover, the comfort and adjustable design of the TOZO HT2 make them my go-to choice for both work and leisure. The ultra-soft protein leather earcups allow for extended wear without discomfort, and the automatic adjustment of the earmuffs to fit different head shapes is a thoughtful touch. The foldable design adds convenience, making it easy to carry them anywhere, and the Hi-Res audio sound with deep bass is simply outstanding. I must mention that the compensation provided for this review adds to the overall positive experience I've had with these headphones. TOZO HT2 truly delivers on its promises and has become an essential part of my daily life. Highly recommended!

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column7: Great ANC and Richter Scale Bass!
column8: Im a bass head who has a large collection of IEMs, TWS buds, and over ear headphones. From an I love bass perspective, these things blow every other device Ive got out of the water, and out past the gravitational pull of the planet. What's more amazing than the bass itself, is that the transducers can handle it without turning into a distorted mess. Its just pure sound pressure.Obviously, though these can be EQd to produce a fairly neutral sound, theyd never be my choice if I were looking for that kind of experience. In fact, Id like to see Tozo release an update that expands the high frequency bands a bit. I like plenty of treble sparkle, and my worn out old ears can just manage it with the EQ adjustments on these.The bottom line is, that if you really love bass, and ever wondered if you could push both eardrums far enough into your skull to have them meet somewhere in the middle, these are for you. They get 5 stars from me, based on how they sound, and for technical achievement. Somehow, this doesnt seem like it should be possible. Thanks Tozo! Im sorry - what?

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: These are great headphones for the money. I dont own another pair of over-ear headphones, and the quality is not as strong as my expensive, wired earbuds. That said, the quality is still very good, and these headphones work very well, and the noise cancelling is also strong.I recently took a work trip, and the noise cancelling made the plane ride quiet and smooth, and I could hear small details in the dialogue of the shows I watched without any issue.All at a fraction of the price.They are well built and feel comfortable, even after a few hours.I will be buying another pair soon for my partner.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: So far so good. This makes my 5th pair of headphones...trying to find something that works, has good range, and ease of use. At first, I had some concerns about the controls. It took a bit of getting used to. However, I now find that I like the small buttons that are almost flush and made of rubber. Being small and almost level you can lie down with them without accidentally turning them off. Once you get used to their location (on the edge by the earpiece) they are quite easy to access. The range is exceptional. I can walk out of the house and to my man cave some 50-60 feet away and maintain the connection. I am pleased with this purchase.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: I bought these headphones for my wife to use while she does her workouts and she absolutely loves them, she says they are the most comfortable headphones she has ever worn and that the sound quality is amazing.There is also an option to put the TOZO app on your phone so you can adjust the sound to perfectly meet your needs for whatever you might be doing.I had ordered another bigger brand name pair of headphones for myself and after doing a comparison with TOZO, I will be sending mine back and ordering a pair of these for a fraction of the cost.Please don't be caught up in the hype of having to have a certain brand, save your money and get these amazing headphones, trust me you won't be disappointed.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: I recently purchased the Bose headphones directly from their website. I have enjoyed them for several weeks but I was looking for an alternative device to watch TV. Im a retired professional classical musician and have been an audiophile my entire life. This headset will become my primary device for listening to music and Ill use the Bose as an alternative device. And I paid one tenth the price of the Bose which I would return if I could receive a full refund. And I must mention that I purchased this device at a discount from the Amazon warehouse in like new condition for $28 delivered to my door. Wow! Lucky day indeed!

column7: Changing modes comes with a very annoying sounding women voice. (Nothing wrong with a women's voice)
column8: I just got these for about a day. But the most annoying aspect is anytime I change the sound modes from ANC/pass through / ANC off there is a women's voice to tell me. I would have much preferred tones of some sort.Overall for the price I paid which was $40, it's a very respectable headphone. It's got decent ANC and good pass through that sounds natural not robotic. The earmuffs are nice and comfy, but my ears did get hot after only 40 minutes. And it's about 60 F at the time, so it was hotter these definitely would have been way hotter on my ears. Overall I think the headband and the size of the cushioning makes these a big headphone not overly big like Sony's, but these feel more premium then Sony's lower end and even maybe Sonys mid range offerings.Sound stage for these was just okay in my book, but then again for the price it's a good option. You definitely need the app to adjust for better sound and has nice extra features to help control and maintain the headphones better.So in the end for the price, look, style, sound, and comfort these are a very solid option for the price. If you want something a little more there are better options. But those are either older or cost twice as much as these.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column7: Great noise canceling, okay sound, wish the ear cups were a little bigger
column8: The noise canceling on these is great. I got them specifically to help shut out the noise of the neighbors stomping around upstairs, and they absolutely do. They also work well for calls.As for music listening, they're not fantastic. Just okay. I had to fiddle with the equalizer quite a bit to get them to where I didn't think they sounded both muddy and too sharp (which is bizarre). I'm a music fanatic and am used to Tozo products providing great sound, so I'm a bit disappointed as far as the sound goes.They seem well built, and they would be perfectly comfortable for hours at a time if the ear cups were just a little bit bigger. The left one doesn't bother me, but the right one makes the top and bottom of my ear sore after an hour or so.Overall, for the price, they're okay headphones. But they definitely get that fourth star for the noise canceling, and not anything else. I am a big fan of Tozo earbuds (I have four pair!), and I feel they sound markedly better than these headphones.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: I wanted to buy a pair of over-the-ear headphones because I had read that sound quality was better. I currently use airpod pros and love them. Upon receiving these headphones, pairing was easy. I charged the headphones and went on a 40 minute walk. The battery went down to 96%. Not bad but I question the claim of 60 hours of battery if after only 40 minutes the percentage went down by 4%.I went for a casual walk. t's not hot or humid but the area that covered my ears were very sweaty. I suppose that may be any over-the-ear headphones but I don't like it. I also felt that the headphones were heavy but that's probably just something to get used to.Sound quality is okay at best. I am not a huge audio person but even I could tell the sound just really wasn't that great. You can "customize" the sound via the app but it didn't do all that much. The noise cancelling is decent but I expected much better for over-the-ear headphones.Overall I would recommend this product if you're okay with the caveats. After all, you do get what you pay for.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: I love nearly everything about these headphones.Pros:- Great sound quality- Comfortable- Noise cancellation works quite well- Dual device pairing (concurrent devices) works well and it switches back and forth automatically quite well.- Bluetooth range is excellent. I can walk nearly anywhere on my main floor (which is quite big) without losing connection.Cons:- They're actually just a tiny bit big for me even on the smallest adjustment level. Not a deal breaker.- Battery doesn't seem to last as long as advertised, though it does easily last two or three pretty long work days.- I wish it came with a storage case or bag to keep it safe and dust free when not in use.One tiny gripe about the Android app is that you can't see an actual battery percentage, just a battery logo to tell how much is left.Overall, I'm very happy with these so far, about a month of use on them at this point. Docked the one star due to battery life not being super close to advertised amount. I'll update this later if I run into anything else note worthy.UPDATE: In a recent app update, it now shows battery percent! One less con... Way to go Tozo!

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: I have had several of Tozo TWS in ears and normally pleased with them, so I thought I would give these a try. I am very happy with these and for the price I got them at. I own several ANC headphones and I can always use more... glad I grabbed these.Like Soundcore and now most other manufacturers they off an app to help. The app will let you customize the EQ as well, pick with ANC mode as well as to supply firmware updates which is a nice offering. I have already had a firmware update since opening, would have been nice to know what changed. I am very happy with how the EQ always me to customize the sound, it seems to be limited to just adding 3 profile settings. The ANC works well and offers several levels of strength and also allows you to customize the ANC directly as well.All in all I am very pleased, just being able to truly be able to adjust the EQ to my exact personal requirements is what really made me loves these. Hope you enjoy these as well.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: Ok, so I've been with these for 1 week and i've used them a lot. So here are the most important things.Sound: These sound pretty good, they have a lot of bass and the mids are good, I used them to play a lot of punk, metal and hip hop and they really deliver.Noise Cancelation: Ok, so this is where everything's getting interesting. My girlfriend have the Bose Quietconfort 45, so that's my point of comparison. In this Tozo, when you have the NC on you have a good quality of sound, you don't hear a lot of the outside noise so they're pretty cool BUUUT when you turn off the NC the quality of the sound really decrease, it's like all the bass is dead, yes, you can hear the outside world but with the other bose, the quality of the sound didn't decrease, you can only hear a little bit of the outside. So I would recomend to mantain the NC on all the time.Confort: They're really good and nice, I have glasses and always have the problem that the headphones always are unconfortable when I put them on but this is not the case, they're pretty solid.Battery: So far so good, I don't know if i've been using them for more than 60 hours but battery is good.So overall, it's a good set of headphones, pretty solid. If you don't use the NC off a lot, it's convenient and at great price.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: After spending almost 2 weeks choosing which headphones to invest in, (I am super cheap with headphones, so this is expensive.) I chose these. It was between the sonys and soundcore.These are my first pair of noise cancelling headphones, so I reckon theyre pretty good with no references.I like the app a lot, even though it had some pairing issues. Going through ios Bluetooth works fine though.The sound quality is good, sometimes it sounds a little tinny when the volume is all the way up. And you do get a liiiittle sound through the headphones on full volume.The mic is good to talk on the phone. Ive been told I sound clear.However, I dont really notice much of a sound quality difference between these and my old powerlocus headphones. Therefore, I think these headphones are worth more like $30-35.I got them in the white, and they seem like they will get dirty easily, so be careful especially if you got these for the gym.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel
column8: For the price, these are decent headphones.Loud (I have some hearing loss so my audio products need to be loud), good bass, somewhat okay ANC & transparency, great battery life, great cup pressure against my head, and they're foldable.For this price point, I don't expect flagship quality.There is one thing that annoys me. It's a minor quibble, but still. This is my second set of headphones (First pair were black), & I'm still experiencing an issue with the in-app battery percentage. After completely charging my first pair the battery level never went above 98%. I went back-and-forth with Tozo tech support: I did a master reset, ensured the firmware was updated, tried different charging cables and adapters - nothing worked.So I returned the first pair with the intention of getting either the Sony WH-CH720N or Soundcore Space Ones. In the end I thought I would give these another try. In white this time. Maybe I would have better luck with a different color?Alas, the same issue. This time after charging for a few hours with the included charging cable I looked at the percentage, & this time it was 97%.Again, it's a minor quibble for the price, but it concerns me because it makes me think these cans have a defective battery and I just bought disposable headphones. Caveat Emptor.

column4: HT2 Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones, Wireless Over Ear Bluetooth Headphones, 60H Playtime, Hi-Res Audio Custom EQ via App Deep Bass Comfort Fit Ear Cups, for Home Office Travel

At the coffee shop, they worked well, but with the added noises around, I could still hear and understand someone having a conversation. So in that instance, I wish it had been a bit more noise canceling.Overall, I have no regrets. As I said before, they are very very comfortable to wear and fit my big ole head just fine. I ordered the blue headphones, but they appeared to be closer to a greenish color to me. And in terms of battery power, it lasted the entire time I was at the library (which was all day). column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column8: Detailed First Impression ReviewIve been on Xbox for a long time for gaming and wanted to see the hype behind PC gaming. I do many things with my computer that a desktop would not work for me, as I have to move it around frequently and like portability, so I explored into the gaming laptop world. This was a cheaper, yet good option for an entry level Device.Processor- I bought the i7-11800H model and this processor seems to be a bit overkill for even some higher end games. But its great to have that extra power to multitask as well. I have not had any issues with the processing power. Its fast and smooth.Graphics- Im using the RTX-3050Ti and Ive seen the card likes to run at 100% nearly all the time when in a game but I have had no issues with its capability of running smoothly and not overheating, and I havent even tried any undervolting yet which could improve it more.RAM- the 16gb ram and 4gb vram work well together. I use the heavily graphic related game of BeamNG Drive that requires a lot of RAM to run smooth and have tried several multiplayer games and have never seen the RAM get over 70% (which is pretty good for heavily demanding games). This was Plenty of RAM for the gaming I do to keep it running smooth.Overall- this is a great starting laptop for anyone looking for a gaming laptop or something fast for multitasking. Sure there might be a couple other options with similar price ranges that might perform slightly better. But this one was the lowest price I saw for what you get out of it and its been working just fine for me. I havent had it long so I may be back to update this if my opinion changes lol. But first impressions were really good.Negatives- the graphics card works really great as mentioned above, but if you use it running at 100% for a couple hours you can completely notice a performance drop because the temperature starts to get too hot. I havent had it overheat but I have had some slight performance differences after a while of hard use. Thats really the only issue, thats not a huge deal, that Ive had. And its correctable by changing up some deeper settings.As I have mentioned, this is a great ENTRY Level laptop. I would not recommend this laptop to anyone that is heavily into gaming. It works great for what I want to do with it but it would work pretty bad for a professional gamer (not that pros would ever use a laptop for gaming lol). I am also newer to PC gaming but Im pretty savvy with computers. So being able to change some settings that the average newer user wouldnt know how to, without YouTube tutorials, have made this laptop perform a little better than out of the box. But these changes I made so far are all settings included on the computer, not third party software included in this review (meaning anyone can change the basic settings to improve the performance slightly as I have).PS- I thought I had a dead laptop when it came like other reviewers complained about. I read the review of one person that said you have to jam the power plug in there really good til it clicks for it to work. I initially thought I pushed hard enough and heard a light snapping sound, but it wouldnt charge or turn on. So I pushed a lot harder and heard it click a lot louder and it started charging perfectly fine and started up right away.

column7: I got a lemon. Returning and eagerly awaiting a second (functional) unit.
column8: UPDATE (22 March 2022):New unit arrived yesterday and started up perfectly.As for a laptop, it's perfectly functional. The design is nice, the keyboard feels nice (trackpad takes some getting used to clicking), there are enough ports for the peripherals I use, and it's run older games for 5 hours straight with negligible heat. I haven't tested the webcam and microphone yet.I don't play new or graphic-intensive games, but this ran very well on older games (Team Fortress 2, Spec Ops: The Line, Magic the Gathering 2014) and some newer ones (Deep Rock Galactic). I plan to run Halo Infinite and Outer Wilds later this week and expect it to perform well.I will keep this updated as my time with this computer progresses. 5/5___________________________________________________________________OLD REVIEW (20 March 2022):TL;DR - I'm sure the laptop is great but the one I received is defective (can't charge - motherboard issue). I am returning it to Amazon and have ordered another one, as I'm sure a functioning unit will meet my expectations for this product. I will update my review when my second order arrives. As for now, 1 star for defective product.I wanted a budget gaming laptop to replace my retired ASUS G55VW (2011). I chose this model due to its strong specs for a budget device, including an RTX 3050Ti (midrange for graphics cards in 2021 but supports the burgeoning ray-tracing technology used in current games), Core i7 CPU, 1 TB SSD storage, and 16GB memory. I also chose this because I wanted a 17-inch screen. The price point maxed out my acceptable budget range (~$1200).I believe this laptop is a good choice for me considering these specs and the price, and I look forward to trying it out.HOWEVER, the model I received appears to be defective - I believe I got a lemon. Upon unboxing, plugging the charger into the laptop did not illuminate the 'charging' light on the laptop, even after trying different electrical outlets and surge protectors. I took it to a local computer repair shop and the tech confirmed the charger itself was functional, as his voltmeter reported 19+ V. Upon opening the device and testing it, he concluded that something was wrong with the motherboard that prevented charging (I am unfamiliar with computers and cannot relay the significance of what he said).I filed for a return-and-replace with Amazon; they accepted the return but denied the replacement - likely so I couldn't keep both laptops and run. The laptop is currently repackaged and I will drop it off at UPS for a return in the next couple of days.I immediately ordered another unit, as this model was my first choice. I expect the second product to work just fine and meet my purchasing expectations, and eagerly await its arrival. I understand defective products are produced and shipped as a natural part of the production process, and do not consider this representative of Acer.While I'm sure the product will meet my expectations, I am saddened to receive a defective model. I will provide an updated review when my second order arrives.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column7: Amazing screen quality and performance at its price, but loud fans and poor speakers
column8: The screen was sufficiently bright and could run games pretty well, but the fans were pretty loud and the speakers were kinda meh quality. The build quality of the laptop itself was very impressive, very rugged and durable, and the hinges seem like they would last at least 6-7 years.I found that you could lower the fan sound a little by setting the Power profile of your computer to Balanced, and helping it even further along by setting the display to 60 Hz, but it might require you to use Vertical Sync/VSYNC in some games.I was able to run Starfield at 100+ FPS on Low, but the fans were blaring at me the entire time. The fact that it also comes with SATA drive support is also very impressive, because most laptops have completely abandoned SATA support for NVME to save space and for slightly better thermal performance. This computer also has 2 fans for improved thermals (weird fact, I know, but some laptops only have 1), but they also generate twice the noise.Aside from that, this is a very solid entry-level gaming laptop and will be able to run modern games at low-medium settings for at least a few years.

column8: at $950 I had to take the chance on this laptop despite some of the reviews being bad. If you're considering this laptop my guess is you're like me in that you dont want to build a pc yourself for whatever reason. I would say this was a fair purchase but if you can wait, i'd say save up a bit more and get a pc built for yourself at microcenter or something. I have played many games and all of them can be played on at least medium settings with no lag. That would include cyberpunk 2077 to give you an idea. I really only have one problem with the laptop and it makes it a bad long term investment. From fully charged, i can only game for maybe 50 minutes. Cant even reach an hour. If that sounds unpleasant to you then pass on this. Otherwise it serves its purpose for me in playing all the games I couldn't on my previous laptop.

column7: From a 3D Game Artist: Best Affordable Gaming Laptop
column8: I am Game Artist. I use 3D modeling and game engine programs like Unity, 3DsMax, Blender, Photoshop, and Unreal. I also play plenty of MMORGs and Steam games in my (very little) free-time. And I really needed a new work/personal gaming laptop as my last Acer Predator was starting to degrade after several years of constant use. So I decided to try the Nitro since I really liked the Predator and have an Acer monitor as well.So here's my thoughts:DISPLAYThis is something very important to me being an artist. And the colors are accurate and vivid. I don't have any issue editing my art as I switch displays. It can also get quite bright, nothing too eye burning (I keep it on the lower side) and the screen itself is quite large, and visible even from 2 feet away on a desk.PROCESSOR SPEED / RAM / GPUUsing Unity and Unreal, this laptop has been able to handle my beefy VFX work without issue. Same with my of my 3D Modeling and 3D Sculpting work which can be quite demanding on the GPU. Although the RAM is on the low-medium side so I will be looking into getting an additional one so things run a little faster.STORAGEI upgraded on hard-drive storage when it came to this laptop and I'm so glad I have. All those programs I listed above + PC games can take up a lot of space and I have not had an issue needing to delete something in order to do something else.HARDWARE DESIGNIts nice, sleek, and simple. Very similar to the 2018 Predator I have. The keyboard does light up, which I always like but you can not program custom colors (which is no issue for me but good to know). The only other thing is that this is a LARGE laptop. It is larger than my last one and I really like it being this size for the display. It luckily does fit in my laptop bag but I would make sure to measure yours to make sure this will work for you.PRICEBuying a laptop will always be an expense, especially a gaming laptop. But for the storage space, display quality, and RAM, this laptop is a great deal for $1,200.FINAL THOUGHTSIts been 2 months since Ive been using this laptop and I have had a great experience. Gamer or Artist, I would definitely recommend.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column8: Let me start with my job turned me on to using high powered laptops plugged into docking stations for productivity. This is awesome because you can take your projects with you. I use the Nitro for video editing (4k 60fps) with Adobe Premiere Pro for youtube content. This thing remders 30 min 4k vids in LESS THAN 25 minutes. My old pc took an hour and would fail at times.It runs three dell 32in monitors no problem. I suspect it will run most games spectacularly. Though you may have to adjust frame rate. The picture quality is awesomeProsPrice pointThis thing is FAST!Graphics are on par with higher 4 digit cost laptopsPicture qualityProcessing powerFast boot upGreat for video editing and moderate gamingThe keyboard is solid and big for a laptop which is a plus.ConsWindows 11Only 512gb storageIts a heavier laptopFans are loudWindows 11The battery life is what youd expect.Looking at maybe 1-2 hours if youre heavy in use and maybe 3-4 woth light use and power saving settings.Lets look at the truth and that is youre not gonna be gaming on batt power and this thing shines hooked into bigger multiple monitors. column8: I am really impressed with this laptop. With the i7-11800H processor and turbo it is fast. One thing that I read in other reviews is to push the power connector until you hear it snap in place. As I was exploring and learning about the machine, I wanted to look at the BIOS. The PDf manual said to push the F2 key when the logo was displayed. Wrong! press and hold the F2 key and then push the power button. Bonus feature - pressing the F2 key at the logo does a fast boot.I have one major complaint with the laptop and that is the red lettering on the black keys, even with back lighting on it is still hard to see some keys. I find it easier to use a seperate keyboard and trackball. My only other issue is Win11. I may at some time go back to Win10 to see an end to cronic updates in a couple of years. I plan to give the machine a major workout with photography, 3d printing and laser engraving and adding a cnc machine in the near future.

column7: Great value gaming laptop, with some standard laptop tweaks
column8: This is my newest laptop since 2017, but the laptop I had was from 2016. Far faster than my old one (of course) and runs every program to its max. For gaming a 3050 ti is limited to mostly 1080p gaming unless you play some of the lighter games where you can eek out 144op, but you can easily get 120fps on most games with some tweaks with around 70 to 90 fps on larger AAA titles. One of the first things you have to do with any Acer laptop is go into control panel and change the power settings, they come standard with USB and HDD/SSD auto power off which pretty much puts your laptop to sleep whether you change sleep settings or not. Also, press the (N) button by the num pad, click on the gear icon, and click to make the keyboard backlight stay on. I read some reviews online that said the keyboard backlight would turn off automatically, luckily my last laptop was a Acer predator and they have the same settings basically. Fans are almost non existent when just browsing and you can control them (finally) when doing some intense gaming (or using programs like CAD or the like). Also, the power cord is a dual step process, the first click means nothing, you have to push in till you hear a second click. I was looking for a 17" inch laptop with more than 2 USB A ports, those ports NOT on the right side (mouse interference), could game at atleast 1080p/above 60 fps, a better processor, and had a ethernet port. Sounds like alot but most laptops are 15" inch with 2 USB A ports and no ethernet ports now. I'm satisfied with this purchase.*Particular Notes: This comes with Norton installed, Firefox, a planet 9 link, and Windows 11. There's a small learning curve with Windows 11 and I hate Norton, but it's easy to uninstall and Windows 11 is whatever. There is no bloatware on this model, I know there is a model that has Alexa but this one doesn't have it. The SSD is pretty fast but not the fastest, it's better than good enough.*

column7: Acceptable for the price; weak battery and fans
column8: Overall, this is a nice budget gaming laptop. I purchase this it replace my previous M..S..I.. as the keys were popping off of that one from tons of use. While the screen is large and the image quality much better on this Acer, that's about where it ends. The battery on this thing is awful, even with battery efficiency settings when performing basic functions like browsing the web. The Acer Cool fans are a joke -- I hit my thermal load on this laptop quicker than I ever have in my life with any gaming laptop. I played Civ VI on this thing for less than an hour, and that's about all it could handle. I did, however, purchase a separate cooling pad, and it seems to have remedied the problem. Overall, if you can get this at a discount (like I did on Prime Day), it's worth it, but not for full price. One perk is it does come with Windows 11 already installed, so saves you time from upgrading later if it's the latest OS you're after.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column7: The Machine is Fine - Build Quality and Support Leaves a Lot to be Desired
column8: I got my computer on February 1st. It had a defective screen. I sent it to Acer. It took them two days to get my a shipping label. It took seven days for it to reach them. After they had it for a week, they could not give me an ETA on when repairs would be finished. I finally got it back today, on the 25th, and immediately returned it to Amazon because I had to have a functional computer and couldn't hold onto my loaner without a solid estimate for when I'd get this one back.So it was nearly a full four weeks from when I originally got it that it was in my hands in a fully working state, and from what I've seen, this is fast for Acer.Which is a shame - this is a lot of computer for the price. To give credit where it's due, I tested the laptop when it was returned to me and it seemed like the screen problems I was having were completely fixed.Considering the price puts this solidly in the mid-range category, you're getting a lot for what you're paying. It doesn't need an additional harddrive or RAM to be completely viable out of the box. (I bought the 1TB/16GB RAM model.) If you want to add a harddrive, there's a SATA cable in the box, and it's fairly easy to get the back panel off. There's even a tutorial by Acer on YouTube on exactly how to do it.In terms of right-to-repair, though, it's mediocre. It's easy to get to the guts of the computer itself. I'd like having easy access panels for the HDD and RAM, but that's a minor complaint - it's not hard to pry this laptop open.What's disappointing is the mount for the screen. Screens die faster than anything else on a laptop. The way this thing is built, I'm not surprised my screen was defective out of the box. You'll want to always open and close the lid with both hands if you want your screen to last the lifetime of the laptop. If you ever need to change the screen out, it's clearly not designed for you to be able to do so. The bezels aren't as simple to pop open as they are on other units, and the screen is held in place by glue, making it so that you probably want to take it to a technician unless you have some experience doing these kinds of repairs yourself.I wish I could say my experience with this was stellar. I loved my Acer Predator Helios from 2018. I've loved the Aspire I've used for writing documents. I'm just completely unimpressed by Acer's service. Three weeks in and no ETA concerning when the laptop would be back in my hands was unacceptable. They only send you updates when they receive your laptop and when they're sending it back. You can't find out any further details - not even where you're at in the queue.I ended up getting a Lenovo Idea Pad 3 Gaming and so far I am loving it. I can't rate Lenovo's support because I haven't had to contact them. The machine I am using now feels rock solid; much better than I would have expected given the amount of power it has for the price. (Under $800.)With this laptop - it looks like it would be worth it if you get it and it works as intended right out of the box. But - I'm far from the only person who has had an issue with it. They've had build quality problems with the Nitro line all the way through, and there are cases where it took 5-6 weeks for people to get their machines back if they went through Acer's support.With these specs, from the testing I did when I had it hooked up to an external monitor, it performs as beautifully as you'd expect. There is a rock solid machine here if you're careful with the screen and get one that works right out of the box.If you don't?Don't deal with Acer support. Buy a third party warranty if you think you'll ever need it. Buying online, I'd go for something without a lot of reported build problems. This is the kind of laptop that I would buy in person so I could test and immediately replace a defective unit.My trust in Acer is completely shot after this experience. At this point, I'm just glad they got it back to me within the return window. I jumped in because I've had amazing experiences with Acer hardware in the past. Those will probably be my last Acer machines. It's completely unacceptable for a multi-million dollar company to mass produce a line of laptops with a high number of defects and a support process that leaves the buyer in the dark for the majority of it.So - based on build quality, it's a 3 1/2 to 4 star laptop if it works. If it doesn't? You're better off returning it and getting another computer.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column8: First off, I scrutinized this purchase to make sure it fit my needs moving forward. Acer Nitro had done great in the past for me. The excellent lifetime given by my previous Nitro 5, i5 Gtx1060from 2018. Brought me back with established brand confidence.Then it hurt my feelings with deceptive system write ups, misleading access port specs, ect...The short version.This is a whole lot of all the right components forced to live with each other against their will. This laptop is an uncooperative disappointment.All the gripes:I picked this model specifically for its Thunderbolt 4 USB C Display Adapter Port and was thrilled about the RTX3060 GPU.It took 20 hours of setup (WTF seriously) to find out that besides all the issues that would have made it a defective return anyhow, the Display Port is hard wired to the Intel HD on-board graphics processor. It is built to fail on that point.This system has issues built into it in ways that boggle your bogs. The screen had 7 to 8 light discoloration areas around the edges like it had been beaten on from the inside. The new power cord design is something I hope they have fixed in 2023. My experience was it caused power failures when moved while plugged in.Sudden total power failures, it was like to a blackout.Speaking of feedback, the audio on board sends back slight popping sounds.Digital distortions from all operations and outputs was intermittent; it does seem consistent as reported by other owners of this model. Some speculation whether this is a new WinOS build issue.If you are a VR user just looking to occasionally link to a laptop, find another. It is possible but the performance of theRTX3060 in this systems build is surprisingly dismal. At midrange settings, no ray tracing, CP2077 (Cyberpunk 2077) was not able to hold 15 FPS for any interaction beyond the menu screen. The RTX GPU and the CPU share a studio apt with inadequate airflow. It heats up fast and "The GPU Little Dual Fans that Could" can't . Why they even let this build go into manufacture is beyond me. This machine cannot keep baseline operating temperature while watching a Movie. This is actually the first time in 13 years of having a laptop as a critical tool of my trade that I even noticed they had any fans. I always just gave them proper ventilation. You will notice these fans thiugh, when the 95 to 110 degree air starts blasting from all possible routes. This is the GPU warning you that an " Emergency Safety Shutdown" is about to occur because you are playing Fortnite or whatever. This was the only helpful unintended feature. I found I had about 15 to 20 seconds to save my game or work. By the time I figured out that workflow hack, I finally admitted to myself that I had been naive and was being stubborn trying to create work arounds and validate the value of my purchase.If you are the kind of person who enjoys taking badly designed hardware platforms and tinkering with them you found a deal here..Cyberware PC, ASUS, NITRO have done well by me for the 3 previous workstations I have built on their bare bones. My 2018 Nitro 5 survived, falls, collisions and was even stepped on (In my bag) and made a cracking noise that brought so many simultaneous gasps in a room full of technicians that you could feel the air leaving the room.So please don't let this lengthy review of this one product turn you away from the brand. It has been solid so far.Goodbye 2018 Nitro 5 you were a adequate tool and anobel machine.R.I.P."MiniPrime"2018-2023 Death by Winter Storm Like tears in Rain,,I found it next an open window after a storm, in a puddle.Waaaah!If you read this whole thing, thanks I guess. I wish you the best in all that you give your best to.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column7: Unsure if this is a good laptop or not - Update
column8: I bought this laptop for my son's 16th birthday. It arrived and my son opened it. He was so excited and then the laptop wouldn't turn on. We thought maybe it needs to be plugged in and charge for a bit. He plugged it in, the charging light came on and it still wouldn't turn on. No sound, no lights, nothing. We waited another couple hours, the orange charging light turned to blue and we tried again.....still nothing. Brand new, straight out of the box and it wouldn't work. I had to then contact customer support and I had to mail this brand new computer to Texas for a technician to work on. Now we have to wait for them to look at it and figure out what is wrong with it and ship it back. So, my experience so far is not great.Update - Finally received the computer back from the technician. It took about 4 days to get there, 3 days for them to fix it, and then 4 to send it back. This was quicker than I expected. There was a cable that wasn't connected right inside, which they fixed. The computer is fast and my son has enjoyed it the last day he has had it. So far, it is a decent computer but who knows what will happen as time goes on. I am giving 3 stars for the aggravation of it not working when we first got it. I will update if the computer exceeds expectations after my son has used it for a little while.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column8: I got the PC Nov 26, 2022 as of today it's Feb 28,2023.The PC operates great but has certain issues. (I would have decided to get another Laptop.)The Graphic card and operating system are good but I have never felt as though this pc has unlocked it's full power.The screen is ok; nothing like the OLED but it does fine at Full HD 144hz.The Battery has to be the most disappointing. I made sure everything was up to date before trying to play a League of Legends game on battery power at a cafe one day. I couldn't even get through a game at 4fps. For those who don't know the game can run on just about any pc but a new pc such as this?When the pc is plugged in it runs great. On battery you might as well just surf the web.Ram is good. I wish I got more for my everyday use but 16gb is not bad.The Solid State Drive at 1TB is great. Not just for games loading but to have the free space.Over all this PC is alright. The price I think is fair but defiantly better option for those looking to get a good pc for gaming.The average life of the battery is about an hour running with application. On energy saver maybe add about 30 to 45 mins longer. That's just sad to mebut I'll defiantly be paying attention to this next time around and not the shinny specs.The blue tooth can be spotty. I have a wireless keyboard and mouse. Replaced the batteries because what was happening is a lag from when I was typing to what was showing on the screen. When you use the onboard keyboard and mouse pad it works fine. With Bluetooth devices its spotty. Same with my Bluetooth headset it has issues with connecting. I have to put the device in pairing mode every time because sometimes it says its connected but no sound comes out of the headset.PC is up to date and I hate to give this a low score but these issues keep happening and drive me crazy.Most likely will be buying a different pc and this will become a back up.If your looking for an affordable pc that's $1000 bucks sure go for it but just as I. Don't think your getting the best out of everything with a price like that. Thanks for reading have a good day :)

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column7: Can't use PIN for login without wifi
column8: I set up a pin for my laptop when I bought it. Was using it and logging in just fine for the first week. And then took the laptop somewhere else where I wouldn't be at home or by wi-fi.I didn't realize that when you log in with your PIN it needs wi-fi to let you log in. I found this out the hard way once I was away from the wi-fi.You will get an error saying "Something and went wrong and your PIN is not available, click here to set up a new pin." When you go to set up a new PIN it tells you you need Wi-Fi to do so.I wasn't at a place where I had access to Wi-Fi and intended to do work for the day at a location away from home. If I had known you need Wi-Fi in order to use a pin I never would have set one up and it was not apparent that this was the case when I set up a pin. I'm going to try and see if I can remove the necessity to have a pin but then I worry about the security so I'll probably have to get a thumbprint login for the USB or something. If I can't figure out another solution I will be returning the laptop. I have another Windows 11 laptop that does not require Wi-Fi to do a pin login so it seems that if something specific to this computer. I think it's quite ridiculous to not have a system or you could log into a computer without wi-fi. But I mostly annoyed because there was no warning that this was the case when I set up the pin. Or if there was they did not make it obvious.Rest for speed, it does okay but it crashed when I was doing render work for video editing within the first week and what I was doing was not very intense. It also is not substantially faster than my basic laptop that has no fancy video card before rendering.It was a reasonable deal money wise but I'm not as impressed as I hoped to be. And then the pin thing happened and I was just very annoyed.

column7: Hardware is legit but it "possibly" comes with viruses
column8: I love this laptop, the hardware allows me to run all the 3d modeling software i need. Warning though, I don't use this cpu for my daily stuff such as anything I have to buy, check email, or any work related stuff.It is strictly used for 3d printing. On that note, since I started up this system, using a specific email address I only use for my 3d stuff, I keep getting a lot fishing emails about Microsoft or McAfee charging me money. Don't buy this laptop for your parents,know it comes with bad stuff. I let my bank know just in case, so far no money has been charged. This could have came from the downloaded programs, but I never had the phishing emails till I got this system. I would buy again though.. It's a beast of a system for the price!

column8: I had high hopes for this laptop, but it has turned out to be one of the worst computers i have ever had.Windows 11 has been nothing but problems.I have to restart several times a day because windows loses my PIN.Every attempt to fix this as failed.There is a magnetic sensor under where your left wrists rests, right where a magnetic watch band sits, that will cause the computer to go to sleep.And often then needs to restart.Hope that nothing you were working on was important or that you saved it recentlyBluetooth connectivity has been terrible.Sometimes works, sometimes doesn't.No rhyme or reason for it.Installed a second HDD.Laptop fragged it in a couple of weeks.No data was recoverable.Speakers are not good.Started fine but decayed quickly.Get random beep codes.If i force a restart they will usually go away.When it works, it works good.No problem with most games or using CAD software.When and if.As soon as i can afford a new laptop i am getting one, and after this ACER is off the list.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column7: The most disappointing laptop I've ever bought- and I've had many laptops!
column8: The screen artifacts on day one were just about constant, and over the days got even worse- and no matter what I did to the settings nor any drivers I downloaded, they never got fixed. These were not trivial; they could go across the entire screen and really distract. While I didn't use the laptop for gaming, I was a hardcore gamer years ago and knew had I gamed with it the absolutely atrocious screen would have been unacceptable. This was by far the worse laptop and computer screen I've used in over 20 years, and that's even including ones that were used for years before I got my hands on them! I had to get a refund based on the terrible screen. I almost certainly got a defective unit, as I'd think people would be up in arms near unanimously had they gotten what I'd gotten out of this laptop. Still, this was my experience- and if it happened to me, it could happen to you too.Outside of that fatal flaw, I didn't have any big issues with it aside from the keyboard only lighting up for a brief period after I'd hit the keys, then the lights would turn off. I found this distracting in darker settings, and kept missing keys in that context when the keyboard wasn't lit up. Also, a minor flaw was the unintuitive connection for the power; as other reviewers here have mentioned, you've got to get two click type feelings connecting the power to the laptop for the power to start transmitting, and you need to put forth far more force than when connecting pretty much any modern device to power. If you plug it in like a normal device, it will transmit zero power and the laptop won't even turn on. The power connection oddity had me at first wondering if the laptop could even be turned on.I ended up doing testing between this laptop and a competitor in the same price range with the same sized screen (Asus TUF A17 made in 2022), and the Asus not only had a superior screen that didn't show any artifacts, but also the memory and CPU usage was noticeably less in similar to mildly more difficult conditions on that Asus vs this Acer. It was a far better product, and I imagine lots of laptops from various companies would be noticeably better than this underperforming Acer.

Perhaps I am not using it well, but as of right now medium is about all it can handle without annoying frame-rate dives. Oh well, this was just meant to be a band-aid until I got a proper desktop. What can you expect with a "gaming" laptop anyway?

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column7: An absolute lemon! Do not buy!
column8: I really shopped around for a laptop I could use for video editing and graphic design. The Acer Nitro 5 AN517-54-79L1 had decent reviews and it seemed like the best option in my price range. Well, the first one I ordered had problems so I had to send it back, then the replacement Amazon sent had the exact same problems so I had to send that back too!The issues (and general things I just disliked):* A weird graphics glitch where the screen would take on a "double image" effect. Nothing would get rid of this but a restart, and then the problem would eventually come back.* Another weird graphics glitch where I'd be watching a video (on Youtube or elsewhere) and suddenly the video would start scrolling quickly from right to left, over and over. Again, the only way to stop this was a restart. These problems happened on both models, and the people at Amazon tech support couldn't fix it.* Loud fans under any significant graphics load. Loud enough to make you worry something might be wrong. I've since switched to a computer with an RTX360 and it seems to handle graphics much better. I never tried playing games with the Nitro but if it was whirring like that with simple graphics software I imagine it'd have a meltdown if you tried to play a modern game.* The case is thin and has way too much flex, especially on the first model. On more than one occasion I picked up the laptop while it was playing a video or audio, I was just moving it normally, and as my hand gripped the case I'd feel the plastic flex, I'd accidentally crush the works inside and the audio would sloooooow down and get wonky. That's WAY too much flex!* This computer is an absolute magnet for dust. I'd wipe it down and by the end of the day it looked filthy again. The stickers on the case also came off and left a weird, sticky residue. Both models always looked old and busted, despite being brand new.* The keyboard is black with faint red letters, only lighting up when you're actually typing on it. I knew about this and got a keyboard cover with printed letters, which helped, but otherwise the illegible keyboard would've driven me nuts.* It was just heavy enough that it was annoying to lug around.* The battery life was not very good.Acer has a decent rep as a company and as I said the reviews were good, but both of the Nitros I dealt with gave me endless problems. I'd strongly caution anyone against buying this model.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column8: Obviously I can't speak to its longevity yet, but after the first few days, I'm pretty happy with it.Pros:Boot time and game startup/load times are extremely fast.Picture quality is good, but not the brightest.Acer provides instructions for installing a second SSD, along with the mounting hardware and cable and was very easy to accomplish. My last Acer laptop had a motherboard failure (8 years old) and the ability to transplant its drive into this machine saved me from time consuming methods to retrieve my data. The surgery took less than ten minutes.Bus speeds for transferring large amounts of data between internal and external drives is extremely fast.Cons:The Nitrosense software allows full control of the speed of the dual fans. This would be great except for the fact that gaming makes it run extremely hot so I end up running the fans on max which is very loud and annoying.Windows 11! First experience with this OS and I am not loving it. Dumb stuff like replacing commands with icons instead that you have to mouseover to figure out which one you are looking for, i.e. rename, cut, paste, etc.Loaded with garbage bloatware, as usual. Frees up a lot of space removing the stuff you'll never use.All in all, very happy so far. Runs everything I've thrown at it, and very quickly.UPDATE: my battery is garbage. I tried running it unplugged for the first time today and within 20 minutes, I was at 13%. Amazon customer service passed me off to Acer. Acer had me run some tests, concurred that my battery is bad, but refused to send me one which could fix my problem within minutes, instead saying that I would have to ship it to them and get it back in a few weeks. Instead of waiting, I now have to buy a new battery to fix my NEW laptop. Not happy.

column7: Fast laptop with horrible colors and speakers
column8: I had a great MSI Dominator for nearly 8 years.It was showing it's age so I went shopping for a new laptop.I found this Acer Nitro 5 and decided to buy it as it was quite a bit less money than a new MSI.It's a zippy laptop loaded with Windows 11, plenty of SSD storage and ram.But the Nvidia Geforce RTX graphics card is a POS.The colors are wrong, for instance, bright red has this rust color to it.bright greens look more like olive green.Worse, there is no way to fix it I can find.The latest drivers from Nvidia are installed.I have scoured the internet for a solution and there appears to be none other than return it and buy another brand.There is no way to increase color intensity or saturation.I am disappointed that a company like Nvidia would produce this crap.Acer was no help either.The speakers sound tinny like a cheap transistor radio.I use headphones or external speakers.

column7: That the laptop actually works properly.
column8: Con. Okay so I ordered this laptop for my daughter's birthday. So on day one I told her it will not turn on till you charge it so first thing she did was plugged it in and let it charge a few moments later we powered it up and my daughter was super excited so she went on to download a game she likes to play online. So the next day she goes to play the game and the screen froze shortly into the game so first thing was to wait to see if maybe it was lag but after a minute or so nothing still froze. Mouse didn't move so next I pushed alt, control, delete. Nothing so the ESC and nothing then the windows key. So I powered it down and powered back up keyboard lights up but no display so I hold the power key down for 15 seconds nothing. So I decided to power down again and power up and nothing but the keyboard powers up. So I this point I'm upset and my daughter is super bummed after being super happy and excited a moment ago .so I called costumer support and they let me know that my computer is under warranty and it can be taken care of but I get cut off and I'm running late for work so I decided I'd call back after work. So I called again and talked to costumer support again so went through the same conversation and then they said they could refund my money or replace it I optioned for a replacement they said ok but because of the price there supervisor would have to ok it I said ok so after about ten minutes on the phone the till me that there supervisor can't ok the transaction that they have to wait for the morning supervisor to do this I said fine and that I would be contacted the next day....... Well it's been so it's been 4 days and nothing I'm starting to feel scammed by Amazon for some reason. So in my opinion stay away from this laptop and DO NOT BUY ANY Electronics from AMAZON.Pros. Didn't work long enough to find out.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column7: Incorrect Description: No Video Out Over USB-C
column8: The description for this laptop is incorrect. In the list of available ports it is state that there is one "USB 3.2 Gen 2 Type-C (DisplayPort)" which would mean that the USB-C port supports video out through an adapter or hub, but that is not the case. The USB-C on this laptop is only a standard USB 3.2 Gen 2 port that DOES NOT support the displayport alt function.I thought it may have been the adapter/hub I was using at first so I bought 5 others with varying capabilities and the results were the same. The USB port will work but the display ports do not. I ended up finding the online user manual for this exact model (on Acer's site) and sure enough, it says that this model has a standard USB-C 3.2 Gen 2 port rather than the thunderbolt 4 port on some of their other models.This was very disappointing to me since this laptop meets my needs in every other aspect. This is a major issue for me since I am using this laptop to replace one that is connected to multiple monitors and peripherals through a dock.

column7: System Board fried just out of warranty.
column8: I liked this laptop a lot. Fans were a bit loud, but it was still nice and responsive. Then the system board crapped out on me within a week of warranty elapsing. Huge disappointment for me. My desktop lasted ages before being outdated. 1200 for 1 year? Not good.

column4: Acer Nitro 5 Gaming Laptop | Intel 12th Gen i7-12650H | NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Laptop GPU | 15.6 FHD 144Hz IPS Display | 16GB DDR5 | 1TB Gen 4 SSD | Killer Wi-Fi 6 | RGB Backlit KB | AN515-58-781P
column8: When I recieved the laptop, it was in perfect physical condition, but it kept crashing due to hypervisor errors during setup (every 3-5mins) It also kept losing connection to the wifi. After spending about 4 hours giving it the benefit of the doubt trying to make sure it had all its updated drivers (it arrived with roughly 2 hours of updates missing) the same error still occurred every 3-5 mins. I called acer, after some quick troubleshooting, they requested for me to send it out to them. The shipping & repair time were quick. I recieved it back within the 5-10 days promised, only to find... the exact same error. It immediately threw identical hypervisor errors (I dont know how Acer support missed those and said it was fixed) to which I called acer, and they said I'd need to mail it back.Thankfully, I wasn't outside of Amazon's return policy yet, so I returned it to the seller instead. Take the 1* reviews seriously; my husband and I saw a few people had issues, so we tested ours almost immediately. The specs on the device are great, but we were given an error-riddled device.

column8: A great deal from a trusted seller, yes please. Got my PC and it works amazing.I will update over the next year if any issues arise, when you pay 1500$ for a laptop you expect to last a few years right.?So After a month or so I am finally trying to register my laptop cause its too hot to go outside and im gonna be inside for a day or 2 and im now realizing this laptop was previously owned and actually used....My "New" laptop is registered to a Russian lady and I'm receiving text messages from Microsoft in Russian and can't understand the Microsoft home page also in Russian thanks to the previous owner. At least they lived in America it says so it's an in country return I received as a new product, but still for some reason Im unable to correct the info or language no matter what I do it won't change now I get to try to contact Microsoft.... that should take all day and accomplish nothing as a lifelong Microsoft customer I know this to be the case. So beware when you buy this item it may not be new it may be preowned and registered to someone else in another language.... not super happy.Also can't even download any games probably because it can't be properly registered I have gamimg laptop that canr even download games so that basicallt means i have a1500$ paperweight and Amazon won't give me back my money.

column8: I sent my laptop for repair 3 times. First time it came back working for a little while. Second time it came back saying No Bootable Device. I called tech support to try and get it to boot up three times. On third time they said to send it in for repair. On this time it came back with a letter saying insects found and on repair paper said water damage. It's never been near any fluid or bugs. They refused to fix it. I then sent it to Asurion for repair. They inform me it has no hard drive. I call Acer and they try to tell me( now) that it didn't have a hard drove the second time I sent it in. I have not sent it to anyone else for repair but Acer prior to Asurion.It is logical to me that Acer kept my hard drive and that is why it did not have a bootable device the second time it was returned to me. Acer refutes this and will not send me my hard drive back. I do not even know what one looks like.I'm now partying on a laptop that doesn't work. If I have to I will call an attorneys office about this issue.I'm hoping contact you will help. It is a Nitro 5 laptop not even a year old.

column8: I've always owned Alienware, Asus and Razer Gaming Laptops, I personally purchased this as a travel laptop as I enjoy staying up to date on my gaming during business trips for extended portions of time. I've never used anything Acer before, and nor have I heard many negative things about them. But overall my experience was simply not good, I hate that I am even going through the refund process as this isn't how I work, I'm also an Amazon Vine member, I try to promote good products and leave feedback that could be beneficial. Though this return process and refund scenario is always a pain for probably good reasons.Though, Unpackaging, installing and playing all was totally fine and operational, ran pretty good on some demanding games. Though this computer was supposed to be brand new and came riddled with power issues, even fully charged It shuts off, Plugged in, shuts off and during gaming shuts off. It's difficult to tell when there is no windows event logs tracking any crashes, I can't imagine It's a GPU or heating issue, I would maybe imagine something revolving around the Power/Battery area.

This is ridiculous to me considering it was THEIR defective product that led to this situation. I now have no option available to me that won't cost me a great deal of extra money. Will not be buying from this company again.
